column2: The Jets are drifting with no apparent direction — sailing to be sailing, drifting to be drifting, with no plan beyond hiring and firing.
Statistics suggest that the robberies may have been fueled by the financial desperation that sets in during a recession and the added pressures of the holiday season.
The U.S. attorney in the criminal case against the governor sought to provide recordings to the Illinois House’s impeachment panel.
The case of Gilad Shalit, an Israeli corporal who has been held by Hamas for over two years, is being debated as Israel goes forward with its action on Gaza.
There were few pictures taken of the Mumbai attacks aside from those of a newspaper photographer and a photography editor.
The M.T.A. released four options that it is considering as part of its effort to close a $1.2 billion budget gap, including plans to increase subway and bus fares.
Authorities stormed the offices of Shirin Ebadi, the country’s most prominent human rights activist and a Nobel Prize winner, seizing computers and documents.
To the Editor:.
Alexei Cherepanov, the Rangers prospect who died during a Russian league hockey game in October, took performance-enhancing drugs, investigators in Moscow said.
Geologists have collected evidence indicating that something very big occurred in the waters near New York around 300 B.C., but convincing other scientists has been an uphill battle.
The Treasury Department took a stake of $5 billion in GMAC and agreed to lend $1 billion to to help it reorganize itself as a bank holding company.
To the Editor:.
It seemed out of character when Eli Manning made a humorous comment alluding to Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo.
To the Editor:.
The children and grandchildren of Spaniards who fled the country during Gen. Francisco Franco’s dictatorship can now apply for Spanish citizenship, the government said.
Mr. Combes spent 27 years as a copy editor at The New York Times Magazine and helped create its "About Men" column.
Tokyo Tower, the city’s Eiffel Tower-like structure, has turned 50, and has become the symbol of a bygone era that has won a new place in the national imagination.
Weatherizing more homes with public help would mark a shift in government energy assistance: cutting poor people’s energy bills instead of helping pay them.
Media moguls have had a rough year, but John Malone appears to have salvaged some value for his shareholders at the expense of another mogul’s shareholders.
The Russian retail association said Wal-Mart Stores had joined the group in the latest in a series of moves indicating its interest in expanding into Russia.
Hong Kong’s exports fell for the first time in five months in November, worsening the outlook for an economy already in recession.
France’s economy expanded in the third quarter as a drop in oil prices helped consumer spending. Gross domestic product rose 0.1 percent from the second quarter.
A young mother struggles to earn a living while caring for her children, one of whom has Down syndrome.
A British children’s clothing retailer, Adams Childrenswear, was on the brink of a form of bankruptcy protection, a spokeswoman for the company said.
South Korea posted a current-account surplus for a second consecutive month in November, which may help ease pressure on the won.
China’s president, Hu Jintao visited a region of southwest China over the weekend that was hit hard by the earthquake last May.
A Turkish court sentenced a man to four years in prison on Monday for stabbing an Italian Catholic priest in 2007.
A prominent Zimbabwean activist and 31 others, some with bloodied and swollen faces, appeared in court on Monday in connection with a supposed plot to oust President Robert Mugabe by force.
The African Union suspended Guinea’s membership on Monday and threatened further sanctions unless young soldiers who seized power last week restored “constitutional rule.”
The Sunni militant group to which the suicide bomber was affiliated had attacked Iranian armed forces and Revolutionary Guards but not through suicide bombings.
The brother and father of Urs Tinner, who spent four years in detention for his connection to the nuclear black market of Abdul Qadeer Khan, are also connected to the Swiss investigation.
The case includes allegations that a construction company   paid for renovations at Bernard B. Kerik's home in the hope that he would help the company obtain a city license.
A nonprofit that Congress set up to help veterans with small businesses was criticized in a Senate report for spending federal dollars on luxuries and high salaries.
The Scarlet Knights quarterback Mike Teel, who struggled throughout the first half in the Papajohns.com Bowl, helped edge out North Carolina State for a seventh straight win.
Genetic tests can show which patients are suited to which drugs, but obstacles remain for personalized medicine.
Holly Wilson, 22, teaches babies, toddlers and preschoolers music and movement at Gymboree in Manhattan.
The giant Russian natural gas monopoly is deep in debt and negotiating a government bailout.
Frequent travelers say that the security checkpoint experience at airports has greatly improved in recent years.
Trip itineraries are bound to fail, so don’t set yourself up for that failure.
The Iraqi city has come to represent hope that the former heart of the insurgency can become a model for peace.
Is the next generation of spacecraft fundamentally flawed? Or are the troubles routine?
A seemingly meager diet of gruel, onions and bread may be a sufficient diet after all, researchers say.
Whether you prefer cutting-edge medicine or time-tested practices, these books cover the gamut of health care advances past, present and future.
Mexico is credited for reducing debt and taming inflation, but it has not escaped the pain of global recession.
Stride length may help the fiddler crab measure its way back to its burrow.
Plants may want to thank bees as nearby buzzing seems to prevent caterpillars from eating.
Do the open bars, late-night revelry and carefree attitude of New Year’s Eve lead to more car accidents?
Trapped in a body that can't walk, a woman learns to appreciate reality.
As Dr. Peter Piot, the only head of the United Nations AIDS program in its 13-year history, retires on Wednesday, he reflects on the success and failures of his tenure.
The Cutting Room, the bar and nightclub on West 24th Street that has provided a home to eclectic performers like Sting, Ronnie Spector, Tenacious D and Salt-n-Pepa, will close on Jan. 13.
Is using a dishwasher really more energy efficient than washing dishes by hand?
Andrew Lloyd Webber said that a recently completed sequel to his musical “The Phantom of the Opera” would send the title character to 19th-century Brooklyn.
Will private companies be able to take the lead and shuttle astronauts to the International Space Station after the current NASA fleet is retired?
Woody Allen shared his clarinet skills with an audience of nearly 3,000 listeners at a concert in Warsaw.
Though the Tom Cruise movie “Valkyrie” received mixed reviews in the United States, it has been greeted with a measured and hospitable reception in Germany.
Scotland has already given the world Robert Burns, Walter Scott and Donovan, and now an American professor says it is also the birthplace of rap battles.
NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” edged past CBS’s lineup on Sunday, according to Nielsen’s estimates.
So far, plans for a film spinoff of the late Fox television comedy “Arrested Development” are living up to that show’s title.
In a rare move for network television, the hospital sitcom is moving from NBC to ABC beginning Jan. 6.
Just as children shouldn't be treated by doctors as small adults, elderly patients shouldn't be treated as old adults.
A superhero movie may not reach theaters on its scheduled date after a federal judge said that he might block the film’s release because of an ownership dispute.
The New York String Orchestra Seminar, a 10-day program that brings a few dozen high school- and college-age musicians to New York every December, is mostly a private affair.

It seems clear that 2008 will go down as the year of Lil Wayne.

In this book Mr. Gilmore writes about stars from the 1960s like the Beatles, Bob Dylan, Jim Morrison, Pink Floyd and Ken Kesey.
Merce Cunningham — who has been choreographing professionally for 66 years — has long spoken of motion in stillness and stillness in motion.
A new book says Moscow acquired the secret of the hydrogen bomb not from its own scientists but from an atomic spy at the Los Alamos weapons lab in New Mexico.
Miguel Gutierrez’s piece, “freedom of information 2008,” consists, ideally, of an improvisational solo by a participant in each of the 50 states and the District of Columbia.
Rates of the avian flu tend to rise during the winter months, but deaths are declining.
The United States, with its credit-driven economy, has long ensured that others, notably China, Germany and Japan, have been able to pile up trade surpluses. Now that dynamic has shifted.

When it comes to seasonal allergies, not all pollen is created equal.
If I’m serious about keeping my New Year’s resolutions in 2009, should I add, “Start going to church”?
Even in a recession, TV networks still have the power to provide advertisers with mass audiences.

A new approach to geriatric care will be essential to improve health care in America, experts say.
The Trojans are in the Rose Bowl for the fourth consecutive year, but the team began the season with greater ambitions.
Need another reason to sleep in? It seems it's good for your heart.
The emotions tied to memories may change as a person ages.
The DVD divisions of the major studios, along with a growing group of dedicated independents, have continued to unearth treasures.
Even with the addition of vitamin D to milk, deficiency during pregnant persists.

With three coaches fired and three more who soon could be, owners of N.F.L. teams who failed to make the playoffs should be squirming as much as their coaches.

An election official said that the secular Awami League party had secured an overwhelming majority.

Nine people accused of intentionally tainting China’s dairy supplies earlier this year went on trial in the country’s worst food safety case in decades.

A day after a suicide bomber killed at least 16 people, a new bombings shook Afghanistan on Monday, killing two civilians north of Kabul and two more in Kandahar Province.

Israel struck at the organization’s civic institutions, with no active diplomacy and protesters taking to the streets around the Arab world.
With power changing hands in Thailand, supporters of Thaksin Shinawatra, the former prime minister who was ousted in a coup in 2006, began to protest.

COMBES--Abbott, otherwise known as Kit, died on December 26th at the age of 64. As son, brother, husband, father, friend, colleague, and soul mate, he left an indelible impression for his charm, wit, sentimentality, strength, and Bermuda shorts. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, 382 Cantitoe Street, Bedford Hills, NY, on Tuesday, January 6th, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Exuma Foundation, 5885 Landerbrook Drive, Suite 300, Cleveland, OH 44124-4031.
MASON--Dr. Ira. You will forever live on in our hearts. We extend our deepest condolences to Gail, Cori, Jonathan and the entire family. Wendy and Edward Sassower

It's the last night to catch Dave Attell at Carolines. This late-late-night comedian, best known as the host of the Comedy Central series ''Insomniac,'' is unlikely to spare any person, place or drink for his end-of-the-year show. Go steal his material. ''Sleepless in Boise, or Any Town With a Comedy Club,'' by Joseph Hooper

DNA MAY THWART DRUGS For more than two years, Jody Uslan, left, had been taking the drug tamoxifen to prevent a recurrence of breast cancer. Then a new test suggested that because of her genetic makeup, the drug was not doing her any good. She is not alone. Specialists say that most drugs, whatever the disease, work for only about half the people taking them. A THREAT TO PROSPERITY Blacks find their economic well-being threatened like no other racial or ethnic group as the auto industry fights for survival. [A1.]

WITTENBORN--Sarah Elizabeth (nee Alwood), of Pottersville, NJ died on December 27, 2008. She was born in Clinton, IL on September 5, 1915. Over the course of 93 years she both raised a large and accomplished family and played a pioneering role in the early days of psychopharmacological re search. She met her husband and colleague, J.R. Wittenborn, at Southern Illinois University, where she graduated with high honors in the class of 1937. After working in children's education in Illinois, she returned to academia as a research associate at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. Over the course of several decades she and her husband co-authored and edited numerous important works on the psychopharmacology of anxiety and depression. In 1995 she received a Presidential Citation from the university honoring her thirty years of service to Rutgers. A New Jersey resident of fifty-five years, she spent her retirement on her farm in Pottersville, in close proximity to her extensive family. She is survived by her four children: Sarah (Betsy) Wittenborn Miller of New York and Pottersville; Gretchen Wittenborn Johnson of Pottersville, East Hampton, NY, and Hobe Sound, FL; J. Richard Wittenborn, MD of Bernardsville, NJ; and Dirk Wittenborn of New York; as well as twelve grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church, Gladstone, NJ on Saturday, January 3rd, 2009, at 1 o'clock in the afternoon. Donations may be sent to the Institute for Women's Leadership at Douglass College, Rutgers University, in lieu of flowers. For more info contact Bailey Funeral Home of Peapack. 908-234-0590.

HITE--Sybil. The Board and staff of the Scholar Rescue Fund of the Institute of International Education wish to express our deep sorrow over the death of Sybil Hite, wife of esteemed SRF Board Member Larry Hite. IIE and the Scholar Rescue Fund convey our sympathy to the Hite family as well as our gratitude for the many ways in which Larry and Sybil have personally contributed to the work of the Fund to assist persecuted scholars from around the world.

The Year In Theater Photographs and reviews of some the best shows of 2008 on Broadway and beyond, as chosen by The Times's Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood. From left, Juston Bohon as Chip, Tony Yazbeck as Gabey and Christian Borle as Ozzie in the musical ''On the Town.''

The Times Square Alliance on Monday tested the air-worthiness of some of the confetti that will shower Times Square on New Year's Eve. Many pieces of the roughly 3,000 pounds of confetti will be inscribed with wishes from people around the world.

FREEDMAN--Carol, of Rego Park, NY, on December 28, 2008. Beloved wife of Bob. Loving mother of Nancy and Karen. Loving grandmother of Justin and Sarah. Dear sister of Frederick Biehl and sister-in-law of Kathy. Funeral Service Tuesday 10:30am at The Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

GABIN--Cynthia, due to complications of heart failure. Beloved mother of Connie Gabin, Kenneth Gabin and Lois (Don Legato) Gabin-Legato. Loving grandmother of seven and great-grandmother of two. Services Tuesday, December 30, 11am, Mount Sinai Memorial Parks and Mortuaries, Hollywood Hills, CA.

GREENWALD--Jane, 80, formerly of Hewlett, NY, died December 28. She was a true woman of her time. She was married to the late Phil Greenwald and was a loving homemaker, raising six children. In the late 1960's, she became a champion of women's rights and an early opponent of the Vietnam War. In the 1970's, she was seized by the entrepreneurial spirit and founded an advertising agency, which she ran successfully for a decade. Afterwards, she traveled the world, settling for a time in Vancouver, BC. In her late years, she returned to New York City to be with her family. She is survived by her children, Jonathan, Susan, Judson, Jennifer, Joseph, and Abraham; 14 grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Funeral Services will be held Tuesday, December 30, 12 noon at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

Guinean soldiers escorting the remains of President Lansana Conté arrived at a stadium from his palace during his funeral ceremony in Conakry. The citizens of Guinea paid their respects to Mr. Conté, 74, as the military junta that seized control in the wake of his death planned a charm offensive to gain international legitimacy. Supporters and even critics of Mr. Conté, a strongman who also took power in a coup and ruled for 24 years, were among the thousands taking part in the ceremonies on Friday.

MASON--Dr. Ira. Our dear friend for so many years, how we will miss you, but you will never be gone from our hearts or minds. So many years, so many wonderful memories, so much love continues on and on. Sleep well dear Ira. Nancy and Ralph Elias Marjorie and Alan Gordon

KALINA--Sophia Felica (nee Rottenberg). Committed to Israel's well-being, she was a long-time supporter of AFHU and The Hebrew University. May her memory be for a blessing. AFHU Ira Lee Sorkin, Chairman George A. Schieren, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director
GREENWALD--Jane. Dear Jane, you have been a part of our lives and in our hearts forever. You loved life, your family and friends. We will miss you always. Mindy and Ron Horowitz Dari, Eric and Perri

ALWILL--Albert. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Albert Alwill, associated with The New York Times from April 1, 1977 until retiring on January 6, 1997.

WIENER--Margaret S.,died peacefully on December 20 at home in Larchmont, NY. For more than 58 years beloved wife of Geoffrey R. Wiener, who survives her. Loving mother of Margaret W. Wiener (Steven L. Goldstein), Geoffrey R. Wiener, Jr. (Wendy J. Banner), Robert S. Wiener (Katherine E. Clark), and Alison H. Wiener (George A. Bryant), and grandmother of ten. Served for many years as social worker to several early childhood education programs in the Larchmont/Mamaroneck area and in the Bronx. A memorial service will be held at a later time.

LEVAN--Robert, died peacefully at home on December 27, 2008 after a long illness, at the age of 91. Born in Manhattan, he attended Temple University and, upon graduation, he returned to New York City, where, for many years, he worked for the New York State Department of Labor as an Occupational Analyst. Bob always took inspiration from the city of his birth, where his interests included drawing and his volunteer work at the American Museum of National History. Bob leaves his loving wife of thirty years, Jeanne, his brother Marvin and sister-inlaw Joan. His family and friends will miss his warm and charming personality, his spontaneous humor and wry wit. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

WINNICK--Alyce, of Lake Worth, Florida formerly of Massapequa, NY. Beloved wife of the late Murry. Loving mother of Michael and wife Alice and Roberta Winnick. Cherished grandmother of Joshua Fryd. Dear sister of the late Richard Bahr and sister-in-law of Frances Bahr. Services today 12 noon at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, LI. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery.

A suicide car bomber killed two civilians and wounded 15 on Monday in Charikar, a city just north of Kabul, officials said. The attack occurred outside the provincial governor's office, and most of the wounded were government employees, said the governor, Abdul Jabar Taqwa. Several hours later, in Kandahar Province, a remote-controlled bomb exploded at a marketplace in the Spin Boldak district, killing two civilians and wounding 19.

VIRANY--Elizabeth. Radwaner. We express our deepest sympathies to Valerie, Steve and all other members of the family.

An electrical explosion blew off manhole covers and knocked out power for hours on Monday morning in downtown Savannah, Ga. No one was injured, and property damage was minimal.

HOLT--Seton Fell. SVCMC mourns the passing of our friend and long-time volunteer, Seton Fell Holt. Seton was a founding member of the St. Vincent's President's Council, and daughter of benefactors Laurence and Eileen Fell, who served as pastpresident of the Auxiliary of St. Vincent's. Seton's commitment to health care and the work of St. Vincent's will always be remembered, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to her entire family. The Board and staff of Saint Vincent Catholic Medical Centers.
UPDATE: Viacom and Time Warner Reach Deal

A collection of historic instruments that belonged to performers including Johnny Cash, Bill Monroe and Mother Maybelle Carter will remain with the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, after the man who helped the museum obtain them committed suicide, The Associated Press reported. Bob McLean, an investor from Murfreesboro, Tenn., had donated two Johnny Cash guitars to the museum, and pledged money that the museum used to buy Monroe’s 1923 Gibson mandolin (valued at $1.1 million), and Carter’s 1928 Gibson guitar (valued at $575,000). Mr. McLean committed suicide last year when his investors accused him of stealing more than $67 million from them in a Ponzi scheme. But a settlement between the Country Music Foundation, which operates the hall of fame, and the trustee handling Mr. McLean’s bankruptcy will allow the museum to keep the instruments and write off $870,850 in unpaid pledges.

Having driven ships to new lands and fought the Battle of Evermore (in song, anyway), Robert Plant, the rock singer and former Led Zeppelin front man, was named a Commander of the Order of the British Empire on Britain’s annual New Year’s Honors List announced by Queen Elizabeth, Reuters reported. Also appearing on the list were the best-selling fantasy writer Terry Pratchett, whose novels include the satirical “Discworld” series, who was awarded knighthood, and the actor Michael Sheen, who portrays David Frost in “Frost/Nixon” and who played Tony Blair in “The Queen,” was made an officer of the Order. The winners of these titles will be honored by Queen Elizabeth at ceremonies in the months to come.

Amy Winehouse has been summoned by a court in Norway to answer charges of drug possession, and is expected to appear there when the case is tried in January, Agence-France Presse reported. In October 2007 Ms. Winehouse was arrested in Bergen, Norway, with her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, and her hairdresser when they were found with marijuana at a local hotel. Ms. Winehouse paid a fine and was released, but later contested the fine. A previously scheduled court appearance was postponed while Mr. Fielder-Civil was serving time in a British jail on convictions stemming from a 2006 assault. A Norwegian prosecutor told Agence-France Presse, “I was informed by British police on Dec. 23 that she has been legally summoned, and we expect that she will be there when the trial opens on Jan. 12.”

The embattled Vancouver dance company Ballet BC has proposed a restructuring plan to its creditors that it hopes will keep it out of bankruptcy, The Georgia Straight newspaper reported. In November, the company laid off 38 employees, including its dancers and its artistic director, John Alleyne; it was narrowly able to stage its year-end production of “The Nutcracker” but has canceled planned tours. Under the restructuring plan, the company’s creditors — who are owed about $300,000 — would each be paid up to about $400 on proven claims, and a further 22 cents on the dollar above that amount. Among those creditors is Mr. Alleyne, who The Straight said is owed about $115,000. The proposal is scheduled for a vote by creditors on Jan. 9.

When his step-dancing company next takes the stage, Michael Flatley will once again be able to perform with them, his arms resolutely at his sides, having been cured of a mystery virus by an energy healer, The Irish Independent reported. In 2006, Mr. Flatley, the dancer and choreographer, was struck by a whole-body infection that forced him to cancel the European tour of his dance show “Celtic Tiger”; doctors were unable to identify the virus and weeks of rest did not cure Mr. Flatley’s fatigue and muscle pain. But he said he has since been treated by Michael O’Doherty, a founder of the Plexus Bio-Energy Clinic, which specializes in “rebalancing the life-force energy within and around the body,” according to its Web site. “When he came to visit me in Ireland, I could barely get out of the chair,” Mr. Flatley said, according to The Independent. “He saw me for about an hour and I walked for about a mile afterwards.”

Harold Pinter, who died on Dec. 24, was buried Wednesday at a private funeral service at the Kensal Green Cemetery in London, Agence-France Presse reported. Those in attendance included Pinter’s widow, Lady Antonia Fraser, as well as the playwright Tom Stoppard and the actor Michael Gambon. According to instructions left by Pinter before his death, no prayers were said at the service, but mourners read from poems about the author’s beloved sport of cricket, and Mr. Gambon read a passage from Pinter’s play “No Man’s Land.” “And so I say to you, tender the dead as you would yourself be tendered, in what you would describe as your life,” Mr. Gambon read, according to Agence-France Presse. Pinter’s agent, Judy Daish, said a memorial service would be held in 2009.

Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) held at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with 262,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the album’s third consecutive week at No. 1, and fourth over all since it was released in November. Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) reached No. 2 with 211,000, Britney Spears’s “Circus” (Jive) was No. 3 with 203,000, and Nickelback was fourth with 177,000 sales of “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner). Kanye West’s “808s & Heartbreak” (Def Jam) jumped six spots to No. 5 with 165,000 sales.

LYNDA is always clued in reference to the actress Carter. There are probably other Lyndas around, but who can resist Wonder Woman? In an interview in November, Elizabeth C. Gorski called Wonder Woman her hero. "I love her uniform, but the accessories are to die for - the boomerang-ing magic tiara, bullet-deflecting cuff bracelets. And what woman wouldn't want a Lasso of Truth hanging from her belt?" I can attest that Ms. Carter was somehow able to appeal to guys as well.

I cleared my hangover on Boxing Day by going for a surf at Espasante, near my home in Galicia, northern Spain. As soon as I started to paddle out, a close-out set came in, every wave of which landed on my head, so that by the time I'd got to the break I was knackered, breathless, and freezing. I fell off a few waves then rode in to shore an hour later, mission accomplished - my head was clear.
With air attacks on Gaza in their fifth day, Israel said it would keep pressure on Hamas but was open to future diplomacy.

Heather Hurlburt of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The New Republic debate whether the attack on Gaza hurts Israel's larger strategic aims.

Blame it on Leap Year.

So you're trapped in the New York Times Building on New Year's Eve, half-afraid to go outside and fight your way through mobs of crazed revelers and meet your friends. An inch of new snow had fallen overnight when we arrived at the cabin site on Tuesday morning. My nephews Paulie and Kevin and I went right to work. At 10.30, the lifting and hammering had warmed my chest and shoulders, and I took off my outer jacket and worked in my sweat shirt. I felt lighter and moved more easily with fewer clothes. I must have been radiating heat into the cold air like a steaming pie set out on a winter windowsill.

As the final hours of 2008 drift away, thousands of people (no one ever seems to know the precise number) are braving the chill and gathering in Times Square for the traditional New Year's ball drop. And as on New Year's Eves past, the New York City police are arraying the crowds into "viewing sections" -- essentially fenced-off, carefully monitored pedestrian bullpens -- throughout the area.

The Mets would like to sign free-agent pitcher Derek Lowe, but don't want to over pay. They're offering Lowe a three-year contract for about $36 million. But as much as the Mets like Lowe, a veteran right-hander, they are not expected to radically improve their offer. Another million a year, for a total package of $39 million? Maybe. But there won't be a fourth year added to the deal.

It's no secret that this has been a tough year for Yahoo. For investors, the company's two major setbacks were the failed merger negotiations with Microsoft and the failed advertising partnership with Google, which disintegrated in the face of opposition from advertisers and the Justice Department. For many employees, much of the pain came from two rounds of layoffs, seemingly endless rounds of reorganizations and a sense that they were riding on a rudderless ship.

My co-op building has a number of storage rooms. The board is reviewing what rental rates should be charged to the shareholders who have the right to use them. Some shareholders have said the board must charge at least a market rate based on retail storage facilities. Does the board have the right to determine what rate, if any, should be charged and not be bound by outside rates? Alan L. Kazlow, a Manhattan co-op and condominium lawyer and former New York assistant attorney general, said that absent a license or lease allowing use of the storage rooms by specified shareholders, the board would have the authority to set the rental rates for use of the building's storage rooms on any basis it sees fit.

In terms of pure volume, it's tough to beat New Year's Eve for bowl games. Sure, the games don't necessarily have the big-time aura of the first games of 2009. But there is still plenty of college football to watch and plenty of intriguing storylines and players to be found. If you haven't had a chance to watch Jaquizz Rodgers of Oregon State or LeSean McCoy of Pittsburgh or the triple-option offense of Georgia Tech, this provides a great opportunity to increase your awareness. Think of it as preparation for the marathon viewing session on New Year's Day.

It happened again yesterday. The Bagger was having "some issues of adjustment" at work yesterday - namely that he did not want to be there - and decided that he would sneak out to "The Day the Earth Stood Still" to prepare for an on-stage interview with Kathy Bates, one of its stars. The Bagger looked for the emptiest part of the AMC 25 theater in Times Square, way up near the top, and sat there. And a guy then lead a loud posse of four right up next to him. Having had a history of confrontation, the Bagger moved and was immediately joined by a happy loving couple who were chattering away through the previews. Noticing a trend, he got up and moved again, to the very last row in the corner.

The headline on a front-page article on Friday, on the role in the housing bubble and consumption binge in the United States played by investment from China, could have been misunderstood. The article described how the United States has been tolerating a huge trade deficit with China while Chinese authorities have invested huge sums in American government securities from savings partly created by the inflow of American dollars. “Dollar Shift: Chinese Pockets Filled as Americans’ Emptied” meant to describe the complications of that situation; it did not mean to imply that China has profited from the weakness of the American economy.

The leader of a small religious sect was sentenced to 10 years in prison for sexual misconduct with two teenage female followers. The sect leader, Wayne Bent, 67, who said the encounters were spiritual, not sexual, was convicted of criminal sexual contact with a minor and contributing to the delinquency of a minor. Mr. Bent, who calls himself Michael Travesser, is the leader of the Lord Our Righteousness Church. A pilot killed this spring while fighting a fire in Fort Carson repeatedly warned officials that winds were too strong but was urged by officials to push on, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded. The pilot, Gert Marais, 42, of Fort Benton, Mont., was killed April 15 when his single-engine air tanker nose-dived into the ground. Officials with the Rocky Mountain Area Fire Coordinator Center, which manages firefighting efforts in Colorado, did not immediately comment on the safety board’s report.

A federal appeals court has refused to stop the government from taking DNA from a prisoner who claims the process would violate his religious beliefs. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit made the decision in a lawsuit filed by Russell Kaemmerling, who is in a Texas prison on a wire fraud conviction. Federal law requires felons to give a DNA sample to be kept in a national law enforcement database. Mr. Kaemmerling, who says he is an evangelical Christian, said that allowing the government to collect his DNA would violate his beliefs on the proper use of what he calls the building blocks of life. But the three-judge panel said DNA collection did not call for Mr. Kaemmerling to change his religious practices and did not hamper his exercise of his religion.

The state is suing the Bush administration to block last-minute endangered-species regulations that are intended to reduce input from federal scientists. Attorney General Jerry Brown said that he had filed the federal lawsuit in San Francisco and that the administration was trying to gut the Endangered Species Act. The Interior Department issued the revised rules this month. They allow federal agencies to issue permits for mining, logging and similar activities without getting a review from biologists. The changes also eliminate a requirement that agencies consider the effects of greenhouse gas emissions when reviewing projects on federal land. The lawsuit also names the Fish and Wildlife Service, the Department of Commerce and the National Marine Fisheries Service as defendants. Mr. Brown, above, is asking the court to block the new rules, which could give the incoming administration of President-elect Barack Obama time to review them.

Democratic leaders in Congress have selected Douglas W. Elmendorf, an economist with experience throughout the federal government, to lead the Congressional Budget Office. The post is vacant because President-elect Barack Obama selected its previous occupant, Peter R. Orszag, to be director of the Office of Management and Budget. Mr. Elmendorf comes to the nonpartisan job from the Brookings Institution, where he and Mr. Orszag both were head of the Hamilton Project, which promotes new approaches to socioeconomic problems.

More than a dozen families filed a lawsuit challenging a new state law banning unmarried couples living together from becoming foster or adoptive parents. The Arkansas chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union filed the lawsuit on behalf of the families in Pulaski County Circuit Court seeking to overturn Act 1, which was approved by voters in last month’s general election. The group filed the lawsuit on behalf of 29 adults and children from more than a dozen families, including a grandmother who lives with her same-sex partner of nine years and is the only relative able and willing to adopt her grandchild, who is now in state care. The law takes effect on Thursday. It does not apply to any adoptions that were completed before then.

Seven astronauts slipped into unconsciousness within seconds and their bodies were whipped around in seats whose restraints failed as the space shuttle Columbia spun out of control and disintegrated in 2003, according to a new report from NASA. While the astronauts' upper bodies flailed, the helmets that were supposed to protect them ended up battering their skulls, the report said, and ''lethal trauma occurred to the unconscious or deceased crew due to the lack of upper-body support and restraint.''

OPATOW--Lorna, pioneering businesswoman in market research, packaging and design, died on Wednesday, December 24th in New York City after a brief illness. Lorna earned a BA from the University of Pennsylvania in 1952, where she attended the Wharton School of Business, although Wharton did not confer degrees on women until 1954, and an MBA in Industrial Psychology from Temple University. Early in her career she was research director for Hearst Magazines. Lorna founded Opatow Associates, a nationally known market research firm in 1963. Her clients included many major corporations. Lorna was a past president and Hall of Fame member of the Market Research Council, past president and honorary lifetime member of the New York American Association of Public Opinion Research, and past president of the International Furnishings and Design Association. She served on the boards of, and headed major initiatives for the Advertising Research Foundation (David Ogilvy Research Awards), the New York American Marketing Association (the Greenbook), and the Institute of Packaging Professionals (Certification). She was awarded Consumer Affairs Professional Member of the Year. She also served on the boards of the Society of Consumer Affairs Professionals in Business (SOCAP), National Home Fashions League, Advertising Women in New York. Lorna was Vice President and Treasurer of the Daniele Agostino Derossi Foundation which funds projects to improve the lives of indigenous women and children in Latin America; Treasurer of New Paths in Music, which showcases music by living composers; and Administrator of Parliamo Italiano, the Italian language school in Manhattan. She was a frequent public speaker, taught at area universities and published articles in many professional and trade publications. Lorna loved to travel, and in the past year had been to Guatemala, Germany, France and Italy. She was a passionate lover of the arts, especially opera, and was known to keep a schedule that had her in theatres almost every night. She was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club, the Coffee House and the Penn Club. Beloved sister of David Opatow (Judy) and Dianne Powell, adored aunt of Jessica Koenig (Bob), Sandy Opatow (Pat Humphries), Mark Opatow (Alicia Zuckerman), and Eve Orio (Guido), devoted great-aunt of Jonathan Koenig and Isabella Orio, and cherished friend to many. She will be dearly missed for her dry wit, her good counsel, her caring concern for friends and family, and her enthusiasm to live life fully. For information contact opatows@gmail.com.

REVSON--Elise Gaines, 89, of Manhattan, died on December 26, 2008. Born January 16, 1919, in New York City, she was a 1941 graduate of Cornell University with a bachelor of arts degree in French. They had three children, Joanne, of Manhattan, and Thomas, of Gloucester, Massachusetts, who survive her, and James, a journalist, who died in 1991. Committed to the arts, she worked in the 1980s as a volunteer at the Whitney Museum at Philip Morris, and later produced plays by Charlotte Meehan. Among her charities were Broadway Cares and God's Love We Deliver. Her charm, wit, and good cheer will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her.

Around the League Seven of this season's playoff teams did not make the playoffs last year. Four (Miami, Baltimore, Philadelphia and Atlanta) finished the 2007 season in last place. ... The Chargers are the ninth 8-8 team make the playoffs since the schedule expanded to 16 games in 1978. Only two have won a game. ... The Packers' Donald Driver and Greg Jennings each had 100-yard receiving games against the Lions and Ryan Grant and DeShawn Wynn, left, each rushed for at least 100 yards. It was the first time a team had two 100-yard rushers and two 100-yard receivers in a game. ... The Colts allowed six touchdown passes, the lowest total for a 16-game season. ... The Chiefs had one sack against the Bengals, leaving them with 10 for the season, the fewest by any team since sacks became an official statistic in 1981. (NYT)

A study of books that have won the Newbery Medal for children's literature has found that their protagonists are increasingly likely to be white, male and from two-parent households, even as American families become more diverse, Bloomberg News reported. The study, conducted at Brigham Young University, looked at the race, sex and family background of characters in 82 books that won the award between 1922 and 2007. It found that fewer books featuring black and Hispanic characters had won from 1980 onward than in the years from 1951 to 1979. ''The Newbery is given for literary quality; ethnicity, gender, nothing of that is necessarily taken into consideration,'' Pat Scales, president of the Association for Library Service to Children, which awards the Newbery Medal, said. She added, ''We owe kids good stories that reflect their lives and give them a more global view.''

Gloves thrown in celebration were left behind at a graduation ceremony for 1,129 new police officers at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly presided over the ceremony. The graduates completed more than six months of intensive training.

The 2008 Detroit Lions will be immortalized as the N.F.L's worst team, but in a season in which so many teams played so badly, it is almost a shame that the Lions have to go into the record books alone. There were three teams with two wins or fewer this season, the most since the strike-shortened 1982 season. Like the Lions, the Bengals (4-11-1) lost their first eight games, but were spared further ignominy by a posting a three-game winning streak to end the season. But the Bengals' offense was in a league of its own. Cincinnati, with Carson Palmer injured, scored the fewest points (204, 64 fewer than the Lions) and gained the fewest yards. The Bengals tied with the Browns and the Rams for the fewest touchdowns (20). Cincinnati also had the most punts (100), and more than a third of its drives (34.4 percent) were three-and-outs.

The Public Theater, which has struggled to raise money to mount its critically successful revival of the counterculture musical “Hair” on Broadway, announced on Thursday that Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel, the producing team behind the Tony Award-winning musical “Spring Awakening,” had agreed to serve together as the lead producers. Elizabeth I. McCann, who had been the show’s lead producer since the Public began working to move the production to Broadway, will continue with the project, but in a reduced role that was not spelled out by Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater. Played six days before the SEC and Big 12 meet in the national championship, the Cotton Bowl may give fans a glimpse of what lies in store for Florida and Oklahoma. On one side, we have Ole Miss -- the only team to beat Florida during the regular season. On the other, high-flying Texas Tech's offensive philosophy provides a similar picture to Oklahoma, though more skewed towards the passing game. The same questions exist here as do in the B.C.S. national championship game: Can Texas Tech control the Ole Miss front seven? Can the Ole Miss secondary contain Graham Harrell and Michael Crabtree? And like the national title game, the Cotton Bowl is expected to be a good one.

“Tess of the d’Urbervilles,” which begins Sunday on PBS 0n “Masterpiece Theater,” is a wan, respectful adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel.

Stanley Tannen turned to begging on the street to support his life's mission: to unite and lift up humanity through free public readings. With the help of several agencies, he now has a new apartment.

With less than two days to go before the N.F.L. playoffs, the Giants are the choice of Las Vegas oddsmakers to repeat as Super Bowl champions. Sports books are giving 2-to-1 odds on the Giants, the National Football Conference's No. 1 seed, according to The Associated Press. The Tennessee Titans are the favorite American Football Conference team at 4-1.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla. -- Approaching the Fountainebleau Hotel here on Wednesday -- a purely journalistic mission, I assure you -- I noticed a large contingent of Cincinnati Bearcat players were waiting outside.That wasn't the only thing I noticed, as the swanky digs were filled with scantily clad women returning form the pool, loud conversations in all sorts of foreign languages and just a wild medley of people.

Alison Lacey is a 6-foot junior point guard for Iowa State, which was briefly in the Top 25 earlier this season. Alison, whose hometown is Canberra, Australia, was an all-Big 12 second teamer last season. This is the holiday edition of her diary for The Quad.

We are still a week away from the B.C.S. title game but there may be no better day for the college football fan than Jan. 1. From late morning (on the East Coast) until late at night, there is wall-to-wall college football. And it's not just quantity. This New Year's Day promises plenty of quality football, too. Whether it's the titantic coaching matchup between Joe Paterno and Pete Carroll in the Rose Bowl or the Capital One Bowl, which features two of the best running backs in the country in Georgia's Knowshon Moreno and Michigan State's Javon Ringer, the five bowl games should make for some terrific viewing as we enter 2009.

The January transfer window has been open for hours and, despite the furious speculation since the previous window closed on Sept. 1 (loans were permitted until the end of November), Real Madrid is the only European team that has made a real splash: The Spanish team brought in Lassana Diarra for £20 million from Portsmouth and Klaas Jan Huntelaar from Ajax for a fee that could reach more than £25 million.

In late October Joao Silva, Max Becherer and Franco Pagetti, three highly experienced photographers who have covered every phase of the Iraq conflict, came together in the Baghdad Bureau of The New York Times during their rotations in Iraq. Architecture | There's little doubt that Eiffel was a genius, a civil engineer writes. "What else can we call a man who produced 14,352 square feet of drawings for the Eiffel Tower-drawings which called for 15,000 structural members and 2,500,000 rivet holes-and who put this immense jigsaw puzzle together without, as far as we know, a single error?" Still, some groused. And others see room for improvement. [Britannica]

Music | The secret of Stradivarius violins? Three-dimensional X-rays reveal that wood used in the fiddles had an exceptionally uniform density. And for that Stradivari can be thankful for having crafted his instruments during the Little Ice Age, when trees grew little more in summer than in winter. [Wired]

Film | No palling around with terrorists, Hollywood: A candid new German film about the Baader-Meinhof Gang can teach America about confronting its history with domestic radicals, a history professor says. "No major American movie has yet told the story of the Weathermen, or for that matter the Black Panthers, with equal honesty." [New Republic]

The New Year has dawned and you, dear reader, are much the worse for wear. But just wait: this physical agony is mere prelude. Yet to come is what Kingsley Amis called the "metaphysical hangover": "that ineffable compound of depression, sadness (these two are not the same), anxiety, self-hatred, sense of failure and fear for the future."

It's a quiet week for the Graphic Books Best Sellers with no new book - whether hardcover, softcover or manga - entering the list. At the comic book store, things were almost as silent. Each Wednesday - new comic book day for those in the know - will normally bring a flood of titles from DC, Marvel and other publishers. This week, there were two: "Fall of the Hulks," which will help solve the mystery of why there is a green and red Hulk running around the Marvel Universe, and "Blackest Night" No. 6, the latest chapter in the Green Lantern event that involves all the heroes of the DC Universe.

An article in some editions on Dec. 24 about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s hiring of Howard Wolfson as a top campaign aide reported that Mr. Wolfson’s wife, Terri McCullough, is the chief of staff to the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi. In fact, Ms. Pelosi has two chiefs of staff: Ms. McCullough, who heads her Congressional office, and John Lawrence, who heads the House speaker’s office.

The Magazines listing in the Most Wanted chart on Dec. 22, ranking five men’s magazines by their number of advertising pages for December, misidentified four of them. Flex, not Men’s Journal, was No. 1 with 221.1 pages; Details, not Men’s Health, was No. 3 with 194.8 pages; Muscle & Fitness, not Maxim, was No. 4 with 162.2 pages; and Men’s Journal, not Esquire, was No. 5 with 154.4 pages. (As the chart correctly noted, Gentlemen’s Quarterly was No. 2 with 208.2 pages.).

An article on Wednesday about President-elect Barack Obama’s interest in golf misidentified the Golf Digest issue in which an article about the subject appears. It is the February issue, not January. (It is scheduled to be on newsstands on Tuesday.).

A picture caption with an article in some editions on Monday about L & S Energy Services of Clifton Park, N.Y., which conducts energy-efficiency audits for small businesses under a program run by a New York State authority, misstated the given name of one of the company’s executives. He is Dennis R. Landsberg, not Daniel.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Dec. 21 about New Yorkers who have served in presidential cabinets misidentified the position held by one New York politician, Jack Kemp, when he was the Republican vice-presidential candidate in 1996. He was co-director of Empower America, a conservative policy group; he was no longer a United States representative from Buffalo.

An article on Saturday about the escape plans of Bruce Pardo, the man dressed as Santa Claus who killed nine people on Christmas Eve in Covina, Calif., misidentified the client of Stanley Silver, a lawyer who said that Mr. Pardo had been trying to get child support payments. Mr. Silver’s client was Mr. Pardo, not Mr. Pardo’s ex-wife, Sylvia Pardo.
Two men accused of killing British soldiers have been turned over to the Iraqi authorities in defiance of the European Court of Human Rights.

The “This Land” column on Dec. 15, about The Bristol Press, a daily newspaper in Bristol, Conn., that is for sale, referred incorrectly to the company that bought the paper from local owners in the 1980s. Although that company, Worcester County Newspapers, is based in Massachusetts, it is not “an out-of-town conglomerate that proved to be too fond of junk bonds.” (That reference was to the newspaper’s current owner, the Journal Register Company.).

A Man in the News article on Wednesday about Roland W. Burris, who was named by Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois to fill the Senate seat of President-elect Barack Obama, misstated the reason that Gov. Dan Walker, who appointed Mr. Burris to a state budget post in the early 1970s, was sent to prison in 1987. He was convicted of bank fraud, misapplication of funds, and perjury, relating to his ownership of a savings and loan after he left office; he was not convicted of corruption.

The races are part of the third edition of the Tour de Ski, which includes seven races in nine days. The overall winner gets 400 World Cup points.

The former race leader Jean-Pierre Dick was forced to retire from the Vendée Globe round-the-world race. Dick, who led the race on four occasions, had to drop out when his yacht, Paprec-Virbac, hit an unidentified object, which caused irreparable damage to the rudder.

Liverpool’s captain, Steven Gerrard, returned to training and received the full support of Manager Rafa Benítez, who spoke to him about his assault charges after a bar brawl. Gerrard, a midfielder, is to appear in court in three weeks and faces a potential five-year prison sentence.

Speedway Motorsports Inc. purchased Kentucky Speedway, clearing the way for S.M.I.’s owner, O. Bruton Smith, to try to bring a Nascar Sprint Cup race to the 1.5-mile trioval in Sparta, in northern Kentucky. The deal was completed more than seven months after S.M.I. agreed to buy the track from the speedway ownership group led by Jerry Carroll. According to papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Smith agreed to pay $78.3 million for the speedway, which cost $152 million to build. The track joins a growing portfolio for S.M.I., which owns seven other Nascar-sanctioned facilities, including Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C.

It’s not a mystery that trees are good for the environment, and the Forest Service’s Center for Urban Forest Research has a software program to compute that benefit. The Tree Carbon Calculator uses data like a tree’s age and location to see how much carbon dioxide it captures from the atmosphere and how much its shade reduces the energy needed for cooling. The program, equipped for California but to be updated nationwide by summer, was created to guide cities, utilities and schools that want to plant trees, said Greg McPherson, the center’s director. But homeowners can use it, too. He entered data about the London plane tree outside his office in Davis, Calif., and learned that each year it captures 113 pounds of carbon and saves his building 162 kilowatt-hours in energy, “relatively good numbers.” The calculator can be downloaded at www.fs.fed.us/psw. To understand your results, comparative data is at www.fs.fed.us/psw/publications under the first “Publication List.” STEVEN KURUTZ.

Rather than gutting the early 19th-century Georgian building that houses the new Rough Luxe hotel in London, or glossing over its imperfections, Rabih Hage, the architect and designer, practiced a different kind of minimalism. He decided “to do the least construction work possible — to change only two doors and add only one door,” Mr. Hage said.

The New York decorator Katie Ridder spends Augusts in Mishaum Point, Mass., a seaside town with not a lot of action, she said. So each year she and her children find a project: one summer, they quilted; another, they made shell necklaces. Two years ago, they began to design wallpaper, an ambitious endeavor that stretched beyond the summer vacation. “It was a very slow process,” Ms. Ridder said, “because I’m not an artist.” (Some would dispute that: her painterly interiors have an exotic Moorish flavor with many handmade elements, like stenciled walls and block-print fabrics.).

“Fearless” (Big Machine) by Taylor Swift, below, held at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart this week with 262,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It was the album’s third consecutive week at No. 1, and fourth over all since it was released in November. Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) reached No. 2 with 211,000, Britney Spears’s “Circus” (Jive) was No. 3 with 203,000, and Nickelback was fourth with 177,000 sales of “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner). Kanye West’s “808s & Heartbreak” (Def Jam) jumped six spots to No. 5 with 165,000 sales. Billboard reported that 47.7 million songs were downloaded last week, a record for a single week. The most popular download last week was Lady GaGa’s “Just Dance,” with 419,000.

Amy Winehouse has been summoned by a court in Norway to answer charges of drug possession and is expected to appear there when the case is tried in January, Agence-France Presse reported. In October 2007 Ms. Winehouse was arrested in Bergen, Norway, with her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, and her hairdresser when they were found with marijuana at a hotel. Ms. Winehouse paid a fine and was released but later contested the fine. A previous court appearance was postponed while Mr. Fielder-Civil was serving time in a British jail on convictions stemming from a 2006 assault. A Norwegian prosecutor told Agence-France Presse, “I was informed by British police on Dec. 23 that she has been legally summoned, and we expect that she will be there when the trial opens on Jan. 12.”.
On Tuesday night, CBS’s broadcast of the 31st annual “Kennedy Center Honors” attracted an average of 10.5 million viewers.

New York City Ballet said it would make available 50 discounted orchestra seats for each performance during its 2009 winter repertory season. The tickets, which regularly sell for $90, will be sold for $25, with the difference to be subsidized by the contribution of an anonymous donor. The discounted tickets will go on sale each week starting Monday, and can be purchased at (212) 721-6500 or at the City Ballet’s box office.

A collection of historic instruments that belonged to performers including Johnny Cash, Bill Monroe and Mother Maybelle Carter will remain with the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum in Nashville, after the man who helped the museum obtain them committed suicide, The Associated Press reported. Bob McLean, an investor from Murfreesboro, Tenn., had donated two Johnny Cash guitars to the museum and pledged money that the museum used to buy Monroe’s 1923 Gibson mandolin (valued at $1.1 million), above, and Carter’s 1928 Gibson guitar (valued at $575,000). Mr. McLean committed suicide last year when his investors accused him of stealing more than $67 million from them in a Ponzi scheme. But a settlement between the Country Music Foundation, which operates the hall of fame, and the trustee handling Mr. McLean’s bankruptcy will let the museum keep the instruments and write off $870,850 in unpaid pledges.

Having driven ships to new lands and fought the Battle of Evermore (in song, anyway), Robert Plant, above left, the rock singer and former Led Zeppelin frontman, was named a Commander of the Order of the British Empire on Britain’s annual New Year’s Honors List announced by Queen Elizabeth II, Reuters reported. Also appearing on the list were the best-selling fantasy writer Terry Pratchett, above center, whose novels include the satirical “Discworld” series, who was awarded knighthood, and the actor Michael Sheen, above right, who portrays David Frost in “Frost/Nixon” and who played Tony Blair in “The Queen.” He was made an officer of the Order. The recipients will be honored by Queen Elizabeth at ceremonies in the months to come.

When his step-dancing company next takes the stage, Michael Flatley, below, will once again be able to perform with them, his arms resolutely at his sides, having been cured of a mystery virus by an energy healer, The Irish Independent reported. In 2006 Mr. Flatley, the dancer and choreographer, was struck by a whole-body infection that forced him to cancel the European tour of his dance show “Celtic Tiger.” Doctors were unable to identify the virus and weeks of rest did not cure Mr. Flatley’s fatigue and muscle pain. But he told The Independent he had been treated by Michael O’Doherty, whose Plexus Bio-Energy Clinic specializes in “rebalancing the life-force energy within and around the body,” according to plexusbio-energy.com, its Web site. Mr. Flatley will be a host of the NBC television show “Superstars of Dance,” which has its premiere on Sunday.

The playwright Harold Pinter, who died on Dec. 24, was buried Wednesday at a private funeral service at the Kensal Green Cemetery in London, Agence-France Presse reported. Those in attendance included Pinter’s widow, Lady Antonia Fraser, as well as the playwright Tom Stoppard and the actor Michael Gambon. According to instructions left by Mr. Pinter, no prayers were said at the service, but mourners read from poems about his beloved sport of cricket, and Mr. Gambon read a passage from Mr. Pinter’s play “No Man’s Land.” “And so I say to you, tender the dead as you would yourself be tendered, in what you would describe as your life,” Mr. Gambon read, according to Agence-France Presse. Pinter’s agent, Judy Daish, said a memorial service would also be held.

Among the more than 40 floats is a homage to Wile E. Coyote and the Road Runner, shown speeding across a New Mexico landscape designed from more than 50,000 roses; an animal safari in the savanna created out of black lichen, ming, fino and Spanish mosses, safflower blossoms, cordon puffs, coconut flakes, chive, onion seed and more than 25,000 yellow giant Oncidium orchids; a salute to epic moviemaking featuring walls, pillars and urns made from yellow, gold and bronze strawflower petals; and an ''Alice in Wonderland'' tea party fantasy good enough to eat, with white sweet rice, orange lentil, green split peas, red pyracanthus berries, safflower spice, walnut shells, cornmeal, paprika and green parsley flakes. 1 P.M. THE crowds at the JetBlue terminal at Kennedy Airport last week straddled two worlds. Fleeing sleet and foot-high snowbanks, some were headed to climates balmy enough to sustain palms, orange groves and swarms of demiclad vacationers. Already at the beach, if only in their minds, they shed their puffers, plump cardigans and boots for tank tops, T-shirts, sandals and flip-flops. Peter Antonsson (slide 6), traveling from Iceland, peeled to a T-shirt and hoodie, and traded furry earmuffs for a headset. Sarah Getto (left) shrugged off the cold in an off-the-shoulder top, and Elizabeth Fuller (slide 3) reached into her suitcase for summery flats. Bound for Sacramento, she planned to kick off her trousers and wear her tunic as a dress. ''It's my way of layering down,'' she said. ''It's a system that's fail-safe. It always works.''

Michael Franzese, a former member of the Colombo crime family, said that top-level tennis matches were being influenced by gamblers and that the sport would be his prime focus were he still in the business of affecting outcomes. Franzese serves as a consultant and speaker regarding his days with the mob and has spoken with ATP players about the methods used to spread corruption. ''It's definitely going on,'' Franzese said. ''If I were in this business now, tennis would be my major target because one player can impact the game. That's all you need.''

Before there were four downs in football, before 6 points were awarded for a touchdown, even before there was an annual Rose Bowl or something called the National Football League, there were chains on the sideline. Since 1906, football teams have needed to gain 10 yards for a first down. From the sideline, far from the action, two sticks connected by a chain have measured the required distance, their placement estimated by eyesight.

FOR weeks now, I have been watching my children endure life in the fishbowl of the holiday season. On hiatus from school, they swim patient laps around one another in the cramped space of a family. I don't envy this. I know from personal experience that the last thing you want, in that awkward decade when you are trying to figure out who you are and where you are headed, is the pressure of being under the constant observation of cranky grown-ups who wonder why you aren't unloading the dishwasher for them more often.

An etching by Picasso and prints by Matisse and Braque were among 30 works stolen from a Berlin gallery during the New Year’s holiday, The Associated Press reported. The artworks, which included Picasso’s “Profil au fond noir” from 1947, Matisse’s “Nude in a rocking chair” from 1913; and Braque’s “Le Boupeut,” from 1962, were stolen from the Fasanengalerie, a private gallery, some time between Wednesday afternoon and lunchtime Thursday, a police spokeswoman told The A.P. The police said the theft was discovered on New Year’s Day, and that it was probably committed by two or more people, given the weight and number of works that were stolen. The total value of the missing works was estimated at $250,000.

For an actor like William Hurt, whose roles have ranged from a gay Argentine prisoner (in “Kiss of the Spider Woman”) to a slang-spouting mob boss (in “A History of Violence”) to a scientist who turns himself into a primitive beast (“Altered States”), the medium of the newspaper is simply too constrictive to do him justice.

When Guns N’ Roses released its album “Chinese Democracy” in November, the Quentin Tarantino film “Inglourious Basterds” moved to the top of the list of hypothetical projects that seemed unlikely ever to see the light of day. But no more: Mr. Tarantino’s long-talked-about World War II drama, which the director has mentioned in interviews at least as far back as 2001, now has an official opening date. The Weinstein Company said that “Inglourious Basterds” would be released on Aug. 21, Reuters reported. The film, which stars Brad Pitt as an American lieutenant who leads a group of soldiers against the Nazis, will be Mr. Tarantino’s first since “Death Proof,” his contribution to the 2007 movie anthology “Grindhouse.”

Legal motions continued to fly this week in the feud over the coming movie “Watchmen,” which 20th Century Fox asserts it has the rights to and whose release it is seeking to prevent; Warner Brothers has shot the movie and plans to open it on March 6. In a particularly hot exchange, lawyers for Warner Brothers filed paperwork opposing Fox’s attempt to block evidence that would show that Fox is an “underperforming” studio or that Warner is “better.” This follows earlier assertions by a Fox executive, in a deposition, that his studio is “unique” and “the very best in the business.” A judge in the United States District Court for the Central District of California has ruled that Fox has rights to the movie, and is expected to conduct a hearing on a possible injunction and other matters on Jan. 20.

In the looking-glass world across the Atlantic, where cultural and not political figures win person-of-the-year accolades, Neil MacGregor, the director of the British Museum, was named Briton of the Year by The Times of London. Mr. MacGregor, who joined the museum in 2002 when it was about $7 million in debt and had closed one-third of its galleries, has since helped restore it to an attraction that now receives more than 6 million visitors a year. He was also believed to be among the candidates to replace Philippe de Montebello at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In naming Mr. MacGregor for the distinction, The Times of London wrote, “He is a committed idealist who, in a world in which culture is increasingly presented as the acceptable face of politics, has pioneered a broader, more open, more peaceable way forward.”

Updated, January 3, 4:55 p.m. Due to an editing error, an earlier version of this entry incorrectly stated that the price of an EvPorsche vehicle does not include the donor car. Prices do include the donor car.

This spring, travelers entering San Francisco International Airport will see a new type of kiosk at check-in -- one offering carbon offsets for those who wish to counter the greenhouse-gas emissions from their trip. It will be the first time that an airport will be peddling offsets, according to the San Francisco Chronicle.

The Liberty Bowl has the misfortune of being sandwiched between two of the most anticipated games of the bowl season, the Cotton Bowl and the Sugar Bowl. It also doesn't provide a matchup that rolls off the tongue; E.C.U.-Kentucky lacks the punch of say, Texas Tech and Mississippi. But it's bowl season, so let's enjoy it while we can. Two months from now, when your only sports options are the Knicks and the Rangers, you'll be begging these two teams to lace 'em up and have another go.The Liberty Bowl: Friday, Jan. 2, 5 p.m. in Memphis

With Al Franken holding on to a razor-thin lead over incumbent Norm Coleman in the protracted contest for the United States Senate seat from Minnesota, Republicans say they are planning to block any attempt by Democrats to seat Mr. Franken when the new Congress is sworn in next week.

A number of years ago, when the London restaurant Locanda Locatelli was new, I reviewed it for another Great Metropolitan Newspaper, saying that it was "in but not of" the hotel a corner of whose ground floor it occupies: then, the Churchill was on the verge of dowdiness, while the restaurant was and remains buzzy and glitzy. The hotel (now a Hyatt-Regency) has caught up: the place is very spiffy, in a fabulous location ten minutes' walk from a good little farmers' market and, if you're lucky, with pretty views over leafy Portman Square, where you can watch the locals trying to play tennis in the rain. (We've started staying there and will be going again soon; I see that on-line hotel sites are showing discount rates for some winter dates.)

UPDATED 12:45 p.m.: Fisher-Price responded via e-mail that its Kid-Tough Digital Camera software does not contain a virus. Rather, the company says that the virus that consumers have experienced is one that can transfer itself from an infected computer to an external device, such as a digital camera. Fisher-Price says anyone with questions or concerns about the Kid-Tough Digital Camera should contact customer relations at (888) 892-6123.

Outside Philadelphia, a lawyer named Whitney Hoffman is wrestling with her résumé. She barely worked a full year as a lawyer after graduating from Penn State 14 years ago, taking what she calls a "mom sabbatical" to raise her sons, who are now 10 and 13. Not that she sat around eating bonbons during those years. She researched a book on public-assembly-facility law being written by a local attorney, served on the board of a local public-­service organization, helped run the community education program for her son's school, created a biweekly podcast on learning disabilities and organized a number of conferences, called PodCamp, to teach new-media skills. "It's not that I don't have experience," she says, "but I worry that I'll sit across the desk at an interview, and they'll say, 'What are you experienced for?' "

Earlier this week I wrote about how consumers appear to be buying less expensive, but more, alcohol. Retailers say their customers have been trading down to less-expensive brands of wine -- but buying more bottles total, leading to approximately the same average purchase size at many stores.

Is it legal for the original owners in a co-op to have benefits that other shareholders do not have? One special benefit that they have in my co-op is the ability to rent out their apartments indefinitely. Other shareholders can sublet their apartments only in an "unusual and special circumstance" and, even then, for only one year.

I own a co-op in Jackson Heights, Queens. I recently asked my co-op board if I could view the building's insurance policy. The board informed me that I cannot; it would allow me to see this information only if I were buying, selling or refinancing my unit. Is this allowable?

Dr. Harold Carr, an orthopedic surgeon in England, was a recluse in his later years, according to relatives. He never married or had children. So when the doctor died in 2007 at the age of 89, few knew what to expect inside his dusty garage. The last thing Dr. Carr's relatives expected to find was one of the rarest cars in the world, a 1937 Bugatti 57S Atalante, which The Associated Press said was one of 17 in existence.

Environment | Highlights from a bleak report on the world's oceans: unchecked overfishing; carbon dioxide in the air making oceans more acidic, threatening the species chain and coral reefs; and a mass of discarded plastic swirling around in two clots in the Pacific, each as large as the United States. Yet the oceans may help avert global warming by providing storage for CO2, or energy through wave or tidal power. Still, nothing gave fisheries a chance to replenish like the devastation of World War II. [Economist, here and here]

Like a lot of folks, the Bagger pulled up to "Wendy and Lucy" not really knowing what, or how much, to expect. The movie is a quiet corrective to a time when movies fly all over the road in search of some kind of connection and end in some kind of far-fetched bow that supposedly ties all of it together. It's a movie that seems small, but stays with you, as A.O. Scott discovered a few weeks back. Over at InContention, Guy Lodge spends time talking with Michelle Williams about why she did the movie and what she learned along the way.

Health | ... There's no fire. Second-hand smoke is what a smoker inflicts on others while he or she is lit up. Now read up on "third-hand smoke" -- what lingers in a smoker's hair and clothing after the butt is put out. A study in the journal Pediatrics finds children vulnerable to such toxins because they're likely to touch or mouth contaminated surfaces. [Science Daily]

Bank of America closed its acquisition of Merrill Lynch on Thursday, ending more than 94 years of independence for the Wall Street investment bank and brokerage firm. One day earlier, Wells Fargo finished buying Wachovia, completing another deal born from the turmoil that has transformed the banking industry in the United States.

The idea of constructing an artificially cooled beach may sound a bit like an anachronistic excess in a world that is struggling to be more energy efficient. But a luxury hotel and condominium complex being constructed in Dubai by Gianni Versace, the Italian fashion house, will include a beach allowing guests to frolic on the sands -- without becoming uncomfortably hot.

Labor | Is the possible retirement of nearly half the federal government's 1.8 million civil servants a good thing or a bad thing? In this new era of massive spending, an article thinks it's a bad thing, citing attrition in "so-called mission critical occupations." Why, there might not be enough people to collect the taxes, or run the bailouts funded by the taxes. [New Republic]

Autos | Put Nascar out of its impending misery, a fan says. "Let's face facts-even if Ford, G.M., and Chrysler get the cash they want from the taxpayers, they are going to have to pull back heaps of sponsorship dough from stock-car racing." In a changing auto business, Nascar's gas-guzzling ways add up to a private jet-style "P.R. disaster" for the Big Three. [Slate]

One of the paradoxes of the Middle East is that all sides tend to be drawn to military solutions, even though they have a terrible record. History suggests that each side empowers its enemies when it turns to firepower. Hamas's reckless terror attacks and rocket attacks gave strength to Israeli hard-liners, and if Bibi emerges as prime minister, it'll be because of Hamas. Conversely, Hamas is a power in Gaza today largely because of Israeli excesses, including attacks on Fatah police infrastructure in earlier years -- and of course Hezbullah was born after the 1982 Israeli invasion of Lebanon.
The Baltimore Ravens’ defensive coordinator, Rex Ryan, acknowledged that at least two teams — the Detroit Lions and the St. Louis Rams — had expressed interest in him, ESPN reported.

Andy Murray defeated James Blake, 6-2, 6-2, o set up a semifinal match with Roger Federer at the inaugural Capitala World Tennis Championship in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. In the other first-round match, Nikolay Davydenko ousted Andy Roddick, 6-4, 6-4, and will face Rafael Nadal in Friday’s other semifinal. Nadal and Federer received first-round byes in the exhibition event, which is not part of the ATP Tour but features 6 of the world’s top 10 players and offers a winner-take-all prize of $250,000.

The Jamaican sprinter Usain Bolt edged the swimmer Michael Phelps in a vote for the 2008 athlete of the year by the international news media. The pole-vault champion Yelena Isinbayeva took the top honor as sportswoman of the year, and Spain’s soccer team was voted team of the year for winning the European Championship.

Karim Darwish of Egypt became the world’s new No. 1 player, ending the 33-month reign of his compatriot Amr Shabana. Darwish, 27, from Cairo, is the 13th player to top the men’s world list, but only the second Egyptian. Darwish, a former junior world champion, was eighth in the rankings at the start of 2008, but he reached six finals — including the World Open in October — and won three titles, including his first Super Series crowns in Qatar and Saudi Arabia. Shabana slipped to No. 2, and the World Open champion Ramy Ashour remained at No. 3.

An art review last Friday about “Artist’s Choice + Muniz = Rebus,” at the Museum of Modern Art, misidentified the photographer whose picture of an African stringed instrument is in the exhibition. The picture is by Charles Sheeler, not Walker Evans.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about a decline in the Manhattan office market included an outdated reference to the law firm Pryor Cashman, which will move into 7 Times Square. It is no longer simply an entertainment law firm; it now has a wide range of practice areas.

A picture caption on Wednesday with an article about entrepreneurs working to make the Web available in more languages misidentified the person shown. CONNELLAN--Fr. Thomas J.,CSP, died December 26. Visitation at Paulist residence today from 2-5 and 7-9pm at Paulist Fathers residence, 415 W. 59th Street. Funeral tomorrow at 10am at Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 60th and Columbus. The oldest son of Anne Jones Connellan and Thomas J. Connellan, he is survived by his sisters, Sr. Anne M. Connellan, S.C. , Helene O'Neil, Angela Murphy, Mary Dougherty and Elizabeth McGahren; 21 nieces and nephews; and 44 grandnieces and grandnephews. His brother, William, and sister, Miriam, predeceased him. Father Connellan graduated from Regis High School, attended Columbia University and graduated from the United States Naval Academy. After World War II, he worked for General Electric. He entered the Paulist novitiate in 1949, ordained a priest in 1956 and served as a former vice president of the Paulist Fathers.

FORMAN--Frances, 84. Beloved mother of Katherine Forman Soll, mother-in-law of Steven Soll and grandmother of Jesse and Lauren died peacefully at her home on Wednesday, December 31. Widow of Yale Forman, to whom she was married of 39 years, until his death in 1986. A graduate of Julliard, she began her professional life as an opera singer, performing at such prestigious venues as Town Hall, Chattaqua Opera, Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra and NBC Opera. She subsequently worked in partnership with her husband in their business, Yale Forman Designs, a full service design and licensing firm serving the home furnishing industry and was an active member of many industry organizations. She devoted her life to her family, music and her love of learning. She was greatly loved and will be deeply missed. Services: Sunday January 4 at 11:15am at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
