Four Seasons Resort Vail WHAT Resort and residential development in ski country. WHERE Vail, Colo. AMENITIES A spa and an après ski lounge, among others. PRICES Full ownership residences start at $5.3 million, shared ownership at $406,000. STATUS Scheduled to open late this year. DEVELOPER Black Diamond Resorts- Vail LLC. CONTACT (877) 748-8245 or www .fourseasons.com/ownvail. DETAILS The town of Vail, which was incorporated more than 40 years ago, recently found itself in a bit of a midlife crisis. While the ski resort remained one of the world's best known, the town below had grown a bit dated, with a number of its buildings still stuck in the '70s. The response was a large-scale renewal effort, now valued at around $2 billion, that includes this 2.7-acre Four Seasons-branded project. Its plans call for a 121-room resort and 35 condominiums in a 10-story building near the entrance to Vail Village. Nineteen of the residences will be two- to four-bedroom, 1,835- to 3,500-square-foot furnished units that are sold in one-12th fractional shares. Fractional owners will be granted at least three weeks of use a year, including one week in winter and one in summer that will be assigned on a rotating schedule. The rest of the residences are whole-ownership, 1,650- to 5,800-square-foot units with one to five bedrooms. Both types of residences will include gas fireplaces and terraces, and most will have views of the mountain. For amenities, there will be the spa, a fitness center, a fine-dining restaurant and a 75-foot-long pool and whirlpools in a courtyard. The ski lounge will include a bar and an outdoor terrace, and ski and snowboard valet service will be offered nearby at the resort's Vista Bahn lift.

In the outside world, images of Russia's penal system have mostly been formed by literature, from Dostoyevsky to Solzhenitsyn's devastating portrait of the gulag. A recent visit to Prison Colony No. 7, a high-security jail 310 miles northwest of Moscow, revealed more about the system, which has proved difficult to open up. Last month, President Dmitri A. Medvedev joined Russia's human rights ombudsman in saying that unusually harsh sentences must be addressed. Clockwise from top left: lines forming outside the dining hall, a dormitory with holiday decorations, the arrival of new prisoners and inmates rehearsing a skit for a New Year's party. More photographs: nytimes.com/world.

But music does it better. [Standpoint]

A front-page article on Thursday about the selection of Roland W. Burris of Illinois to fill the Senate seat vacated by Barack Obama reported that four black Democrats in the House had said that Mr. Burris should be seated, despite the opposition of Senate Democrats. The article said that “some of those House members” warned that to deny the seat to Mr. Burris, who is black, could anger black voters. That view was not expressed by Representative Maxine Waters of California, one of the four, who said in an interview that “I don’t think race has anything to do with it.”.

I've gotten to know a heap of young people of late -- people I call "Generation E" -- who are working on every facet of the climate-energy challenge. Some are trying to spread awareness of climate science and its implications. Others are working on ways to cut the human impact on the environment as inventors or entrepreneurs. [UPDATE, 5/7: Lately, I've been summarizing the themes represented by the E in Generation E this way: Environment, Energy, Equity, Enterprise.]

BARTFELD--Rhoda, died peacefully on December 31, 2008 at the age of 82, at her home in Queens, NY. She was married for 63 years to her husband, Frederick, who survives her. For her entire life she was devoted to her husband, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She is also survived by her son Jeffrey, daughter Leslie, daughter-in-law Suzanne and son-in-law Bruce; her six grandchildren Rachel, Sarah, Diana, Mark, Emily and Jonathan, grandson - in - law Tony and her great-grandchildren Nathan, Eliza and Peter. A memorial service is being held on Sunday January 4, 2009 at 8:30am at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Donations in memory of Rhoda Bartfeld may be made to: Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, NY 10087-7106. Rhoda has made two lasting bequests to her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, one is roots and the other is wings. We will forever be grateful.

More often than not, when teams from so-called midmajor conferences face a reckoning in Bowl Championship Series games, they prove their brand of football is not so inferior. No. 7 Utah of the Mountain West Conference capped a perfect 13-0 season with an upset of No. 4 Alabama of the Southeastern Conference, 31-17, in the Sugar Bowl on Friday night. It was the third time in four tries that a team from outside the major conferences has won a B.C.S. bowl game.

8 P.M. (Animal Planet) UNDERDOG TO WONDERDOG Abandoned shelter dogs are given a shot at being the pets they might have been, in this new canine makeover series that even Cinderella might envy. Led by Ryan Smith, a Wonder Team rescues and rehabilitates strays, after which they are trained by Andrea Arden, a dog behaviorist; groomed by Ali McLennan; and then placed in a loving home with a custom-designed doghouse built by David Leon. In this premiere episode, the fairy tale begins for Lucky, a Yorkshire terrier who was given up after being hit by a car and, after surgery and some T.L.C., is placed with the family of 11-year-old Olivia Maryanski, above with Lucky. THESE days, as we contemplate the future of the automotive industry, we would do well to remember the words of Henry Ford: ''Failure is the opportunity to begin again more intelligently.'' For Detroit, there is plenty of failure. But there are also plenty of opportunities to begin again. In fact, there are many new technologies to make cars safer, cheaper, cleaner and more convenient. All these could be adopted by the automobile industry in the near future and without too much trouble.

Truckloads of Ethiopian Army soldiers began to pull out of Mogadishu, Somalia's capital, on Friday, the first signs of Ethiopia's expected withdrawal. Almost as soon as they began to move, the trucks hit a roadside bomb. At least nine civilians and an unknown number of soldiers were killed. Thousands of Ethiopian troops stormed into Mogadishu two years ago to shore up Somalia's weak transitional government. But their efforts have mostly failed, and Islamist insurgents have retaken most of the country. It was not clear whether the troops were leaving Somalia entirely or redeploying to other areas of the country. Western diplomats estimate that several thousand Ethiopian troops remain in Somalia.

After 87 years as a New York literary haven of international stature, the Gotham Book Mart is moving to Pennsylvania -- or at least, the store's inventory is. An anonymous donor who bought the inventory of the store, which closed in 2007, has given it to the University of Pennsylvania. The 200,000 items -- primarily poetry and literature, but also works on art, architecture, jewelry, music, dance and film -- will go to Penn's Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

GOLDFARB--Mark, 74, of Manhattan. Adored by his wife, Barbara Barnett Goldfarb. Brother of Annette Sherman. Extraordinary father of Soozy Gaby Goldfarb Miller and Andrew Nathan Goldfarb. Beloved fatherin-law of Aviva Laser Goldfarb and grandfather of Solomon and Celia Goldfarb, and Clark and Jessica Miller. Mark was a lifelong fan of the Yankees, the Giants, and the Red and the Blue. His life was enriched by his passion for books and the New York Times crossword puzzle. He was perennially in pursuit of a longer backswing and a topspin backhand. At the time of his retirement, he was Chief Financial Officer of St. Martin's Press. Mark made a statement without being verbose. Service at Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, January 4, at 10:30am.
CAROLYN B. MALONEY Representative, 14th District

Andrea Carla Michaels co-constructed the very first puzzle I talked about here at Wordplay and she's back again, this time with a solo work. I've never had a chance to meet her but I hear she's a wild and crazy gal, by which I mean a former stand-up comic among other things. She writes for magazines (Games, TV Guide) and has written for TV (Designing Women) . She once won a motor home on Wheel of Fortune, and she now runs a business called Acme Naming where she uses her word skills to sell names. On Saturday night, the American Economic Association held its very first humor session. The room was packed. Like the "Recent Financial Crises" panel earlier in the day (headlined by some of the profession's top macroeconomists), this one played to a standing-room-only crowd.

Among the many interesting papers being presented this weekend at the American Economic Association's conference in San Francisco, two relating to "choice architecture" -- that is, the idea of creating a context that nudges people toward a better decision -- have caught my eye. This concept, also known as "libertarian paternalism," has been popularized recently by Richard Thaler's and Cass Sunstein's book "Nudge."

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Of all the alarming statistics entering Thursday's national title game between Oklahoma and Florida, perhaps none is more surprising than Oklahoma's pass defense being ranked No. 98 nationally. The Sooners have yielded 253.1 passing yards per game, sandwiching them statistically between the college football immortals Marshall and Utah State.But that didn't stop Sooners cornerback Dominique Franks from tossing a few verbal barbs toward Florida on Sunday morning. Franks said that Florida quarterback Tim Tebow was not as good as Oklahoma's Sam Bradford, Texas' Colt McCoy or Texas Tech's Graham Harrell."I'd say he'd probably be about the fourth best quarterback in our conference," Franks said of Tebow.Asked to expand on his bulletin board material, he happily obliged."I really think with those three guys, it's a lot harder to prepare for those guys," Franks said. "We're coming in and facing Tebow, and he wants to run the ball a lot more. He's predominantly a running quarterback. So to me it's going to be a lot easier for us to prepare to stop the run than having to face a quarterback that might throw the ball 40 or 50 times a game."When told of Franks's comments, Florida Coach Urban Meyer chuckled. "Ah, the gift of youth," he said.In terms of production, Tebow lags behind the three Big 12 quarterbacks in overall yardage and touchdown passes. But he ranks fourth nationally in efficiency (behind Bradford and McCoy but ahead of Harrell). Perhaps his most impressive statistic is his 28 touchdown passes compared to 2 interceptions.And while Tebow finished third in the Heisman Trophy voting behind Bradford and McCoy, he finished with more first-place votes. Franks said the Sooners hoped to show that Bradford was the rightful winner."Everybody is going to think Tebow should have won the Heisman," he said. "But the right person won the Heisman, and we're going to go out there and show the reason why he won it."Needless to say, the Oklahoma defensive coordinator Brent Venables wasn't pleased with Franks for poking at Tebow, saying Franks was "just a young guy that doesn't know any better."

History | A new book challenges conventional wisdom about William Randolph Hearst, according to this review. First, the press baron's megalomaniacal "Citizen Kane" persona grew falsely from a Lincoln Steffens profile that Steffens himself later regretted as a hatchet job. Second, Hearst's Journal was not "the epitome of yellow journalism" after the sinking of the Maine; other papers were rabid too, while the Journal's reports on sabotage were credibly sourced. [Wall Street Journal]
A look at the process that helped Brad Pitt age as Benjamin Button.

Ivory Tower | On the death of Samuel Huntington (see Sunday's Week in Review), Francis Fukuyama recalls his former teacher's swimming against the tide of political science's idealistic "modernization theory" in the 1960's. Huntington argued "that the actual experience of newly independent countries was one of increasing social and political disorder." And his view of "modernizing authoritarianism" was vindicated by the "Asian miracle." [American Interest]

With less than three weeks before Barack Obama is sworn in as president, the demands for a fiscal stimulus package are mounting. Fiscal stimulus can take the form of additional government spending or tax cuts. While you have probably already heard calls for reductions to personal and corporate income taxes, here is one tax-related stimulus suggestion that you may not have come across: eliminating tariffs, the taxes on imports to the United States.

I was fascinated by Tina Rosenberg’s article (“A Payoff Out of Poverty?” Dec. 21) about Mexico’s Oportunidades program. Seeking to ameliorate rural poverty through cash subsidies to support health care and education seems like an attractive approach that could be embraced by both ends of the political spectrum. But as Rosenberg notes, without the creation of large numbers of well-paying jobs, the cycle of poverty will continue. In Mexico, 6,500 students graduate from medical school annually, but tens of thousands will end up as taxi drivers, book vendors and laboratory technicians, or in other jobs that have nothing to do with their training. Tiny cash supplements can never be a meaningful substitute for real jobs.

Delving into the head and heart of the actor Philip Seymour Hoffman so brilliantly, as Lynn Hirschberg has done, has left us with the sense that we know this man, this actor, personally as well as anyone could (Dec. 21). We not only like him. We want to be there as he immerses himself in the character so completely that we no longer realize that Hoffman is playing a role. He becomes the character from the inside out. We are pulled into Capote for he is Capote as we knew him in the flesh. He is the priest in “Doubt” and could step permanently into this priestly role in real life, and we would not know the difference.

A SELLOUT IN MINNESOTA After two deadline extensions from the league, the Minnesota Vikings sold out Sunday's playoff game against the Philadelphia Eagles late Saturday afternoon. The Vikings' first playoff game since the 2000 season will not be blacked out in Minnesota. Under league rules, a team must sell out a home game before it can be broadcast on local television, with the normal deadline to do so set 72 hours before kickoff.

Come Jan. 20, eggheads can celebrate a historical first: the first time a president, vice president and both spouses bring experience in higher education to the table. Michelle Obama was a dean at the University of Chicago from 1996 to 2002; her husband spent 12 years teaching law there. Both Joseph and Jill Biden taught right up to this semester: Mr. Biden at Widener University in Scranton, Pa.; his wife at Delaware Technical and Community College. Mr. Biden is now on leave; Dr. Biden's office says that, after Inauguration Day, she will look into continuing to teach.

The N.H.L. enters 2009 on a high from the New Year's Day outdoor game at Wrigley Field. Like last year's game outside Buffalo, it was a ringing success in terms of aesthetics and television ratings. But beyond the afterglow, the league has several concerns in the year ahead. Here are five of the biggest. THE ECONOMY The recession has put at least one franchise, the Phoenix Coyotes, in critical condition. They will lose an estimated $25 million this season. Other teams are also hurting. If overall revenue holds steady and keeps the contract-mandated salary structure near its current level, some clubs may not be able to meet payroll minimums in 2009-10.

Service at Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., on Sunday, January 4, at 10:30am.

f you are an all-American preppy, a sports-obsessed jock or a hipster with meticulously messed-up hair, we are sorry to inform you that spring will not be your season, at least stylistically. Judging by the spring men's collections (which will be hitting stores any day now), designers are going for a more pulled-together Euro look. You might consider throwing out those beat-up jeans and breaking out the printed silk scarves. Who better to exemplify this new continental trend than Gabrielecorto Moltedo, the young designer well known for his aristo look? It doesn't hurt that he is also a member of Italian fashion royalty: his family owned the luxury house Bottega Veneta until 2001, when they sold it to the Gucci Group. In 2004, Moltedo started an eponymous line of high-end accessories on his own.

THE NEWS Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois said he would appoint Roland W. Burris to fill the Senate seat vacated by Barack Obama. BEHIND THE NEWS After Governor Blagojevich was arrested Dec. 9 on federal corruption charges including trying to auction the seat for personal gain, Senate leaders said they would not seat anyone he chose. He seemed to dare them to carry out that threat when he named Mr. Burris, a former state attorney general who was the first black candidate to win statewide office in Illinois and who is regarded as an honest elder statesman. Legal experts disagreed on whether the Senate had valid grounds to exclude Mr. Burris.

VINOLOGY Brent Simon declared himself an official collector after he began buying bottles of wine he had no intention of ever drinking. His collection began in earnest after his college graduation, when he bought a 1997 bottle of Beringer Private Reserve cabernet sauvignon for $100. Thereafter, each time something nice happened, he acquired a bottle . And when something great happened, he might drink one. Mr. Simon, 30, founder of a medical device company, is in his second year at the Johnson School of Management at Cornell. His admission prompted a 1996 Cristal. Today, his collection hovers at 40 bottles. Still, he's perfectly content drinking a $10 zinfandel, he says, adding, ''I don't read Wine Spectator or anything like that,'' though he takes field trips to nearby wineries with the Johnson Wine Club. Wine aficionados also congregate at clubs at Middlebury, Hamilton and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business. And one of the more popular courses at Cornell's School of Hotel Administration is ''Introduction to Wine,'' which enrolls more than 700 a term.

THE WILD SIDE It's hard to become a fossil, to leave a tangible record of your presence on the Earth millions of years after you died. Most of us swiftly get recycled into other beings. After all, the competition for corpses is fierce. Species of bacteria, worms, ants, flies, beetles and even some butterflies have a taste for rotting flesh. And that's without mentioning larger scavengers, like vultures, hyenas and mongooses. But evading Nature's undertakers is only the first step in becoming a fossil. If you want to be preserved for millions of years, you also have to choose the right place to die. If you're lucky, you'll have a quick burial in the silts and sediments of a river bed, or under volcanic ash. For many environments can never yield fossils. Die on top of a mountain, for example, and your fossil hopes are slim. The reason is that mountains don't bury, they erode. (You might get frozen in ice, in which case you may last as long as the ice does; that may be several thousand years; but it won't be several million. Ice is for those with modest ambitions for immortality.)

About 80 percent of private colleges assess applicants for admission without regard to their ability to pay, according to a new report from the National Association for College Admissions Counseling. But don't confuse "need blind" and "need met." Only 18 percent say they provide a package of loans and/or grants covering the full cost of attendance for students with demonstrated need. "Many schools hide behind the fact that they're need-blind, need-blind being a proxy for providing access," says Jennifer Rickard, Bryn Mawr's dean of admissions and financial aid. Colleges like Bryn Mawr are "need sensitive." They consider finances, but usually only for the academically marginal. For less wealthy institutions, being need-sensitive can mean more money for those they do admit. Below are responses to an Education Life questionnaire on the subject.

Some women discovered their own closets this fall as the gloomy financial news dampened enthusiasm for shopping. Marjorie Stern, Nos. 1 through 8, wore her cherished designer coats on her way to work at her nonprofit children's boutique. No. 1 is from one of Kansai Yamamoto's earliest collections, in Paris, over 30 years ago. Lorry Newhouse revived No. 9, Balenciaga's spiral-seamed 1960s masterpiece. No. 11, the $135 pleated coat from H&M, a success last year, continues to be a favorite of young women. No. 12, a late 1930s Schiaparelli bias-cut evening dress with an embroidered sea urchin on one shoulder, was retrieved from a family trunk and worn to a holiday party. All of the wearers expressed the opinion that their long-held designer favorites were better than anything being offered today. No. 10, outfits made entirely of plastic bags, seen one morning at 8:45 on East 57th Street, seemed an overstatement of the new reality.

SHARING A COOL, QUIET MOMENT, ZIPAQUIRÁ, COLOMBIA, JULY 25, 2008 Yolanda Vasquez, 37, a television producer from Fort Lee, N.J., and her daughter, Laura, 8, explore the Salt Cathedral of Zipaquirá, built amid miles of tunnels from an underground salt mine, north of Bogotá. ''I was part of a group of reporters that went to Colombia for four days as part of a press tour, and I brought my daughter along with me. It was very entertaining. We went to historical places like the cathedral, but we also went to a restaurant-club and to the botanical gardens. I was very touched, because Colombia did not have a really good reputation before because of the drugs. But nowadays, if you go to the right places, it's O.K., and it was beautiful. I felt like I was about to cry, because I really was proud of Colombia. I'm from Colombia. I lived over there until I was 26, and had never been to the Salt Cathedral before. I was like, 'Can you believe I had to move to the U.S. and come back to know my country better?' '' As told to Austin Considine

For those susceptible to the romantic allure of attending the last performance of a Broadway show, January will be one for the history books. The annual post-holiday doldrums in the theater district are proving particularly doleful in 2009, as more than a dozen plays and musicals -- almost half of the current lineup, incredible though it may seem -- get ready to close by the end of the month. Harvey Fierstein, who has returned to the cast of ''Hairspray,'' will saunter forth from a giant, glitter-bedecked aerosol can and rasp his last girlish rasp on Sunday afternoon. Patti LuPone will tear into the worn soul of Mama Rose for the last time on Broadway a week later. And the questing kids from ''Spring Awakening'' will sing their last moody hymn to the wondrous ache of self-discovery a week after that.

Van OORTMARSSEN-Gerry. It is with deep regret and sadness that we announce the untimely death of our dear friend and colleague Gerry Van Oortmarssen, who died in a plane crash, piloting his own plane, in Vienna, Austria on December 14, 2008. Gerry came to Elekta in 1997, bringing with him vast experience and skills in managing the sales, marketing and service of advanced medical technologies from Siemens, ADAC and other companies in the international health care market. Over the years, Gerry held several senior management positions in Elekta, including Head of the European Region, Global Head of Sales, Marketing and Service and most recently of Executive Vice President Business Region Asia, making major contributions to the growth and development of Elekta. He was a long time member of the Elekta Executive Committee and a very good and close friend to many of us. Regardless of position, we all had come to depend on Gerry's strong commitment, his high energy level and his persistence to ''close the deal''. He was called ''The Flying Dutchman''. The reason for this was not merely his love of flying and his habit of flying himself to meetings whenever and wherever he could. It was something more. Something in his ''can-do'' personality that made this label so appropriate for Gerry. A great man, so suddenly stolen away. Our thoughts go out to his wife and family. When we now have to say farewell to Gerry, it is with an immense gratitude for his considerable contributions to Elekta. He will be deeply missed, both as a friend and as a colleague. Tomas Puusepp, President & CEO, Elekta

Here’s one more volume that President Bush and Karl Rove can add to their years-long book-reading contest: Laura Bush will write a memoir of her life and her years in the White House. The publisher Scribner, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, said in a release that it had acquired Mrs. Bush’s as-yet untitled book and plans to publish it in 2010. The release follows weeks of speculation and rumblings that the first lady had been meeting with editors in New York to discuss the project. Scribner said in its announcement that the memoir would offer “an intimate account of Mrs. Bush’s life experiences.” Mrs. Bush said in the release that she would tell “the stories of the extraordinary events and people I’ve met in my life, particularly during my years in the White House.” Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

The Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Scotland’s annual celebration of comedy, drama and performing arts, may be forced to shut down its popular Fringe Sunday event because of a funding shortage, The BBC reported. As it prepares for the 2009 festival in August, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society is facing significant shortfalls as the costs of the event have increased. Ticket sales for last year’s festival were down 10 percent after several malfunctions at the box office. The festival recently received a loan of about $180,000 from the Edinburgh City Council and two grants for about the same amount, but is still seeking a sponsor for its Sunday celebration. A spokesman told The BBC that a final decision about the future of the Sunday event had not yet been made.

The Scottish government has confirmed that it made a fundraising pledge to help save a valuable Titian painting, but denied a report that it had granted as much as $25 million for the artwork, Bloomberg News reported. The National Galleries of Scotland and the National Gallery in London are seeking to buy two Titian paintings, “Diana and Actaeon” and “Diana and Callisto,” from their owner, the Duke of Sutherland, who announced plans in August to sell his collection. The British newspaper The Independent reported that the Scottish government has granted about $25 million towards the duke’s total asking price of about $74 million for “Diana and Actaeon.” The galleries have denied that report, and in an email message to Bloomberg News, a spokesman for the Scottish government said only that it had made “a significant funding pledge to the National Galleries of Scotland which was essential to get its fundraising campaign off the ground.” The galleries had already received more than $15 million in public and private pledges.

The distance between a Broadway show and an authentic Chinese meal is about to get a lot shorter, at least for theatergoers in the Eastern hemisphere. A $686 million construction project will bring a 32-theater complex to Beijing, where imports of Western musicals and other shows will play year-round, Variety reported. The entertainment complex is being built by Beijing Shibo Real Estate in the city’s Haidian district, and is expected to run more than 100 shows a year. Its biggest theater will seat 2,000 people, while others will accommodate 300 to 500 audience members. Translated versions of Western musicals like “Mamma Mia!” and “The Lion King” have become increasingly popular in China, and theatrical producers like Cameron Mackintosh and Nederlander Worldwide Entertainment have previously announced plans to bring their shows to that country.

A promising development for fans of 3D movies with no drive-in theaters at which to appreciate them: two high-profile 3D television broadcasts, both on NBC, will be coming at you in February, The Associated Press reported. The first, a 90-second commercial for the DreamWorks Animation feature film “Monsters vs. Aliens,” will be broadcast during the Super Bowl on Feb. 1. The following night, NBC will show a special 3D episode of its tongue-in-cheek secret agent series “Chuck.” Both broadcasts will use a combination of 3D technologies that require special polarized glasses (rather than the more familiar red-and-blue specs). More than 150 million pairs of glasses will be given away in retail promotions before the Super Bowl.

BAGHDAD -- The number of Iraqi civilians killed in violence here has been on the decline for three years now. In 2006, 76 per day, down to 67 per day in 2007 dropping to 25 per day in 2008, according to an analysis by Iraq Body Count. But even on good day, when the death toll is lower than that in some American cities, explosions and gunfire can be heard around the city and the aftermath can be devastating. Below is a list of the day's violence in Iraq in which at least three people were killed and more than 50 wounded.

There is no doubt that 2008 was a tough year for the deal-makers, but it may not be as bad as some would make it out to be. The final numbers from Dealogic show that the combined volume of global mergers and acquisitions announced in 2008 came in at $3.3 trillion. That is down 28 percent from the record total of 2007, but still the fourth-highest yearly total on record -- hardly a terrible year in the scheme of things.

Lindsey Vonn crashed just five gates before the finish Sunday on the icy Crveni Spust slalom course in Zagreb, Croatia, losing a likely victory and the overall lead in the World Cup standings. Maria Riesch of Germany finished in a combined time of 1 minute 58.69 seconds to win her third straight slalom and take the lead in the standings. Vonn led after the opening leg and was 0.94 faster than Riesch at the second intermediate time in the final run before hitting a gate and crashing. She was not injured.

Defending champion Manchester United cruised to a 3-0 victory at second-tier Southampton in the F.A. Cup and will host Tottenham in the fourth round. Two goals by James Milner gave Aston Villa a 2-1 victory at Gillingham of League One.

Seventh-seeded Richard Gasquet recovered to beat Marc Gicquel, 4-6, 6-2, 6-2, in the first round of the Brisbane International tournament in Australia. The joint ATP-WTA tournament is being played for the first time at the new Queensland Tennis Centre. In other men’s matches, Taylor Dent beat Steve Darcis, 7-6 (7-0), 6-2, and will play Gasquet in the second round. Among first-round women’s matches, second-seeded Victoria Azarenka defeated Kateryna Bondarenko, 6-0, 6-2.

Let's get this out of the way at the start: Everyone knows Texas does not want to be in the Fiesta Bowl. The Longhorns believe they should be playing in the B.C.S. title game in Florida, having already beaten Big 12 foe Oklahoma in a head-to-head matchup on a neutral field. But with the possibility of skimming some first-place votes in the A.P. poll sitting out there, the Longhorns certainly have plenty to play for. So do the Buckeyes, who have become something of a bowl-season punchline in recent seasons. Ohio State was soundly defeated in the last two B.C.S. title games and you can bet that Jim Tressel and this proud program do not want to go down meekly again in front of a national audience.

Mr. Taffet devoted his life to his family and the last 20 years to feeding the needy and hungry. He will be missed. Taylor Swift, shown above during New Year's Eve festivities in Times Square, had two of the top 10 albums last year. According to the Nielsen Company, she was the top-selling artist in 2008, with sales of just over four million albums. Lil Wayne and AC/DC each sold 3.4 million albums; no other artist reached the three million mark. Album sales declined 14 percent over 2007. Sales of very old-fashioned albums -- vinyl LPs -- reached their highest point since Nielsen began tracking music sales in 1991. Some 1.88 million LPs were purchased in 2008, mostly at small independent stores. SHELLY FREIERMAN

Amalia Dominguez was 18 and desperate and knew exactly what to ask for at the small, family-run pharmacy in the heart of Washington Heights, the thriving Dominican enclave in northern Manhattan. ''I need to bring down my period,'' she recalled saying in Spanish, using a euphemism that the pharmacist understood instantly. It was 12 years ago, but the memory remains vivid: She was handed a packet of pills. They were small and white, $30 for 12. Ms. Dominguez, two or three months pregnant, went to a friend's apartment and swallowed the pills one by one, washing them down with malta, a molasseslike extract sold in nearly every bodega in the neighborhood.

GILBERT--Stewart E.,M.D., age 87, of Floral Park, New York and West Palm Beach, Florida, passed away January 3, 2009. He is survived by Judith (Klein), his adoring wife of 62 years, his devoted children Karyl Cole (Errol Dendy), Kathy, Kim (Larry Rubin) and Kevin (Michelle), and eight grandchildren. Services will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York, Monday, January 5, 2009 10:30am.

GLASVEGAS (Columbia) The Jesus and Mary Chain and Bruce Springsteen both cherish the three-chord structures and hefty beats of the old Phil Spector girl-group productions. Now Glasvegas has built its sound on the same foundation. From the Jesus and Mary Chain -- which, like Glasvegas, is from Glasgow -- come swaths of reverberation and guitar tremolo, though never to the point of drowning out the tunes. And from Mr. Springsteen come tales of misfortune and whoa-whoa choruses that call for singalongs.
STEVENS--Herbert. 15 years have not dimmed the beautiful memories. You will be remembered forever with love.

MATZDORF--Kurt, internationally renowned silversmith and founder of the State University of New York College at New Paltzs Metals Program, died on December 20, 2008. He was 86. Known for his ceremonial and liturgical work, Matzdorf created more than 900 designs during a career that spanned six decades. Matzdorf, who was born in Stadtoldendorf, Germany, on May 26, 1922, taught at SUNY New Paltz from 1957 to 1985. Professor Emeritus of Metals, he founded the colleges gold and silversmithing programs in 1966. He was predeceased by his wife, Alice. Survivors include two sons, David Matzdorf of London, England and James Matzdorf of Rensselaer, NY; one sister, Elizabeth Duff of Oxford, England; one granddaughter; and his partner, Stephanie Rosenblatt. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Kurt J. Matzdorf Memorial Fund, c/o The College at New Paltz Foundation, New Paltz, NY 12561. A memorial service will be held at 5pm on January 24 at the Temple Emanuel, 243 Albany Avenue, Kingston, NY 12401. For more information, contact Temple Emanuel at (845) 338 - 4271 or www.temple emanuelkingston.org.

LANE--Christine Elizabeth, 54, of New York City, died unexpectedly on December 31. Born in New York City on January 22, 1954, she was a daughter of the late Peter A. and Mary Elizabeth (Suehs) Lane of Simsbury, CT. Chris grew up in Housatonic, MA and Simsbury, graduating from Simsbury High School in 1972. She graduated from the University of Rochester in 1976, receiving her BS/RN. In school and in her early years in New York, Chris studied dance with, among others, Martha Graham. Chris also was a volunteer in the 1980s at GMHC helping AIDS patients. She earned her MSW degree from Hunter College in 1986 and was a Certified Social Worker. Chris worked for many years as a head nurse in the medical ICU at Mt Sinai Hospital in New York, before becoming disabled. She is survived by her mother; sister, Barbara; brothers, Peter (Barbara Bornemeier) and Michael; her nephew, John (''Jack'') Bornemeier Lane; her niece and goddaughter, Elizabeth Christine Lane, as well as many cousins and friends. Christine's family wishes to thank Dr. Richard Crane for extraordinary medical care. A funeral will be held Tuesday, at 2pm, at Vincent Funeral Home in Simsbury. A memorial service will be held in New York City at a later date. Contributions in Christine's name may be made to an organization whose mission she admired greatly, the Southern Poverty Law Center.

Daniel Barenboim has canceled two concerts in the Middle East because of safety concerns, the BBC reported. Mr. Barenboim had been scheduled to conduct the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, the Arab-Israeli group he founded with the writer Edward Said, in Doha, Qatar, on Saturday and in Cairo the following Monday. But on Tuesday, Mr. Barenboim said those concerts had been canceled “due to the escalating violence in Gaza and the resulting concerns for the musicians’ safety,” according to the BBC. The orchestra will instead begin its tour in Berlin on Monday, followed by scheduled performances in Moscow, Vienna and Milan. Mr. Barenboim, who was born in Argentina and raised in Israel, is an outspoken advocate of Palestinian rights, and announced last year that he had accepted honorary Palestinian citizenship.

More than 25 years after the death of Bruce Lee, fans will once again be able to get their kicks from the martial arts legend after the approval of a plan to turn Lee’s Hong Kong home into a tourist attraction, Reuters reported. In July, Yu Panglin, a real estate tycoon and philanthropist, reversed his decision to sell Lee’s 5,600-square-foot town house in the Kowloon area of Hong Kong and instead donated it to that region’s government for use as a museum. On Tuesday, Hong Kong’s Commerce and Economic Development Bureau said it had agreed to preserve the “original outlook of the building and its features,” according to Reuters. Parts of the home, including Lee’s study and training hall, will be restored; Mr. Yu has said he wants to add a movie theater, a library and a martial arts center.VIDEO: Watch a trailer for “Enter the Dragon.”

Amy Winehouse has dropped her appeal over a drug-possession charge in Norway and will accept a fine in the case, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Winehouse, the British soul singer, was expected to appear in court in Bergen, Norway, next Monday to answer charges of drug possession, after an incident in October 2007 when she, her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, and her hairdresser were found with marijuana at a hotel, according to the police. At that time, the three were held overnight and paid a fine of about $428. Ms. Winehouse later said that the police had made errors in the case and appealed the fine. But on Tuesday, a lawyer for Ms. Winehouse said she had decided to accept the fine. A Norwegian prosecutor confirmed that Ms. Winehouse had withdrawn the appeal and would not appear in court. “That means the fines stand,” he said, according to The A.P.

The British talk show host at the center of a recent broadcasting controversy will return to the airwaves this month after a three-month suspension, The Guardian newspaper reported. Jonathan Ross, who hosted programs on BBC1 and Radio 2, was suspended from both in October after appearing on a radio show hosted by the comedian Russell Brand, during which they left a series of lewd messages on the answering machine of the actor Andrew Sachs. The broadcast resulted in thousands of complaints to the BBC, and was criticized by Prime Minster Gordon Brown; Mr. Brand later resigned, as did two Radio 2 executives. The Guardian said that Mr. Ross would resume hosting his BBC1 television show on Jan. 23, and his radio show the following day.

An up-and-down year for Broadway ended with at least one high note, as overall grosses for 2008 were slightly higher than in 2007, The Broadway League said. Broadway’s total grosses for the 2008 calendar year (which is measured from Dec. 31, 2007 through Dec. 28, 2008) were more than $940 million, with total paid attendance of more than 12.31 million; the previous calendar year, total grosses were about $938 million, and total paid attendance was about 12.29 million. Christmas and New Year’s week grosses were also up, to $50.99 million in 2008 from $49.06 million in 2007. An additional week of performances were recorded in 2007, due to the method that Broadway uses to measure its calendar, but the industry was also shut down for 19 days that year because of the stagehands’ strike.

Oprah.com, the Web site of Oprah Winfrey, has posted a disclaimer acknowledging that Herman Rosenblat, the author of a memoir that said he had met his wife, Roma, during the Holocaust, had invented portions of his story. “Based on this admission,” the disclaimer said, “the publisher of his forthcoming memoir ‘Angel at the Fence’ canceled plans to print his book.” In “Angel at the Fence,” which was canceled by Berkley Books, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that while he was a prisoner at a concentration camp in Germany he met his future wife at its fence, where she would throw apples to him from the outside; this claim was later disputed by several scholars who said the layout of the camp made this impossible. Ms. Winfrey had featured Mr. Rosenblat on her show, calling his story “the single greatest love story, in 22 years of doing this show, we’ve ever told on the air.” She has not commented publicly on the book’s cancellation.

The daylong expedition to Okemo Mountain Resort did not begin auspiciously. It was almost 5 a.m. last Saturday, and my bus was supposed to have left the Upper East Side 30 minutes earlier on the four-hour journey to Ludlow, Vt. Outside, in the yellow predawn street light, stood five friends who'd bought tickets for the trip. Inside, however, were only three empty seats. The trip, operated by Emilio's Ski Shop, was overbooked. The Okemo Five could either split up or go home.

So apparently Obama plans to appoint CNN's Sanjay Gupta as Surgeon General. I don't have a problem with Gupta's qualifications. But I do remember his mugging of Michael Moore over Sicko. Is another transit strike in store? Not likely. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's labor agreement with its largest union, Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union of America, is set to expire on Jan. 15. In December 2005, the union went on strike for 60 hours -- its first strike since 1980 -- and officials seemed determined to avoid a devastating repeat.

The 1929-30 Boston Bruins were defending Stanley Cup champions. They featured the great Eddie Shore and Dit Clapper (names you know) as well as four other Hall of Famers -- Cooney Weiland, Marty Barry, Harry Oliver and goalie Tiny Thompson. There were other stars as well, like Dutch Gainor, Myles Lane (who is in the College Football Hall of Fame and later became a United States Attorney in Manhattan and a State Supreme Court justice) and Shore's defense partners George Owen and Lionel Hitchman. They finished the season with only 5 losses in 44 games, tying only once. Their .875 percentage of available points still stands as an N.H.L. best.

When I read the recent Times article about the typical length of a professional coach's tenure, I was immediately curious to see how college basketball coaches compared. I began by running the numbers for the six major B.C.S. conferences and found that, entering this season, the average tenure for head coaches at their current universities was 4.95 years, with a median of 3 years. Of the 73 coaches in those six leagues, only 11 had been leading their teams for 10 years or more. One challenge to getting energy-saving initiatives off the ground is that the presumed social benefits arising from improved energy efficiency (fewer greenhouse gases, for instance) are often at odds with the rational economic calculus of homeowners on the ground. From solar panels to efficient window systems, the capital costs of such projects can be prohibitive -- and take years, sometimes decades, to pay for themselves.

Economics | Blaming deregulation for the meltdown is misleading, an article says. Regulation is everywhere, in finance, patents, copyrights -- you name it. And conservatives, especially corporate interests, are just as likely to favor more regulation as liberals. "The government is always present, steering the benefits in different directions depending on who is in charge." So why do we speak as if the situation were otherwise? "False ideological claims have circumscribed the public debate over regulation and blinded us to the wide range of choices we can make." [Boston Review]

A bit more information to go with my post on stimulus: forecasters surveyed by the WSJ predict, on average, that unemployment will reach 8.1 percent by end 2009 and peak at 8.4% -- that is, it will keep rising into 2010. That's a forecast of what will happen with the stimulus plan, not of what would happen absent stimulus, which would presumably be considerably worse.

Bit by bit we're getting information on the Obama stimulus plan, enough to start making back-of-the-envelope estimates of impact. The bottom line is this: we're probably looking at a plan that will shave less than 2 percentage points off the average unemployment rate for the next two years, and possibly quite a lot less. This raises real concerns about whether the incoming administration is lowballing its plans in an attempt to get bipartisan consensus.

When we left our story more than a year ago, the fate of the Art Deco jewel box known as the Metro Theater was up in the air. Though the building's exterior is one of the most recognizable landmarks on upper Broadway, its interior -- no longer usable as a cinema -- had been gutted and no one could say for sure what kind of tenant might make use of such an idiosyncratic space, though the Winick Realty Group was searching.

The extraordinary growth in power generation in China in recent years, which quickly vaulted the emerging industrial powerhouse to the top of the global list of carbon dioxide emitters, has collapsed under the weight of the global economic implosion -- at least for now. Emissions of the main human-generated greenhouse gas are surely tracking the reversal in electricity output, given that the vast majority of the country's electricity comes from burning coal. But those data lag the power statistics.

He countered the Soviet military threat," with missiles in Europe. And "the landmark Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty he fashioned remains in force today." Plus, he never said "malaise." Politics | An ode to Calvin Coolidge, a man not of this hour: "Coolidge's qualities -- thrift, recognition of the limits of government's responsibilities and capabilities, and presidential modesty seem positively antiquated today. Tom Williams, an assistant with the Jacksonville Jaguars, has been hired at Yale, becoming the first black head football coach at the university. A person familiar with the decision confirmed the choice Monday on condition of anonymity because a formal announcement had not been made. The university called a news conference for 2 p.m. Wednesday to introduce the new coach. Williams replaces Jack Siedlecki, who retired in November after 12 seasons to become an assistant athletic director at Yale.

Canada won its fifth straight gold medal at the world junior championship, beating Sweden by 5-1 in the final in Ottawa. The streak tied Canada’s record of five consecutive titles in this tournament from 1993 to ’97. Canada’s 15th gold at the world juniors also matched Russia/Soviet Union for the most ever.

The distance between a Broadway show and an authentic Chinese meal is about to get a lot shorter, at least for theatergoers in the Eastern Hemisphere. A $686 million construction project will bring a 32-theater complex to Beijing, where imports of Western musicals and other shows will play year-round, Variety reported. The entertainment complex is being built by Beijing Shibo Real Estate in the Haidian district and is expected to run more than 100 shows a year. Its biggest theater will seat 2,000 people, while others will accommodate 300 to 500 audience members. Translated versions of Western musicals like “Mamma Mia!” and “The Lion King” have become increasingly popular in China, and producers like Cameron Mackintosh and Nederlander Worldwide Entertainment have previously announced plans to take their shows to that country.

The Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Scotland’s annual celebration of comedy, drama and performing arts, may be forced to shut down its popular Fringe Sunday event because of a money shortage, the BBC reported. As it prepares for the 2009 festival in August, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society is facing significant shortfalls as the costs of the event have increased. Also, ticket sales for last year’s festival were down by 10 percent after several malfunctions at the box office. The festival recently received a loan of about $180,000 from the Edinburgh City Council and two grants for about the same amount but is still seeking a sponsor for its Sunday celebration. A spokesman told the BBC that a final decision about the future of the Sunday event had not yet been made.

MATZDORF--Kurt, internationally renowned silversmith and founder of the State University of New York College at New Paltzs Metals Program, died on December 20, 2008. He was 86. Known for his ceremonial and liturgical work, Matzdorf created more than 900 designs during a career that spanned six decades. Matzdorf, who was born in Stadtoldendorf, Germany, on May 26, 1922, taught at SUNY New Paltz from 1957 to 1985. Professor Emeritus of Metals, he founded the colleges gold and silversmithing programs in 1966. He was predeceased by his wife, Alice. Survivors include two sons, David Matzdorf of London, England and James Matzdorf of Rensselaer, NY; one sister, Elizabeth Duff of Oxford, England; one granddaughter; and his partner, Stephanie Rosenblatt. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Kurt J. Matzdorf Memorial Fund, c/o The College at New Paltz Foundation, New Paltz, NY 12561. A memorial service will be held at 5pm on January 24 at the Temple Emanuel, 243 Albany Avenue, Kingston, NY 12401. For more information, contact Temple Emanuel at (845) 338 - 4271 or www.temple emanuelkingston.org.

COHANE--Francis G.,Esq., Hawthorne, NY died peacefully on January 4, 2009. Beloved husband of 51 years of Marion (Duffy) Cohane. Devoted father of Francis, Jr. (Kathleen), Thomas, Kevin (Kate), Brian (Lori), Katherine and Christopher (Jacqueline). Loving brother of John (dec.), Gerard (Sally), Joseph (Mary), Kathleen Sussingham (dec.), Marion Peterson (dec.) and Laura Jones (dec.). Cherished grandfather of 12 and a well-loved uncle of numerous nephews and nieces. A native of the Bronx and a World War II, U.S. Navy veteran, Frank held degrees from Manhattan College, St. John's Law School and the NYU School of Law. He pursued a successful career as a tax attorney, serving with distinction such corporations as Union Carbide, Union Pacific, CIGNA and GTE. A man of extraordinary warmth and humanity, his gifts for love, laughter and generosity will be missed by a large company of colleagues, friends and family. Mass 10am, Wednesday Holy Rosary Church, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting 2-4 and 7-9pm Tuesday, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry (914693-3330) In lieu of flowers, memorials to St. Cabrini Nursing Home 115 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry.

An Estonian court on Monday cleared four pro-Russian activists of wrongdoing in connection with widespread rioting in Tallinn, the capital, in 2007, after authorities removed a Soviet World War II monument. More than 1,000 Estonians of Russian descent demonstrated when the monument, known as the Bronze Soldier, was removed. The Russian Foreign Ministry celebrated the decision as a rebuke to the ''provocative escapades of the Estonian authorities.''

McGILLICUDDY -- John F.,the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Chemical Bank, and its predecessor, Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, died on January 4, 2009 at his home in Harrison, New York. He was 78 years old. McGillicuddy was married for over 50 years to the former Constance Burtis of Harrison, New York. They resided in Harrison. Along with his wife, he is survived by their five children: Michael Sean (Maureen) McGillicuddy, of Astoria; Faith Burtis (Stephen) Benoit, of Rye; Constance Erin (Jonathan) Mills, of New Canaan, Connecticut; Brian Munro (Kym) McGillicuddy, of Harrison; and John Walsh McGillicuddy, of Harrison. He is also survived by his sister, Mary Jean O'Connell, of Harrison, and six grandchildren. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, on Wednesday from 2-9 PM. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Thursday at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to Prostate Cancer Research, New York Presbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065.

With his country in the throes of an economic collapse, a cholera epidemic, the breakdown of public services and a dire political crisis, President Robert Mugabe has gone on a monthlong vacation, the state-owned Sunday Mail newspaper reported. Mr. Mugabe will probably form a government by the end of February, the state-owned Herald newspaper reported Monday. The opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai, set to be prime minister under a power-sharing deal with Mr. Mugabe, has refused to join such a government, citing state-sponsored abductions of opposition workers and what he sees as Mr. Mugabe's refusal to share the most powerful ministries.

Spikes in blood sugar can take a toll on memory by affecting the dentate gyrus, an area of the brain within the hippocampus that helps form memories, a new study reports. Researchers say the effects can be seen even when levels of blood sugar, or glucose, are only moderately elevated, a finding that may help to explain normal age-related cognitive decline because glucose regulation worsens with age.

After months of delays and other problems, the enormous new United States Embassy compound in Baghdad was dedicated on Monday by Iraqi and American officials, who declared the start of a new era for relations. The embassy is America's largest in the world, and the final cost was said to be $736 million. Also on Monday, a wave of bombs went off across Baghdad, leaving at least six dead and dozens wounded.

The logjam of free-agent outfielders finally showed signs of breaking Monday. Pat Burrell joined the Tampa Bay Rays, and Milton Bradley has apparently decided to play for the Chicago Cubs. After nine seasons in Philadelphia, Burrell will become the Rays' full-time designated hitter, agreeing to a two-year, $16 million deal. There were multiple reports that Bradley was set to sign a three-year contract with Chicago worth about $30 million, giving the Cubs a left-handed middle-of-the-order presence they lacked last season.

GRINBERG -- Gedalio. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of a devoted and long term congregant. We extend to his wife Sonia, and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing.

GRINBERG -- Gedalio. Be loved husband of Sonia. Cherished father of Efraim, Miriam and Alex, and father-inlaw of David and Lisa. Adored grandfather of Margot, Sam, Adrien, Nathan, Noah and Gideon. Respected business man and revered corporate leader. Founder and chairman of Movado Group, Inc., Gedalio ''Gerry'' Grinberg was a venerated figure in the watch industry. A man of deep passion, insight, conviction, curiosity, loyalty and generosity, Gerry inspired family, friends, colleagues and competitors through keen intellectual engagement and personal example. Gerry was widely regarded as a visionary in the industry for recognizing the potential cache of luxury watches and marketing them accordingly. Born in Cuba in 1931, he had established a successful partnership as the exclusive Cuban distributor of Omega and Piaget timepieces. Following Castro's takeover of that country in 1960, Gerry came to the United States, arriving in Miami. He soon relocated to New York City and established Piaget's U.S. distributorship, adding the U.S. distributorship for Corum, another prestigious Swiss watch line, in 1967. His company, then known as North American Watch Corporation, acquired the Concord watch brand four years later, and in 1983, acquired Movado, transforming it from small Swiss watchmaker into a world-recognized brand. In 1993, the company changed its name to Movado Group, Inc. Today, Movado Group encompasses nine distinct watch brands, and is publically traded on the New York Stock Exhange. A dedicated philanthropist, Gerry held a lifelong passion for the arts, and was active and generous in his support of many community and cultural endeavors. He was honored by the UJA-Federation of New York in 2005 with the Award for Humanitarian Excellence, and he received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Jewelry Information Center in 2003. A man of unforgettable character, commitment and passion, Gerry will have a place in the hears and memories of everyone he touched. The family requests that donations be made to Mt. Sinai School of Medicine Development Office, Box 1049, 1 Gustav Levy Place, New York, NY 10029. Services Wednesday, 12:30pm, Park Avenue Synagogue 87th Street and Madison Avenue.

Men wielding submachine guns, assault rifles and grenades attacked a police unit in central Athens on Monday, seriously wounding a police officer. The attack occurred near the Culture Ministry, a few blocks from the site where the police fatally shot a teenage boy last month, setting off days of rioting. The authorities said at least two masked gunmen fired more than 30 bullets, seriously wounding the officer. Ballistics tests showed that two of the weapons used had also been used in an attack on the United States Embassy in Athens in January 2007.

The Chinese government broadened its effort to limit pornography on the Internet by criticizing 19 Internet companies on Monday, including the two market leaders in China, Google and Baidu. A statement on a government-run news site said that the companies had failed to do enough to stop the spread of pornography and that government agencies would work ''to purify the Internet's cultural environment and protect the healthy development of minors.''

Ben Roethlisberger returned to practice on Monday for the Pittsburgh Steelers and said he was close to 100 percent after sustaining the third concussion of his career on Dec. 28 when he was slammed to the ground by two Cleveland Browns defenders in the regular-season finale. Roethlisberger said that he briefly lost feeling in his arms and that his headaches subsided only a couple of days ago.

TONGUE LASHING The Securities and Exchange Commission has been excoriated by Democratic lawmakers who said the agency had ''failed miserably'' in its oversight of Bernard L. Madoff. Meanwhile, federal prosecutors sought to have his bail revoked. AUTO SALES PLUMMET Vehicle sales in the United States fell more than 35 percent in December, dragging the Big Three automakers' annual year totals to their worst level in nearly 50 years. Sales were down a whopping 53 percent at Chrysler, 37 percent at Toyota, 35 percent at Honda, 32 percent at Ford, and 31 percent at General Motors and Nissan. [B1.]

WILSON--Lummis Boydena, on January 1, 2009 of Philadelphia, PA. Associate Professor of History at Queensborough Community College. Survived by five stepchildren and a host of family and friends. Services Wednesday January 7, 2009, 11am, at the Chestnut Hill United Methodist Church, 8812 Germantown Ave., Philadelphia 19118. Interment Ivy Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Oriental Division of the New York Public Library.

PORT--Charles S. of Scarsdale, New York peacefully passed away in his 102nd year on January 4, 2009 at White Plains Hospital. Charlie was the adored husband of Lilly B. Lieb Port and the late Reggie Port. He cherished his daughters, Francine Port and Jennifer Port and doted on his grandchildren, Amanda Port Rhine and Joshua Port Rhine. Charlie served as a major in the U.S. Army, practiced law for over 60 years, loved reading and a good cigar. Funeral services will be held at 1pm, Wednesday, January 7 at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. Donations in Charlie's memory can be made to Congregation Kol Ami or White Plains Hospital.

(13) THE OLD MAN AND THE STORM During Mardi Gras 2006, six months after Hurricane Katrina devastated New Orleans, June Cross met 82-year-old Herbert Gettridge, left, who had skipped the festivities to clear debris from his lawn. In this ''Frontline'' episode Ms. Cross, a correspondent for the series, follows Mr. Gettridge, a master plasterer and builder, for 18 months as he; his wife, Lydia; and five of their nine children endure political turmoil and painstaking bureaucratic processes in order to rebuild their homes -- and their lives -- in the Lower Ninth Ward. 7 A.M. Days after Berkley Books announced that it was canceling the publication of Herman Rosenblat’s memoir “Angel at the Fence” following the author’s acknowledgment that he had falsified parts of his story, an independent publisher said it is negotiating to release the book as a work of fiction based on a screenplay adapted from the book. In the memoir, Mr. Rosenblat wrote that he met his future wife during the Holocaust, when he was a prisoner at a concentration camp and she would throw him apples from outside the camp. The book was canceled after scholars disputed the truth of that and other details. But York House Press, a publisher based in White Plains, said it was in discussions to release the book as a work of fiction called “Flower at the Fence.” In a statement on its Web site, York House Press said, “We believe Mr. Rosenblat’s motivations were very human, understandable and forgivable.”

Charges have been dropped against the actors Josh Brolin and Jeffrey Wright after their arrest in Louisiana last year, The Associated Press reported. While working on the Oliver Stone movie “W.” in July, Mr. Brolin and Mr. Wright were arrested in Shreveport, La., along with five members of the film’s crew, after a bar fight. At that time, Mr. Brolin and Mr. Wright were charged with interfering with police officers; Mr. Brolin was booked and posted a $334 cash bond to be released. Blair Berk, a Los Angeles-based lawyer who represented the actors and crew members, told The A.P. that prosecutors in Shreveport had agreed to drop all charges against the group within 60 days. Mr. Brolin was not required to appear Tuesday at a court hearing on the case.

It may not require you to wear special 3D glasses, but a Hyundai commercial scheduled to be broadcast during the Super Bowl will feature its own special effects, of sorts: a performance by the cellist Yo-Yo Ma will be heard in the commercial, which viewers can later re-edit online, Billboard reported. The commercial, produced by the advertising agency Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, will feature a track from Mr. Ma’s 2002 recording “Bach’s Cello Suites Nos. 1, 5 & 6,” and direct viewers to a Web site where they can manipulate and reassemble the ad. “Within the context of all the other advertising, which can be so chaotic that it almost becomes white noise, a quiet, gorgeous solo cello moment can be very arresting,” said Jim Elliot, the creative director of Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, according to Billboard.

After years of neglect, misuse and haphazard reconstruction of the ancient city of Babylon, a master plan is being developed for the restoration of the Mesopotamian site, in present-day Iraq. The project, called “The Future of Babylon,” was announced in a news release by the World Monuments Fund, which will collaborate with Iraq’s State Board of Antiquities and Heritage. Babylon endured numerous restoration and reconstruction projects during the reign of Saddam Hussein; it was heavily plundered after his fall, and used as the site of an American military base. The “Future of Babylon” project, financed by a $700,000 grant from the State Department, will map the city’s archeological sites, develop conservation plans and pursue possibilities for tourism and education.

Shepard Fairey’s ubiquitous illustration of President-elect Barack Obama, seen in rallies, parties, shop windows and construction sites throughout the 2008 election season, has found a permanent home. The National Portrait Gallery in Washington, D.C., announced that it had acquired Mr. Fairey’s work for its collection. The portrait, a mixed-media stenciled collage that depicts Mr. Obama above the word “hope,” was created by Mr. Fairey, a Los Angeles-based artist known for rock-music album covers and a sticker campaign featuring the wrestler Andre the Giant. In a release, Martin E. Sullivan, the director of the National Portrait Gallery, said that the Obama poster was “an emblem of a significant election, as well as a new presidency.” The portrait is expected to be on display by Inauguration Day.BONUS: A slide show of works by Shepard Fairey can be found here.

Though the full roster of Oscar nominees won’t be announced until Jan. 22, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has already announced one award winner: Edwin Catmull, the president of Walt Disney and Pixar Animation Studios and a founder of Pixar, will receive the Gordon E. Sawyer Award for his contributions to the field of computer graphics. The academy also announced that seven films, including “The Dark Knight,” “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button” and “Iron Man,” were on the short list for the best visual effects Oscar, and that seven films, including “Benjamin Button,” “The Dark Knight,” “Tropic Thunder” and “The Wrestler,” were on the short list for the best makeup award. The winners will be announced on Feb. 22.

Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) remained No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for the fourth week in a row, and fifth week overall, with 90,000 sales, according to Nieslen SoundScan. With no major new releases the Top 10 was mostly reshuffled from previous week, as Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) held at No. 2 with 77,000, and Kanye West’s “808s and Heartbreak” (Def Jam) rose two spots to No. 3 with 71,000. Most albums lost sales last week, but one in particular had a big gain: “All Wrapped Up” (Hollywood), a Target exclusive with Christmas songs by the Jonas Brothers, Miley Cyrus and others, jumped to No. 10 from No. 88 with 40,000 sales, a 112 percent increase.

My Thursday column is about the events in Gaza. I still have a couple more columns to run from my Southeast Asia trip, but I delayed them to weigh in on Gaza. One interesting point, which I didn't have room to explore in the column, is that Hamas had been gaining vis-à-vis Fatah in Palestinian polls during the siege of Gaza, and then in the last six months during the ceasefire it faltered and Fatah made gains. That may help explain why Hamas didn't extend the ceasefire and why it may welcome a pounding by Israel. The more bloodshed in Gaza, the more Hamas will gain in public opinion -- so could Israel be playing into Hamas's public relations strategy?

Spotted, at the southern edge of Central Park, at the Avenue of the Americas today: a wild turkey, looking somewhat confused. Adrian Benepe, the city parks commissioner, said he noticed the turkey in the rain. "I saw the wild turkey on the corner of 59th and and Sixth Avenue, right in front of the statue of Simon Bolivar, just completely out in the open by itself, as if its a pigeon, except it's five times bigger."This was not the first sighting of fowl in Manhattan in recent months. Last September, chickens, roosters, hens and a turkey were found roaming the streets of Harlem, last September until they were rescued and taken to an upstate sanctuary.

Reporters at The New York Times are schooled from birth (well, almost) to avoid modifiers like unique or biggest or oldest. The reasoning goes something like this: There is a strong likelihood that almost any feature or phenomenon has been known before, in relatively similar form. And if anyone is aware of that, it will be the knowledgeable Times reader, a discerning creature only too happy to deflate our incorrect use of a superlative and compel us to publish a correction.

The City Council voted unanimously on Wednesday to require New York Police Department officials to file annual reports about the use of deadly force by officers, including the race, gender and age of the people who were shot. The move by the City Council would make mandatory what has been a voluntary system of disclosure by the nation's largest police force about one of its most critical actions: using deadly physical force. Before May, when police officials handed over 11 years' worth of firearms-discharge reports, the disclosure of the reports was sporadic and the facts they included were not uniform.

Quite often, what fans see of a hockey coach on the bench comes when a television camera pans to him screaming at his players or the officials. Coaches swear they are not always screaming. Rangers Coach Tom Renney, for one, has perfected a fuming-but-silent pose to use in place of the expected screaming. But for large stretches of the game, the coach gets to watch without yelling, dispensing advice and experiencing the game from the best point of view in the arena.
Like much of Wall Street, Wallstrip is pulling in its horns.

The agent Scott Boras, already in New York for the Mark Teixeira news conference, prolonged his visit to meet Wednesday with the Mets and General Manager Omar Minaya to discuss the free-agent pitchers Derek Lowe and Oliver Pérez, according to a baseball executive with knowledge of the situation. The Mets have put Lowe and Pérez atop their wish list, and they have already offered Lowe a three-year, $36 million contract, which he has turned down. They are unwilling to improve their proposal to Lowe.
Five football coaches scouted the B.C.S. title game, between Florida and Oklahoma on Thursday night, for The Quad. This is a report by Lloyd Carr, the former Michigan coach, as told to Pete Thamel.

Coal-ash - the coal-plant byproduct that recently spilled from a pond in Tennessee, spreading toxic chemicals far and wide - often ends up in a dump, as my colleague Shaila Dewan wrote in a front-page article today.

President-elect Barack Obama met in the Oval Office today with President Bush and three former occupants of the White House: former Presidents Bill Clinton, George H.W. Bush and Jimmy Carter.
Updated, 4:56 p.m. | Arbitron, the radio ratings company, will overhaul a new measurement system for radio stations under a settlement announced Wednesday with the New York attorney general's office.

The Bagger has noticed that a nice-sized quorum has developed in the comments section, so he thought it might be good for people to argue amongst themselves on a regular basis about an issue of broad cultural moment. Hence, a new feature called "Today's Throwdown."
Update | 4:06 p.m.

1. The new CBO budget and economic outlook is out. Above is its forecast for the GDP gap -- the hole stimulus has to fill. I'd guess that the CBO estimate, which has unemployment averaging 8.3 percent in 2009 and 9 percent in 2010, is actually too optimistic (see 3, below), but even so it puts the Obama plan in perspective: a 3% of GDP plan, with a significant share going to ineffective tax cuts, to fill an 8% or more gap.

The World Junior Championship tournament is over, and that means the rush to rearrange the roster for a league and Memorial Cup run is on as contending teams add strength and middle-of-the-road teams exchange stars for prospects and draft picks.

Bernard L. Madoff, the financier accused of running a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, violated his bail terms by sending his friends and family packages containing 13 watches, 4 diamond brooches, a jade necklace, two sets of cufflinks and other jewelry totaling at least $1 million, federal prosecutors argued in a legal brief released Wednesday.

Shepard Fairey's ubiquitous illustration of President-elect Barack Obama, seen in rallies, parties, shop windows and construction sites throughout the 2008 election season, has found a permanent home. The National Portrait Gallery in Washington, D.C., announced that it had acquired Mr. Fairey's work for its collection.
Earlier this week I posted a comment on the implications for environmental policy stemming from the dispute between Russia and Ukraine that has halted gas deliveries to Europe.

From our colleagues at the Wheels blog:

This starch-on-starch dish, a stewlike combination of little more than the two main ingredients and canned tomatoes, may seem to be the most unlikely ever. But it's actually a satisfying, traditional Neapolitan dish, maybe all the more enjoyable because it breaks the rules.
Under pressure to ease its 12-day bombardment of Gaza, Israel suspended fighting and agreed to do so for three hours every other day to permit the delivery of aid.
Will we soon be letting the sunshine in for a new generation of cars running solely on solar power?

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Hey, did you see this in the paper? In an interview with the Washington Times, Vice President Dick Cheney said he is not a big fan of rap music. You could have knocked me over with a feather. I was stunned by that.
Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on CBS: On this date in 2001, George W. Bush was certified as the winner of the 2000 presidential election. How about that? That turned out pretty well, didn't it?
"It was like riding a tiger, not knowing how to get off without being eaten."
Readers: Today marks a changing of the guard at The Opinionator. This is the first post by Eric Etheridge, a new contributor. -- The Editors
President-elect Barack Obama named Nancy Killefer, a senior executive at the consulting firm, McKinsey & Company., to be his administration's chief performance officer.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Yesterday, President-elect Barack Obama described the economy as "very sick." Historians say it was a childish way to describe a complex problem but still the smartest thing they've heard a president say in eight years.

Today, the Writers Guild of America will bestow its awards, and the betting here says the slaves to the word processor will probably give some love to Simon Beaufoy, who drops the ole "chocolate pudding" metaphor here in describing the story at the heart of "Slumdog Millionaire."

Japan's government-supported whaling fleet is out in the Southern Ocean killing hundreds of minke whales and other species in the name of science (but also for meat), and once again being harassed by the animal-rights crusaders -- and now Animal Planet celebrities -- aboard the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society vessel Steve Irwin.

Today's PsychCentral.com highlights a recent study that found one in five teens are using cell phones and online technology to send sexually explicit pictures of themselves to others. The research is from the National Campaign to Prevent Teen and Unwanted Pregnancy and CosmoGirl.com. (Click here to read the original report.)
The unstudied look of Nevan Donahue, a character on MTV's new show, "The City."
Phil Schaap, the D.J. and historian, teaches jazz survey classes at the Jazz at Lincoln Center's adult education program known as Swing University.
Where does it end? And how silly can it get?

Reports that President-elect Barack Obama had approached CNN's medical correspondent, Dr. Sanjay Gupta, to be the next Surgeon General inspired a parlor game among people who have too much free time (a k a media types): What if Mr. Obama were to assemble his administration entirely from TV experts? Scary thought, granted, but what the heck: here are our nominees from among the best and brightest of the boob tube:

The Los Angeles Times points out in a photo essay that Oscar himself has a tendency toward very public displays of nudity, not to mention a soft spot for same when it comes to whose hands he lands in.
David Carr, the Carpetbagger, gives his own daily take on awards season news.

Christmas present for Magnitka: The penalty shootout on Wednesday, Orthodox Christmas in Russia, that put Metallurg Magnitogorsk through to the Champions League final. Actual highlights start at the :40 mark of the video.
How's this for high drama: "He bid too low. Now he wants to bust the contract so that he can bring the successful bidders to their knees."

David Poland takes a long, hard look at the movies of 2008 and decides that quality is down, clunkers are up and that the dying herd of specialty divisions will make good movies as hard to find as a parking spot at a blockbuster-engorged multiplex.

Xenia Stewart is a senior guard for the Pittsburgh women's basketball team. The Pitt Web site says she is the toughest defender on the Panthers, who have been in the Top 25 all season. Xenia, a 1,000-point scorer, hails from Bowie, Md., and makes her Quad debut with today's diary entry.
Last week, in the depths of quiet in the capital markets, two rather intriguing events occurred involving significant shareholders of publicly traded companies.

A day after President-elect Barack Obama raised the possibility of "trillion-dollar deficits for years to come," he plans to discuss budgetary issues and introduce a new White House position, chief performance officer, at a press conference in Washington this morning.

Kate Winslet came right out and said it, telling Britain's Reveal magazine, "I want to win, I'm not denying that." Some people gasped at her candor, but where is it written that the talent needs to pretend it doesn't care. Ms. Winslet has practiced that frozen smile five times - three times for best actress and twice for supporting - and she is ready for her close-up. "I don't want to be sitting there with a fixed grin on my face while someone else wins. But we all do that, don't we?"
If you are a parent of an infant and planning to attend Barack Obama's swearing-in ceremony, you may want to leave Sweet Pea behind.

A top aide for the state's attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, urged labor leaders and upstate officials to refrain from embracing Caroline Kennedy for New York's soon-to-be-vacant Senate seat, according to several people with direct knowledge of the conversations.

Personality | Charisma seems an ineffable quality, but some scholars think it can be "analyzed, understood, and broken down into parts," an article says -- for example, words or phrasings perceived as charismatic, or nonverbal cues, like how the charismatic smile. "In the process, it is becoming clear that while not everybody can be an Obama, there are aspects of charisma that even the least magnetic among us might learn." [Boston Globe]
