An update to the classic bovine-based parody of political systems describing the rococo methodology of Lehman Bros financing.

As the stock market gyrates, and my 401(k) statements sit unopened in a drawer (the Ostrich Method of Investing), we have been talking a lot at our house about reeling in family spending. Most of that talk has been directed at our teenagers. Now along come pollsters in Britain to tell me that however free my children are with a dollar is probably my fault.
A pro-democracy movement in Burma.
Citadel Investment Group's main hedge funds lost 53 percent for 2008, Dow Jones reported, citing a person familiar with Citadel's preliminary estimates.
Dow Chemical is prepared to pay a penalty for delaying its proposed acquisition of chemical maker Rohm & Haas, the company's chief executive, Andrew Liveris, told The Financial Times.

For the past six months, Parisians have had a new mode of public transport at their disposal: a fleet of dual-engine catamaran boats along the Seine river. The Voguéo service, which debuted last June, covers about 9 kilometers as it chugs through South Eastern Paris.

Arts | Why melancholy often fosters creativity, from the author of "Against Happiness": "We yearn for a deeper, richer relationship to the world, and in yearning for that, we're forced to explore potentialities in ourselves that we would not have explored if we were simply content ..." [Smithsonian]
Investors in private equity funds may have to brace themselves for some bad news in the next few weeks.
The next big deal for distressed investor Wilbur Ross may well be a bank.
Days before his arrest, Bernard L. Madoff received $250 million from one of his oldest friends and the man who gave him his start on Wall Street.

After speaking Tuesday night with Kerry Byrne, publisher of Cold, Hard Football Facts, for a short print item, he sent along some additional postseason statistics on Peyton Manning and how he compared with quarterbacks with lesser reputations:
Investors in venture capital and private equity funds who want out are discovering that their stakes are worth less than they paid for them.

With an aggressive style that stood out in the staid world of Austrian banking even more than her bouffant red wig, Sonja Kohn made few friends gathering billions for Bernard L. Madoff from wealthy investors in Russia and across Europe.
Here's a shocker: Wall Street doesn't appear all that excited by pornography.
The winner in the long-awaited sale of the Chicago Cubs Major League Baseball team will be identified this week, according to press reports.
A federal appeals court has upheld the conviction of Jeffrey K. Skilling on charges of fraud stemming from the 2001 collapse of Enron, the company he once ran.
Bank of America, raising cash to weather a dismal market at home, sold a $2.83 billion chunk of its holding in China Construction Bank on Wednesday, dragging the Chinese bank's stock 6 percent lower.
A judge extended an order on Tuesday barring hedge fund founder Ezra Merkin from shutting down funds that had invested with accused swindler Bernard L. Madoff or withdrawing money from them.
The wife of billionaire Chinese appliance retailer Wong Kwong-yu has been detained as police investigate Mr. Wong for possible financial offenses, according to news reports.
Wall Street and Detroit got bailouts. Now investors who lost money with Bernard L. Madoff may get a bailout of sorts, too, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning writes.

Stock markets pushed higher on Tuesday as investors shrugged off economic reports showing more troubles for America's factories and service sector, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported. Worries from the Federal Reserve that the recession could persist despite their best efforts did not hold back gains, either.

Society | Obama's election illustrates the gradual erosion of "whiteness" as "the touchstone of what it means to be American," an essay says. As the country gives birth to its "first post-white generation," the arrival of what Patrick Buchanan derided as "Third World America" is "all but inevitable." But what does this mean? "If the end of white America is a cultural and demographic inevitability, what will the new mainstream look like-and how will white Americans fit into it?" The article raises such questions but, of course, cannot answer them. [Atlantic]

Sellers of protection on Tribune's bonds are facing losses of 98.5 percent of the insurance they sold, based on the results of an auction on Tuesday to determine the value of the bankrupt company's credit default swaps.

U.S. banks will have to raise fresh capital in 2009, and a sharp increase in credit-rating downgrades on mortgage-related securities will lead to further stresses on the companies' capital, according to prominent banking analyst Meredith Whitney.
Madison Smartt Bell is the author of numerous books, including a recent biography of Toussaint Louverture.
One True Media, the start-up that runs video ad platform SpotMixer, has landed $9 million in a second round of funding.
Superfish, a start-up in stealth mode that VentureBeat says will eventually let users search by sight, has hooked $5.3 million in second-round financing.
Talbots shares jumped 24 percent on Tuesday, a day after the women's apparel retailer said it entered into agreements with three banks to secure a total $150 million in committed lines of credit.
The privately-held discount retail chain Goody's Family Clothing will begin liquidating its stores on Friday as the retailer becomes one of the year's first victims of the worsening economy.

The chairman of Satyam Computer Services, a leading Indian information technology company that serves numerous Fortune 500 companies, resigned on Wednesday after disclosing major accounting irregularities, sending Satyam's shares down 77 percent, The New York Times's Heather Timmons and Bettina Wassener reported.
The European Commission, Europe's competition watchdog, said it had extended its review of a bid by Lufthansa to buy a smaller Belgian rival, Brussels Airlines.
Credit Suisse said it had injected 7.94 billion rupees ($164 million) into the operations of its nonbanking financial company in India.

John F. McGillicuddy, who assembled one of first big bank mergers in the wave of consolidation that emerged from the economic slump of the early 1990s, the one between Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical Bank, died on Sunday at his home in Harrison, N.Y., The New York Times's Eric Dash reported. He was 78.
Casey B. Mulligan is an economist at the University of Chicago.
The latest fad of posting videos of luxury homes for sale on YouTube is "a complete waste of time," argues Luxury Property Blog author Mark Knowles, who has developed a minor obsession on the topic.
The word "green" may be overused, as my colleague James Kanter has reported, but renewable energy companies are apparently still on the hunt for just the right name.

The Disk Defragmenter program on my Windows XP computer is supposed to help me get some space back on my hard drive, but every time I try to run it, I get a message saying the program doesn't have enough room to run. How do I know what I can safely dump off the PC?

Cities | Oh, great. Now that most of the world's population resides in cities for the first time in history, "new research suggests that they actually dull our thinking, sometimes dramatically so," by taxing the brain with too much stimulation. The solution is incorporating natural elements into urban design, so you don't have to make like Picasso and flee Paris. [Boston Globe]

Sex | Those recent media reports about how virginity pledges don't stop teen sex? They're bunk, an article says. The Johns Hopkins study in question compared "teens who take a virginity pledge with a very small subset of other teens: those who are just as religious and conservative as the pledge-takers." But when compared with the teen population at large, the article says, those groups are much less promiscuous. [Wall Street Journal]

The Utah attorney general is investigating the Bowl Championship Series for a possible violation of federal antitrust laws after an undefeated Utes team was left out of the national title game for the second time in five years. Attorney General Mark Shurtleff contends that the B.C.S. unfairly puts teams like Utah, which is a member of a conference without an automatic bid to the lucrative bowl games, at a competitive and financial disadvantage. ¶The legal fight over exhuming the remains of the Notre Dame great George Gipp may have ended, now that the Michigan Court of Appeals has refused to hear an appeal of a decision that rejected a lawsuit filed by two men who say they are Gipp’s distant cousins. The court issued its refusal Dec. 17. Ron Gipp and Karl Gipp filed the suit in November 2007, a month after Gipp’s body was exhumed to determine if he had fathered a child out of wedlock before his death in 1920. DNA testing produced negative results. The suit accused those responsible for the exhumation of trespassing. Other family members said the testing was justified. gipp.

Officials at a Kentucky racetrack are trying to determine if their ban on a certain type of shoe aimed at making racing safer had the opposite effect. Turfway Park in Florence reported that eight horses died from racing injuries during its 21-day holiday meet that ended Dec. 31. During the same meet in 2007, which had six additional race days, four horses died on the track and another in the paddock. Bryce Peckham, the chief veterinarian for the Kentucky Horse Racing Commission, disclosed the figures Tuesday at the commission’s first meeting of the year.

The legal fight over exhuming the remains of the Notre Dame great George Gipp may have ended, now that the Michigan Court of Appeals has refused to hear an appeal of a decision that rejected a lawsuit filed by two men who say they are Gipp’s distant cousins. The court issued its refusal Dec. 17. Ron Gipp and Karl Gipp filed the suit in November 2007, a month after Gipp’s body was exhumed to determine if he had fathered a child out of wedlock before his death in 1920. DNA testing produced negative results. The suit accused those responsible for the exhumation of trespassing. Other family members said the testing was justified.

Bode Miller was disqualified from a World Cup slalom race by the International Ski Federation for wearing boots that were one-hundredth of an inch too high. Miller finished 29th in the first run of the race, but was disqualified before the second after a random check showed the soles of his boots were a bit high.

The French skipper Jean Le Cam was freed from his capsized yacht by a rival in the Vendée Globe solo around-the-world race. Race officials said Le Cam was healthy and aboard the PRB, the boat of Vincent Riou. Organizers said they expected a Chilean naval vessel to rescue Le Cam on Wednesday, but Riou was the first to reach Le Cam, whose yacht capsized west of Cape Horn early Tuesday.

Which player gives his team the most bang for the buck?As part of a contest promotion, Vizio had the former general managers Tom Donahoe and Ron Wolf select five finalists. The criteria, boiled down, are: good player, low salary, best value.
The Stocks in the News chart on the DataBank page on Sunday misstated the price of Johnson & Johnson’s acquisition of Omrix Biopharmaceuticals. It was $438 million, not billion.
As the 111th Congress opened, Roland W. Burris tried unsuccessfully to join the senators and representatives who were taking their oaths in the Capitol.

You may never have heard of Friendfinder Networks, a company that is trying to go public in this market -- and plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange if it does find buyers. But you may have known of the company under its previous name: Penthouse Media Group. It publishes a magazine of that name, which competes with Playboy.
Ms. Freeman was one of the most influential patrons of contemporary composers over the last 40 years and long the keeper of a famously gracious musical salon in Los Angeles.
Jeff Adrien scored 13 of his 17 points in the second half and No. 5 Connecticut defeated No. 25 West Virginia, 61-55, on Tuesday night.
Mr. Seaver defied censorship and conventional literary standards to bring works by rabble-rousing authors like Samuel Beckett, Henry Miller and William Burroughs to American readers.
Brandon Sutter, Carolina’s goalkeeper, survived a rally and had the last laugh against his father on Tuesday.
Raymond Felton scored 25 points and the rookie D. J. Augustin added 11 of his 20 points in overtime to help the Charlotte Bobcats stun the Boston Celtics, 114-106, on Tuesday night.
The discount retail chain Goody’s Family Clothing will begin liquidating its stores as the retailer becomes one of the year’s first victims of the worsening economy.

Google Trends, a service that shows the relative popularity of search terms, fell victim to what appeared to be an ugly stunt on Tuesday: a sketch of an airplane flying into two towers appeared as its second most popular item under Hot Trends, its list of the fastest-rising searches at any given moment. TechCrunch and Search Engine Land both grabbed screen shots of the Google Trends page before the offending query receded in popularity later in the day.
Apple cleared the way for distribution of more than 10 million songs on iTunes without copy protection restrictions.
The most recent report about retail sales showed double-digit declines in some closely watched categories, but also indicated the numbers were stabilizing.

This is the weekly notebook that runs in the Wednesday newspaper. There's a little bonus material here because "All the news that's fit to print" can sometimes be translated as "All the news that fits."

The Knicks followed up on their biggest victory of the season with an absent-minded effort in Oklahoma against a team with four wins in its existence. Make that five.
When governors fill Senate vacancies without directing new or special elections, this frustrates the whole democratic thrust of the 17th Amendment.
It has become clear that the Senate’s power to reject Roland W. Burris is, at best, highly debatable. The wisest course for the Senate is to end the dispute by accepting the appointment.

This is a wonderful thing about astronomy. Our understanding of the galaxy undergoes a shift, and the only real change is the new terrain that opens up inside our heads.
A bill that gives Washington’s Congressional representative full voting rights deserves approval, and Congress also must give the city budgetary and legislative autonomy.
The Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act merits passage, along with the Paycheck Fairness Act, which also combats gender-based wage discrimination.
It’s strange but true. President Bush, who has been indifferent to the health of continents, is going down in history as a protector of the oceans.
A teenage girl abandoned by her father finds a surrogate family at a community center.
A vehicle being used in campaign activities for Michael P. Ricatto struck and killed a 9-year-old boy in Queens on Tuesday.
Hiram Monserrate, who has been charged with second-degree assault for attacking his companion, is expected to take his seat as a new state senator on Wednesday.
Supervisors of an engineer who had been text-messaging right before an accident with an oncoming freight train had been warned that he often used his cellphone while on the job, lawyers said.
Barack Obama’s goal has to be a settlement in Gaza that eliminates the threat of Hamas rockets and opens Gaza economically to the world, under credible international supervision.
After Andy Pettitte rejected the Yankees’ one-year, $10 million offer, the negotiations could be viewed in the past tense.
INTERNATIONAL.

The Books of The Times review on Saturday, about “The Invention of Air” by Steven Johnson, an account of the life of the English scientist and philosopher Joseph Priestley, mentioned three members of the Lunar Society, a group that Priestly joined, and named one of them, Erasmus Darwin, as the grandfather of Charles Darwin, but did not identify another member who was named, Josiah Wedgwood, as Darwin’s other grandfather.

An obituary on Saturday about Daniel Nagrin, a modern-dance choreographer and performer, referred incorrectly to Friendship Village in Tempe, Ariz., where he died. It is a retirement community that offers hospice care; it is not a hospice.
Members have been wrestling with an unsettling reality: Barack Obama can propel their agenda but may diminish their influence.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,215 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 624 who have died as a part of the Afghan war.

A listing on Tuesday about new and returning television shows from this week through March misidentified the network that will show “Breaking Bad” and the date it returns. It will be shown on AMC, not FX, and its second season starts on March 8, not March 15.

An article on Friday about efforts by the Arizona Cardinals and the Minnesota Vikings to avoid a local television blackout of their N.F.L. playoff games because of sluggish ticket sales referred incorrectly, using information from the N.F.L., to previous playoff blackouts. As the article correctly noted, the Dolphins’ game against the Baltimore Ravens was blacked out in the Miami area in 2002, but the Jets-Raiders game that year was not. (Both Arizona and Minnesota eventually sold enough tickets to avoid blackouts in their markets.).
Not one major bank has agreed to handle the planned $460 million initial public offering of the parent of Penthouse magazine.

An article in some editions on Dec. 22 about Gov. David A. Paterson’s proposal to reduce pension benefits for new state and municipal employees referred incorrectly to a 1976 state law that required government workers to contribute to their pensions for the first time. The law applied to employees of New York State and other municipal governments — but not to New York City workers, who had always made some contributions to their pensions.
Despite a powerful and varied résumé , Elena Kagan, President-elect Barack Obama’s choice for solicitor general, has provided few clues on where she stands on the great legal issues of the day.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the approaching N.F.L. playoff matchup between the Eagles and the Giants misstated Philadelphia’s record since losing to the Giants on Nov. 9. It is 5-2-1, not 5-1-1.
If the Knicks can trade Eddie Curry, their only player with a huge salary in 2010, it will give them more room to re-sign Damon Lee and Nate Robinson.

A headline on Dec. 30 with an article about elections in Bangladesh referred imprecisely to the reason voters were returning to the polls “after two years.” Elections had been suspended for nearly two years under army-backed emergency rule; the last time citizens voted was not two years ago. (That occurred in 2001.).
Lottery numbers for Jan. 6, 2009.
The fractious Senate Democratic caucus reached a deal on Tuesday night that will give the party control of the Senate for the first time in four decades.
Caroline Kennedy is smart, cultivated, serious and unpretentious. The Senate, shamefully sparse on profiles in courage during Dick Cheney’s reign of terror, would be lucky to get her.
Opposition lawmakers ended their violent, 12-day siege of South Korea’s Parliament on Tuesday after successfully delaying a crucial vote on a United States free-trade deal.
India’s national airline has fired nine flight attendants for being overweight, an official said Tuesday.
Rescuers have ended their search for victims of a landslide in northern Guatemala because rocks raining down from the mountain have made it too dangerous to look for victims.
The NATO-led force in Afghanistan on Tuesday rejected claims that its soldiers had killed civilians during an operation against Taliban insurgents in Helmand Province.
The Lord’s Resistance Army, a rebel group, killed at least 12 people in northeastern Congo, officials said Tuesday.
An attempt at understanding why a Brooklyn courthouse will be named for Theodore Roosevelt and not Hugh Carey — a native Brooklynite and former governor of New York.
Sheikh Hasina was sworn in as the country’s prime minister on Tuesday.
Construction workers in Hanoi have found a huge unexploded bomb that is believed to have been dropped by the United States during the Vietnam War.
Jacob Zuma, the president of the governing African National Congress, is taking a third wife, according to local press accounts.
Senator Arlen Specter, the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, questioned the independence of Eric H. Holder Jr.
A debate persists over the most effective form of stimulus and what role tax cuts should play.
A top aide for Andrew M. Cuomo urged labor leaders and upstate officials to refrain from embracing Caroline Kennedy for New York’s Senate seat.
Barack Obama and his aides scrambled to defend the choice of Leon E. Panetta as C.I.A. director.
The Bloomberg administration has given up a hard-won perk: a luxury suite at the new Yankee Stadium.
Sonja Kohn, who gathered billions for Bernard L. Madoff from investors in Russia and across Europe, has disappeared from view.
Mr. McGillicuddy assembled one of first big bank mergers in the wave of consolidation that emerged from the economic slump of the early 1990s.
Senator Dianne Feinstein said publicly that Roland W. Burris should be seated. Al Franken did not appear in Washington, as his race appeared headed to court.
Mr. Grinberg amassed a fortune in the U.S. by helping turn expensive wristwatches like Piaget into widely advertised portable status symbols with mass appeal.
Florida’s Tim Tebow and Oklahoma’s Sam Bradford are the only sophomores to win the most prestigious award in college sports.
When Nissan said it would not put up a display at the auto show in Detroit, local dealers decided to do it themselves — until the company intervened.
Carl Pavano, whose four-year Yankees tenure was marked by almost continuous injury, agreed Tuesday to a one-year, $1.5 million contract with the Cleveland Indians.
At one church near the city's Garden District, police broke down the door and arrested two parishioners who had locked themselves inside to keep the churches from being shuttered.
The banter around the locker room and on the practice tee was lighter than the Maui breeze with a couple days left before the start of the 2009 season.
To the Editor:.
The five guards for Blackwater International pleaded not guilty in federal court to manslaughter in the case of the 2007 shootings in Baghdad that left at least 17 Iraqis dead.
A Jets employee said that Jeff Jagodzinski had interviewed with the team, promising to add at least another twist to a strange tale.
Charlie Strong, Florida’s African-American defensive coordinator, has seemingly done everything necessary to merit the chance to be a head coach in his 25-year career.
Many voters said the sniping over a still-unfilled Senate seat could hurt Norm Coleman, the Republican incumbent, in particular.
The move to enforce a law that bans foreign companies from broadcasting in the country effectively bans Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Voice of America and the BBC.
Mark Teixeira instructed his agent to make a deal with the Yankees after Teixeira’s wife admitted to preferring the team over the Red Sox.
Warehouses in northern New Jersey are faring better than average in vacancy rates.
Tarrion Adams rushed for 207 yards and 3 touchdowns as Tulsa defeated No. 23 Ball State, 45-13, in a soggy GMAC Bowl on Tuesday night.
An agent for the John Galt Corporation, the company charged with demolishing the former Deutsche Bank building, has been charged with $1 million in theft.
Jeb Bush said that he would not run in 2010 for the seat being vacated by Mel Martinez, ending speculation about whether he could renew the Bush brand from Congress.
Historians are looking to the struggles of the 1930s for hints on how baseball teams will hold up in a downturn.
The European Commission, Europe’s competition watchdog, said it had extended its review of a bid by Lufthansa to buy a smaller Belgian rival, Brussels Airlines.

The Indian unit of General Motors will raise its car prices by 1 to 2 percent to cover rising costs and does not expect the market to improve in the first half of 2009, a senior official said on Tuesday.

As true fans know, to properly experience Bruce Springsteen, below right, you must see him live, yet the Boss has been ramping up his online and digital efforts as the countdown to his next album continues. On Tuesday Mr. Springsteen’s song “Life Itself” was made available for free download from Amazon.com; it’s the third song to have been released from his coming album “Working on a Dream,” which he recorded with the E Street Band. That album will be released on Jan. 27; on the same day, Billboard reported, Mr. Springsteen’s songs “Born to Run” and “My Lucky Day” (another track from “Working on a Dream”) will be released as downloads for the video game Guitar Hero: World Tour. Those downloads will be free until Feb. 4, after which they will cost $2 each.

An up-and-down year for Broadway ended with at least one high note, as gross sales for 2008 were slightly higher than in 2007, the Broadway League said. Broadway’s total grosses for the 2008 calendar year (which was measured from Dec. 31, 2007, through Dec. 28, 2008) were more than $940 million, with total paid attendance exceeding 12.31 million; the previous calendar year, total grosses were about $938 million and total paid attendance about 12.29 million. Christmas and New Year’s week grosses were also up, to $50.99 million in 2008 from $49.06 million in 2007. An additional week of performances was recorded in 2007 because of the method Broadway uses to measure its calendar, but the industry was also shut down for 19 days that year because of the stagehands’ strike.

More than 35 years after the death of the martial-arts legend Bruce Lee, below, fans will once again be able to get their kicks from him following the approval of a plan to turn his Hong Kong home, above, into a tourist attraction, Reuters reported. In July Yu Panglin, a real estate tycoon and philanthropist, reversed his decision to sell Lee’s 5,600-square-foot town house in the Kowloon area of Hong Kong and instead donated it to that region’s government for use as a museum. On Tuesday, Hong Kong’s Commerce and Economic Development Bureau said it had agreed to preserve the “original outlook of the building and its features,” according to Reuters. Parts of the home, including Lee’s study and training hall, will be restored; Mr. Yu has said he wants to add a movie theater, a library and a martial-arts center.

Amy Winehouse has dropped her appeal of a drug possession charge in Norway, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Winehouse, the British soul singer, was expected to appear in court in Bergen, Norway, next Monday to answer charges of drug possession, after an incident in October 2007 when she, her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, and her hairdresser were found with marijuana at a hotel, according to the police. At that time the three were held overnight and paid a fine of about $428. Ms. Winehouse later said that the police had made errors in the case and appealed the fine. But on Tuesday a lawyer for Ms. Winehouse said she had decided to accept the fine. A Norwegian prosecutor confirmed that Ms. Winehouse had withdrawn the appeal and would not appear in court. “That means the fines stand,” he said, according to The A.P.

Daniel Barenboim, right, has canceled two concerts in the Middle East because of safety concerns, the BBC reported. Mr. Barenboim had been scheduled to conduct the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra, the Arab-Israeli group he founded with the writer Edward Said, in Doha, Qatar, on Saturday and in Cairo the following Monday. But on Tuesday Mr. Barenboim said those concerts had been canceled “due to the escalating violence in Gaza and the resulting concerns for the musicians’ safety,” according to the BBC. The orchestra will instead begin its tour in Berlin on Monday, followed by scheduled performances in Moscow, Vienna and Milan. Mr. Barenboim, who was born in Argentina and raised in Israel, is an outspoken advocate of Palestinian rights and announced last year that he had accepted honorary Palestinian citizenship.

GOODMAN--Maurice, Jr.,of New York, NY, Salisbury, CT, and Kennebunkport, ME, died at his home in Manhattan on December 23rd after a protracted battle with heart disease. ''Buddy'', as his many friends called him, was 87 years old. A graduate of the Hotchkiss School and Yale University, Mr. Goodman remained active in the alumni affairs at both schools. As a First Lieutenant U.S. Naval Aviator, he served in World War II and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with cluster for action in the Pacific theater where he piloted the huge ''flying boats.'' A true renaissance man, after the war Mr. Goodman served in various executive positions in advertising, shifting gradually into mergers and acquisitions, and ultimately into several corporate start-ups. Holding patents in widely diverse fields including solar panels and various industrial grinding/deburring processes, he also was an accomplished lyricist whose 1950s songs ''My April Heart'' and ''Way Out There'' were highly praised. More recently, he wrote a song for the Yale Glee Club to recognize their new coeducational status. In his later years, Buddy took great pride in his internet column, ''Letter From New York'', written for The Blockhead Journal. Mr. Goodman was also concerned with New York social welfare issues and he actively served on the Executive Committee of Planned Parenthood of New York City for many years, as well as in various capacities with the Community Service Society and the Boy's Club of New York. He was Chairman of the Task Force on Criminal Justice for the Mayor's Voluntary Action Council for 12 years. As a loving husband, brother, and father and as an avid tennis player, sailor, and golfer, Buddy enjoyed his life to the fullest. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Georgine Rake Goodman; his brother, Walter F. Goodman of Miami, FL and New York, NY; three children: Mrs. Prudence G. Meyer of Durham, NC, Mrs. Susannah E. Rake of Santa Barbara, CA, and John R. Goodman of Santa Barbara, CA; and three granddaughters: Laura, Georgina, and Annabelle. A memorial service will be held at The Brick Church on April 18th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the Community Service Society or the Boys Club of New York would be appreciated.

Neale Donald Walsch, author of the best-selling series ''Conversations With God,'' recently posted a personal Christmas essay on the spiritual Web site Beliefnet.com about his son's kindergarten winter pageant. During a dress rehearsal, he wrote, a group of children spelled out the title of a song, ''Christmas Love,'' with each child holding up a letter. One girl held the ''m'' upside down, so that it appeared as a ''w,'' and it looked as if the group was spelling ''Christ Was Love.'' It was a heartwarming Christmas story from a writer known for his spiritual teachings.

Reid's Playoff Pedigree In Andy Reid's 10 years as the coach in Philadelphia, the Eagles have won at least one playoff game each of the seven times they qualified -- a record of 9-6. If you count his seven years as an assistant with the Packers, the only time in 13 postseasons that Reid's team did not win at least one game was 1998, when the Packers lost to the 49ers, 30-27.

It was a little more then seven years ago that Jason Giambi, above, stood in the same room at Yankee Stadium that Mark Teixeira did Tuesday and, like his fellow first baseman, announced how happy he was to become a New York Yankee. ''This is an incredible day for me and my family,'' Giambi said that day, his eyes moist, his wallet about $120 million fatter.

As the Yankees plowed money into pitching early this winter, General Manager Brian Cashman could not shake the Mark Teixeira highlights embedded in his brain. There was the four-hit night for the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium in 2006, when Teixeira crunched Jorge Posada in a collision at the plate. There was the grand slam for the Los Angeles Angels in the Bronx last August, a hit that Cashman predicted as soon as Teixeira got ahead in the count. And there were the many diving grabs at first base, where doubles died in Teixeira's Gold Glove.

McGILLICUDDY--John F. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, John F. McGillicuddy. As Chairman Emeritus and Life Trustee of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, he made lasting contributions toward improving patient care and securing the future of our Hospital for many years to come. A natural leader with a keen business sense who was loved by all, he was instrumental in the success of the 1998 merger that created New York-Presbyterian Hospital, and he generously supported the Hospital's modernization, helping to realize the construction of the Greenberg Pavilion. Deeply committed to the community, he worked toward improving health care, education and the public good. We remember John McGillicuddy as a prince of a man with gracious and impeccable character who instantly earned the respect and affection of everyone with whom he came into contact. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, Conna, his children and grandchildren and the extended McGillicuddy family. John Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Daniel B. Burke Chairman Emeritus Maurice R. Greenberg Chairman Emeritus Frank A. Bennack, Jr. Vice Chairman Mrs. Charlotte M. Ford Vice Chairman Peter A. Georgescu Vice Chairman Jerry I. Part of the name Dousoeur de Paris Patisserie Salon is a play on words in French. When dousoeur is spoken, it can mean ''sweetness'' or ''two sisters.'' It means both, when referring to the elegant little bakery that Corine Fina and Diane Cepeda, Parisian twins, have opened in Clinton. Ms. Fina, who studied pastry-making in Paris, is the chef, and her sister, shown, designed and runs the place. ''We love New York but we felt it needed something that looked like the pastry shops of Paris, that had a traditional feeling,'' Ms. Cepeda said.

LARSON--Darlene, 72, Professor of English as a second language at New York University, died on December 17, 2008, of mesothelioma. She had taught at NYU for 40 years. During that time, she was elected president of both NYS TESOL (Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages) and international TESOL and worked with the United Nations, U.S. State Department, and Fulbright Commission. Darlene and her husband were active in Northern Westchester community affairs. Darlene will be remembered for her selfless service, good humor, enormous laugh, and positive spirit. A memorial service will be held in April at NYU.

There were no serious injuries.

McGILLICUDDY -- John F.,the former Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Chemical Bank, and its predecessor, Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, died on January 4, 2009 at his home in Harrison, New York. He was 78 years old. McGillicuddy was married for over 50 years to the former Constance Burtis of Harrison, New York. They resided in Harrison. Along with his wife, he is survived by their five children: Michael Sean (Maureen) McGillicuddy, of Astoria; Faith Burtis (Stephen) Benoit, of Rye; Constance Erin (Jonathan) Mills, of New Canaan, Connecticut; Brian Munro (Kym) McGillicuddy, of Harrison; and John Walsh McGillicuddy, of Harrison. He is also survived by his sister, Mary Jean O'Connell, of Harrison, and six grandchildren. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, on Wednesday from 2-9 PM. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Thursday at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in his memory to Prostate Cancer Research, New York Presbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, Box 123, New York, NY 10065.

PORT--Charles S. of Scarsdale, New York peacefully passed away in his 102nd year on January 4, 2009 at White Plains Hospital. Charlie was the adored husband of Lilly B. Lieb Port and the late Reggie Port. He cherished his daughters, Francine Port and Jennifer Port and doted on his grandchildren, Amanda Port Rhine and Joshua Port Rhine. Charlie served as a major in the U.S. Army, practiced law for over 60 years, loved reading and a good cigar. Funeral services will be held at 1pm, Wednesday, January 7 at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, New York. Donations in Charlie's memory can be made to Congregation Kol Ami or White Plains Hospital.

Author Solutions, a publisher of print-on-demand books based in Bloomington, Ind., has acquired Xlibris, a rival self-publisher, expanding its footprint in one of the fastest-growing segments of publishing. Author Solutions, which owns imprints including iUniverse and Author House, last year published 12,000 titles and sold more than 2.5 million copies of its books, according to Kevin Weiss, chief executive. The company is owned by Bertram Capital, a private equity firm. Together with Xlibris, currently based in Philadelphia, the title count for the combined company was about 19,000 in 2008. Authors who are either unable to secure a traditional publishing contract or don’t want one pay the companies to turn their manuscripts into saleable books. Some of Author Solutions’ imprints also offer services like cover design or copy editing. Some writers go on to sell their books through Amazon.com, the Web site of Barnes & Noble or other traditional booksellers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

Though it will still feature the stabbing of Goneril, the poisoning of Regan and other assorted tragic fates that befall its characters, the coming PBS broadcast of “King Lear” will avoid offense to delicate sensibilities by omitting a nude scene by Ian McKellen, who plays the title role, The Associated Press reported. Though Mr. McKellen regularly performed the scene in the Royal Shakespeare Company’s production of the play, a taping of “King Lear” that PBS will show on “Great Performances” on March 25 will omit it. Not that this bothers Mr. McKellen: “If it’s a distraction of that sort, it’s not worth the candle,” he said to the Television Critics Association on Wednesday, according to The A.P. Mr. McKellen added: “Every night, when I’d take my clothes off, you know what I used to do? Pull in my stomach. That’s pathetic.”

An Ohio state representative said he would seek the assistance of the state’s attorney general after the sudden closure of the Carousel Dinner Theater in Akron, The Akron Beacon Journal reported. The theater’s owner, Joseph Palmer, told The Beacon Journal that the decision to close the 35-year-old performance space was made on Dec. 30, because of the “reversal of certain stakeholders’ written or verbal promises,” rising operating costs and declining ticket sales. No tickets for its 2009 season were supposed to be sold, Mr. Palmer said. But some customers said they were sold tickets, now worthless, for 2009 performances. “People are just frying, they’re upset,” said John Otterman, an Ohio state representative, according to The Beacon Journal. He added that the theater probably knew it was “going out of business, yet they were continuing to sell these gift certificates several days before Christmas.”

Chicagoans who have been waiting 3.2 million years (give or take) for the bones of “Lucy,” the famous fossil skeleton, to visit the city’s Field Museum will have to continue their vigil: the museum said that it would not present Lucy as planned this fall because of a decline in its endowment, The Chicago Sun-Times reported. The museum said that the recent downturn of the stock market had resulted in a 30 percent decline in its endowment — a loss of $95 million, leaving it with a remaining total of $220 million — that has forced it to cancel a planned exhibition of Lucy, a fossil female discovered in Ethiopia in 1974. John McCarter, the president of the Field Museum, said that it was also offering buyouts to employees and cutting salaries to reduce operating costs.

The cast and crew of “In the Heights” can breathe a little easier: the producers of the Broadway musical said that it had recouped its initial $10 million investment after 10 months and 337 performances at the Richard Rodgers Theater. “In the Heights,” which won the 2008 Tony Award for best musical, also set a financial record for the show and theater by earning $1,136,062 for the week ending Jan. 4, its producers said. Other Broadway shows have also enjoyed record-breaking weeks, including “Shrek the Musical,” which earned a personal best $1,268,342 for the week ending Jan. 4, and “Mamma Mia!”, which earned $1,261,938 that same week. Earlier this week, the Broadway League announced that the industry’s calendar 2008 grosses had exceeded the previous year’s.

With the opening date for the Broadway transfer of “Hair” approaching, the musical revival has already lost one cast member as it added another: the show’s producers said in a statement on Thursday that Eden Espinosa, who was to have joined its cast in the role of Sheila, had withdrawn from the production. The statement said that Ms. Espinosa had withdrawn “due to personal reasons.” The producers also announced that Gavin Creel, a Tony Award nominee for the 2002 revival of “Thoroughly Modern Millie,” would join the cast as Claude; the role was previously played by the “Spring Awakening” star Jonathan Groff when “Hair” was performed at the Delacorte Theater in the summer. The Broadway production of “Hair” is scheduled to open on March 31 at the Al Hirschfeld Theater.

You walk into Bailey's or O'Neill's or McCann's. In the soft light, the sounds of ice clinking and glasses being put on the polished wood plank punctuate the oldies from the jukebox. Someone at the end of the bar is reading the newspaper, and a couple of young men are playing darts, their beers in dripping steins on the shelf beside them. You breathe in the smell of sawdust and memories as the bartender pulls a glass from behind the bar for your sacred regular drink. It's the first draft beer of the day, or a vodka and grapefruit, or if you are nursing a hangover, a glass of white wine and soda and a Fernet Branca.You take a sip and the bright street and blaring horns fade away, replaced by soothing, time-honored rituals: the fifth drink on the house, the way you can ask for a "traveler" in a plastic cup if you're leaving, the bills you leave on the bar so that the price of each drink is subtracted without the tawdry business of asking for money. Time stops. Sometimes, when the light is just right or you are with a certain person, you look into the mirror behind the bottles at the back of the bar - you always look wonderful in that mirror - and experience a moment of breathtaking transcendence. You are entirely at home in the world, the song on the jukebox is exactly the right song, the drink is perfect, and everything, everything is exactly as it's meant to be.

There's a lot of pleasure to be had in eating pigs' feet (or, to give them a slightly more charming name, trotters -- or a far more charming, outmoded one, pettitoes). It's not that they have the most elegant flavor of any cut: although they are plenty porky, they're more memorable for their texture -- some meat, some fat, some skin, and enough collagen to make your lips sticky. So it's all come down to this. After a wild college football season, which produced plenty of highlights and controversy (and only one undefeated team), Florida and Oklahoma will play Thursday night in the B.C.S. championship game. You want story lines? This game has plenty of them. It matches the past two Heisman winners, Florida's Tim Tebow and Oklahoma's Sam Bradford, who also happen to be the only two players to ever win the prestigious award as sophomores. It pits two of college football's high-profile coaches, Oklahoma's Bob Stoops and Florida's Urban Meyer, against one another. Both have elevated their programs among the elite in college football and both have already won one national title. The game is also a chance for either the Southeastern Conference or the Big 12 to gain bragging rights as to which is the preeminent league in the country. Teams from the SEC have won the past two national titles, while offenses in the Big 12 this year were some of the most prolific in college football history. It all adds up to one of the most anticipated national title showdowns in recent memory and a game you won't want to miss.

In this deteriorating economy, even the makers of GPS devices can't find their way. The stock of Garmin, the Kansas City-based developer of technologies using the global positioning system, has fallen more than 75 percent in the last year. People are buying fewer devices and the company is slashing its prices and depressing its profit margins as a result. And mobile phone makers have mounted a growing challenge, giving away free location tools in handsets like the Apple iPhone.

Andrei Markovits, is the author of "Offside: Soccer and American Exceptionalism" and the forthcoming "Global Players." Born in Romania but raised in Austria and the United States, Markovits is now the Karl W. Deutsch Collegiate Professor of Comparative Politics and German Studies at the University of Michigan. He is a lifelong follower of the beautiful game, traveling far and wide to satisfy a craving for soccer. His Ultimate XI is a collection of the greatest players of the post-World War II period whom he has seen play "live and in color."

If there were a chase scene in this particular crime drama, it would not be too hair-raising. But the long arm of the law still drew plenty of stares from passers-by on a recent Sunday along the Central Park Mall, the long promenade leading to the Bethesda Terrace. At one moment, three pedicab drivers, some with passengers still ensconced, were pulled over almost simultaneously by enforcement officers and issued summonses."Pedicabs are not allowed to be on pedestrian pathways, and obviously the Mall is a major pedestrian pathway," said Douglas Blonsky, the Central Park administrator and president of the Central Park Conservancy, the private, nonprofit organization that manages the park under contract with the Department of Parks and Recreation.

Thomas V. Liccardi was an accountant who specialized in tax returns for estates - often dealing with people whose elderly parents had died, usually after long and comfortable lives. Environment | Canada's vast forests, once dubbed the "lungs of the planet" for their ability to absorb CO2, may now be harming the climate, an article says. Damage from global warming, insect infestations and persistent fires mean the forests are "now pumping out more climate-changing carbon dioxide than they are sequestering." [Chicago Tribune]

The days of walking into Home Depot and having an Olympic gold medalist help you pick out paint could be coming to an end. The big-box home store said it was ending its multimillion-dollar sponsorship deal with the United States Olympic Committee and discontinuing a program that offered jobs and benefits to American athletes. The 86 athletes currently in the program will be offered traditional part-time jobs or the chance to interview for full-time jobs. But after March 2, they will no longer receive either full-time benefits or full-time pay for their part-time work.

The filmmaker Ken Burns is taking another swing at baseball, chronicling the sport over the past 15 years in “The Tenth Inning.” It will be broadcast in the spring of 2010, PBS announced. The film will feature interviews with managers Felipe Alou and Joe Torre, the players Omar Vizquel and Ichiro Suzuki and fans from across the country and overseas.

The Penn State police are looking out for Joe Paterno’s Coke-bottle-thick glasses — the bronzed ones that were perched on the Paterno statue that stands outside Beaver Stadium. Vandals apparently cut the glasses off just above the base of the ears of the 7-foot sculpture between 11 a.m. Sunday and 11 a.m. Monday, when a police officer noticed the damage.

A Frenchman became a fatality in the Dakar Rally in Argentina. The body of the motorcyclist Pascal Terry, missing since Sunday, was found in dense bush between Santa Rosa and Puerto Madryn. Terry, a first-time Dakar racer, was near his motorbike without his helmet, but with food and water beside him. An autopsy revealed the 49-year-old Terry died of a pulmonary edema.

Manchester United was upset by Derby in the League Cup semifinals, losing, 1-0, on a goal in the 30th minute by Kris Commons. Derby, which plays in the League Championship, ended a 14-game unbeaten streak for United, the defending English, European and world champion. United did not start many of its top players, bringing in Cristiano Ronaldo and Wayne Rooney as substitutes. The second leg is Jan. 20 at Old Trafford.

Jack Kemp, the former housing secretary, congressman, vice presidential nominee and Buffalo Bills quarterback, has cancer, his office said. A statement issued in Washington said Kemp was undergoing tests to assess the origin of the disease and the treatment. It did not disclose the type of cancer. Kemp, 73, said he would continue to serve as chairman of his Washington-based Kemp Partners consulting firm and would remain involved in charitable and political work.

Picture captions on Saturday with a music column about a film from the 1967 Stax/Volt Revue tour of Europe that was broadcast on WLIW, using information provided by the station, misidentified several performers. It may not require you to wear special 3D glasses, but a Hyundai commercial scheduled to be broadcast during the Super Bowl will feature its own special effects, of sorts: a performance by the cellist Yo-Yo Ma, above, will be heard in the commercial, which viewers can later re-edit online, Billboard reported. The commercial, produced by the advertising agency Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, will feature a track from Mr. Ma’s 2002 recording “Bach’s Cello Suites Nos. 1, 5 & 6,” and direct viewers to a Web site where they can manipulate and reassemble the ad. “Within the context of all the other advertising, which can be so chaotic that it almost becomes white noise, a quiet, gorgeous solo cello moment can be very arresting,” said Jim Elliot, the creative director of Goodby, Silverstein.

Though the full roster of Oscar nominees won’t be announced until Jan. 22, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has already named one award winner: Edwin Catmull, the president of Walt Disney and Pixar Animation Studios and a founder of Pixar, will receive the Gordon E. Sawyer Award for his contributions to the field of computer graphics. The academy also said that seven films, including “The Dark Knight,” “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button” and “Iron Man,” were on the short list for the best visual effects Oscar, and seven films, including “Benjamin Button,” “Dark Knight,” “Tropic Thunder” and “The Wrestler,” were on the short list for the best makeup award. The winners will be announced on Feb. 22.

NBC won big in the ratings with “The Biggest Loser” on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the seventh-edition premiere of the reality weight-loss competition drew Tuesday’s highest ratings among viewers 18 to 49 and a series record 11.8 million total viewers. CBS earned the night’s largest audiences with “NCIS” (19.1 million), “The Mentalist” (19.6 million), and “Without a Trace” (13.2 million). ABC was third, attracting 7.8 million viewers for the premiere of “Homeland Security USA” and 7 million for “Primetime: What Would You Do?” In between, ABC broadcast two new episodes of “Scrubs” at 9 (6.8 million) and 9:30 (6.6 million), which delivered ratings in line with its previous average on NBC last season. Fox finished fourth with repeats, although the network dominated Monday night’s ratings with live coverage of Texas’ victory over Ohio State in the Fiesta Bowl, which averaged 17.1 million viewers.

After years of neglect, misuse and haphazard reconstruction of the ancient city of Babylon, a master plan is being developed to restore this Mesopotamian site, in present-day Iraq. The project, called “The Future of Babylon,” was announced in a news release by the World Monuments Fund, which will collaborate with Iraq’s State Board of Antiquities and Heritage. Babylon endured numerous restoration and reconstruction projects during the reign of Saddam Hussein. It was heavily plundered after his fall (a recovered artifact is above), and used as the site of an American military base. The Babylon project, financed by a $700,000 grant from the State Department, will map the city’s archaeological sites, develop conservation plans and pursue possibilities for tourism and education.

Charges have been dropped against the actors Josh Brolin and Jeffrey Wright after their arrest in Louisiana last year, The Associated Press reported. While working on the Oliver Stone movie “W.” in July, Mr. Brolin and Mr. Wright were arrested in Shreveport, La., along with five members of the film’s crew, after a bar fight. At that time Mr. Brolin and Mr. Wright were charged with interfering with police officers; Mr. Brolin was booked and posted a $334 cash bond to be released. Blair Berk, a Los Angeles lawyer who represented the actors and crew members, told The A.P. that prosecutors in Shreveport had agreed to drop all charges against the group within 60 days.

With no major new releases the Top 10 was mostly reshuffled from the previous week, as Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) held at No. 2 with 77,000, and Kanye West’s “808s and Heartbreak” (Def Jam) rose two spots to No. 3 with 71,000. Most albums lost sales last week, but one had a big gain: “All Wrapped Up” (Hollywood), a Target exclusive with Christmas songs by the Jonas Brothers, Miley Cyrus and others, jumped to No. 10 from No. 88 with 40,000 sales, a 112 percent increase.

GOODMAN--Maurice, Jr.,of New York, NY, Salisbury, CT, and Kennebunkport, ME, died at his home in Manhattan on December 23rd after a protracted battle with heart disease. ''Buddy'', as his many friends called him, was 87 years old. A graduate of the Hotchkiss School and Yale University, Mr. Goodman remained active in the alumni affairs at both schools. As a First Lieutenant U.S. Naval Aviator, he served in World War II and was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with cluster for action in the Pacific theater where he piloted the huge ''flying boats.'' A true renaissance man, after the war Mr. Goodman served in various executive positions in advertising, shifting gradually into mergers and acquisitions, and ultimately into several corporate start-ups. Holding patents in widely diverse fields including solar panels and various industrial grinding/deburring processes, he also was an accomplished lyricist whose 1950s songs ''My April Heart'' and ''Way Out There'' were highly praised. More recently, he wrote a song for the Yale Glee Club to recognize their new coeducational status. In his later years, Buddy took great pride in his internet column, ''Letter From New York'', written for The Blockhead Journal. Mr. Goodman was also concerned with New York social welfare issues and he actively served on the Executive Committee of Planned Parenthood of New York City for many years, as well as in various capacities with the Community Service Society and the Boy's Club of New York. He was Chairman of the Task Force on Criminal Justice for the Mayor's Voluntary Action Council for 12 years. As a loving husband, brother, and father and as an avid tennis player, sailor, and golfer, Buddy enjoyed his life to the fullest. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Georgine Rake Goodman; his brother, Walter F. Goodman of Miami, FL and New York, NY; three children: Mrs. Prudence G. Meyer of Durham, NC, Mrs. Susannah E. Rake of Santa Barbara, CA, and John R. Goodman of Santa Barbara, CA; and three granddaughters: Laura, Georgina, and Annabelle. A memorial service will be held at The Brick Church on April 18th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, a contribution to the Community Service Society or the Boys Club of New York would be appreciated.
FIRDMAN--Billie G. Social worker, artist. Survived by husband Marvin, children Stephanie, Wendy, Robert, Melissa and granddaughter Jessica and sister Sandy.

ROSENBERG--Mortimer Wilson, born March 4th, 1913, 95 years of life. A man who was loved by everyone. Husband for 60 years of the late Helen Rosenberg, father of Alan and Joan, and the late Susan, grandfather of Andy and Melissa, David and Dara, and Elizabeth and Adam, greatgrandfather of Madison, Claudia, Stevie, Josh and Ethan. A graduate of West Virginia University. Captain in the U.S. Army. Leader in the surplus truck parts industry as CEO of Morris Bros. A world traveller who was smart, sharp, devoted and lovable until the end.

President-elect Barack Obama and his top aides called lawmakers, deployed surrogates and offered public testimonials on Tuesday as they scrambled to mend a divide in Democratic ranks over the nomination of Leon E. Panetta, a former White House chief of staff, to take over the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Obama and his aides were trying to mend damage done on Monday when news of Mr. Panettas selection leaked before it had been shared with senior senators, and some Democrats responded with surprise and skepticism because Mr. Panetta lacks much intelligence experience.

FUELED by still-fresh New Year resolutions, many people are looking for new slim-down solutions. According to the research concern Mintel International, one-third of dieters are constantly searching for a better weight-loss plan. Besides comparing NutriSystem with Jenny Craig, dieters can now turn to their mobile phones, laptops and even Nintendo DS for help. Several new high-tech weight-loss systems and devices keep track of calories, provide diet tips and promote exercise. While online weight-loss guidance isn't new, interactive customized support is. With these systems, users type in food preferences, weight-loss goals, workouts or even what they ate at Taco Bell for lunch; in return they get a text message or shopping list on their iPhone.

NEIMETH--Richard, died on January 7th in his home in New York after a long illness, surrounded by his loving family. Beloved husband of Peggy (Sprung), cherished father of Deborah (George Barrett), Pamela (Norbert Lazar), Amy Sachs, and Lisa (Peter Dickstein). Grandfather of Kate, Zachary and Emma Barrett; Kylie and Cass Neimeth-Lazar; Joshua and Benjamin Safdie and Maggie Sachs; Jackson and Tess Neimeth-Dickstein. A graduate of Cornell University, he also attended the MBA program in Pharmaceutical Business Administration at Brooklyn College of Pharmacy. He received an honorary Ph.D. from Long Island University in 1994. Mr. Neimeth was founder and CEO of NMC Labs, a generic pharmaceutical company in Queens, New York. He was President of National Magnesia Company founded by his late father, Edward, in Queens, New York and Vice President and partner of Major Pharmaceutical, a generic drug wholesale distributor in Chicago. He served as Chairman of the Council of Overseers of the Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy, member of the Board of Trustees of Long Island University, member of the Community Board of Metropolitan Hospital in New York and member of the Board of Trustees of the Gunn Memorial Library in Washington, CT, where he had a home. He was a talented photographer and his photographs grace the walls of his many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations made be made to Hospice, VNS and Mt. Sinai Hospital liver program, care of Dr. Douglas Dieterich. Funeral services will be on Sunday, January 11 at 11:45am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be sitting shiva at the family's home in New York on Sunday evening from 6-8pm and Monday from 4-8pm.

AROMANDO COYLE--Terri, 60, Short Hills, NJ resident passed away peacefully in her sleep at the home she shared with her husband, Thomas C. Coyle, on December 16, 2008 after a three year battle with breast and liver cancer. ''She lived her life to the fullest.'' The cancer could never defeat her beautiful spirit. Terri had a long and very successful career in the world of bond trading on Wall Street. Terri had an amazing collection of frog figurines. Terri was born in the Bronx. She graduated from Cardinal Spellman High School, and City College of NY in Manhattan. She attended Brooklyn Law School and entered into Wall Street in 1970. In March 1990, Terri was elected to the office of Managing Director, Capital Markets Divisions Manager, Northeast Municipal Bond Trading Region at Smith Barney. She is a past President of the New York City Women's Bond Club in 1988-1989. She continued her career at Merrill Lynch, before becoming stricken with cancer. Terri was listed in ''Who's Who of NY Women'' and was a member of The Financial Women's Association. Terri is survived by husband, Thomas C. Coyle; son and daughter-in-law, Chris and Meredith Coyle of Flemington, NJ and three grandchildren; CJ, Tommy and Katie. She is also survived by her mother, Dorothy Aromando of North Carolina; her brother and sister-in-law, Bart and Ada Aromando of Manhattan and their children Michael and Elizabeth; and her sister Diane Havelock and her daughter Chelsea. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday January 10th at 11am at Corpus Christi Church, Southern Blvd. Chatham, NJ. Friends may visit on Thursday January 8, from 7-9pm and on Friday January 9, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham. To send condolences to learn of donations in lieu of flowers or for further information go to www.bradleyfuneralhomes.com

KILLIAN--Edward J.,M.D., in Woodstock, VT January 3, 2009, age 81. Born November 14, 1927, Brooklyn, NY, only son of the late Helen and Edward J. Killian, Sr. Graduated Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY, 1954. Performed Internship and Residency at The Brooklyn Hospital, 1954 to 1956, where he met his future beloved wife, Henriette M. Sarno, R.N. They married October 26, 1957 and lived in love together for 51 years. Captain in the United States Air Force at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, Dayton, OH from 1956 to 1959, USAF Reserves from 1959 to 1963. Entered private pediatric practice in Brooklyn in 1959, then East Islip, Long Island, NY 1961 to 1994, when he was also on staff at Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip and Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, NY. 34 year resident of Islip, Long Island, he and his wife moved to their pastoral home ''Sweetmeadow'' in Woodstock, VT in 1997. Survived by cherished wife, Henriette M. Killian. Three sons: Christopher E. Killian, Ph.D. and daughter-inlaw Carole Ungvarsky of Berkeley, CA, Bryan A. Killian of New York City and Paul M. Killian, Esq. and Philip Scalice, Jr. of East Moriches, NY. Three dear grandchildren: Daniel E. Killian, Victoria Corbo Killian, and Nora K. Killian. Beloved brother-in-law to Carol Crager Murphy and Richard Murphy of Bay Shore, NY and loving uncle to Catherine J. Beckett, William C. Crager, III, and John C. Crager and families. Reposing, the Fredrick Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy. (1/4 mile West of the Robert Moses Cswy.), Friday, January 9th, 2 to 4:30pm and 7 to 9:30pm. Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, St. Mary's R.C. Church, East Islip, NY, Saturday, January 10th, 9:15am. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

BERMAN--Eugene, 87, of Flat Rock, died Monday, January 5, 2009 at Memorial Mission Hospital. A native of Bronx, NY, he lived most of his life in Westchester, NY before moving to Henderson County in 2004. He was the son of the late Saul and Bella Berman formerly of New York. He is also preceded in death by his former wife, Elaine Berman who died in 1999; a daughter, Nancy Berman who died in 1971 at the age of 23; and a brother, Robert Berman. He served in the US Air Force during WWII; and worked approximately 30 years for the Department of Social Service in New York City as a social worker before retirement. He was a member of the Agudas Israel Congregation. He was an avid square dancer, bridge player, enjoyed acting, was a member of the Kenmure Show Chorus, and ritually completed the Sunday NY Times Crossword puzzle. He is survived by his wife, Ann E. Adam; a daughter, Dr. Helene Berman and her husband Mark Flink of Ontario, Canada; two grandchildren, Neil Berman Flink of Boston, MA and Sarah Berman Flink of Toronto, Canada. KAHN--Marilyn (Sklar), 76, died of pancreatic cancer, January 7, 2009. Beloved wife of 39 years to Jerry Kahn, mother to Adam; stepmother to Beth and Nanci; grandmother to Boaz, Yarden, David, Michael, Jesse and Chloe; sister to Samuel and Daniel; in-law to Doris, Nili, Adina, Stu and Steve; and loving aunt to many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. A graduate of Pratt Institute, Marilyn clothed middle America as a renowned dress designer; was an accomplished artist, was active in the American Israel Cultural Foundation, and was a supporter of the Jewish Community and lover of the State of Israel. Marilyn survived paralysis and aphasia caused by a stroke 27 years ago. Marilyn will always be remembered for her strength, determination, strong will, love of family and friends, vibrancy and incomparable sense of style. The funeral will take place January 8th at 11:30am at The Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

McGILLICUDDY--John F. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, John F. McGillicuddy. As Chairman Emeritus and Life Trustee of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, he made lasting contributions toward improving patient care and securing the future of our Hospital for many years to come. A natural leader with a keen business sense who was loved by all, he was instrumental in the success of the 1998 merger that created New York-Presbyterian Hospital, and he generously supported the Hospital's modernization, helping to realize the construction of the Greenberg Pavilion. Deeply committed to the community, he worked toward improving health care, education and the public good. We remember John McGillicuddy as a prince of a man with gracious and impeccable character who instantly earned the respect and affection of everyone with whom he came into contact. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his wife, Conna, his children and grandchildren and the extended McGillicuddy family. John Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Daniel B. Burke Chairman Emeritus Maurice R. Greenberg Chairman Emeritus Frank A. Bennack, Jr. Vice Chairman Mrs. Charlotte M. Ford Vice Chairman Peter A. Georgescu Vice Chairman Jerry I. VLAHAKIS--Anthony, 82, died on December 18, 2008 at his home in Port Richey, FL after a long illness. He was a prior resident of NYC where he worked as an artist and designer. Like its enigmatic protagonist, Don Draper, the fate of “Mad Men” continues to unwind at its own unhurried pace. At a panel discussion held by AMC during the Television Critics Association tour, the cable channel’s president, Charlie Collier, announced that “Mad Men,” its Emmy Award-winning drama about 1960s-era advertising executives, would return to AMC for its third season this summer, Variety reported. The network has not yet announced an agreement with the show’s creator and executive producer, Matthew Weiner, with whom AMC has been negotiating since his previous contract expired after the second season of “Mad Men.” Mr. Collier was nonetheless confident that a deal would be struck in time for the show’s third season. “As long as we get the writers’ room up and running over the next few months, we’re fine,” he said, according to Variety.

The architectural firm that will redesign a former firehouse to serve as the new home of the Brooklyn Philharmonic unveiled its plans on Wednesday, the Web site GlobeSt.com reported. The firm HOK said that its plan would preserve the exterior of the decommissioned firehouse of Engine 204, at 299 DeGraw Street in Cobble Hill Brooklyn, and carry out a gut renovation of the building’s two-story 4,250-square-foot interior; the new building will be known as the BP Music Center. In May, the city’s Economic Development Corporation chose the Brooklyn Philharmonic to remake the firehouse over a group called Friends of Firefighters, which had hoped to turn the space into a center for counseling and therapy. At that time, the corporation also gave the former firehouse of Engine 212 in Williamsburg to advocacy groups that will use it as a community center.

The following item is recommended for hardcore theater nerds (and the people who love them): The Broadway League and the American Theater Wing have announced key dates for the 63rd Annual Antoinette Perry Awards, better known as the Tonys. Tony nominations will be announced on the morning of May 5, and the annual Tony nominees luncheon, an event so exclusive that not even the press is permitted to attend, will take place on May 21. The awards will be announced in a ceremony at Radio City Music Hall on the night of June 7.

American Ballet Theater announced that it had selected David Lansky as its general manager. It is the first time the company has offered the position since 2004, when it let go its last general manager, Nancy Fleeter, and distributed her duties to other staff members as a cost-cutting measure. Mr. Lansky has held various positions since he joined the company in 1986 as its assistant stage manager, and most recently served as its director of production and operations.

Jermaine Dupri was dismissed this week as president of urban music at Island Records, according to a person at his record company who was not authorized to speak publicly. Mr. Dupri, 36, a top producer who has been behind hits by Mariah Carey and Janet Jackson, his longtime girlfriend, was hired by Island in early 2007 to recruit artists and produce records for Island Def Jam and other divisions of the Universal Music Group. But aside from Ms. Carey, he has had little success at Island, and has been dogged by low sales of Ms. Jackson’s music; both had been at Virgin Records, a division of EMI, before coming to Island, which released Ms. Jackson’s album “Discipline” last year. Mr. Dupri is expected to remain the head of Tag Records, a partnership between Island Def Jam and Tag Body Spray. A spokeswoman at Island Def Jam declined to comment.

Ryan O’Neal pleaded guilty on Friday to a felony drug possession charge and was sentenced to an 18-month rehabilitation program, Agence-France Presse reported. Mr. O’Neal and his son Redmond were arrested in September when authorities had gone to Mr. O’Neal’s home in Malibu, Calif., to check on Redmond, who was serving three years probation for a previous drug charge. Mr. O’Neal pleaded guilty to one felony count of possessing methamphetamine, and must return to the court for a progress report on July 10. Redmond O’Neal’s arraignment is scheduled for Feb. 20.

Hide the honey pots: Winnie-the-Pooh will return in the first authorized sequel to A. A. Milne‘s children’s books, The Associated Press reported. The maladroit bear, whose realist philosophy was immortalized in two books by Milne (and later a series of Walt Disney cartoons), had his last official print adventure in 1928’s “The House at Pooh Corner,” which ended with his human companion, Christopher Robin, leaving for boarding school. The new book, “Return to the Hundred Acre Wood,” may pick up there, though its author, David Benedictus, said only that his new work would “both complement and maintain Milne’s idea that whatever happens, a little boy and his bear will always be playing,” according to The A.P. Dutton Children’s Books, an imprint of Penguin Books, is scheduled to publish “Return to the Hundred Acre Wood” on Oct. 5.

Patrick Swayze, who is suffering from pancreatic cancer, has been hospitalized with pneumonia, executives from the A&E Network accounted today. Swayze had been scheduled to head a panel discussion today promoting his new drama series, “The Beast,” in which he plays an FBI agent who teams with a rookie partner to infiltrate a weapons smuggling ring, at the Television Critics Association meeting in Universal City, Calif. Bob DeBitetto, the president and general manager of the A&E Network, announced there this morning that Mr. Swayze had checked himself into a hospital for observation after recently contracting pneumonia. Swayze was diagnosed with advanced stage four pancreatic cancer last January, and has been undergoing chemotherapy. The 13-episode series, which is scheduled to premiere on A&E on Jan. 15, has been completely filmed, executives said.

Stephen Sprouse may have died in 2004, but his legacy was alive and kicking on Thursday night when Louis Vuitton paid tribute to the New York glamour punk with a triumvirate of events splashed with graffiti and Day-Glo. A cocktail party at the Greene Street store, where all manner of Sprousified LV merch was on display, including specially reissued Sprouse LV bags from 2001, was followed by a preview of "Rock On Mars," an installation of original Sprouse memorabilia (and amazing runway footage) at Deitch Projects on Wooster Street. The final stop was the Bowery Ballroom, for a special performance by Debbie Harry, appropriately dressed in a rather hairy vintage Sprouse jacket.

It's cheesecake vs. cheese steak. New York vs. Philly. Giants vs. Eagles. Mayor Bloomberg vs. Mayor Nutter. In the ever-continuing tradition of sports-contingent food wagers between mayors, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Mayor Michael A. Nutter of Philadelphia made a wager on the football game between the Giants and Eagles this Sunday, to see which team which will advance to the National Football Conference championship game.If the Giants win, Mayor Nutter will send a sampling of five cheese steaks from popular shops across Philadelphia. If the Eagles are triumphant, Mayor Bloomberg will send a giant New York-style cheesecake from the Carnegie Deli in Manhattan. (Never mind last year's suggestion from the mayor of East Rutherford, N.J., that Mayor Bloomberg should check his GPS before placing a bet on a team that plays in New Jersey.)

It has been clear for a while that change was afoot at the Rainbow Room, the venerable restaurant, bar and event space on the 65th floor of Rockefeller Center. Its current operator, the Cipriani company, announced on Saturday that it was ending dinner service at the Rainbow Grill, the facility's restaurant, in response to the dismal economy. The situation became even more worrisome: Cipriani's landlord, Tishman Speyer, announced it was moving to evict the company for unpaid rent, and would seek a new restaurateur to run the space, as Charles V. Bagli of The Times is reporting this afternoon.As it happened, I was at the Rainbow Grill on Wednesday night, before this latest development became public, to talk to patrons and employees for this weekend's Dispatches feature in the City section. At the time, I was seeking their response to the reduced services, and even then, people who had heard the news -- staff members, that is, and the few customers I met there who were not tourists -- seemed uneasy about the future.

Back in 1980s, I bought a studio co-op in Astoria, Queens, which I shared with my girlfriend. I wanted to build a house upstate, so we made an agreement. I borrowed twice what I had paid for it and left her with the apartment. She pays the maintenance fee and her share of the loan. In all this time, she has never put the shares in her name. Is it possible I still own this apartment and therefore could sell it?
