FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Urban Meyer, Florida's football coach, looked a little bleary-eyed Friday morning from a lack of sleep, but he still managed to flash a smile as bright as the South Florida sunshine. He met with the news media in the afterglow of the Gators' national title victory on Thursday night. Here are a few of his thoughts:

Earlier today The Guardian reported that it had spoken to "three people with knowledge of the discussion in Obama's camp" who said the incoming administration would "abandon George Bush's doctrine of isolating Hamas by establishing a channel to the Islamist organisation."
It's official: Marian Robinson, the 71-year-old mother-in-law of President-elect Barack Obama, will be moving into the White House, transition officials said on Friday.

While televisions of all sizes, shapes and image technologies are the main draw at this week's Consumer Electronics Show, it's their connectivity functions that will make for an intriguing situation down the road.

Hotels that are charging as much as $12,000 a night for an inaugural stay -- four, even five night minimums, prepaid, no refunds -- have to find a way to make their package different from all the other hotels that have also raised their prices.

At the beginning of December, New York State gave New York City a scary ultimatum: Give raises to the providers of government subsidized in-home day care, or lose state and federal contributions to all day care programs. These programs serve roughly 100,000 poor children citywide. The state set Dec. 31 as a deadline for the city to give it a plan. If not, the state said, it would withhold reimbursements for day care for each day over the deadline that the city was late. That left the meter for additional money that the city would have to raise running at roughly $1.3 million a day starting on Jan. 1.

Reviewing books and TV shows is easy; as easy as sitting in a chair and passing judgment. By contrast, reviewing new media is a headache. It can be humiliating. To jump in and post comments and make response videos requires a measure of enterprise and exhibitionism that critics rarely possess. Instead of skeptically inspecting a work of art or entertainment, only to pronounce on it from a carefully cultivated distance, you have to get mixed up in whatever you're reviewing. There's no way to maintain an ex cathedra advantage when you're cavorting in a circus ring.

Like a lot of us, David Poland has noticed that Clint Eastwood has come out blazing late in Oscar season with another "small" movie that seems to be working its way into the conversation. But Mr. Poland goes on to point out what a lot of us are thinking - that as great as it is to have Mr. Eastwood in the running, "Gran Torino" is a movie many would not give the time of day if it were branded with someone else's name. Some critics have said that it's not just small, it's a little sloppy, with non-actors doing a lot of non-acting and a performance from its star director that is less "Dirty Harry" than "Grumpy Old Men."

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Well, there was a historic meeting in Washington this week. Yesterday, Barack Obama and all the former US presidents met at the Oval Office. Did you see it? All the living ex-presidents were there. Jimmy Carter, George Bush Sr., Bill Clinton, Dick Cheney. All of them were there.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Urban Meyer, Florida's football coach, became angry just once in his briefing Friday morning, the day after the Bowl Championship Series title game. It was when he started talking about Charlie Strong, his defensive coordinator, who put together a masterly game plan to slow Oklahoma's high-powered offense in the Gators' 24-14 victory.

Dow Chemical's $15.3 billion acquisition of Rohm & Haas was cleared by the European Commission on Thursday. Under the acquisition agreement, the only remaining condition to Dow's obligation to complete the transaction is United States antitrust clearance from the Federal Trade Commission. Presumably, European and United States regulators are coordinating their reviews, as they usually do. So it is likely that the U.S. clearance should come soon.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on CBS: Couple of days ago in New Jersey, there were UFO sightings. Believe me, it's not an invasion. The aliens are actually here because they want some of that Federal bailout money.
Israel said that continued barrages of rocket fire from its adversaries made the United Nations resolution “unworkable.”

At her confirmation hearing for labor secretary on Friday, Representative Hilda Solis was challenged by several Republican senators for supporting a bitterly contested bill that would make it easier for workers to join unions.

This weekend's Automobiles section features a preview of the North American International Auto Show, which opens to the press on Sunday. In the section, Lawrence Ulrich, a Times auto reviewer, writes about growing up in the Motor City. Now living in Brooklyn, Mr. Ulrich returns to his family's home every year for the auto show. Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: It was an exciting first day for our first lady, who got a new set of plates. First Lady Laura Bush showed off the new gold-rimmed official state china. It cost $493,000, but don't worry. It was paid for by a private trust, funded by lunatics who donate half a million dollars to buy the White House plates.

Warner Brothers and 20th Century Fox are pointed toward a settlement of their bitter dispute over the upcoming "Watchmen" movie. Lawyers for both sides on Friday morning asked a federal judge in Los Angeles to postpone a Friday hearing on the status of their case until Monday, while they pursue settlement talks.

This week: Stacey D'Erasmo discusses her new novel, "The Sky Below"; Motoko Rich has Notes From the Field; Bill Morgan talks about the letters of Allen Ginsberg; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

Every January for last ten years, Bruce Sterling takes up virtual residence on the Well, one of the earliest online communities, to offer his view of "Things in General, the State of the World, Where We Have Been and Where We are Tending," in conversation with other Well members. The process takes place over a number of days.

Three bloggers who had sued New York City after the Police Department denied them press credentials because they work for online or nontraditional news outlets were issued credentials on Friday after the police relented, the bloggers' lawyer, Norman Siegel, said.

I have little patience for bio/organic perfume collections, and perhaps less for the people behind them because, to give the most fundamental reason, the perfumes usually smell inferior. For example, I have never really understood (the diplomatic term for "liked") a single Strange Invisible Perfume scent despite great effort on my part and the sincerity and hard work of its founder. Most organic lines offer various versions of woody mushroom. In fact, I would have told you that a good all-organic was impossible, but I would have been wrong. Recently, Red Flower somehow managed it. Now Patyka proves me wrong again.

The John Tavares trade watch in the Ontario Hockey League is finally over, with London stocking up for a fight with Windsor in the Western Conference. In the Eastern Conference, Oshawa is looking to the future while Belleville, Brampton and Ottawa prepare to contend for the top spot.

New York is a city of characters. On the subway and in its streets, from the intensity of Midtown to the intimacy of neighborhood blocks, is a 305-square-mile parade of people with something to say. One in 8 Million is a new collection of a few of their passions and problems, relationships and routines, vocations and obsessions. A new story will be added weekly.

The economy lost 524,000 jobs in December, raising the unemployment rate to 7.2 percent. More than 10 million Americans are now unemployed. Many more millions of Americans worry about their own job security. These anxieties are transforming the workplace. Employees may be working harder, experts say, but they may also be less productive. What is the toll on individual workers and on the economy as a whole? Our Room for Debate panelists try to answer the question. We hope readers will share their own stories and observations.

Literature | An animator has posted nearly 250 clips on YouTube featuring images of great poets with mouths animated "in the style of old, scratchy movies" to show them "reciting" their work. Fascinating? Creepy? Both? Check them out, from Rimbaud to Bronte to Poe to Sexton. [YouTube]

Crime | A falling economy means rising crime, right? Think again, says the crime authority James Q. Wilson. Crime fell in Los Angeles last year as the economy reeled, and it rose in the prosperous 1960's. And some think crime stayed low in the Great Depression because families pulled together. A lot of other factors affect the crime rate, including the age of the population, gangs, drug abuse, and good old police work. [Los Angeles Times]
At least one private equity firm is seeking to cut its exposure to the business of high fashion.
Ron Burkle, who made his fortune buying and selling supermarket chains, has acquired a 7 percent stake in Whole Foods Market, generating lots of speculation about what his intentions are.

Mark Matthews, the chief Asia strategist at Merrill Lynch, has reportedly left the firm, in what would be the latest executive departure from Merrill, following the investment bank's takeover by Bank of America.

Economy | Punish savers and make them spend, a British financial columnist says. "The government could tax all bank deposits and other risk-free savings," he says; that would encourage good borrowing to replace bad debt as well as more consumption to speed a global recovery. Bite victim, meet hair of dog. [Times of London]
A founder of The Children's Investment Fund has left the high-profile British activist hedge fund, Reuters reported Friday.

Energy efficiency is a top priority for President-elect Barack Obama. On Thursday he called for "modernizing" more than 75 percent of federal buildings, and increasing the energy efficiency of two million homes.

Yahoo is nearing the end of its search for a new chief executive officer, with a decision coming possibly as soon as next week, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people close to the internet company.
Activist investor Carl C. Icahn called for changes in federal bankruptcy laws, which he argues are thwarting private investment in the banking system.
The chief executive of Nasdaq OMX is joining the tub-thumping for a merger of U.S. securities and futures regulators, saying it's incomprehensible that they both monitored the same products.

Air France-KLM looked set to seal an alliance with Alitalia as rival Lufthansa backed away from taking a minority stake in the revamped Italian airline on Thursday after a three-month battle.

The federal investigation that prompted Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico to withdraw his nomination as commerce secretary offers a rare glimpse into a long-simmering investigation of possible bid-rigging, tax evasion and other wrongdoing throughout the municipal bond business, The New York Times's Mary Williams Walsh writes.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly backed away from a rule that had allowed the accounting firm that audited Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities to avoid oversight by a regulator that was created after the Enron and WorldCom scandals, The New York Times's Floyd Norris reported.

Citigroup expects to take a $1.4 billion pre-tax charge in its just-completed fourth quarter related to its exposure to LyondellBasell, the world's third-largest petrochemical company, whose U.S. operations filed for bankruptcy protection this week.
Paul Collins's books include "Sixpence House: Lost in a Town of Books" and "The Trouble With Tom: The Strange Afterlife and Times of Thomas Paine."

Lehman Brothers, the fallen brokerage firm now under bankruptcy court protection, has struck a complex deal to spin off part of its private equity unit into an independent firm, The New York Times's Zachary Kouwe reported, citing a person briefed on the matter.
One company's scandal is another's opportunity.

John Doerr, the prominent cleantech venture capitalist for Kleiner Perkins Caufiled & Byers, gave his standard earnest speech before a Senate Committee hearing on how greentech investing can spur the economy on Wednesday morning, GigaOm says. As per usual, he first chided the U.S. for not doing enough to cut carbon emissions and invest in cleantech, and then laid out his broad plan on what to do next.

The Indian outsourcing company Satyam was struggling on Thursday to determine the extent of a financial fraud that left it fighting for survival as investors began to search for ways to recoup their losses, The New York Times's Heather Timmons and Jeremy Kahn reported.

Two year old life-story repository Dandelife seemed to have everything going for it. It launched to praise from some of the biggest tech blogs on the web, it built a wildly loyal user base and its company advisory board was stocked with some of the biggest names in social media.
An 82-year-old businessman was charged on Thursday with running a Ponzi scheme that took in at least $17 million from a clientele gleaned largely through ads in Catholic newspapers.

Under pressure from federal authorities, the Swiss bank UBS is closing the hidden offshore accounts of its well-heeled American clients, potentially allowing their secrets to spill into the open, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

China Construction Bank said on Thursday it was "fully confident" in its strategic relationship with Bank of America, after the top U.S. lender sold nearly 13 percent of its holding in the Chinese bank this week.

Stock markets recovered from early losses to finish largely in positive territory on Thursday, but an earnings warning from Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, weighed down the Dow, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.

Ssangyong Motor Company became a casualty of the global economic downturn Friday, filing for receivership in a bid to stave off collapse, The New York Times's Choe Sang-Hun and Bettina Wassener reported.

Author Solutions, a publisher of print-on-demand books based in Bloomington, Ind., has acquired Xlibris, a rival self-publisher, expanding its footprint in one of the fastest-growing segments of publishing, The New York Times's Mokoto Rich reported.

The German government on Thursday took a quarter stake in Commerzbank, the country's second-largest bank, as it stepped up efforts to stabilize the financial system and consolidate one of Europe's most fragmented banking landscapes, The New York Times's Carter Dougherty reported.

A picture on Monday with an obituary about Lt. Gen. Victor H. Krulak, a Marine commander who championed innovative tactics, was published in error in some copies, and a correction in this space on Thursday described the picture incorrectly. It showed General Krulak’s son, Gen. Charles C. Krulak, retired commandant of the Marine Corps, wearing four stars, the highest rank — not five — and a billed hat. (The correct picture showed his father wearing three stars and a soft cap.).

An article on Wednesday about the admission by the author Neale Donald Walsch that a personal Christmas essay he recently posted on the Web site Beliefnet.com was actually written by another author, Candy Chand, who published it 10 years ago, misspelled the given name of a Beliefnet.com executive whom Ms. Chand contacted. The executive is Elizabeth Sams, not Elisabeth.

Because of editing errors, an article on Thursday about the new Manhattan Marriage Bureau misstated the year that the city clerk’s office issued 66,600 licenses and performed about 40,000 marriages, and also misstated the year that 106,000 licenses were issued in Clark County, Nev., which includes Las Vegas. All figures were for 2007, not last year.

Because of an editing error, the London Journal article on Wednesday, about the Atheist Bus Campaign, a group that has placed advertisements questioning God’s existence on 800 buses across Britain, misstated the day the advertisements were introduced. It was on Tuesday, not Wednesday, Dec. 31.

Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 24 about the resignation of the speaker of the Iraqi Parliament, Mahmoud al-Mashhadani, misidentified his political party. It is the National Dialogue Council, not the Iraqi Islamic Party.
Tom Daschle’s confirmation hearing did not tell us much about how the incoming Obama administration intends to pay for its health care programs.

An article on Dec. 5 about financial problems at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles misstated the size of the museum’s endowment a decade ago. Some prominent foodies have been clamoring for change in the White House kitchen. But President-elect Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, have decided that Cristeta Comerford, the executive chef at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, will stay put, a transition official said on Thursday. Ms. Comerford, the first woman to hold the post of executive chef, has been in the job since 2005. And some lovers of fine food have argued that that is long enough. Ruth Reichl, the editor of Gourmet magazine, along with the restaurateurs Alice Waters and Danny Meyer, sent a letter to Mr. Obama offering to help him select someone new for the job.

DEUTSCH--Lisa B. We mourn the passing on January 7, 2009, of Lisa B. Deutsch, Litigation Counsel at Dewey & LeBoeuf. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Law School, Lisa was a summer associate at the firm's predecessor in the summer of 1995 and returned as a full-time associate in 1997 after a federal court clerkship. Lisa was known for her tremendous work ethic, her good humor and her dedication. She worked tirelessly for her clients, including pro bono clients like Olympic hopeful Oscar Pistorius, for whom she recently achieved great success. She was always ready with a smile and a remark that would make others around her smile as well. She was integral to the fabric of our institution, and we will miss her greatly. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lisa's parents, Ronald and Eleanor Deutsch, and her fiance Matthew Cohen. Dewey & LeBoeuf LLP

DAVIDSON--Hazel, passed away peacefully at home on January 7th. She was born in Atlanta on September 20, 1919, and studied Classics before marrying Donald Roth in 1937 and moving with him to Chicago, where their daughter Melissa was born. Hazel and Melissa moved to New York City in 1953, where Hazel lived on the Upper West Side for the rest of her life. She married Ira Davidson in 1956; Ira passed away in 1992. A lover and supporter of the arts, Hazel lived a full and adventurous life which she never failed to appreciate. Hazel is survived by her daughter Melissa Roth Bloch, her son-in-law Frank Bloch and their two children, Julia and Sara Bloch; her stepdaughter, Leslie Plotkin and her two children, Lisa and Andrew Plotkin.

SPOTA--Marie, died on January 6, 2009, at her home in Los Angeles, after a long and heroic battle with Alzheimer's disease. She is now at peace. She spent her life fighting for the rights of workers, the civil rights of all Americans, and for the happiness of her family. She was the devoted wife of George Spota, who she survived, and now joins. She was the adoring mother of George-Ann Hyams. She was the amazing mother - in - law of Peter Hyams. She was the doting grandmother to Christopher, John, and Nick Hyams, the grandmother-in-law of Lize Burr, and she was loving great-grandmother of Emma and Mazie Hyams. She was a woman of enormous generosity and heart to her many nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends. Funeral Services will be held at Pierce Brothers Chapel, 1218 Glendon Avenue in Westwood, on Friday at 1:00pm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, to honor her memory, all donations be sent to: The Marie Spota Fund c/o The Alzheimer's Association 5900 Wilshire Boulevard Suite 1100 Los Angeles, California 90036 Attention: Judy.

Eric Mangini said he would use his experiences with the Jets, good and bad, to make himself a better coach for the Cleveland Browns, who hired him less than two weeks after the Jets fired him. ''You learn so much from your experiences,'' Mangini said as the Browns introduced him Thursday at a news conference in Berea, Ohio. ''I tell players, win or lose, be honest. I ask myself that all the time. Nobody stops improving. I learned so many things over three years. There's no 'Dummies' guide to head coaching.''

He was much respected for his work within the labor movement, AFL-CIO and the Teamsters, where among other duties he served as Administrative Assistant to James R. Hoffa. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Navy as a medic. He received the Medal of the Negev from the State of Israel for whom he worked tirelessly. Reposing Saturday, January 10th from 2-4 and 6-8pm at George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, NY (914) 632-0324. Services and interment Sunday, January 11th at 11am. Contributions in his honor may be sent to a charity of your choosing.

A team of four Italian climbers and their Argentine guide stranded for almost two days on the Aconcagua in western Argentina, the highest mountain in the Americas, were rescued, the police said, adding that two members of the party had died. The rescue, which took less than three hours, was undertaken in extremely low temperatures along with heavy wind and snow. The group was ascending the 22,841-foot peak on Tuesday when a powerful storm forced them to shelter at the Polish Glacier, one of the glacial fields on the Aconcagua that climbers use as a base before attempting the summit.

MORGAN--Temple Emmet, (Brother Dominic Maria, OCSO), died on December 2, 2008, in Caldey Abbey, on Caldey Island off the coast of Wales. A Mass for the repose of his soul will be said on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 10am, in the Church of Saint Vincent De Paul, 123 West 23rd Street, New York, New York. Temple Emmet Morgan was born on May 10, 1922 in New York City. He was the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Denison Morgan. Descending from a prominent American family with illustrious ancestors, he was proudest of his descent from Thomas Addis Emmet, brother of the great Irish patriot Robert Emmet, who was hanged by the British in 1803. Following his service in the Army Air Corps during World War II, he returned to Harvard College. He was on the varsity crew and a member of the Porcellian Club. Two months before Commencement, on April 5, 1947, he was received into the Catholic Church by Fr. Leonard Feeney. From that moment he turned his back on his former life. Until 1988 he was active as a monk at Saint Benedict Center in Harvard, Massachusetts. At that time he left, seeking a stricter form of monastic life. In 1990 he entered Caldey Abbey, a monastery of the Cistercian Order of the Strict Observance, where he made his solemn profession on December 8, 1995. During his remaining years in Wales he touched the lives of many people. After a life of joy, he died in peace, having received his daily Holy Communion, surrounded by his brothers of the Order of Cistercians of the Strict Observance.

In leaving the Braves after 21 years, John Smoltz joins a small but distinguished group of players who toiled for at least two decades with their original team before moving on. That group includes Ty Cobb, below, who played for the Tigers for 21 years before joining the 1927 Philadelphia A's; Warren Spahn, who pitched for the Boston and Milwaukee Braves for 22 years before joining the 1965 Mets, where he played in one game with a briefly unretired Yogi Berra; and Willie Mays, who played for 21 years with the New York and San Francisco Giants before joining the 1972 Mets. A year later, Mays went to the World Series with the Mets, got two hits in seven at-bats and never played again.

New York is a city of characters. On the subway and in the streets, from the intensity of Midtown skyscrapers to the intimacy of neighborhood blocks barely known to anyone who does not live there, is a 305-square-mile parade of people with something to say. This begins a weekly series of portraits of individual New Yorkers. Photographs by Todd Heisler, interviews conducted and condensed by Sarah Kramer and Alexis Mainland.

NEIMETH--Richard, died on January 7th in his home in New York after a long illness, surrounded by his loving family. Beloved husband of Peggy (Sprung), cherished father of Deborah (George Barrett), Pamela (Norbert Lazar), Amy Sachs, and Lisa (Peter Dickstein). Grandfather of Kate, Zachary and Emma Barrett; Kylie and Cass Neimeth-Lazar; Joshua and Benjamin Safdie and Maggie Sachs; Jackson and Tess Neimeth-Dickstein. A graduate of Cornell University, he also attended the MBA program in Pharmaceutical Business Administration at Brooklyn College of Pharmacy. He received an honorary Ph.D. from Long Island University in 1994. Mr. Neimeth was founder and CEO of NMC Labs, a generic pharmaceutical company in Queens, New York. He was President of National Magnesia Company founded by his late father, Edward, in Queens, New York and Vice President and partner of Major Pharmaceutical, a generic drug wholesale distributor in Chicago. He served as Chairman of the Council of Overseers of the Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy, member of the Board of Trustees of Long Island University, member of the Community Board of Metropolitan Hospital in New York and member of the Board of Trustees of the Gunn Memorial Library in Washington, CT, where he had a home. He was a talented photographer and his photographs grace the walls of his many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice, VNS and Mt. Sinai Hospital liver program, care of Dr. Douglas Dieterich. Funeral services will be on Sunday, January 11 at 11:45am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be sitting shiva at the family's home in New York on Sunday evening from 6-8pm and Monday from 4-8pm.

My Sunday column is about sex trafficking again. It's based on interviews with brothel-owners and looks at how we can make sex slavery more risky and less profitable for those who engage in it. I think the key to eradicating it is to put ourselves more in the shoes of the traffickers; they're profit-maximizing business people, and if we change their incentives they'll turn to stealing motorcycles instead.

There's been some talk abut risks of deflation, but there's one alarming comparison I haven't seen made. The figure above shows that the CBO is currently projecting an output shortfall from the current slump comparable to the slump of the early 1980s. Actually, it's very close: if you compare the CBO's projections of unemployment from 2008 through 2012 with its estimate of the natural rate, we're looking at cumulative excess unemployment of 13.9 point-years; that compares with 13.7 point years from 1980 through 1986. (If the natural rate -- the unemployment rate that keeps inflation unchanged -- is 5 percent, and the actual unemployment rate averages 7 percent over a year, that's 2 point-years of excess unemployment.)

BERRY--Nancy Michaels, passed away peacefully on January 8, 2009. She was 80 years old. Nancy was born in Kansas City, Kansas, on September 3, 1928 to William and Allene Michaels, but grew up in Tulsa, Oklahoma. She graduated from Holland Hall School with highest honors. She was the valedictorian of her class each year of her attendance, and graduated when she was 15 years old. She received a scholarship to Wellesley College. In her junior year, she met and married, Charles N. Berry Jr., a fellow Oklahoman who was a student at Harvard Law School. Nancy and Charlie moved back to Oklahoma City, and raised four sons. Nancy went on to obtain her Bachelor's Degree in History, and a Master's Degree in International Relations from the University of Oklahoma. Through her work with the Junior League, she became passionately involved in numerous philanthropic causes. She worked for World Neighbors before becoming the Executive Director of the Oklahoma City Community Foundation. Nancy moved to New York City in 1980 where she worked for Project Orbis, which educated doctors around the world in advanced eye surgery techniques. She then went to work for the National Executive Service Corps, which provides management expertise to nonprofits throughout the United States, as their only paid executive. After retiring, she traveled extensively throughout Europe and the United States, making life - long friends wherever she went. Nancy always believed in living life to the fullest. She lived by the maxim, ''Carpe Diem''. Nancy is survived by countless friends, and her two sons, Charles Nelson Berry III of Seattle, Washington and Michaels Crittenden Berry, of Bainbridge Island, Washington. Her youngest two sons, David Shelby Berry and Chrisopher Norris Berry, predeceased her. She is also survived by her daughter-in-law, Paula Grant Berry, of Brooklyn, New York. She is also survived by her brother, Bill Michaels, and his wife, Kim, of Basking Ridge, New Jersey. She is also survived by seven grandchildren. There will be a Memorial Service at 4:00pm on Wednesday, January 14, 2009, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, located at Fifth Avenue and East 90th. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer a donation be made in her name to the Oklahoma City Community Foundation, located at 1000 N. Broadway, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma 73102.

MEEKER--Guy Bentley Sr.,died peacefully in New York on December 20, 2008 of cancer. Guy is deeply missed and lovingly remembered by his family as well as by his many cherished friends in New York, Miami, Nassau, and around the world.

If the Giants and the Eagles met on Saturday afternoon at Giants Stadium, their matchup might just evoke that epic battle in the snow that the Patriots and the Raiders engaged in seven years ago. But the game will be played Sunday at 1 p.m., when the only snow will be what's left over from the day before, some of which Giants and Eagles fans may just throw at each other. At game time, according to the Penn State Department of Meteorology, the temperature should be in the low-to-mid 30s. In Pittsburgh, where the Steelers take on the Chargers on Sunday at 4:45 p.m., the snow will have already passed through, too, Penn State said. Game-time temperature should be around 30. That's not all that forbidding, either.

The police plan to ban cars from miles of streets in downtown Washington on Inauguration Day so charter buses streaming into the city for Barack Obama's swearing-in have somewhere to park. But Dulles Airport in nearby Northern Virginia may do something more dramatic: close a runway to make space to put all the private planes. Runway 1 Left/19 Right, which is 11,500 feet long and 150 feet wide, Dulles's fourth runway, opened last November, and could provide parking space for about 100 planes, said Tara Hamilton, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority.

LEE--Thomas Sim, died on January 9, 2009 at Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY, from complications arising from cancer and a stroke suffered on August 18, 2007. A son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lee, he was born on August 18, 1937, and was a direct descendent of Thomas Sim Lee, second Governor of Maryland, and Charles Carroll, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. He graduated from Middlesex School and from Harvard University, Class of 1959. After service in the U.S. Army, he began a lifelong career in the securities industry in New York City. He was associated with several firms, most recently with Smith Barney. He was an active supporter and Board Member of the East Side Settlement House in New York City and an avid and accomplished bridge player and chef. Tom is survived by two sisters, Cynthia L. Russell (Mrs. John B. Russell) and Mary L. Lambert (Mrs. Paul C. Lambert) and a brother, Charles C. Lee. His sister, Eleanor L. Congdon, predeceased. He was a devoted and loving uncle to 18 nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88 Street, New York, NY, on Thursday, January 29, 2009, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

CLARKE--Charles V.,87, of New York, NY, died Thursday, January 8th at NY Presbyterian Hospital. He was born over P.J. Clarke's Saloon, one of six sons of James and Mary (Mahan) Clarke. He later enlisted in the US Army serving his country during WWII in the Air Corps. Mr. Clarke was the proprietor of P.J. Clarke's in New York City from 1946 to 1989. He was actively involved in AA for over 40 years. He was married for 61 years to Margaret ''Peggy'' (Cardon) Clarke until her death in 2007. A Mass will be held on Tuesday and visitation on Monday in Schoharie, NY. Further information is available at: langanfuneralhome.com

WILNER--Miriam, (Mitzi) Wilner in San Francisco on January 7, 2009, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Adolf Wilner; loving mother of Erica (Andrew) Rosenblatt, Cheri (Art) Kessner, and Susan (David) Wilner Golden. She was adored by her seven grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. A Holocaust survivor from Lvov, Poland, she immigrated to the United States with her husband in 1947 and lived in New York and subsequently in San Diego and San Francisco. Mitzi was dedicated to educating hundreds of school children about tolerance and the perils of prejudice. She was a volunteer speaker for The Holocaust Center of Northern California, and a docent for Daniels Story sponsored by the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. She also volunteered at California Pacific Medical Center, and she was a devoted member of Congregation Beth Sholom in San Francisco. Donations may be made in her memory to: Congregation Beth Sholom of San Francisco (1301 Clement Street, SF 94121); California Pacific Medical Center Foundation (2100 Webster Street, SF 94115); or Holocaust Center of Northern California (121 Steuart Street, SF, 94105).

(Starz) THE OTHER BOLEYN GIRL (2008) Natalie Portman, above left, plays a saucy Anne Boleyn, and Scarlett Johansson, above right, is her more somber sister, Mary, who together cater to the appetites of King Henry VIII (a glowering Eric Bana), while he is still wed to Catherine of Aragon (Ana Torrent). HIRSCH--Joseph A.,80, died January 9, 2009 after complications associated with Parkinson's Disease. Joe was the dean of American turf writers in the United States. He retired from the Daily Racing Form in 2003 after five decades, but always kept in touch with friends and the sport. He suffered from Parkinson's Disease for many years but handled it with dignity and strength. He is survived by his close cousins, Peter Krulewitch and Steven Jerski as well as a large family of friends and admirers. A Funeral Service will be held Sunday 10am at The Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Columbia University Center, 630 West 168th St., attn: Dr. Thomas Q. Morris, for research in Parkinson's Disease in honor of Joe Hirsch.

NEIMETH--Richard, died on January 7th in his home in New York after a long illness, surrounded by his loving family. Beloved husband of Peggy (Sprung), cherished father of Deborah (George Barrett), Pamela (Norbert Lazar), Amy Sachs, and Lisa (Peter Dickstein). Grandfather of Kate, Zachary and Emma Barrett; Kylie and Cass Neimeth-Lazar; Joshua and Benjamin Safdie and Maggie Sachs; Jackson and Tess Neimeth-Dickstein. A graduate of Cornell University, he also attended the MBA program in Pharmaceutical Business Administration at Brooklyn College of Pharmacy. He received an honorary Ph.D. from Long Island University in 1994. Mr. Neimeth was founder and CEO of NMC Labs, a generic pharmaceutical company in Queens, New York. He was President of National Magnesia Company founded by his late father, Edward, in Queens, New York and Vice President and partner of Major Pharmaceutical, a generic drug wholesale distributor in Chicago. He served as Chairman of the Council of Overseers of the Arnold and Marie Schwartz College of Pharmacy, member of the Board of Trustees of Long Island University, member of the Community Board of Metropolitan Hospital in New York and member of the Board of Trustees of the Gunn Memorial Library in Washington, CT, where he had a home. He was a talented photographer and his photographs grace the walls of his many friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice, VNS and Mt. Sinai Hospital liver program, care of Dr. Douglas Dieterich. Funeral services will be on Sunday, January 11 at 11:45am at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will be sitting shiva at the family's home in New York on Sunday evening from 6-8pm and Monday from 4-8pm.

For the third time in history, the Hollywood Foreign Press Association gave two dramatic acting trophies to the same person. Kate Winslet seemed more surprised that anybody by the honors, trying to thank the other nominees - Meryl Streep, Kristin Scott Thomas, and "who was that other one in the drama category? Yes, Angelina." And there was another, Anne Hathaway.
Mickey Rourke on the long road back:

PHILADELPHIA EAGLES at ARIZONA CARDINALSSunday, 3 p.m. Eastern, FoxUniversity of Phoenix Stadium, Glendale, Ariz.Early line: Eagles by 3Were the Cardinals keeping this well-balanced team under wraps all season, hoping to catch their playoff opponents off guard? Was Donovan McNabb's benching just a ploy to heighten the drama of this season? Is there anybody who six weeks ago would have predicted that this would be the N.F.C. championship game? The Cardinals may have better insight into the Eagles' late-season run than any other team since they were the ones who started it - with a 48-20 loss at Philadelphia on Thanksgiving. The Cardinals have been a far better team in the playoffs than they were late in the season, after it was clear they had a lock on the division and seemed to give up. The Cardinals' defense has been reborn, but the pass defense will get a test from the Eagles. Philadelphia had 437 yards of offense in the earlier meeting with Brian Westbrook and Donovan McNabb each accounting for four touchdowns.

"Slumdog Millionaire" continued its improbable run (a third of the movie is in Hindi, after all), racking up four Globes, including best picture, best director, best screenplay and best score, a suite of major awards that suggests the dance may not be over for this particular Cinderella. The Hollywood Foreign Press lived up to its name in crushing hard on this hybrid of a Bollywood love story and throbbing Hollywood storytelling.
"Slumdog Millionaire" wins best motion picture drama, beating "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button," "Frost/Nixon," "The Reader" and "Revolutionary Road."

Mickey Rourke ("The Wrestler"), beats out Leonardo DiCaprio ("Revolutionary Road"), Frank Langella ("Frost/Nixon"), Sean Penn ("Milk") and Brad Pitt ("The Curious Case of Benjamin Button") for best actor in a motion picture drama.

"Mad Men," which AMC announced last week is coming back for a third season (hopefully with creator Matthew Weiner), won the Golden Globe for best television drama, its second year in a row. It beat "Dexter," "House," "In Treatment" and "True Blood."
For what it's worth, the very first words of the Golden Globes ceremony, the ones you don't get to hear on television, are, Applause in the room, please!

Kate Winslet wins her second Golden Globe of the evening, this time for a drama, "Revolutionary Road." She beat out Anne Hathaway ("Rachel Getting Married"), Angelina Jolie ("The Changeling"), Meryl Streep ("Doubt") andKristin Scott Thomas ("I've Loved You for So Long").
Woody Allen's "Vicky Cristina Barcelona" captures the Golden Globe for best motion picture comedy or musical, slipping past "Burn After Reading," "Happy-Go-Lucky," "In Bruges" and "Mamma Mia!"

Colin Farrell, a star of "In Bruges", was the surprise winner in the best actor in a motion picture comedy or musical category, beating out Javier Bardem ("Vicky Cristina Barcelona"), James Franco ("Pineapple Express"), Brendan Gleeson ("In Bruges") and Dustin Hoffman ("Last Chance Harvey").

Danny Boyle wins best director for his work on Slumdog Millionaire," beating Stephen Daldry ("The Reader"), David Fincher ("The Curious Case of Benjamin Button"), Ron Howard ("Frost/Nixon") and Sam Mendes ("Revolutionary Road").

Fred is zonked, so I can't get his final thoughts on Globes fashion, and Toby, being a Lab, loves everybody, so he's not reliable. I'm not sure how you go from the sleepy Jonas brothers to Johnny Depp, but it would be nice to seem some genuine individuality and cool among young male stars. This was the night of the cloned dude: thatched black hair and scruffy beard.

For a long time now I've been obsessed with suburban and exurban master-planned communities and how to make them better. But as the economy and the mortgage crisis just seem to get worse, and gas prices continue to plunge, the issues around housing have changed dramatically. The problem now isn't really how to better design homes and communities, but rather what are we going to do with all the homes and communities we're left with.
Sally Hawkins, the star of Mike Leigh's "Happy-Go-Lucky" is on her first trip through the prize machinery and it shows in charming ways.

Tina Fey captured another Golden Globe for "30 Rock," winning for best actress in a television comedy or musical. She beat out Christina Applegate ("Samantha Who"), America Ferrera ("Ugly Betty"), Debra Messing ("The Starter Wife") and Mary-Louise Parker ("Weeds").

A.R. Rahman won best original score, motion picture, for his work on "Slumdog Millionaire." He triumphed over Alexandre Desplat ("The Curious Case of Benjamin Button"), Clint Eastwood ("Changeling"), James Newton Howard ("Defiance") and Hans Zimmer ("Frost/Nixon").

"30 Rock" captured the Golden Globe for best television comedy or muscial, winning over "Californication," "Entourage," "The Office" and "Weeds." Tracy Morgan gives the best acceptance speech of the evening so far.

Paul Giamatti won the Golden Globe for best actor in a miniseries or TV movie for his title role performance in "John Adams." He beat out Ralph Fiennes ("Bernard and Doris"), Kiefer Sutherland ("24:Redemption), Kevin Spacey ("Recount") and Tom Wilkinson ("Recount").

Kate Winslet was anxious to get inside to the Golden Globes ceremony, but not because she thought it was going to be her night. "I really don't think I have a chance," she told the Bagger of her chances as supporting actress for "The Reader," an unsympathetic turn as a former concentration camp guard in a relationship with a young man.

Alec Baldwin won his second Golden Globe for best actor in a television comedy or musical for his portrayal of a TV network honcho on "30 Rock." He prevailed over Steve Carell ("The Office"), Kevin Connolly ("Entourage"), David Duchovny ("Californication") and Tony Shalhoub ("Monk").

Simon Beaufoy, the screenwriter of "Slumdog Millionaire," nabbed the Golden Globe for best screenplay, beating out Peter Morgan ("Frost/Nixon"), Eric Roth ("The Curious Case of Benjamin Button"), John Patrick Shanley ("Doubt") and David Hare ("The Reader").

Laura Linney, for her role in "John Adams", won best actress in a miniseries or TV movie, beating out Judi Dench ("Cranford"), Catherine Keener ("American Crime"), Shirley MacLaine ("Coco Chanel") and Susan Sarandon ("Bernard and Doris").

"Waltz With Bashir," Israel's entry for best foreign-language film in the upcoming Oscars, has won the Globe in that category, beating out "The Baader Meinhof Complex" (Germany), "Everlasting Moments" (Sweden/Denmark), "Gomorra" (Italy) and "I've Loved You So Long" (France).
In certain quarters, when discussing drinks, it's probably best not to mention the Old Fashioned.

Heath Ledger, whose performance as the Joker in "The Dark Knight" has made him a favorite in the Oscar race, has won the Golden Globe for best supporting actor in a motion picture. He beat out Tom Cruise ("Tropic Thunder"), Robert Downey Jr. ("Tropic Thunder"), Ralph Fiennes ("The Duchess") and Philip Seymour Hoffman ("Doubt").
HBO picks up another Golden Globe, this time for "John Adams," which beat out "A Raisin in the Sun," "Bernard and Doris," "Cranford" and "Recount."
Julio Ponce, a 55-year old chef, is one of 50,000 jobless New Yorkers expected to become ineligible for extensions to unemployment benefits.

Sally Hawkins, the irrepressible heroine of "Happy-Go-Lucky," was named best actress in a motion picture musical or comedy. The other nominees were Rebecca Hall ("Vicky Christina Barcelona"), Frances McDormand ("Burn After Reading"), Meryl Streep ("Mamma Mia!") and Emma Thompson ("Last Chance Harvey").
"Wall-E," the latest Pixar/Disney feature, was named outstanding animated feature, beating "Bolt" and "Kung Fu Panda."

Ari Folman, director of "Waltzing with Bashir," the Israeli animated documentary about the 1980s invasion of Lebanon would not cop to having a good time."It's not fun, all of this, but it's funny," he said. "It's not for directors anyway. We can come and go, get inside and no one will notice us. I'm planning on just watching it all and taking in the spectacle."
Gabriel Byrne of "In Treatment," beat out Michael C. Hall ("Dexter"), Jon Hamm ("Mad Men"), Hugh Laurie ("House") and Jonathan Rhys Meyers ("The Tudors") in the best actor in a TV drama category.

Anna Paquin, the star of "True Blood," HBO's vampire series from Alan Ball ("Six Feet Under") has beaten out Sally Field ("Brothers and Sisters"), Mariska Hargitay (Law & Order: Special Victims Unit"), January Jones ("Mad Men") and Kyra Sedgwick ("The Closer."

The message at the Golden Globes this year seems to be that it's okay for Americans to take their hands out of increasingly empty pockets and put them in the air, or at least applaud some of the more remarkable movie work of the past year. High-end fashion maintains it tenacious grip on the imagination, at least as expressed on the red carpet here. As Cathy Horyn pointed out, Eva Longoria of "Desperate Housewives" was draped in a Reem Arca tomato red dress with a train that seemed almost as long as the carpet, a frock that had the fashion press drooling.
The Eagles moved one step closer to the Super Bowl on Sunday after beating the Giants, 23-11, in the N.F.C. divisional playoffs.

Angelina Jolie, nominated for her role as a mother who is judged crazy in pursuit of her child in "Changeling," talked about her director Clint Eastwood, who doesn't have much of a presence tonight at the Golden Globes, but is likely to have a big footprint in the Oscar race with the surging "Gran Torino."
I've nearly finished polishing my nails. I mean, things have been so slow. The Glamastrator hasn't had much to frisk or anything I want to see.
That spiky collar at Eva Mendes's throat seems to be the jewelry statement of the night, though doesn't it make her head look small? On a many-pronged plate?

Evan Rachel Wood looks absolutely stunning and grownup in a black tiered dress; might be Chanel. Like many of the actresses on the carpet, she's wearing her hair neat and swept-up. Amanda Seyfried ("Mamma Mia") added a frieze of pincurls. And I see Debra Messing is going for a big frisky ponytail. Did she tease it? Now the Glamastrator is marking her up. What a sport!
Jeremy Piven, nominated tonight for best supporting actor for his characterization of Ari Gold in "Entourage," will indeed be here, if the placard with his name sitting at table 113 is indication.
"The Fabric of Human Nature "

Now that I have the dogs, Fred and Toby, bedded down to watch the Golden Globes, I can concentrate on the red carpet. It's so funny to see beautiful young women glancing down awkwardly at their silk bodices as if something might be wrong or maybe they don't -oops! - belong in the dress. So far, at this early stage, strapless dresses seem to prevail: Jennifer Morrison ("House") in vivid blue, Angela Kinsey ("The Office") in a rusty red, and Eva Longoria-Parker in a scarlet Reem Acra. The dress looks painted on.

David Moritz designed the new Golden Globe award that will be handed out this year, and he said the weight -- 5.5 pounds -- was carefully calibrated. Too heavy and winning one might become an aerobic activity for some of the tiny stars that will be clutching them; too light, and the thrill would be gone as soon as it arrived.

Inside the ballroom, finally. The theme here isn't nautical, I don't think, but the stage looks distinctly like a cross-section of the Golden Hinde (Sir Francis Drake's famous 16th-century sailing ship.) There might be a connection between Drake's ship and the two spheres spinning clockwise on either side of the stage. But unlike the Golden Hinde, it's all done in champagne pink.

Out on the carpet, the bleachers did not get the memo about how dreary these times are. Under a surprisingly brutal sun, the audience was seismically loud when the announcer made the smallest pitch for a warm-up run of "screaming, yelling, and applause." "Wow, thank you," came the disembodied voice. The evening's producers would like the television audience to be as jazzed, if not as loud.

One of the more charming rituals here appears to involve drinking Moet & Chandon White Star champagne straight from the bottle -- tiny little bottles, actually. It requires a tiny sipping attachment on top, but no brown bag, as far as this reporter can see.

I don't know how constructors keep coming up with new themes. The obvious ones have already been used: the Three Stooges, the four elements, the five Platonic solids, the six wives of Henry VIII, the seven dwarfs, the eight (or is it nine?) planets. Or maybe Plato's still open, but it's hard and yet constructors keep coming through. It's like trying to find a URL for your new company. However creative you are, the first 20 you think of are already taken.

DETROIT -- The griffin is a legendary beast with the head of a lion, wings of the eagle and a home in the Saab logo. And to help finish the lifetime of the 9-5 sedan, Saab has trimmed out a special edition called Griffin. It has a matte grille, a black instrument panel and fancy seats from the top-line Aero models. "Griffin" is spelled out on the fender.

It is a testament to the enduring appeal of Clint Eastwood that his little film, "Gran Torino," is occupying conversation in all corners of the room on Golden Globes weekend even though he and his film are nominated for nothing more than original song. But while Hollywood loves a great movie, a wonderful story or a surpassing performance, one thing its denizens love above all else is lucre. And "Gran Torino," which was made for a budget that would not fund craft services on a blockbuster, did huge bank this weekend, almost $30 million (and more than $40 million overall).

Tim Tebow has made it official. He will be coming back to Florida next season.

Welcome to our gametracking post of today's divisional playoff game between the Eagles and the Giants. You can check out the action below, scrolling backward, as it happened. Please take time to vent or celebrate in our comments section.

If you need to get your mind off the Giants, you're in the right place. This weekend's final Divisional Round game pits the Chargers, winners of five straight, against the Steelers, winners of six of their last seven. When these two teams met in the regular season, it was the Steelers who squeaked by with an 11-10 win. However, this is a different San Diego team than the one we saw lose three straight in November. Will we see a different result? As an added bonus, this post is a Giants-free zone. Yes, out of sight, out of mind.

There are few more reliable purgatories than the valet parking at the Chateau Marmont after or during a big event. There is abundant sound, fury and wattage, but the car never comes. "Can I get a status check on number 170," the Bagger said after an hour, adopting the nomenclature of his imprisoners, Stockholm-style. Here is the status: We will tell you it's on the way and then it will not come and then you will ask again. The Bagger should have known better, but his pal succumbed to the Roach Motel allure - easy to get in, impossible to get out.

Politics | "Inaugural poets to date have not had the most sterling track record," a poet writes. Here's hoping Obama friend Elizabeth Alexander -- she of "slashing, politically charged" verse like "The Venus Hottentot (1825)" -- has better luck than Robert Frost, who did not burnish his rep with lines like, "Our venture in revolution and outlawry / Has justified itself in freedom's story." Alas, "the public voice has never been the long suit of American poetry, despite its roots in Whitman ..." [Wall Street Journal]

I'm not a fan of universal remote controls. You know, the kind that can operate even scores of home theater gear, lighting and even drapes? While I've tested many over the years, I don't find the compromises of the affordable ones, at least, to make a purchase worthwhile (and the unaffordable ones, with prices that reach high into the hundreds, are just ridiculous).

Politics | Rare is the leader who can actually write well, but perceptive writing offers a window into governing style, from Lincoln to Disraeli to Obama, an essay says. "It signifies the watchful eye and patiently attentive ear; a proper humility in the face of the multiplex character of human society; and, most of all, a belief in the power of the writer's imagination to comprehend and ultimately reconcile the manifold contradictions in his teeming world." [Wall Street Journal]
South Cobb High School’s band director, Zachary Cogdill, set the Blue Eagles apart with a portfolio that captured the spirit the 95-member troop.

Just got back from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas-the biggest trade show in North America, although it didn't seem quite as big this year. (An editor told me that he witnessed four slightly drunk electronics-company reps walk to the curb; to their happiness and amazement, they found a taxi immediately. Giving a hip-hop sign, one of them turned and shouted with glee, "RECESSION!!" He may not be quite so happy about the recession as the months drag on.)

Kendall Coyne scored on a power-play goal 6 minutes 47 seconds into overtime as the United States won the world women’s under-18 hockey championship, defeating Canada, 3-2, in Fussen, Germany. Goaltender Alex Rigsby made 38 saves for the United States, which finished the tournament 4-1-0-0 to successfully defend its title. Brittany Ammerman and Taylor Wasylk also scored for the United States.
Andy Roddick lost Saturday to the defending champion Andy Murray, 6-4, 6-2, in the final of the Qatar Open, a tuneup for the Australian Open.

Benjamin Raich of Austria won the classic men’s World Cup giant slalom on the steep Kuonisbaergli course in Adelboden, Switzerland, and Bode Miller failed to complete a race for the eighth time in 16 events.

The men’s and women’s singles champions will earn $1.42 million at the Australian Open, which is increasing overall prize money by 12 percent. All the extra money is going to the singles finalists, the Tennis Australia chief executive Steve Wood said in a statement Saturday. The losing singles finalists will received $706,300. The Australian Open, the first of the year’s four tennis majors, starts Jan. 19 in Melbourne.

Police union officials want an investigation of the father of Green Bay Packers receiver Donald Driver, saying he lied about a police beating and being forced to swallow cocaine. The union sent a letter to the Harris County district attorney requesting a perjury investigation of Marvin Driver Jr. after an internal investigation cleared three officers of wrongdoing in the arrest.
Tina Maze of Slovenia won a women’s World Cup giant slalom in Maribor, Slovenia, and Lindsey Vonn finished seventh.
Asia took a commanding 6 ½-to-1 ½ lead over Europe by dominating fourball play at the match-play Royal Trophy in Bangkok.

The Columbus Blue Jackets acquired left wing Mike Blunden from the Chicago Blackhawks in a trade for right wing Adam Pineault. The Blue Jackets assigned Blunden to their A.H.L. affiliate in Syracuse. The 22-year-old Blunden has tallied three goals and seven assists in 37 games with the Blackhawks’ A.H.L. affiliate this season. He was drafted into the N.H.L. in 2005.

Venus Williams dominated Vera Zvonareva, 6-2, 6-2, to give Team Americas the victory over Russia in the Hong Kong team tournament. Williams finished her only warm-up event before the Australian Open without dropping a set in singles play.
Annika Sorenstam married Mike McGee, four weeks after she ended her Hall of Fame career.

Politics | Cass Sunstein, the much-quoted academic reportedly tapped as Obama's "regulatory czar," says government should benignly "nudge" people toward better choices using the insights of behavioral economics. But this reviewer argues that, far from being a "third way" for politics, Sunstein's "libertarian paternalism" could "empower, not limit, political elites" for any ideological end; "accepting the legitimacy of certain nudges may eventually diminish the value we place on liberty." [Reason]
Capron Hannay and Matthew Levine met as members of the Blue Hill Troupe, but got to know each other after putting in long hours of rehearsal for Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Yeoman of the Guard."

History | Never mind the film "Valkyrie," a reviewer says. Three new books demonstrate that "the history of German resistance to the Nazis is not quite as straightforward as a movie-maker might like." There was a "moral murkiness" to plotters' motives (see also the Week in Review), glossed over in postwar Germany's attempts to feel better about itself. [Times of London]

An article last Sunday about a visiting priest at St. Vito’s Catholic Church in Mamaroneck, who is accused of sexually abusing a woman, misstated the role of the Hispanic Resource Center of Larchmont and Mamaroneck in raising awareness about sex-related crimes since the priest’s arrest. The center says it would take part in a workshop to help women understand such crimes if the police department organized a session about the case and related issues; the center itself is not planning a workshop.

A calendar listing last Sunday misstated the hours and admission prices for the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington. The museum is open from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Tuesdays through Fridays, and 1 to 5 p.m. Saturdays and Sundays. Admission is $8 for adults, $6 for those 62 and over, $5 for students 10 and over, and free for children under 10, with discounts for Huntington residents.

The women in picture No. 24 are Anne Goodwin, at left, and her daughter Alexandra Goodwin; they are not Susan de Saint Phalle and Françoise Amelie de Saint Phalle.
Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday on the wedding of Tamar Schwartz and David Wise misstated the day of the ceremony. It was the day of the report, not Jan. 3.

Depending on whom you asked, Mercedes was either showing the cars outside of the show held at the Cobo Center to save the expense of a press conference during these austere times, or simply booking a big enough space to hold the 650 guests expected to come.

Among today's headlines:

With specialty food stores and every kind of restaurant, New York is an eater’s paradise for the well-to-do. But as the economy slows, more of the city’s residents are struggling to pay for rent, utilities and other necessities without scrimping on food. Inexpensive foods are often calorie-dense but nutritionally deficient, and such a diet can contribute to health problems, including diabetes, which is increasing among the poor more than among the wealthy.
Urban institutions such as the Brooklyn Museum and the Detroit Institute of the Arts are rethinking their missions in a push for survival.

The cover article in the Travel section this weekend, about the 44 Places to Go in 2009, does not include Nos. 32 to 44. Those can be found at nytimes.com/travel, as indicated in the text of No. 31 on Page 14.

An obituary last Sunday about Oliver Lincoln Lundquist, an architect and industrial designer who led the team that created the United Nations logo, misstated the given name of the designer of the first version. He is Donal McLaughlin, not Donald.
The Rockets turned a 1-point halftime deficit into a durable double-digit lead, delivering a 96-76 blowout defeat.
A headline last Sunday with an obituary about the film actor Edmund Purdom misstated his age in some copies. He was 84, not 82.

The Memphis Grizzlies re-signed forward Darius Miles on Saturday despite a threat of legal action by the Portland Trail Blazers, who had waived him due to injury.

A chart last Sunday about student ratings of Barack Obama, Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Jill Biden as professors misidentified the location of Widener University School of Law, where Mr. Biden has taught. It has campuses in Wilmington, Del., and Harrisburg, Pa. It is not in Scranton, Pa.
Baltimore’s defense coordinator, Rex Ryan, will interview Sunday for the Jets’ and the St. Louis Rams’ head-coaching vacancies.
Gov. David A. Paterson and Caroline Kennedy were said to have met in person for the first time to discuss her interest in being appointed to the U.S. Senate.
A chart last Sunday about the way in which colleges weigh applicants’ ability to pay misidentified the state in which Dartmouth College is located. It is in New Hampshire, not Massachusetts.

The Keeping Score column last Sunday, about the shortcomings of major college football’s Bowl Championship Series, omitted the co-author of a study that appeared last spring in The Journal of Quantitative Analysis in Sports that proposed a playoff system for the sport. In addition to Brady T. West, Madhur Lamsal also wrote the paper.

An article in some editions last Sunday about a decision by the State Court of Appeals that cast doubt on the accuracy of city sidewalk maps relied upon by trial lawyers in personal-injury cases misspelled the surname of a former city corporation counsel who said of trial lawyers in a 1983 interview, “I think they prefer streets to be in bad shape so they can bring more lawsuits.” He is Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., not Schwartz.
NEW YORK.

An article last Sunday about the reputation and tactics of the New York Police Department under the Bloomberg administration misstated the size of the department’s intelligence division and the number of surveillance cameras in Lower Manhattan. The division has more than 600 officers — not 1,000, which is the total number assigned to counterterrorism duties. And although the department originally planned to have 1,000 cameras downtown at the end of 2008, only about 180 are up, with the deadline for the rest pushed back to 2011.

David Hajdu superbly captured the iconoclastic hero that Will Elder was to America’s youth in the dull ’50s and beyond (Dec. 28). And while his article was 99 percent lavish praise, the last paragraph left us feeling as though Willie wasted more than half his career on one of the most extravagantly illustrated comic strips in history — Playboy’s “Little Annie Fanny.” Will Elder himself would certainly take exception to the idea that he wasted his time exploring previously uncharted territory. The “Little Annie Fanny” watercolor technique alone has, at the very least, astounded artists and critics alike. Each panel was a beautifully executed painting. From our perspective, Will Elder delivered on his end of the “Little Annie Fanny” bargain. The downside of “Little Annie Fanny” was always, of course, that it was edited by committee, a process that just does not work in art and satire. “Annie” did, however, afford Will the time to paint oils, still lifes, landscapes, portraits and other personal projects that Hajdu extolled. I guess you take the good with the bad, and Will’s part of “Annie” was really rather good.

HIRSCH--Joseph A.,80, died January 9, 2009 after complications associated with Parkinson's Disease. Joe was the dean of American turf writers in the United States. He retired from the Daily Racing Form in 2003 after five decades, but always kept in touch with friends and the sport. He suffered from Parkinson's Disease for many years but handled it with dignity and strength. He is survived by his close cousins, Peter Krulewitch and Steven Jerski as well as a large family of friends and admirers. A Funeral Service will be held Sunday 10am at The Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Columbia University Center, 630 West 168th St., attn: Dr. Thomas Q. Morris, for research in Parkinson's Disease in honor of Joe Hirsch.

AT 62, Jane Birkin -- the singer, actress, fashion icon and onetime girlfriend of Serge Gainsbourg -- admits that she has been offered ''purses of gold'' to write an autobiography. Instead, she has put it all to music. ''I don't have a very good memory,'' she said. ''It's more like a washing machine.'' ''Enfants d'Hiver,'' which was released in the United States this week, is the first album she has written herself; it takes the listener through her life, starting with childhood summers on the Isle of Wight. (The cover photo shows her there at age 12.) There are songs written for her daughters and her lovers, and a track called ''Madame'' about growing old. ''People call me that with such respect,'' she said, ''but I still look at myself as an adolescent.'' Of course, there is also a ballad about Serge, portraying him as a ghost at the window. ''He was the greatest poet in France since Baudelaire,'' she said. ''I miss him greatly.''

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Dec. 27, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

LET IT BEGIN HERE! April 19, 1775: The Day the American Revolution Began. Written and illustrated by Don Brown. Roaring Brook. $17.95. (Ages 6 to 10) ''One of the most famous days in American history'' comes to life in this account. Using a blunt, expressive style -- except for redcoats and splashes of blood, the watercolors are mostly in shades of brown -- the author conveys the human scale of the revolution that began in a field in Lexington (some images make the age guidance of 6 seem on the young side). The book's sourcing could be more informative, but as history lessons go, this one is fast-paced and accessible.

FRISCH--Dolly Hemphill. Born August 26, 1928, died on December 9, 2008. Married to the late Robert E. Frisch, she is survived by her children, Katharine, Robert, Peter, and ten grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Rye, NY on February 21 at 11am.

THE British jewelry designer Fiona Paxton spent 15 years creating prints and embroideries for the likes of Chloé, Armani and Moschino before deciding it wasn't really her thing. ''I just didn't feel strongly about patterns anymore,'' she said. ''I wanted my statement to be in the form of jewelry.'' Her first collection incorporates the handcraft of the Indian artisans she has worked with for years. Each necklace, scarf and bracelet is designed like an embroidered garment, with a mosaic of glass and metal beads hand-stitched onto tulle and affixed with chains. It makes for particularly striking adornments that have caught the eye of Hilary Swank, Drew Barrymore and the artist Marilyn Minter. And the pieces, priced rather inexpensively, are doing brisk business: Barneys is on its second re-order, and Curve sold nearly a dozen in their first week in store.

SULLIVAN--Bradford E.,77, died peacefully on December 31, 2008. He leaves seven nieces and nephews and many friends who adored him. A graduate of the University of Maine, he also trained at the American Theatre Wing in New York. He proudly served in the U.S. Army during the Korean War. Sullivan was a character actor whose film credits include Slap Shot, The Prince of Tides, The Untouchables, Sister Act 2, and The Abyss. He had roles in several television series including NYPD, Nothing Sacred, and I'll Fly Away. He made his Broadway debut in 1977 and was nominated for the Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Featured Actor in a Musical for ''Working.'' He also had roles in Orpheus Descending and a stage adaption of On the Waterfront. He retired in 2000 and always remained a member of the Screen Actors Guild. He lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was a dedicated mentor to school children, had a deep affection for the Chinese people, and an unwavering Christian belief which guided him through his very exceptional life. There was no pretense in his approach to life. He had a special attachment for the people he loved and appreciated them without reservation. He will always be remembered by those who loved him for the richness of his life, the care he gave to others, and the integrity of his values.

DAVID LETTERMAN Today is a historic day down in Washington because five living presidents had lunch together. George Herbert Walker Bush, George W. THE NEWS Israeli ground forces swept into the Gaza Strip, the densely populated coastal Palestinian enclave between Israeli and Egyptian territory, from which Israel had withdrawn its troops and settlements in 2005. BEHIND THE NEWS Last weekend's incursion followed a week of Israeli airstrikes. Israel said its air and ground assault was meant to stop the intensifying rocket attacks on civilian areas of southern Israel, especially after a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas, the militant group that controls the Palestinian government in Gaza, lapsed on Dec. 19. Israel moved quickly to cut the Gaza Strip in two and to attack Hamas fighters and destroy its weapons and facilities.

''It was like riding a tiger, not knowing how to get off without being eaten.'' Ramalinga Raju, who just resigned as chairman of the Satyam Computer Services, a big outsourcing company. He described in a letter to his board how a small financial discrepancy had mushroomed into one of the biggest scandals in Indian corporate history.

Soilange Villagran, 49, tapped on a computer keyboard at the Grace Institute on the Upper East Side. She looked well put together and cheerful, showing little sign of the strain she has been through in recent years. ''I have a concept of presence -- it is very important,'' said Ms. Villagran, a mother of three, during a break from her computer class. But her body aches. She has lupus, a chronic autoimmune disease that attacks normal tissue.

THE housekeeper -- not in uniform -- instantly answers the doorbell at the author Nelson DeMille's hillside Tudor mansion in the topographically distinctive section of Garden City known as the Hill. It's the only authentic hill in town, with room for only a couple dozen homes, none nondescript. Especially not this $4 million dream house, 10,000 square feet of imported slate, stone, Brazilian mahogany and plaster that is connecting Mr. DeMille, a builder's son, to his inner squire.

RENWICK--John Phillip Jr.,of Bedford, NY died January 8, 2009 at age 87. He was predeceased by his wife, Louise Husted Renwick and is survived by their sons: John P. Renwick III of Katonah, NY, James B. Renwick of Bedford, NY, David R. Renwick of Rehobeth, MA and their wives: Meryl S. Renwick, Marjorie B. Renwick and Terell N. Renwick. He is also survived by his sister, Beatrice R. Jordan of Newtown Square, PA and ten grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren, as well as several nieces and nephews. He attended Taft School and Trinity College, served in the Army in WWII and played field hockey in the 1948 Olympics. For many years he owned and managed Renwick and Winterling Real Estate in Bedford. Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to St. Matthews Church, Bedford, NY 10506. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthews on January 13, at 1pm.

EXCEPT perhaps for Jimmy Carter, Barack Obama arrives at the White House having the fewest obligations to the established political order in modern times. But administrations never really start from scratch, no matter how stark the change in policies from their predecessors. Last week, at Mr. Obama's urging and President Bush's invitation, the former presidents gathered for the ultimate power lunch to trade stories and advice. We've broadened that gathering to list some of the ideas, traits and personnel from previous administrations that may guide President Obama. BILL MARSH

THINK AGAIN Suppose that in the long run Gov. Rod Blagojevich is cleared of all charges, and suppose that in the short run his Senate appointee, Roland Burris, is denied a seat and someone else is appointed in his place. What then? Is the second appointee now dismissed because his or her appointment was ''tainted'' (he or she reached office as the result of an injustice)? Does the state start all over again and hold a new election? Questions like these highlight the difficulties and conundrums that arise once the lawfulness of an official action is made to depend on the purity of the person who performs it. If the rectitude of the officeholder is crucial, how far back does one go in an effort to validate it? College? High school? Grade school? Sand box? -- Stanley Fish,

MORGAN--Charles, Jr. The American Civil Liberties Union expresses its sorrow for the loss of civil rights lawyer Charles Morgan, Jr., who died of complications from Alzheimer's disease on January 8th at the age of 78. A native of Birmingham, Alabama, Morgan courageously fought the city's segregationist leaders in the early 1960s. After losing his law practice for condemning the Birmingham church bombing in 1963 that caused the death of four young black girls, Morgan established the southern regional office of the ACLU in Atlanta, which continues today as one of the nation's foremost defenders of voting rights. He later served as Director of the ACLU Washington Legislative Office before entering private practice. A pioneer civil rights lawyer, Morgan was involved in many landmark cases before the Supreme Court. The civil rights movement owes great gratitude to Mr. Morgan for his historical accomplishments. The ACLU shares that appreciation and extends our deepest sympathy to his wife Camille and son Charles.
To the Sports Editor: ''Oklahoma City Is a Winner, Even Though the Thunder Isn't'' (Jan. 6) implies that Oklahoma City and Seattle are comparable markets.

USING found materials like twigs, buttons, old sequined clothes and broken screen doors, the artist Nick Cave (as opposed to the musician Nick Cave) constructs what he calls Soundsuits -- wondrous costumes that confound even him. ''Are they an African ceremonial thing? Tibetan? Asian?'' questioned Mr. Cave, whose new show of Soundsuits is on view at the Jack Shainman Gallery. The answer is all of the above, with a little George Clinton, drag queen, medieval knight and Wall-E thrown in. ''It's a new hybrid,'' said Mr. Cave, who also is chairman of the fashion department at the Art Institute of Chicago. ''A whole new identity formed from other people's junk.'' And if the strange and beautiful structures evoke a sense of fear -- well, that's the point. ''It's what makes them so powerful,''
Theater Jason Zinoman
