SQUIRE--C.B. ''Chick'', editor and author, 88, died peacefully in his sleep January 4 of natural causes in Asheville, NC. Mr. Squire was born in Caldwell, NJ and attended Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, the University of Connecticut and New York University. Between 1940 and the present he had a long and varied career as an editor, author, correspondent or consultant for many different news organizations including Newsweek, CBS News, The Wilton (CT) Bulletin, The Ridgefield (CT) Press, The Bridgeport (CT) Post-Telegram, The New York Daily News, The Daily Star, Dar al-Hayat, in Beirut, Lebanon (founding editor), An-Nida, a weekly newspaper in English, in Beirut, The New York Times, The Religious News Service, McGraw-Hill Publications, The Chicago Tribune, London Illustrated News, Acorn Press, Inc. (Ridgefield, CT), Platt's Oilgram (managing editor), Early American Life, State Magazine, International Oil News, Petrochemical News, Grolier Encyclopedia, World Petroleum Magazine, and Mountain Xpress, in Asheville, NC. From 1942-1946 Mr. Squire served as a volunteer ambulance driver for the American Field Service with the British Eighth and Fourteenth Armies in the Middle East, North Africa, Italy and India, and received various British and Allied army campaign medals. He was instrumental in securing veterans' recognition for AFS volunteers who served with Allied forces in World War II. He was a founding member of the AFS International Scholarship Program, which continues today. In 1999 he received the Oscar Arias Foundation Peace Award. He served as trustee or board member for numerous organizations, including the North Carolina and Western Carolina chapters of the American Civil Liberties Union, the Asheville - Buncombe Library, The Fund for Investigative Reporting & Editing, AFS Archives & Museum, News & Observer Publishing Co., Gordon H. Greenwood Foundation, and the Mark Twain Library. He also served in a number of political offices during his life, including justice of the peace, State of Connecticut; Democratic Town Committee, Wilton, CT; Democratic State Convention delegate, Hartford, CT; registrar of voters, Buncombe County, NC; elections judge, Buncombe County, NC; Democratic Precinct Committee member, Buncombe County, NC. He was the author of ''Heroes of Conservation,'' (1973); co-author of ''Oil Industry U.S.A.'', (1977); co-author and general editor of The Saga of Section Six, (1994); and editor of ''The Liz Reader,'' (2002), a collection of shorter works by his beloved wife of 53 years, noted author Elizabeth Daniels Squire, who died in 2001. He is survived by three sons, J. Hart Squire, of Weaverville, NC, Mark M. Squire of Fairfax, CA, and Worth P. Squire of College Grove, TN, as well as seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to AFS Intercultural Programs, Inc., 71 West 23rd St., 17th Floor, New York, NY, 10010-4102.

SCIENCE FAIR A Story of Mystery, Danger, International Suspense, and a Very Nervous Frog. By Dave Barry and Ridley Pearson. Disney Editions. $18.99. (Ages 10 and up) Mean rich kids, heavies from the Republic of Krpshtskan and a ''Star Wars'' memorabilia collector in a Darth Vader mask are some of the bad guys in Pearson and Barry's hilarious new novel. Toby Harbinger has to win the $5,000 first prize at the Hubble Middle School science fair to make Darth Vader go away, but much more is at stake: a plot to steal top-secret technology, unwittingly aided by hypercompetitive parents. Somehow it all makes sense.

HUBER--Michael Wright. December 29, 1927-January 5, 2009. Michael W. Huber of Locust, NJ, died at home, surrounded by his family, early in the morning on January 5, 2009. Mike graduated in 1949 from Princeton University with a degree in Mechanical Engineering. He married Caroline Parker on July 28th, 1951 on Mishaum Point in Massachusetts. After college, Mike went to work in the family business, the J.M. Huber Corporation. He worked at Huber for more than 45 years, with an interruption only for service in the Air Force during the Korean War. Mike held the positions of Chairman, CEO, and Director guiding the company's growth into diverse, international businesses including engineered wood, mineral products, and energy. A lifelong resident of Monmouth County, NJ, Mike and Caroline spent summers sailing the coast of Maine from their homeport in Sorrento. Mike's travels took him from Antarctica to the Arctic Circle and to every continent in search of birds. He could identify hundreds of species of flora and fauna by sight, sound, and sign, and he worked tirelessly in support of many organizations devoted to the protection and preservation of wild spaces and natural diversity. Among New Jersey's environmental groups, he served on the boards of the Monmouth Conservation Foundation, the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, The Nature Conservancy, the American Littoral Society, and the Pinelands Preservation Alliance. He was also an active supporter of a wide range of organizations promoting civil rights, social and economic justice, education, family planning, political reform, and the performing arts. He will be remembered as a generous and thoughtful advocate of a more livable and sustainable world. Mike is survived by Caroline and their children and grandchildren: Eleanor Huber, husband David Lovins, and their children, Katie and Josh Lovins; Hans Huber and his children, Max and Lucy; Michael Huber, wife Martha Cody Huber, and their children, Jacob and Isabella; Sepp Huber and his children, Ben, Jay, and Woody; and Sam Huber, his wife Catherine Weiss, and their children, Alexandra, Eliza, and Zoe Huber-Weiss. Mike is also survived by his sister Cat Anderson and his brother Toni Huber. A memorial service will be held on February 8th at 12 Noon at the Fort at Sandy Hook Theater. Posten's Funeral Home in Atlantic Highlands, NJ is in charge of services.

VIDEO: Reporter's Notebook: The Tunnels of Gaza Gaza is almost completely shut off from the world. To the north, east and west: the Israeli military. To the south: a sealed border with Egypt. But beneath that border a vast network of tunnels has been dug. They are used to smuggle everyday goods, like cheese and cigarettes. Not-so-everyday items are smuggled, too, like the rockets and other weapons Hamas uses. A main aim of Israel's assault in Gaza is to shut down the tunnels. A video report by Vijai Singh and Steve Farrell explores a tunnel from Rafah. Left, a tunnel destroyed by Israel in the current conflict.
Dance Claudia La Rocco

8 P.M. (NBC) THE 66TH ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS The Hollywood Foreign Press Association honors achievement in film and television and, perhaps, forecasts the Academy Awards. Movie nominees include ''The Curious Case of Benjamin Button,'' ''Frost/Nixon,'' ''The Reader,'' ''Revolutionary Road'' and ''Slumdog Millionaire'' for best drama; Anne Hathaway, Angelina Jolie, Meryl Streep, Kristin Scott Thomas and Kate Winslet for best actress in a drama; and Leonardo DiCaprio, Frank Langella, Sean Penn, Brad Pitt and Mickey Rourke for best actor in a drama. On the television front, ''Dexter,'' ''House,'' ''In Treatment,'' ''Mad Men'' and ''True Blood'' will compete for best drama, and ''30 Rock,'' ''Californication,'' ''Entourage,'' ''The Office'' and ''Weeds'' will vie for best comedy. ABBEY--William P. One of the last of World War II's U.S. Naval Officers and a New York City resident, died on November 24, 2008 at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 93. Mr. Abbey participated in the invasion of Normandy on DDay, at Utah Beach. He served as legal advisor to the Tripartite Naval Commission established at the Potsdam Conference in 1945 to dispose of the German Navy. He counseled on denazification and was the Legal Advisor to the U.S. Delegation on the rebuilding of the steel industry in the Ruhr. He stayed on in Europe as Director of the Free Europe Citizens Service. He used his language skills as a freelance translator while continuing to promote international cooperation and education when he returned to the United States. The only child of William Colin and Bertha Evangeline (nee Lanich) Abbey was born in Chicago in 1915. He graduated from the University of Michigan Law School in 1942. He worked his way through college as an assistant on the psychiatric unit of a hospital. He married Barbara (nee Dill), a German physiotherapist, in 1962. He was widowed in 1986. He is survived by five stepchildren who live in Germany. His wish to donate his body for medical research is being honored. Donations may be sent to the University of Michigan Law School.

ANTOINE--Clarel, II. The Horace Mann School mourns with deep sorrow the untimely death of Clarel Antoine II, Horace Mann Class of 2003. A strong, indefatigable presence at HM. Clarel not only excelled in his academic and musical career, but also in his devotion and loyalty to Horace Mann. He was a principled, articulate, compassionate individual who enriched all our lives. Horace Mann and others will surely miss his eloquence, charm and generosity of spirit. His legacy -the creation of HM's Music Week, his memorable instruction of students in a special summer music program, and his grace and enthusiasm with which he approached life itself, lives on. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his parents, Dr. Ingrid Fitz-James Antoine and Dr. Clarel Antoine, his sister, Nathalie Pascale Antoine, HM 2010, and to his beloved friends. His family welcomes friends to his memorial service on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 1:30pm at Riverside Church, 120th St. and Riverside Dr. Thomas M. Kelly, Ph.D. Head of School Steven M. Friedman HM 1972, Chair, Board of Trustees

ANTOINE--Clarel II, March 9, 1985 passed away unexpectedly in Boston, MA on December 29, 2008 at the age of 23. Beloved son of Clarel Antoine M.D., and Ingrid FitzJames Antoine M.D., adored brother of Nathalie Pascale Antoine and grandson of Ilse and Francine. HAMID--Henry A.,beloved husband of Carolyn Hamid, passed away on December 26, 2008 from ventricular fibrillation. Mr. Hamid retired from Wellington Associates in 1972 where he served as a General Manager of a chain of 24 hotels located throughout the United States, including the St. Regis, Gotham & McAlpin and Stanhope Hotels in New York City. Mr. Hamid was CEO of National Sugar Corporation and was on the Board of Directors of the NYC Hotel Association. He was also a real estate investor and management consultant. Early in his career, Mr. Hamid was General Manager of GAC Corp., a National Theatrical Management Agency which owns the Hamid-Morton Circus and was instrumental in booking the Beatles in the early 1960s in Convention Hall in Atlantic City. The family also owned the Steel Pier in Atlantic City. Mr. Hamid was the son of Ameen A. Hamid who performed in Buffalo Bills Wild West Shows in the late 1800s and early 1900s. Mr. Hamid was 81 years old and a graduate of Blair Academy and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute with a BS in Electrical Engineering. He is survived by his wife Carolyn Hamid, daughters Debra Hamid-Zygmunt and Pamela Sutherland, and three grandchildren, Alanna, Caroline and Henry Sutherland.

ENJOYING THE BLUE WATER OF THE MALDIVE ISLANDS, NOV. 20, 2008 Anne Margot, 36, a designer from Choëx, Switzerland, snorkeling on the coral reef near Maayafushi Island. Her husband, Christophe (not shown), took the photograph. ''We wanted a quiet vacation because it's usually a bit exhausting when we travel, and we wanted something different. I chose the Maldives because Christophe really likes the blue water, and because I had been diving once in Egypt and it was wonderful. It was a romantic vacation, just the two of us. The water was amazing because you couldn't feel your body; you felt so light. You realize you're swimming with these wonderful animals who do what they want -- you can't force anything; you're just there to float along and look at the beauty of nature flowing underwater. You're constantly surprised by your environment, like you've been given this extraordinary moment, like a gift.'' As told to Austin Considine

HARTENSTINE--Barbara Hurlbut, formerly of Millburn, NJ and Shadow Lake Village in Redbank, NJ, died New Years Day at Touro Infirmary in New Orleans, LA after a short illness. She had been living in New Orleans with her daughter, Carolyn Hartenstine Sinclair for two years. She was 85 years old. Mrs. Hartenstine, a native of California and graduate of UC Berkeley, lived and worked in New York City and New Jersey since the mid-1950s. Her late husband, Charles Jefferson Hartenstine, Jr. practiced criminal law in New York City and was appointed to the Federal Bench in the Southern District of New York in 1974 where he served until his death in 1976. In addition to Carolyn, she is survived by two daughters, Kimberly Tunison Del Guidice of St. Louis, MO, and Susanne Hartenstine Savage of Los Angeles, CA, one son, Alexander ''Sandy'' Hartenstine of Boston, MA and one grandson, Tristan Sinclair. The deceased requested no services. The family has asked donations be made in her name to the National Aphasia Association, www.aphasia.org

She moved to Southeastern Connecticut in 1994, where she was assisted by her Caregiver Ena Brown. Elaine was a graduate of Dominican Academy and Sarah Lawrence College. She is survived by her brother William King, son Thomas Hahn, daughter Sarah Hahn-Burke and grandson Griffin Burke.

Will fashion history repeat the drastic hemline changes that followed the 1929 crash? That's when the short flapper skirt gave way to a demure tea length. Revolutions in fashion usually begin because of world events. Christian Dior's romantic 1947 New Look was a reaction to the end of World War II, and its many hardships and restrictions. But today it would be simplistic to expect the ups and downs of the stock market to be reflected in the ups and downs of skirt lengths. For one thing, women are working and 90 percent wear trousers.

A protester in London tried to hit a mounted riot police officer outside the Israeli Embassy in London on Saturday. Fifteen people were arrested after a confrontation between a group of 2,000 demonstrators and police officers guarding the embassy, the police said. Three police officers were hurt as shoes and placards were hurled by protesters. In cities across Europe and in Lebanon on Saturday, tens of thousands of people turned out to protest the Israeli offensive in Gaza.

The suspensions last Tuesday of two major league baseball players who tested positive for steroids after they said they took tainted supplements came a month after the N.F.L. confronted a similar problem. In that instance, the N.F.L. suspended six players who tested positive for a masking agent after they had taken an over-the-counter weight-loss drug. The common thread in the two cases are the arguments presented by players that league officials should have told them that the products were tainted and could cause them to test positive. While the players maintained that they were unwitting victims, there is no language in the collective bargaining agreements of either sport that compels league officials to warn players about potentially tainted products. In fact, legal experts said, there are several obstacles and legal liabilities that prevent sports leagues from doing so.

Around the 10th of the month, Margaret Callahan maneuvers a small cart down six flights of stairs to the supermarket one block from her one-bedroom apartment in Astoria, Queens. As she pushes the cart slowly down each aisle in the store, she surveys her choices, checks prices and calculates how much she can afford on the $74 that she receives monthly in food stamps.

SPECTOR--Edward Robert, of Croton died peacefully on Friday, January 9, 2009 after a 15 month battle with cancer. Edward was born July 7, 1959 in the Bronx, NY to Stuart and the late Roberta Spector. He attended Bronx High School of Science graduating in three years. Edward graduated form Pace University with a Masters in Tax and a BBA in Accounting. He worked with Merrill Lynch for the last eight years, during which time he was recognized by Worth Magazine as one of the Nation's Top Financial Advisors for five consecutive years. He was active in the local community coaching Little League and Flag football for many years. He also received awards for his work with the students at P.S. 2 in the Bronx to expand their Social, Educational and Athletic Programs and made generous donations to the Educational Jewish Center in the Bronx. His generosity was an inspiration to all that knew him. He was an avid Yankee fan following them since he was a young boy working as a vendor at Yankee Stadium. He was the beloved husband of Robyn and devoted Father of daughter Elizabeth and son Matthew. He is also survived by his father Stuart and his wife Mildred; sisters Wendy, Lynda and Tami; many nieces and nephews; sistersin-law Nancy and Margy; brothers-in-law David and Peter; and mother-in-law Mary Louise. Ed is also survived by his best four legged friend ''Buddy''. Funeral Services will be Monday, January 12 at 1pm at King David Memorial Chapel, 288 East Main St., Mt. Kisco, NY 10549. Donations may be made in Edwards name payable to: The Mt. Sinai Sarcoma Program, c/o James C. Witig M.D., Director Sarcoma Division, Mt. Sinai Tisch Cancer Institute, 5 East 98th St., Box 1188, NY, NY 10029.

STRAUSS--Claire, of Manhattan, NY passed away at the Palm Gardens Senior Residence Center in Palm Beach, Florida. She was the sister of Elise Kapell, a former New York resident now living in Daytona Beach, Florida. Claire was an Executive Buyer for Abraham and Strauss Department Stores in the greater New York area. She traveled the world buying fashion and millenary for their four major stores. She graduated and later taught at the School for Fashion Merchandising and Design in New York. She was married to the late Col. Morton Strauss, he was the directing Officer for the National Guard Armory in New York City. She was a member of Temple Emanuel and the National Council of Jewish Women. Claire lived an exciting life, she enjoyed the Arts, Broadway shows and Concerts. She enjoyed social gatherings with family and friends. She looked forward to weekends at her home in the Hamptons. She later retired to her winter home in Palm Beach, Florida. A memorial service was held for Claire Strauss at Temple Beth-El in Ormond Beach, Florida on December 14, 2008. Elise Kapell, Claire's sister suggest that any contributions may be made in Claire's memory to Temple Emanuel or Temple Beth-El at 579 North Nova Road, Ormond Beach, Florida 32174.

EON Dragoneye Reborn. By Alison Goodman. Viking. $19.99. (Ages 12 and up) The odds are stacked almost too heavily against Eon, a girl masquerading as a 12-year-old boy -- a would-be ''dragoneye apprentice'' to one of the ''12 energy dragons of good fortune'' (Goodman's fantasy world is based on East Asian astrology). But this novel includes plenty of exciting sword fights and plot reversals, and the dragons themselves, which only mystics of Eon's ability can see, are beautifully described. Eon's rise and fall take an unpredictable course, and a surprise awaits at the end, setting up Book 2.

BERRY--Nancy Michaels, passed away peacefully on January 8, 2009. She was 80 years old. Nancy was born in Kansas City, Kansas, on September 3, 1928 to William and Allene Michaels, but grew up in Tulsa, Oklahoma. She graduated from Holland Hall School with highest honors. She was the valedictorian of her class each year of her attendance, and graduated when she was 15 years old. She received a scholarship to Wellesley College. In her junior year, she met and married, Charles N. Berry Jr., a fellow Oklahoman who was a student at Harvard Law School. Nancy and Charlie moved back to Oklahoma City, and raised four sons. Nancy went on to obtain her Bachelor's Degree in History, and a Master's Degree in International Relations from the University of Oklahoma. Through her work with the Junior League, she became passionately involved in numerous philanthropic causes. She worked for World Neighbors before becoming the Executive Director of the Oklahoma City Community Foundation. Nancy moved to New York City in 1980 where she worked for Project Orbis, which educated doctors around the world in advanced eye surgery techniques. She then went to work for the National Executive Service Corps, which provides management expertise to nonprofits throughout the United States, as their only paid executive. After retiring, she traveled extensively throughout Europe and the United States, making life - long friends wherever she went. Nancy always believed in living life to the fullest. She lived by the maxim, ''Carpe Diem''. Nancy is survived by countless friends, and her two sons, Charles Nelson Berry III of Seattle, Washington and Michaels Crittenden Berry, of Bainbridge Island, Washington. Her youngest two sons, David Shelby Berry and Chrisopher Norris Berry, predeceased her. She is also survived by her daughter-in-law, Paula Grant Berry, of Brooklyn, New York. She is also survived by her brother, Bill Michaels, and his wife, Kim, of Basking Ridge, New Jersey. She is also survived by seven grandchildren. There will be a Memorial Service at 4:00pm on Wednesday, January 14, 2009, at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, located at Fifth Avenue and East 90th. In lieu of flowers, the family would prefer a donation be made in her name to the Oklahoma City Community Foundation, located at 1000 N. Broadway, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma 73102.

MacMILLEN--William Charles, Jr.,longtime resident of Lawrence, New York, on January 8, 2009 at the age of 95. Born May 24, 1913 in Troy, New York, to the late William C. and Anna (Dugan). Bill graduated from Williams College in 1934 and Albany Law School in 1937, cum laude. He served as a major in the United States Army Air Forces during World War II and was decorated with the Legion of Merit. Bill is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Barbara Southack Christy Downing, and by his children, Anita MacMillen Bird (J. Raymond) of Point Pleasant, New Jersey, William C. III (Kay) of Burbank, California, and Nancy MacMillen Brown (John) of Pomona, New York, and his stepson, Paul Cook Downing, III (Martha) of Topsham, Maine. Also surviving him are seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. His stepdaughter, Sally Downing Candler Thompson, predeceased him. Bill practiced as a lawyer in the firm of MacMillen & Filley, Troy, New York from 1939 to 1942 and thereafter began a long association with Robert R. Young, first as his assistant and then as the President of the Federation of Railway Progress until the late 1940s when he began a career in the film and entertainment industry as an officer of Pathe Industries, Eagle Lion Films, Eagle Lion Studios and Eagle Lion Classics Inc., which was sold to United Artists in the early 1950s. A banker and investment banker, he was the President of Colonial Trust Co., a director and President of the Cosmos American Corp., a founder of Lexington International Inc., a venture capital firm, a director of Commercial Alliance Corp. from its inception in 1963 to 1984, a director of Financial Federal Corporation from its inception in 1989 to 2005, a founder and director of Republic National Bank and Republic New York Corporation from its inception in 1965 to December 1999, a commentator and member of The Management Executives Society for over forty years and President of William C. MacMillen & Co., an investment banking firm, from 1960 to 2005. Bill was an avid sports fan, who was a founding director of the Cleveland Browns, a lifelong fan of the New York Mets and the New York Giants and a longtime thoroughbred racehorse owner and breeder; one of his horses, Sweet Woodruff, was named Horse of the Year in 1979. He was a member of The Jockey Club and the Turf and Field Club, where he was the President from 1972 to 1981. Bill also served as President of the New York Division of the Horsemen's Benevolent Protective Association. A jazz aficionado, a competitive bridge player and an athlete, particularly in squash and tennis, Bill was a lifelong member of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Lawrence Beach Club, The Racquet & Tennis Club, the Saratoga Golf Club, The Sky Club and the Saratoga Reading Rooms. He will be remembered by his family and his many friends as a man of the utmost integrity who enjoyed a debate with his fine wit, candor and intellect. A memorial tribute and luncheon will be held at The Racquet & Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue, on Friday, January 16, 2009 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bill's memory to BEST, Backstretch Employees Service Team of New York, Belmont Park, Gate 6, Cottage 28B, 2150 Hempstead Turnpike, Elmont, NY 11003, would be appreciated.

LEE--Thomas Sim, died on January 9, 2009 at Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY, from complications arising from cancer and a stroke suffered on August 18, 2007. A son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lee, he was born on August 18, 1937, and was a direct descendent of Thomas Sim Lee, second Governor of Maryland, and Charles Carroll, a signer of the Declaration of Independence. He graduated from Middlesex School and from Harvard University, Class of 1959. After service in the U.S. Army, he began a lifelong career in the securities industry in New York City. He was associated with several firms, most recently with Smith Barney. He was an active supporter and Board Member of the East Side Settlement House in New York City and an avid and accomplished bridge player and chef. Tom is survived by two sisters, Cynthia L. Russell (Mrs. John B. Russell) and Mary L. Lambert (Mrs. Paul C. Lambert) and a brother, Charles C. Lee. His sister, Eleanor L. Congdon, predeceased. He was a devoted and loving uncle to 18 nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88 Street, New York, NY, on Thursday, January 29, 2009, at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

THE delicate and springlike silk-cotton knits that have started to trickle into stores have no place in 20-degree weather. Winter, as the thermometer indicates, has arrived. It is time to bring out the woolly beasts. Fortunately, fall was a season for thick, oversize sweaters. On the runway, Stella McCartney showed a brushed mohair pullover; Donna Karan sent out a slouchy alpaca cowl neck; Fendi presented several beefy knit variations; and at Etro there was a short, shaggy number that looked as if the model Lily Donaldson had wrapped a flokati around her shoulders. And here lies the problem. Chunky sweaters can be tricky to wear, particularly when you're still trying to look pulled together.

After starring in the hit Disney Channel show “Lizzie McGuire” and releasing two top-selling albums while still in her teens, Hilary Duff probably thought she had the market on precociousness cornered. But Ms. Duff, 21, has nothing on 18-year-old Kathleen Holtz, who in 2007 became the youngest person to pass the California bar exam. Now Ms. Duff will play Ms. Holtz in a Fox sitcom, “Barely Legal, ” according to The Hollywood Reporter. The executive producer of the show, which is still in the script development stages, is Rob Morrow, who appeared as an actor on “Numb3rs” and “Northern Exposure. ”

Well, she warned him that love is a losing game: Blake Fielder-Civil, the husband of Amy Winehouse, is beginning divorce proceedings against her, his lawyer announced on Monday. The lawyer, Henri Brandman, said that Mr. Fielder-Civil would seek a divorce on the grounds of infidelity, The Associated Press reported. The couple were married in May 2007 , and both have had legal problems since then. Mr. Fielder-Civil was arrested in 2007 and later sent to jail for assaulting a man and offering him a bribe. Last week, Ms. Winehouse dropped her appeal of a fine she paid in Norway for possession of what the police said was marijuana. In separate interviews with the British newspaper News of the World, Mr. Fielder-Civil has said he blamed himself for his wife ‘s drug problems, and Ms. Winehouse, who was hospitalized several times last year, said she was off drugs and in love with a 21-year-old she met on vacation in St. Lucia.

A little more than a month after the departure of the publisher of Simon & Schuster’s children’s division, the company has appointed Jon Anderson, currently president of Running Press Book Publishers, to fill the post. Mr. Anderson, 45, replaces Rick Richter, who left in early December. Mr.Richter’s departure was announced on the same day Simon & Schuster disclosed layoffs. Carolyn Reidy, chief executive, said at the time that Mr. Richter left to “explore other opportunities in publishing.” Ms. Reidy said she quickly decided to look outside the company for Mr. Richter’s replacement because she was looking for somebody who could handle a broad range of publishing formats, including licensing deals for books based on characters like Dora the Explorer and Spongebob Squarepants. “Looking for somebody who can go across all those levels of publishing is a tough job to fill,” Ms. Reidy said.

The last two days of 2008 saw the Dow Jones industrials gain 3.45 percent. It was, Dow Jones promptly announced, the third best end-of-year rally ever for the index. The best one, Dow added ominously, came in 1929, when the index leaped 4.22 percent over the final two sessions, rising from 240.66 to 248.48.

DETROIT -- On Wall Street, the billionaire Wilbur Ross may be one of the canny carnivores of private investing. At the Detroit auto show, though, Mr. Ross takes on a milder role.

A proposal to create the city's first Hebrew-language charter school has just been approved by a committee of the New York State Board of Regents. If the full board ratifies the committee's decision on Tuesday, as is widely expected, the school would open in Brooklyn's District 22 this fall.The school, to be called the Hebrew Language Academy Charter School, would begin with 150 kindergartners and first graders, and is designed to eventually serve 675 students in kindergarten through eighth grade. Students would be chosen by lottery, with preference for residents of the district, which includes the Sheepshead Bay, Mill Basin and Midwood neighborhoods.

FIFA announced its men's and women's players of the year at a gala reception in Switzerland on Monday. As expected, Manchester United and Portugal star Cristiano Ronaldo sped away with the award. So did the Brazilian star Marta, who recently bid her Swedish club farewell in order to sign with the Los Angeles Sol of the Women's Professional Soccer League. This is the third consecutive year the dynamic Brazilian has won the award.

Updated Senate Democratic leaders today cleared the way for Roland Burris to be seated as a senator from Illinois, after his appointment by the state's now impeached governor had turned into a weeklong spectacle shifting between the nation's capital and the corruption scandal back in Illinois.
John D. Feerick, the chairman of the state Commission on Public Integrity, has resigned.

The number of fire-related deaths in New York City fell to 86 last year from 95 in 2007, while the Fire Department recorded that its average response time to building fires was its fastest in 14 years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta announced on Monday.The number of fire-related deaths fell from 297 in 1990 to 97 in 2002 (not counting the deaths in the Sept. 11, 2001, attack on the World Trade Center), before rising again to 125 in 2003. Since then, the number of deaths has remained fairly level: 82 in 2004, 104 in 2005, 85 in 2006 and 95 in 2007.
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation urged its member banks on Monday to publicly disclose how they are using the hundreds of billions of dollars of government capital injections and guarantees.

I recently came across a new product useful for those of us who brew coffee with a press pot, cone filter or Chemex: Breville's variable temperature kettle ($149.95 at Williams Sonoma). It heats water to a number of pre-programmed temperatures, including 200˚ Fahrenheit, which is ideal for coffee.

DETROIT -- "We're going from the first idea to the market in 24 months," said Henrik Fisker of his luxury plug-in hybrid, the Karma, which was unveiled a year ago and is expected to go on sale by the end of the year for $87,900.

The Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn proposed Monday to close at least 14 of its elementary schools as part of a reorganization that officials said they hoped would stem a steady decline in enrollment that has plagued Catholic school systems nationwide for decades.This would be the second major round of elementary school closings in recent years for the diocese, which comprises Brooklyn and Queens. In 2005, it closed 25, and in the next two years, seven more. If the proposed closings are carried out, the diocese will have shut down nearly one-third of the elementary schools it had just half a decade ago.

Unlike the washing machine, dishwasher, and refrigerator, the clothes dryer can not achieve Energy Star status because, according to the United States Department of Energy, "there is little difference in energy use between models."

Sometimes a food becomes so pervasive, so accepted, so much a part of New York life, that you forget that once upon a time, it wasn't there. That is the case with that tangy red onion sauce that is slathered over hot dogs in New York alongside sweet relish and sauerkraut. Similar to the frumpy oversize black-and-white cookies, lifelong New Yorkers may never realize that it's something that is native to this city.

Bernard L. Madoff, the financier accused of running a huge Ponzi scheme, can remain in his Manhattan penthouse for now. A federal judge on Monday denied the prosecution's request to revoke Mr. Madoff's bail and send him to jail, saying that the government had not proved that he was a flight risk or a security risk. Instead, Mr. Madoff will remain under house arrest in his luxury apartment on the Upper East Side, guarded by private security guards paid for by his wife. The federal magistrate judge did imposed additional bail conditions, ordering Mr. Madoff to compile an inventory of all valuable items at his home and forbidding him to transfer property. [See NYTimes.com Reader Comments.]

Ah, January! It's that special time of year when marketers manipulate our resolution-shackled psyches to sell us all sorts of diet pills and exercise schemes. But if you're a researcher in computational linguistics, natural language processing or machine learning, the last thing you want to do is slim down. As Google's example has consistently shown, more data usually beats better algorithms, and if you're a researcher looking for a new motherlode of high-quality textual data - who also has a love of The New York Times's writerly chops - where better to start than The New York Times Annotated Corpus?

Dr. Jack Resnick, an internist in New York, believes that if the frail elderly are treated at home by doctors making house calls, as they did in the good old days, then medical outcomes will improve and Medicare costs can be reduced. Dr. Resnick hosted one of the community health care forums arranged by the Obama transition team on Dec. 29 at the Good Shepherd Community Center on Roosevelt Island in New York City. The following week, Dr. Resnick brought his message to the state capitol in Albany, where he met with health officials responsible for long-term care policy. Dr. Resnick's own anecdotal experience with house calls has been documented in various medical journals, which report that keeping geriatric patients out of the hospital reduces costs between 30 and 60 percent. With Medicare cost-containment high on the agenda of the incoming administration, I asked Dr. Resnick to share his thoughts. For a different perspective on house calls, you can hear first-hand from his patients at therooseveltdoctor.com. - Jane Gross

From where this reporter sat at the Golden Globes last night, that sure looked like Tom Rothman of Fox and Alan Horn of Warner Brothers down among the superstar seats, smiling and back-patting - each other, not the superstars - just before the show began. A public display of affection between studio chiefs, along with those pricey "Watchmen" ads on the National Football League playoff games this weekend, would add up to a message as big as the Hollywood sign: The talks between hitherto warring Fox and Warner over a settlement of Fox's lawsuit over rights to "Watchmen" must be on track.

About 50,000 New Yorkers who had been collecting unemployment checks for 11 months will stop receiving weekly payments this week, according to the State Labor Department. For many of those facing the loss of that lifeline, the next step may be welfare, experts say.

Economy | Stop criticizing people for saving, an economist writes, arguing "it is pure myth to suggest that parsimony is an act of economic destruction" when savings ultimately provide the capital for productive investment. Actually, he says, the 19th century political economist Jean-Baptiste Say had it right when he observed "that excessive consumption is the equivalent of capital destruction, because the amount of capital available to new businesses is being reduced." [Forbes]
Credit Suisse has decided to join the restructuring party, setting up a group to advise companies seeking to reorganize their debt as they face potential bankruptcy, The Financial Times reported.
Harbinger Capital Partners, the activist hedge fund, has clamped down on investors' requests to withdraw their investments, The Financial Times reported citing two unnamed investors.

Federal banking regulators are pressing Citigroup to shake up its board and replace its chairman, Winfried F. W. Bischoff, in an effort to restore confidence in the beleaguered financial giant, The New York Times's Eric Dash reported.

The board members of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York weighed who will become its next president over the weekend, interviewing candidates and meeting to discuss them, The New York Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin reported, citing people briefed on the conversations.
The anticipated combination of brokerage units at Citigroup and Morgan Stanley is seen by analysts as the likely start of a fresh wave of consolidation in the troubled and thinning banking industry.
The British government and British banks are mulling a plan to set up a fund that would absorb companies' bad debt in order to prevent further corporate defaults, The Wall Street Journal reported.

There is still about a decade to go before large numbers of solar cells lose their effectiveness. But the solar industry in Europe is not taking any chances with its reputation as a clean business - and has pledged to collect and recycle large numbers of them so they don't end up in the garbage dump.

Schapiro, who appears this week at a confirmation hearing on her selection to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been accused in two lawsuits of making misleading statements to quickly complete a merger of regulatory organizations after which she received a 57 percent raise in her pay, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton reported.

Health | In tough times, people may not splurge on meals and vacations, but they still get sick, have babies and require operations. So why is the health-care industry in trouble -- bucking the long-held assumption that it's recession-proof? Could it be that the much-maligned cost-shifting to consumers has made them more discriminating? Or have people been forced to suffer? Or forgo Botox injections? All of the above? [Slate]
Land of Leather Holdings, the struggling British leather furniture retailer, said on Monday trading in its shares had been suspended, pending clarification of its financial position.

The planned sale of Daewoo Shipbuilding to Hanwha Group for about $5 billion is likely to fall apart on financing concerns, despite efforts by the South Korean government to save the deal, Reuters said, citing people familiar with the matter.

Chrysler's recent cost cutting, including white collar layoffs and the exit of senior executives, was not done with the goal of positioning the company for sale, Chief Executive Bob Nardelli said on Sunday.

The co-founders of the Indian software company Satyam Computer Services, who are at the heart of a corporate fraud scandal that has sent shock waves through Indian business circles, were expected to seek bail on Monday, even as Satyam's newly appointed board meets to discuss the company's future, The New York Times's Jeremy Kahn and Bettina Wassener reported.

Senator Carl Levin said on Sunday he plans to subpoena the Treasury Department to see its agreement with Citigroup and determine what commitments the financial institution made in exchange for government aid, Reuters reported.

When the CBS Corporation bought CNet for $1.8 billion last year, it acquired TV.com, a Web site that had little to brag about except a valuable domain name. Now CBS is transforming it into a video destination, The New York Times's Brian Stelter reports.

The first full trading week of 2009 started with optimism but ended with stock markets down about 4 percent for the five days, as bleak employment numbers battered Wall Street Friday and raised new fears about the scope of the economic downturn, The New York Times's Jack Healy reported.

Monday. The Christmas tree has been discarded, the unwanted presents have been tossed, the best of last year's liquor has been drunk. It's time to face the fact that the cheerless slog of winter has begun. But as the poet once said, "If drinking is bitter, turn yourself to wine." Consider these as tonics for the season: "Winter Notes on Summer Impressions" (Dostoyevsky, looking for an epilepsy cure, visits Western Europe, where he mocks the French and confronts child prostitution in London); "To Build a Fire" (Jack London's nameless traveler dies in the snow wastes of the Yukon; his dog survives); "Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening" (Robert Frost captures the creepy isolation of the season. Also plays a crucial role in the Charles Bronson thriller "Telefon").Hammer Shanks 101

Geography | How the new cartography is like mapmaking in the Middle Ages: Today's maps are "geographically accurate beyond the dreams of a medieval mind," yet they're still, perhaps more than ever, vehicles for representing the world's geography as the mapmaker idiosyncratically interprets it -- never mind getting from point A to point B. [Boston Globe]

CBS transforms TV.com | CBS Corporation is turning TV.com into a video destination. The New York Times on Monday reports that CBS has redesigned the previously clunky site to showcase the thousands of new and old television episodes that it offers, from "CSI: Crime Scene Investigation" to "Charlie's Angels." And on Monday, the company is expected to announce distribution deals with PBS, Sony, MGM and Endemol that will expand its free advertising-supported online library.

ABC may bring 'Millionaire' back in prime time | ABC may present a prime-time revival of the game show "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" this summer. TV Week reports: "Staged as a multi-night event over one or two weeks, the 'Millionaire' redux likely would air in August as a commemoration of the 10-year anniversary of the show's American debut." Regis Philbin, the original host of the prime-time version, could return as host.

MTV to broadcast Obama's 'Youth Inaugural Ball' | The Associated Press reports: "MTV will be broadcasting from President-elect Barack Obama's 'Youth Inaugural Ball' on Jan. 20, the cable network announced Sunday." The network had planned to present its own party, but instead decided to work with the inaugural committee.

The Detroit auto show, which kicked off on Sunday to smaller, subdued crowds, finds a desperate industry facing plummeting sales and trying to stave off financial collapse. Even with a $17 billion government bailout, the industry's long-term viability still depends on making cars that people want. What will it take to convince consumers that Detroit's products are worth buying? We asked some veteran Detroit watchers for their ideas.

Serena Williams, who seemed visibly upset by a chair umpire’s mistake, rallied to pull out a 6-3, 6-7 (4), 7-5 first-round victory over Samantha Stosur of Australia in the Sydney International. Williams was serving for the match at 6-5 and 30-30 in the second set when the umpire, Asitha Attigala of Sri Lanka, missed a let call on Williams’s serve. Stosur went on to break Williams and won the ensuing tie breaker. Williams fought off four match points in the 10th game of the third set before breaking Stosur two games later to win the match.

The right-hander Takashi Saito has agreed to a one-year deal with Boston, giving the Red Sox another veteran arm in their bullpen. Saito, 38, who had 18 saves and a 2.49 earned run average last season despite being limited by an elbow injury, became a free agent when the Los Angeles Dodgers did not offer him a contract by the Dec. 12 deadline.

David Beckham made a surprising start in his A.C. Milan debut Sunday, playing 89 minutes in a solid if not outstanding performance at A.S. Roma. Beckham, wearing No. 32, was replaced by Mathieu Flamini in the 89th minute with the game tied at 2-2, the final score. His exit was met mostly with boos from the Roma crowd. Beckham joined Milan on a two-month loan from the Los Angeles Galaxy of M.L.S., hoping to stay sharp so he can earn a spot on the English national team.

Lindsey Vonn, the defending overall and downhill champion, put down a blistering second run in a women’s World Cup slalom in Maribor, Slovenia, but it was not enough to catch Maria Riesch of Germany, who won her fourth straight slalom. Vonn had the fastest second leg by far but still finished tied for fourth, 2.04 seconds behind Riesch.

Utah’s attorney general is using his personal blog to answer criticism that he is wasting state resources by investigating whether the Bowl Championship Series violates federal antitrust laws. The attorney general, Mark Shurtleff, contends that the B.C.S. unfairly puts Utah, and teams in other conferences like the Mountain West that do not get an automatic bid to a B.C.S. bowl, at a competitive and financial disadvantage. For the second time in five years, Utah finished the season undefeated and was shut out of playing in the B.C.S. national title game, which was won by Florida.

HIRSCH--Joseph. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our lifelong friend. Joe was a kind and gentle soul who bore the ravages of Parkinson's Disease with the same grace and dignity with which he lived his life. He will be deeply missed and lovingly remembered by all who were fortunate enough to have known him. The Waters Family

Netflix's Founder on the Future of TV In the last year, Reed Hastings, above, the founder and chief executive of Netflix, has moved the company far beyond those familiar red envelopes. The company's Watch Instantly video library, which allows subscribers to select from around 12,000 movies and TV shows to stream on demand over the Internet, is now available on TiVo, Xbox and a variety of Blu-ray players. Mr. Hastings was at the Consumer Electronics Show last week in Las Vegas talking about Netflix's availability on LG's new line of broadband HDTVs.

SOTER--George N.,84, said goodbye to the ''whole catastrophe'' and died peacefully on January 8. George was an award - winning advertising copywriter at many of the major agencies from the 1950s to the 1980s and from 1963 to 1982 ran the Greek Island boutique, part of his lifelong love for all things Greek. Adios, Yiorgo.

YUSEN--Henry Martin, 83, died January 9, 2009 in Charlottesville, VA, after a brief illness. He was the devoted husband of the late Muriel Spear Yusen. Mr. Yusen owned and operated the Gertrude Yusen Party Shop in Great Neck, NY for over 50 years. A navel veteran of WWII and the Korean War, he was a graduate of Syracuse University '48 and a member of Sigma Alpha Mu. He is survived by his children Susan Perry and her husband Jay of Charlottesville, VA and Andrew Yusen and his wife Darlene of Portsmouth, RI, as well as grandchildren Maxwell Perry and Matthew and Kyle Yusen. Graveside services Monday 11am at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

SHERMAN--Samuel Richard, M.D.,98, passed away on January 11, 2009. The youngest of four children and last surviving among his siblings. An Army veteran of World War II, he participated in the Battle of St. Lo and was awarded a Purple Heart as a Medical Captain. He graduated University of Michigan and finished L.I. College of Medicine. His practice was in Great Neck, NY for three decades. He retired to Palm Beach and Westhampton Beach. A beloved husband to Carol Sherman, father to Lisa and Ben Dardashtian and Jeff and Susan Sherman. Grandfather of Joshua, Michael, Jake, Samuel and Robert. Gracious and loving, he lived a long life and will be missed by many he touched by his extraordinary good nature.

LATE OF THE PIER ''Fantasy Black Channel'' (Astralwerks) There are 12 songs on ''Fantasy Black Channel,'' the debut album from the attention-deficit-disorder-afflicted young British band Late of the Pier (14 if you count the bonus tracks) but it can feel as if there are many, many more.

ROKIA TRAORé ''Tchamantché'' (Nonesuch) In its traditional roles as historical chronicle and community conscience, West African music doesn't favor introspection. That's what makes the Malian songwriter and singer Rokia Traoré such a graceful exception. Not a member of a musical dynasty like the many musicians named Diabaté and Kouyaté, with no family tradition to uphold, Ms. Traoré is a well-traveled diplomat's daughter who is creating her own radically delicate fusions.

The Smart Home, Without a Market The vision of the smart home has been around for decades. And an appealing vision it is -- a computerized triumph of automation, controlling a house's lighting and heating, even the kitchen.

S.E.C. CHOICE IN LAWSUITS Mary L. Schapiro, below, Barack Obama's choice to head the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been accused in two lawsuits of making misleading statements to quickly complete a merger of two regulatory bodies, the NASD and an arm of the New York Stock Exchange. The merger resulted in a 57 percent raise in her pay. HOLLYWOOD'S 3-D GAMBLE Hollywood has dozens of three-dimensional movies in its pipeline, a big gamble on the technology, which promises higher profits and artistic advancement. Movie theaters, however, have been slow to get on board, as it costs about $100,000 for each full upgrade. [B1.]

Israel Horowitz, a record producer who was also an executive editor and classical music columnist for Billboard magazine, died at his home in Closter, N.J., on Dec. 26. He was 92. His death was announced by his son Robert Horowitz.

Bats The Similarities Between Rickey and Manny As Jack Curry reported for an article about Rickey Henderson's anticipated election into the Baseball Hall of Fame, the similarities between Henderson and Manny Ramírez came up twice. Like Ramírez, Henderson possessed a quirky, goofy personality. And like Ramírez, he was so dominant that opposing teams had to adjust their game plans to deal with him.

ROGERS--David, at age 83, on January 11, 2009. Beloved husband of Marilyn, of 62 years. Cherished father of Barbara (Lenny) Schultz. Adoring grandfather of Neil (Anita) and Jaclyn. Services today 9:30am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY.

Some $100 million was spent on advertising in the first three quarters of 2008, although spending was down 0.6 percent over the same period in 2007. What may pull 2008 even with 2007, when the final numbers are out, is the tremendous campaign spending through Election Day, and efforts across all media by carmakers to alert consumers to deals and discounts. The concentration of ad buys was no surprise: cable TV gained in year-over-year spending, while national newspapers (down 6.4 percent) and local Sunday supplements (9.9 percent) continued to decline. SHELLY FREIERMAN
For Palm, Phone Won't Be Enough

YOSHIKO CHUMA and SHIROTAMA HITSUJIYA Center for Remembering & Sharing In ''X2,'' an enchanting evening of dance-theater by Yoshiko Chuma and Shirotama Hitsujiya, the world is a block of ice where human beings have been frozen in time. It's a screwball comedy, Japanese style. In the work, performed Friday night at the Center for Remembering & Sharing in Greenwich Village, the collaborators look at the political implications of a country trapped in an ice age.

MILANO--Michael (Cutzie), 56, of Henderson, NV, formerly of New York, peacefully on January 9, 2009 surrounded by love ones at USC Medical Center after a valiant five month battle. ChFC, president Milano Wealth Management. Devoted, loving and exuberant with family, friends and clients. Predeceased by his mother, Judith, survived by his father, Michael, children, Sarah and Gabriel, fiance, Hillary, former wife, Carol, brother, Joseph (Karen), Jeffrey (Marjorie), sister, Caryn (Paul), many nieces and nephews and countless dear friends; all will love and miss him forever. Services Tuesday in Henderson.

ELIANE ELIAS ''Bossa Nova Stories'' (Blue Note) The pianist Eliane Elias grew up in São Paulo long enough ago to appreciate bossa nova as an ascendant force. She has spent much of her career swimming with or just slightly against its current, while establishing her jazz credentials. Twenty years ago, when she made an album called ''Eliane Elias Plays Jobim,'' her approach was imaginative: she accessed her background for interpretive license rather than stylistic precedent.
RAGOVIN--Seth D.,suddenly died on January 10. Beloved and devoted son, brother, brother-in-law and uncle. We adore you and will miss you.

GALLIM DANCE Joyce SoHo Working with a powerful creative figure is a mixed blessing for artists who want to be creators too. The problem bedeviled more than one generation of ballet choreographers in and after the Balanchine era; today it is figures like William Forsythe and Ohad Naharin whose highly individual, complex ways of moving dominate a new generation of dance-makers.

FRISCH--Dolly Hemphill. Born August 26, 1928, died on December 9, 2008. Married to the late Robert E. Frisch, she is survived by her children, Katharine, Robert, Peter, and ten grandchildren. Memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Rye, NY on February 21 at 11am.

RADOW--Corynne G.,on January 10, 2009. Beloved wife for 67 years of Seymour. Loving mother of Margie (Barry) Forrest, Joan Osleeb, Debra (Chris) Soussanin and Steve (Robin) Radow. Devoted Nana of nine grandchildren and four great-grandmother. Service Monday at Gutterman's Inc. 175 North Long Beach Rd Rockville Centre.

BODY CARTOGRAPHY PROJECT Performance Space 122 Often the titles of dance pieces, like those of musical compositions, have absolutely nothing to do with what's happening in the performance, and looking to them for elucidation is a waste of effort. But in the case of the Body Cartography Project's ''Holiday House'' at Performance Space 122, the title is all-revealing.

SEVERS--Charles A.,III, died peacefully on the morning of January 9th, with his loving wife Jean, and devoted children; Charles, Cornelius, Rudyard and Olivia, by his side. He is fondly remembered by his five grandchildren, his extended family, and by those fortunate enough to have known him. Services will be held at St. Thomas Moore Church in Manhattan, on Wednesday, January 14th, at 10am.

SESAN--Lolly, 77 years old, died on January 10, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Robin and Michael, mother-in-law of Sheila Sesan and Judith Hand. Cherished grandmother of Sarah and Alex Robins, Tyler and Jordan Sesan. Lolly was an undiscovered talented jewelry designer and was loved by all who knew her. Graveside service Monday 10:30am at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd, Woodbury, NY 11797.

RAVI COLTRANE ''Blending Times'' (Savoy Jazz) ''Blending Times'' mixes serious, memorable songs with easy-come, easy-go spontaneities credited as ''improvisations conceived and directed by Ravi Coltrane.'' You can argue that in jazz, improvisation is just fast composition; those two approaches aren't necessarily opposites. Here, though, they sound that way.
LEFER--Henry, of Montvale, NJ, 89, on January 11, 2009. Loving husband of Sylvia (nee Ladner). Loving father of daughters Diane, Betty and Amy. Loving grandfather of John, Rebecca, Sarah and Lisa.

LAKOW--Phyllis. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Ellen Sunness, President Richard J. Jacobs, Rabbi Jonathan Blake, Rabbi Jack Stern, Rabbi Emeritus

SONTAG--Richard, Founder and CEO of Liberty National Bank in Stamford, CT and Originator of the Banks of Westport and Greenwich. Longtime Board member of Goddard College Plainfield, VT. Survived by wife Lois, 58 years, children, grandchildren and brother David. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Goddard College or the charity of your choice.

The television personality Howie Mandel has been hospitalized in Canada, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Mandel, 53, was in Toronto filming his new show, “Howie Do It!” when he was taken to the hospital with an irregular heartbeat, according to his publicist, Lewis Kay. Police officers were called to a hotel on Monday evening regarding a man with a medical condition, Staff Sgt. Devin Kealey told The Canadian Press. Mr. Kay confirmed that the man was Mr. Mandel, but added in a written statement that “ he did not have a heart attack” and would be back to work on Wednesday. Mr. Mandel hosts the game show “Deal or No Deal” on NBC and his new show had its premiere on that network last week.

“Slumdog Millionaire” has yet to be screened in Mumbai, but that hasn’t stopped the Indian film capital from celebrating. Newspaper headlines captured the city’s pride after the Golden Globe awards on Sunday night, when the movie, set in the gritty streets of Mumbai, took home four awards, including best dramatic picture, The Associated Press reported. “The $lumdog Has Its Day,” the Times of India said while the Hindustan Times declared “Indian tale catches global fancy.” The movie was also honored with awards for best director for Danny Boyle, best screenplay for Simon Beaufoy and best original score for the Indian composer A.R. Rahman. Mr. Rahman’s award inspired particular pride for the country and city of Mumbai, which produces more than 200 films a year, according to Subir Malik, an Indian musician. “It was brilliant, it may sound cliched, but it felt very good seeing Rahman winning an award and our own guys like Anil Kapoor on the same stage as Brad Pitt,” he said. The film will be released in India on Jan. 23.

If all goes according to plan, Arthur Miller’s Holocaust drama, “Incident at Vichy,” will be performed in New York this spring. The Actors Company Theater/TACT has announced dates for its off-Broadway production, to be directed by Scott Alan Evans, March 8-April 11, Playbill.com reported. Set in a detention room in France during the German occupation, the drama, which was first directed by Harold Clurman and had its premiere in 1964, features 10 men who are suspected of being Jewish undergoing interrogation. To date, the current cast includes the TACT company members Jamie Bennett, Richard Ferrone, Todd Gearhart, Jack Koenig, Ron McClary, James Prendergast and Gregory Salata. The play is set to open officially on March. 16 at the Beckett Theater.

Lincoln Center Theater has announced casting for its production of a new musical, “Happiness,” including Fred Applegate, Sebastian Arcelus, Miguel Cervantes, Hunter Foster, Joanna Gleason, Ken Page and others. The show will be directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, has a book by John Weidman, music by Scott Frankel, and lyrics by Michael Korie. It is to begin previews on Feb. 27 and open on March 30, at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater…Geoffrey Rush and Susan Sarandon will star in Eugene Ionesco’s comedy “Exit the King” the producers announced. Directed by Neil Armfield, with translation by Mr. Armfield and Mr. Rush, the production will be Mr. Rush’s first appearance on Broadway. The play is to begin performances March 7 at the Barrymore Theater and run through June 14….Mark Lamos has been named artistic director of the Westport Country Playhouse in Connecticut, the theater announced. Mr. Lamos succeeds Joanne Woodward and Anne Keefe who shared the post at the theater, which is entering its 79th season. Michael Ross will also join the organization as managing director and both men will assume their positions in February.

Much of the great art in France may be ancient, but the audience is about to get much younger, officials hope. President Nicolas Sarkozy unveiled a plan on Tuesday that will allow all French youths under 25 and schoolteachers free entry to musuems starting April 4, Agence France-Presse reported. In a speech promoting French culture in the coming year, Mr. Sarkozy also said that he would lift a partial freeze on state financing for the performing arts He announced as well that he planned to create a new national history museum.

I'd like to introduce Aaron E. Hirsh, the first guest columnist for The Wild Side during my sabbatical. Aaron is a biologist and writer based in Colorado. He has a doctorate in Biological Sciences from Stanford University, where he studied aspects of how molecules such as proteins evolve. He has, for several years led a summer field course in Baja California, Mexico, looking at the animals that live in the Sea of Cortez -- otherwise known as the Gulf of California. A book about his adventures there, called "Telling Our Way to the Sea," will be published next year. He is also a research associate at the University of Colorado, Boulder.

To ERR is human but since most dictionaries still prefer that word to be pronounced "ur" it doesn't fit today's theme. Too bad, because err I did. I found this one gettable but tough for a Wednesday. If you could conjure up "exegesis," already an obscure word unless you're a Bible scholar, you might be able to pull out EXEGETE, meaning an "expert at interpreting a text." If not, you had to remember that the Little Rascal Buckwheat said OTAY to get that cross.

Having written last week about beers costing as much as $35 a bottle, I was a little uneasy about my column Wednesday, which discusses good values to be had at wine auctions. Why? Because while value is a relative term, the column still deals with ultra-expensive wines at a time of economic disaster. With most of the wines in these auctions, the bidding doesn't even start below around $100 a bottle. Frankly, that's a little rich for me.

There's travel, there's frugal travel and then there's Leon Logothetis. In his television show, "Amazing Adventures of a Nobody," which airs on the Fox Reality Channel (an all-reality channel on cable and satellite), Mr. Logothetis, a bald 31-year-old Briton, roams the world on an inconceivably low budget: He circled the United Kingdom on £5 a day, and got from Times Square to the Hollywood sign on $5 a day. And in the third season beginning Jan. 25, he journeys from Paris to Moscow on just 5 euros a day. Mr. Logothetis spoke about his no-budget travel strategies by telephone from Las Vegas, where he'd just spent an atypically unexciting New Year's Eve.

Updated, 3:46 p.m. | A federal judge rejected the legal challenge to the changes to New York City term limits law on Tuesday, and that is a big victory for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who sought the change so he could run for a third term this fall, and for the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who backed Mr. Bloomberg's bid.A federal judge in Brooklyn, Charles P. Sifton, dismissed the lawsuit on Tuesday in a 64-page ruling [pdf]. Judge Sifton rejected the plaintiffs' contention that their constitutional rights were violated when the Council amended the term limits law. And he found that under state law, the Council was not required to conduct a referendum before adopting the term limits amendment. He also rejected the plaintiffs' contention that New York City's conflict of interest law was violated by the Council's adoption of the term limits amendment.

I'm always mystified that more people don't know about Times Reader, which is by far the best way to read The New York Times on line. I still prefer the physical newspaper to the cyber version, but if I'm on the road and can't get the newspaper then I live by Times Reader. It's a 10-minute download of the entire paper, and then it sits on your laptop and you can read it on a plane or in a car. There's none of that infuriating waiting for a page to open, and you can read the paper systematically from beginning to end.

By rights, a company named for the goddess of victory should not be selling its women's goods like so many Gillette Venus razors. (Because the answer to "What do women want?" really is not "Anything, as long as it's dipped in pastels and embossed with flowers.") But with Nike's just-announced new Sister series of women-only training shoes, what's good for the goose is only good enough for the goose. According to today's Media Post online, Nike has found that too many women wear running shoes for gym workouts, so it's cooked up a lighter sneaker with soles designed to withstand more side-to-side movement as opposed to a running shoe's forward thrust. So far, so good. It's the company's also-just-announced online ad campaign, which plans to have "viral videos that show the shoes being folded up and compressed into tiny handbags" that has us wanting to hurl a socket wrench from the Think Pink Tool Kit at the company's collective head. What's next? A complimentary issue of Cosmo with every purchase?

When Mickey Rourke won a Golden Globe the other night for his role in "The Wrestler," the Bagger found himself watching with warring impulses. The newsman side of him - he still is one deep inside the ninny suit he is wearing - was hoping that Mr. Rourke would do something spectacular: Say something either ill-considered or too true for his own good, thereby creating a stir, which creates feelings, which kicks up coverage - well, you get the idea. In an industry and ritual that too frequently follow the script, Mr. Rourke is the one who will not obey, who will not go along, who will not shut his mouth even when it is in his interest to do so. (His posse from the film is ferociously protective - the Bagger has not once encountered Darren Aronofsky, the director of "The Wrestler," without getting an earful about a piece that appeared in The New York Times Magazine which he felt was not honest or fair.)

Two former rivals, now playing very different roles, will head to Capitol Hill on Tuesday. President-elect Barack Obama intends to make the case for his proposed $800 billion bailout package to Senate Democrats at their weekly lunch. And Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will face questions from the Foreign Relations Committee at her confirmation hearing for the job of secretary of state.
Los Angeles Times: Peter Schrag says the state G.O.P. is looking more and more "like a suicidal cult than a political party."

Even as some allies expressed doubts about his intention to run, Representative Anthony D. Weiner laid out a forceful agenda for a possible 2009 mayoral campaign and issued a stinging critique of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, his likely chief rival in the race.

President-elect Barack Obama intends to nominate Julius Genachowski , an adviser on technology issues and longtime friend, to become the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, advisers to Mr. Obama said.
BAGHDAD -- What do you get when you take 14,300 candidates vying for 440 seats in a nascent democracy where suicide bombings are a daily threat?

Among the 2,500 companies showing their wares at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas all last week was Lok8U, a British manufacturer of a watch, called Num8, which uses satellites to allow you to track your children.

In an op-ed in The Los Angeles Times, David L. Ulin, the paper's book review editor, takes issue with the National Endowment for the Arts' report, issued yesterday, which reported an increase in reading in the last six years: "I'm not so sure reading really was in crisis - any more than it ever has been."

DETROIT -- With Cobo Center overrun with weenie hybrids and electric-car one-upmanship, it's good to see there's still room for what every teenager demands from an auto show: Comic-book curves, superhuman speed -- and a name straight out of a study-hall doodle pad.

My colleague John Leland, writing from the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, sent us these musings on the first-ever exhibit there devoted to technology aimed at the elderly, their adult children and their medical providers. He would like to pursue this subject in the future, so if you've had some experience, good or bad, with technological innovations intended for seniors, please post below. We welcome the thoughts of all concerned digerati, parents and children, old and not-so-old. - Jane Gross
Vector Capital has finally won Aladdin Knowledge Systems, the maker of computer security products that it has been chasing since August.
The wealth-management joint venture between Citigroup and Morgan Stanley is expected to be highly lucrative. But according to The New York Post and The Financial Times, it will also be expensive.

The Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs the Bronx Zoo and New York Aquarium, and wildlife research projects around the world, has sent out a bitingly funny video distress call (kind of a 1-minute mashup of "The Office" and "Wild Kingdom") on behalf of all of New York State's "living museums" -- public institutions that display plants and wildlife. For 15 years, they have gotten a small, but important, amount of money -- $9 million this past year -- through New York State's Environmental Protection Fund, society officials said. But that money is going away.

Decorated with swooping birds and stars and flowers, Toyota's electric vehicle normally might seem out of place at the Detroit auto show, where carmakers generally have put their most formidable iron on display.

Reinet Investments, the investment vehicle of South African billionaire Johann Rupert, confirmed that it's in discussions about participating in a management buyout of Lehman Brothers Merchant Banking, according to Bloomberg News.

After a federal magistrate refused to revoke bail on Monday for Bernard L. Madoff, the financier accused of operating a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, signs emerged that his lawyer was actively negotiating a plea agreement that could conclude the baffling fraud case without a trial, The New York Times's Diana B. Henriques reported.

For a few brief weeks, it seemed as if Vikram S. Pandit, the chief executive of Citigroup, was regaining a bit of trust on Wall Street. But on Monday, as the struggling financial giant moved toward a deal with Morgan Stanley for its Smith Barney brokerage unit, all the old demons returned, The New York Times's Eric Dash writes.

Language | Environment advocates have a sales problem because global warming is frightfully dull, an article says. Advice: Drop "environment," "sustainability" the prefix "eco" and the hectoring "save the planet." Talk instead of beauty, health, wealth, leisure, what have you. (Oh, and sex; don't forget sex.) "Since climate change is driven by per-head consumption, the way to mitigate it is simply to reimagine each of those values in ways that don't depend on buying too much stuff." [Intelligent Life]

Britain's private equity industry may find itself back in the crosshairs of British regulators following a report that said that many of the buyout shops that had agreed to a voluntary industry code on transparency are not complying with it.

Aster Data Systems, which stores data for social networking site MySpace and others, has raised $12 million in a second round of venture funding, VentureBeat reported.

The ruling by a federal magistrate judge Monday that allowed Bernard L. Madoff to remain free on bail is another example of our two-tiered system of justice, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his latest DealBook column.

The federal Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV got a phone call Monday morning from a colleague on the bench, who teased him about a ruling he had made, which had made the front page of a legal publication.

Hedge-fund firm GMB Capital Management is shutting down a fund that lost millions on bad bets that included having putting money with accused swindler Bernard L. Madoff, Reuters reported, citing sources familiar with the matter.

Lennar, the No. 2 U.S. homebuilder, again denied on Monday treating its joint ventures like a "Ponzi scheme" and tried to counter the allegation by providing fresh data on those ventures, Reuters reported.

Several start-up automakers are in hot pursuit of electric-powered vehicles, but they face an uphill road as they challenge major car companies like Toyota and General Motors in the race for the green car market, The Associated Press reported.

American International Group, moving ahead with asset sales, has received the first round of bids for its aircraft leasing unit, and is expected to start shopping its asset management business soon, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the matter said on Monday.

World | In a week of Bush swan songs, an article reminds that "some corners of the world will miss the 43rd president of the United States." There's Israel, of course; and Africa, where his approval stands as high as 80 percent for his commitment to fighting AIDS and malaria, and opposing atrocities in Sudan. ("In Darfur, many people reportedly name their newborn children George Bush.") Also among the wistful: India (see Week in Review); Colombia (free trade), Georgia and Ukraine (support against Russia). [BBC]
When the body of Adolf Merckle was discovered on the railroad tracks here last week, authorities ruled the German billionaire's death to be a suicide.
JPMorgan Chase said on Monday it will announce fourth-quarter results on Jan. 15, six days earlier than planned.

Citigroup will close its private banking unit in China, which aimed at the country's growing ranks of millionaires, and fold the operations into its consumer banking arm as it streamlines its businesses, Reuters reported, citing sources familiar with the situation.
Spanish prosecutors are investigating Banco Santander's loss of more than 2.3 billion euros of its clients' money by investing with Bernard L. Madoff, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Bank of America shares skidded 11.2 percent on Monday after an analyst said the largest United States bank might suffer a $3.6 billion fourth-quarter loss and again slash its dividend.
