Share your thoughts on the topic here, or discuss the Prius directly with Ms. Maynard at our Prius Diary discussion board on Facebook.

Republican and Democratic Senate leaders signaled on Monday that they would support the release of the second half of the Treasury's $700 billion financial system bailout fund, despite anger among many rank-and-file lawmakers over the Bush administration's management of the program, Dabid M. Herszenhorn and Edmund L. Andrews of The New York Times report.
Edward L. Glaeser is an economist at Harvard.

The Italian airline Alitalia agreed Monday to sell a minority stake to Air France-KLM, cementing ties with the airline just a day before Alitalia takes to the skies as a leaner, more cost-efficient airline, Caroline Brothers of The New York Times reported.
Is it time for Kohlberg Kravis Roberts to take Dollar General public?
A bad day on Wall Street was an even worse one for America's largest banks, Jack Healy of The New York Times writes.

Technology | Why do we still have fax machines? And come to think of it, why haven't print calendars gone the way of the dodo bird? In the case of facsimiles, it's because faxes have legal standing; multifunction printers give them a new life; and PDF's are a more complex technology. Print calendars? An indulgence of short attention spans. [Wired, Smart Set]
Update | 9:02 a.m. The Borders Group, the troubled book chain, named a hedge fund executive as its chairman on Tuesday as part of its effort to stay afloat.

Daoud Kuttab, a Palestinian journalist and former professor of journalism at Princeton University, joins our panel of analysts to discuss Israel's war against Hamas, which entered its 18th day on Monday.

History | The history of in-laws staying in the White House suggests the Obamas are joining some interesting company. Truman's pain of a mother-in-law supposedly asked, "Why would Harry run against that nice Mr. Dewey?" Then there's Grant's irascible, unreconstructed Confederate father-in-law -- the "Colonel" -- who wasn't shy about giving visitors a piece of his mind. Also, Ike's beloved, joke-cracking Min, and more. [Mental Floss]

Pity the poor public relations executives assigned to make real estate projects sound exciting and innovative. There are only so many ways you can say a condo development will "redefine urban/coastal/rural living."

Internet | Does the debate over the future of copyright law make your eyes glaze over? Try some comic No Doz with this encounter between the Creative Commons advocate Lawrence Lessing and Steven Colbert last week on Comedy Central. [Hulu]

Privacy | A new 50-state map, "You Are Being Watched," raises alarm about the $300 million Washington has doled out to local governments to create what the A.C.L.U. calls a nationwide surveillance society filled with closed-circuit cameras. Yet beyond law enforcement, there's an upside to some cameras: ubiquitous casino surveillance and quick responses give Las Vegas one of the best heart attack survival rates in the country. [Wired, Parade]
The Borders Group book chain plans to name a hedge fund executive as its chairman as part of its effort to stay afloat, a person with knowledge of the announcement said.
A fast-moving blizzard brought snow and high winds, closing schools and causing more headaches for residents still trying to dig out from a record snowfall last month.
Stanford University has announced a $100 million initiative to study energy issues.
The salmonella bacteria that has sickened more than 400 people in 43 states has been conclusively linked to peanut butter, state health officials said.
Senator George V. Voinovich said he would not seek re-election in 2010, becoming the fourth Republican to make departure plans since the Democratic landslide in November.

The Tennessee Valley Authority said that tests showed slightly elevated levels of contaminants downstream from a coal-waste spill in Stevenson but that the amounts met federal standards for drinking water.
Al Franken was turned down when he asked Minnesota’s governor and secretary of state to issue an election certificate that would let him take office in the Senate.
The Department of Defense has identified 628 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.

Adam Helfant, a former lawyer for the N.H.L. and a Nike executive, was hired to run the men’s professional tennis tour. Helfant takes over the ATP a week before the start of the Australian Open. Helfant, 44, replaces Étienne de Villiers, who ran the tour since 2005 and stepped down last year.

Azeri, a former Horse of the Year, was still the property of Michael Paulson after a bid of $4.4 million fell short of the owner’s reserve price. Azeri, an 11-year-old mare in foal to another Horse of the Year, Ghostzapper, was expected to be the highlight of the first day of Keeneland’s horses of all ages sale. Instead, her failure to meet the reserve price underscored the effect the national economic crisis is having on the thoroughbred business.

Cristiano Ronaldo won the FIFA World Player of the Year award Monday to complete a sweep of the game’s top individual honors for 2008. Ronaldo, a 23-year-old winger for Portugal and Manchester United, received 935 votes in a worldwide poll of national team captains and coaches. Lionel Messi, a midfielder for Barcelona and Argentina, was the runner-up. Brazil’s Marta won the women’s award.

The French yachtsman Vincent Riou will be given a finishing position of third equal in the around-the-world Vendée Globe race despite having to pull out of the event when his yacht PRB lost its mast last week. Race organizers accepted his appeal, which was based on the fact the Riou, the 2005 race winner, had sustained the damage while rescuing a rival, Jean Le Cam.

The former Florida State safety Myron Rolle said in a text message that he would be heading to Oxford, England, for his Rhodes scholarship instead of entering the 2009 N.F.L. draft. Rolle started for most of three seasons at Florida State and was considered a strong professional prospect. Instead he will go to Oxford for a one-year master’s degree in medical anthropology. He said he would enter the 2010 draft.

Mike Schmidt and Barry Larkin will be coaches on the United States team at the second World Baseball Classic. The pitching coach Marcel Lachemann and the hitting coach Reggie Smith were also chosen for Manager Davey Johnson’s staff, USA Baseball announced. Schmidt, Larkin and the former major league player Bill Ripken will serve as auxiliary coaches.

Trevor Daley knocked his own rebound into the goal 1 minute 51 seconds into overtime to give the Dallas Stars a 5-4 victory over Detroit, ending the Red Wings’ six-game winning streak. In a flurry of activity in front of Detroit goalie Chris Osgood, Daley took a shot that was knocked down. The puck was still on the ice when he followed up for his fourth goal of the season. Osgood had a season-high 45 saves.

Tony Dungy retired Monday, after toying with the idea the last few seasons. He leaves such a legacy in Indiana, where he became the first African-American head coach to win the Super Bowl, that The Indianapolis Star will publish a special section on Tuesday to commemorate his tenure with the Colts. An obituary on Saturday about Charles Morgan Jr., a leading civil rights lawyer in the South, misstated his role in an appeal by Muhammad Ali of his conviction on draft-evasion charges. Mr. Morgan handled the appeal in district and appellate courts; he did not argue the case before the Supreme Court, where Mr. Ali was represented by the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. (Chauncey Eskridge and others argued the case there, and the court ruled in Mr. Ali’s favor in 1971.).
Democrats, in control for the first time since 1965, plan to revise rules that created a two-class system and left the minority party with little legislative authority.

A dance entry in the Listings pages on Friday about Gallim Dance, at Joyce SoHo, misstated the closing date. As schedule information with a review on Monday noted, the company performs through Sunday; the run does not end tonight.

Federal authorities have opened a criminal investigation of assaults against Latinos on Long Island, and an inquiry into the local police’s handling of such crimes.

An article on Monday about Al Jazeera’s coverage of the Gaza conflict misidentified the streaming service that the television network uses to put its content online. It is Livestation, not LiveStream.

Because of an editing error, an article and an accompanying picture caption on Monday about concern that an emphasis on prosecuting immigration crimes has siphoned resources from dealing with other crimes referred incorrectly to a comment by Barbara LaWall, a county prosecutor in Arizona, about the effect on federal cases in the future. She said she did not know how much longer she could take on such cases, not that she “did know.”.

An article on Saturday about popular anger against Israel in the Arab world over the Gaza invasion overstated, in some editions, what is known about Palestinian civilian and combatant deaths in Gaza since Israel’s military operation began on Dec. 27. While hundreds of Palestinians have been killed, as the article reported, the number of combatants among them is unclear. Combatants are not necessarily “most” of the total.

NBC’s broadcast of the Golden Globes ceremony attracted 14.6 million viewers during prime time on Sunday, according to Nielsen’s estimates, lifting the network to second place in the night’s ratings. Although the broadcast was down more than 5 million viewers from two years ago (20 million), it was up considerably over last year’s show (6.2 million), when a news conference substituted for the regular awards ceremony because of the writers’ strike. CBS led Sunday’s ratings, averaging nearly 30 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour with postseason football coverage. CBS’s “60 Minutes” followed at 8 (15.7 million), but the network gradually lost viewers as the night went on with “Cold Case” at 9 (12.4 million) and “The Unit” at 10 (10.4 million). ABC finished third, attracting 13.8 million viewers at 9 for “Desperate Housewives,” well below average for the series. At 8 ABC drew 10.3 million for “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition,” and at 10 “Brothers & Sisters” garnered 9.1 million. Fox ranked fourth over all as the two-hour seventh-season premiere of “24” delivered 12.5 million viewers from 8 to 10, well short of the 15.8 million who tuned in to the show’s last season debut, in 2007.

Well, she warned him that love is a losing game: Blake Fielder-Civil, the husband of the singer Amy Winehouse (both pictured above in June 2007), is beginning divorce proceedings against her, his lawyer announced on Monday. The lawyer, Henri Brandman, said that Mr. Fielder-Civil would seek a divorce on the grounds of infidelity, The Associated Press reported. The couple were married in May 2007, and both have had legal problems since then. Mr. Fielder-Civil was arrested in 2007 and later sent to jail for assaulting a man and offering him a bribe. Last week Ms. Winehouse dropped her appeal of a fine she paid in Norway for possession of what the police said was marijuana. In separate interviews with the British newspaper News of the World, Mr. Fielder-Civil has said he blamed himself for his wife’s drug problems, and Ms. Winehouse, who was hospitalized several times last year, has said she was off drugs and in love with a man she met on vacation in St. Lucia.

A little more than a month after the departure of its publisher, the company has appointed Jon Anderson of Running Press to fill the post.
On the heels of its attention-grabbing trip to North Korea last February, the New York Philharmonic is planning another high-profile visit for next season: to Vietnam.

Why would a mosquito bite one person many times in a short period?
Rickey Henderson was elected into the Hall of Fame in his first year on the ballot, while Jim Rice walked in.
Maybe it sounds vindictive to dwell upon the rejection of Mark McGwire for the third consecutive year, but he brought it on himself.
Measles remains a public health problem in Europe, and there are “serious doubts” that it can be eliminated by 2010 as health officials had hoped, according to a new report in The Lancet.

At a two-day conference to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the normalization of relations, speakers focused on China’s stunning economic growth.

LOS ANGELES -- From a glass-walled penthouse above the Sunset Strip it is impossible not to observe that times have changed. Just down the street, the original Spago restaurant, that emblem of the flush 1980s, is an empty shell. And here in the penthouse offices of Senator Entertainment, Bret Easton Ellis, another symbol of those super-slick times, is sprawled in a soft chair, wearing decidedly unslick running shoes and sweats.

Services Tuesday in Henderson.

Q.When you wake up with several mosquito bites and find one very bloated mosquito in the room, why has it bitten you so many times in a short period? A. A female mosquito takes a blood meal when it is carrying fertilized eggs, seeking a blood protein that allows the eggs to develop. Several reasons have been suggested for the multiple bites that many people (and animals) may experience from a single mosquito.

SIGNER--Michael A. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion family mourns the untimely death of our beloved friend, teacher, and mentor, Michael A. Signer. Professor Signer was the Abrams Professor of Jewish Thought and Culture at the University of Notre Dame. As an expert in medieval Hebrew and Latin interpretations of and commentaries on the Bible, he was a leader in Jewish-Catholic dialogue in Israel, Europe, and North America. An esteemed rabbinical alumnus of HUC-JIR, he served for almost two decades at our Los Angeles campus as Professor of Medieval History and Commentaries and as co-chair of the Joint Commission on Inter-religious Affairs of the Reform Movement since 1998. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Betty, and their daughters, Alisa and Hanna. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Barbara Friedman, Chair

WALDMAN--Seymour M. It is with deep regret that the law firm of Vladeck, Waldman, Elias & Engelhard announces the passing of Seymour M. Waldman, a longtime partner, this past weekend in Croton-on-Hudson. He was 85. Mr. Waldman had been a named partner at the firm for thirty years. He also served as general counsel to the Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers Union, the parent organization to bricklayers locals around the country. Prior to joining the firm, he had practiced law for over twenty years with his father, Louis Waldman, and his brother, Paul. Mr. Waldman, who represented unions throughout his entire career, was recognized nationally for his skills as an advocate in a wide variety of cases ranging from antitrust to racketeering law. Mr. Waldman served in the Navy in World War II and graduated from Columbia Law School. The firm extends its heartfelt condolences to Seymour's wife, Lois, and his children and grandchildren. He will be missed for his wise counsel, and the mentoring he provided through the years. A memorial service is planned for the near future. For details, call 212-403-7329.

SOTER--George N.,84, said goodbye to the ''whole catastrophe'' and died peacefully on January 8. George was an award - winning advertising copywriter at many of the major agencies from the 1950s to the 1980s and from 1963 to 1982 ran the Greek Island boutique, part of his lifelong love for all things Greek. Adios, Yiorgo.

MADOFF STAYS AT HOME A federal magistrate has declined to jail Bernard L. Madoff after the government said he had violated the terms of his bail. Welcome to the two-tiered system of justice: the one for the rich -- and the one for everybody else. DealBook: Andrew Ross Sorkin. [B1.]

St.CLAIR--Robert Churchill, 83, died Sunday, January 4, 2009 in Poughkeepsie, NY. Robert was a graduate of the American Ballet Theater School and was a stage manager and dancer in the Actors Equity Union in New York City for 30 years. He also worked for Esquire and the New York Times on their photo shoots. He is survived by his life-partner of 46 years, John Baylis of Wappingers Falls, his half-sister, Lotus LaRocca; nephew, Joe St.Clair and niece, Rusty Huffsteader. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Actors Fund of America, 729 7th Avenue, 10th Fl., New York, NY 10019. Services by Robert H. Auchmoody Funeral Home, Fishkill, NY.

ESBIN--Jerry, 77, passed away on January 9th surrounded by his loving family after a valiant 13 year battle with non-Hodgkins Lymphoma. Beloved husband of Judy. Cherished father of Scott (Beth) and Randi (Peter) Leeds. Devoted grandfather of Tyler and Casey Esbin and Zachary, Bennett and Sydney Leeds. Son of the late Sadie and Joseph Esbin. Loving brother to Martin Esbin, Brenda Monaco and the late Seymour Esbin. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was a graduate of Lafayette High School. He served in the US Navy during the years of the Korean War. Jerry was a member of the motion picture industry for over 40 years, beginning his career at the age of 18 in the mailroom of Columbia Pictures. He left Columbia after 24 years to work for AMC and then to Paramount Pictures where he became Division Manager. He then moved on to United Artists, where he rose to the title of President of Distribution, and remained there during the merge with MGM. He then took up the position of Executive VP of Domestic Distribution at TriStar Pictures during its inception, leaving to become President of Lowes Theatres after which he retired. He was a member of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts & Sciences and a former President of the Will Rogers Institute. He was involved for many years with Variety Boys and Girls Clubs in NY and was also a longtime member of the Friars Club. Jerry was a dynamic personality and was generous throughout his life to those friends and family he cared for deeply. A memorial service was held on Monday. Donations may be offered to the Will Rogers Institute in his name.

KAU--Nicholas, 1990 - 2009. Cherished friend and classmate from pre-school and Trinity School. Embodiment of shining youth. Our profound condolences to parents Elizabeth and Randall, brothers Andrew and Timothy, and Nick's grandparents, uncles, aunts, cousins, and other family members and legions of friends and admirers. Anne, Ed, Louisa, and Eleanor Strauss

MINDLIN--Ruth, 92, of New York City, died January 10. Colorful, creative, fun, giving. Loved by many. Wife of the late Sidney. Three children, eight grandchildren, 16 greatgrandchildren, a sister and brother.

A federal magistrate refused on Monday a government request that Bernard L. Madoff be jailed until he can be tried on charges of operating a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, saying that the government had not proved that he was a flight risk or a security risk. The ruling, by Magistrate Judge Ronald L. Ellis, allows Mr. Madoff to remain in his Manhattan apartment, wearing an electronic monitor device and being watched around the clock by a security team paid for by his wife.

BREGLIO--Sylvia V.,on January 11, 2009, beloved wife of John (deceased), loving mother of Joan Perrella, John and Jeffrey Breglio, wonderful grandmother to Eliza Mason, Nola Heller and Louis Perrella. CHRISTMAN--Paula J. The administration, trustees, directors and staff of Catholic Health Services of Long Island and St. Francis Hospital, The Heart Center, mourn the death of Paula J. Christman, our cherished friend and longtime benefactor. Mrs. Christman and her husband Thomas have been dedicated members of the St. Francis community for many years, and their outstanding generosity helped to secure St. Francis's position as one of the leading heart centers in the nation. Mr. Christman is a member of the St. Francis Hospital Board of Trustees and the CHS Board of Directors and is a Past Chairman of the Board of St. Francis Hospital. Mrs. Christman's friendship and support will never be forgotten by the St. Francis family. Our deepest sympathies are extended to Mr. Christman and sons Thomas, Theodore, Daniel, and John Paul and their families.

LEVINE--Beatrice (nee Stern), 94 of North Woodmere, NY on Sunday, January 11, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Solomon Levine. Devoted mother of Robert (Mana) and Ronnie (Ira). She had a extraordinary enthusiasm for life.

HOLLOWAY--Cynthia Ellen, passed away on November 14, 2008. She embraced life with remarkable passion and ended life with exceptional courage and grace. With a brilliant mind and an eye for beauty, she focused her creativity, energy, and initiative on corporate goals for her employer with the same fervor that she played the piano, selected a work of art for her home, or mastered the par five hole on her favorite golf course. She was a loving wife and dearly cherished her sister, mother, and father. She was a graduate of Vassar College and received a MBA from The Wharton School. She worked for the Alcoa Aluminum Company in various capacities for 33 years, most recently serving as Assistant Treasurer. She had homes in Manhattan and in Chestnut Hill, MA. She traveled extensively growing up and during her career with Alcoa, living in Madrid, Spain and in Tokyo, Japan. She is survived by her husband, George Wharton, her sister, Katherine Holloway, her mother, Martha Holloway and her father, Pierre Holloway. We mourn her passing and celebrate her spirit.

Late last month, Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, declared that anyone killed defending Palestinians in the Gaza Strip would be rewarded in heaven as a martyr. Young men began lining up -- 70,000 in all -- to go off and die. A week later, however, Ayatollah Khamenei announced without explanation that no one was going anywhere to fight. ''I thank the pious and devoted youth who have asked to go to Gaza,'' he said in a televised address. ''But it must be noted that our hands are tied in this arena.''

Obese older women who never took postmenopausal hormones are at almost double the risk of developing ovarian cancer compared with peers of normal weight, a study has found. Among all older women, however, obese women were at only slightly higher risk for ovarian cancer than those of normal weight, the scientists found.

Pitchers with more than 300 victories and batters with more than 3,000 hits have no trouble piling up hundreds of votes for entry into baseball's Hall of Fame. But then there are the more modest players who get exactly one vote in their one year on the ballot, perhaps because a voter was trying to be funny -- each voter can list up to 10 names -- or maybe trying to be nice. Hal Lanier, who batted .228 in 10 seasons with the Giants and the Yankees, is a member of that club. So is Gates Brown, who played in 1,051 games with the Tigers and collected 582 hits. If you're doing the math, that's 2,418 short of 3,000. Jim Bibby, who pitched with four teams and went 111-101, got one vote, too.

An Army helicopter crashed at Texas A&M University in College Station on Monday afternoon, killing one person and injuring four. No one on the ground was hurt when the Blackhawk, engaged in training exercises for the university R.O.T.C., went down.

SLIDESHOW: Singing Its Last Aria Audio and images from the Amato Opera, a small opera company on the Bowery in downtown Manhattan, which, after 60 years, has sold its building and will close at the end of the season. At left, cast and crew after the last performance of ''The Merry Widow.''

RADOW--Corynne G.,on January 10, 2009. Beloved wife for 67 years of Seymour. Loving mother of Margie (Barry) Forrest, Joan Osleeb, Debra (Chris) Soussanin and Steve (Robin) Radow. Drivers over 70 are keeping their licenses longer and driving more than earlier generations, a trend that has led to dire predictions about car accident risks for aging baby boomers. But new research from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety should ease those fears. It shows that fatal car accidents involving older drivers have actually declined markedly in the past decade.

KAU--Nicholas James Peter, April 15, 1990, beloved son of Elizabeth Olmsted and Randall Kau and brother to Andrew and Timothy, died unexpectedly on January 10, 2009, at the age of 18. A lifelong Upper West Sider, Nicholas attended Park Avenue Christian and Trinity School before matriculating at Cornell University in 2008. Iron man wrestler, uproarious comic, Mario Party champion, walking Bmovie encyclopedia, master Shakespearean, Francop hone, bonnie bairn, char siu bao connoisseur, harlequin and ladies' man, storyteller and beach bum, footloose, generous, irrepressible, and joyous, Nicholas taught everyone around him to embrace their passions and love the just and noble. His death leaves desolation in many hearts, yet these same hearts rejoice with the utmost pride in his life--pride in his intelligence, kindness, and poise; pride in his beauty, vigor, and laughter. His family invites friends to stop by to pay their respects at a vigil any time between 6pm and 9pm on Friday, January 16, 2009, and an mass for the resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 11am, both at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, entrance on 87th St. between Broadway and West End Ave. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date at Trinity School. Instead of flowers, if you wish, please contribute to the Nicholas J. P. Kau fund at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 St., New York, NY, 10024. We hope to support theater and athletics as his particular passions.

Rickey Henderson never wanted to stop diving headfirst or dashing home or making a snatch catch of a fly ball or wearing a major league uniform. He never wanted to stop playing baseball. Even on the day that Henderson was elected into the National Baseball Hall of Fame, he still mused about playing one more game with the Oakland Athletics. ''I always want to reappear in a uniform with Oakland,'' Henderson said.

REDD--M. Paul, President and Publisher of The Westchester County Press, died on January 9th at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, CT. He was 80 years old. He served in the U.S. Army in World War II, and in 1954 married Orial Banks Redd. Redd was State Coordinator for Richard Ottinger's U.S. Senate campaign, statewide coordinator for William Van den Heuvel's Gubernatorial bid, and consultant to Sen. Edmund Muskie in his run for U.S. President. He was Executive Director of the West/ Putnam Affirmative Action Program and placed more than 4000 women and minorities in training programs to become union tradespeople. Redd was a Life Member of the NYS NAACP and board member of the Girl Scouts, the Urban League, the United Way and the American Red Cross. The landmark discrimination case he brought when denied a home in Rye led to passage of NYS anti-discrimination legislation called The Redd Bill in 1962. Later he would be elected that association's first cooperative board president. He is survived by Orial Redd, a daughter, Paula Redd Zeman and a son, M. Paul Redd, Jr. Memorial Service Friday, January 16th 10am, Grace Baptist Church, 52 South 6th Avenue, Mount Vernon, NY.

Stephanie Blythe, the mezzo-soprano and “a once-in-a-generation opera singer,” according to Anthony Tomassini, will be replaced at the Met on Jan. 14 in the role of Orfeo in Gluck’s Orfeo ed Euridice. The Metropolitan Opera has announced that Kirsten Chávez will sing the role, replacing Ms. Blythe who is ill.

The film director who was rejected by the president of Iran seems to have a bit more success in this hemisphere. In his latest foray into geopolitics, Oliver Stone chewed coca leaves and played soccer with the president of Bolivia on Tuesday. The activities accompanied an interview with President Evo Morales that is probably connected to Mr. Stone’s planned documentary on President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela, The Associated Press reported. In photos taken by the Bolivian government, Mr. Morales and Mr. Stone were seen kicking a ball and indulging in a local pastime around the presidential residence in La Paz. Mr. Stone interviewed President Chavez in Caracas this month.

Add Jennifer Hudson to the mix of overly ambitious beer commercials, office bets, French onion dip, and the assorted accouterments that go with America’s favorite sporting event. The singer will perform at the Super Bowl, The Associated Press reported. Brian McCarthy, a spokesman for the National Football League, confirmed on Wednesday that Ms. Hudson would sing the national anthem at the game in Tampa, Fla., on Feb. 1. The appearance will be the first in public since Ms. Hudson’s mother, brother and nephew were killed in Chicago in October.

Expect tears from “Legally Blonde” obsessed teeny-boppers and howls from Kings of Leon fans vacationing from Kansas. The Virgin Megastore in Times Square is closing, Billboard reported. The store, which is the highest-volume music store in the United States with an estimated $55 million in annual sales, is scheduled to shut its doors in April. Two real estate companies — Vornado and the Related Cos. — bought Virgin Entertainment Group North America in 2007. Vornado, the owner of the retail space in the building that houses the Megastore, is believed to want a tenant that would pay more rent.

Folk fans rejoice. Leonard Cohen, the 74-year-old Canadian singer-song writer, poet, novelist and voice of general romantic discontentment will play his first United States concert in more than 15 years next month, Reuters reported. Mr. Cohen, who has been on a worldwide tour since May, will perform at the Beacon Theater in New York on Feb. 19 with tickets to go on sale on Friday. A spokeswoman did not provide details of any additional shows.

The rap group that pioneered collaboration with rock ‘n’ roll will be added to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, along with another band that has broken genre barriers. RUN-D.M.C. and Metallica are among the musicians that will be inducted at a ceremony in Cleveland on April 4. The others are Jeff Beck, Little Anthony and the Imperials, Bobby Womack, and Wanda Jackson in the early influences category, along with Bill Black, DJ Fontana and Spooner Oldham as sidemen. The ceremony, which is taking place in Cleveland for the first time since 1997, will be broadcast live on Fuse TV. A limited number of tickets will be available to the public for the first time in the foundation’s history during a one-day walk-up sale on Jan. 24 at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame box office in Cleveland and through ticketmaster beginning Jan. 26.

The Zipper Factory, a theater and tavern, has closed, its owner, Lee Z. Davis, said. The theater, which opened in 2001, was home to such productions as “The Sensuous Woman” by Margaret Cho, “Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris,” “Jesus Is Magic” by Sarah Silverman, “Betty Rules” and Alan Cumming’s adaptation of Jean Genet’s “Elle.” Payments for advance tickets for shows scheduled at the theater will be refunded. … “Altar Boyz,” the musical comedy about to begin its fifth year at New World Stages, will make tickets available on a “pay what you can” basis for the 8 p.m. performance on Jan. 21. Tickets, which will cost a minimum of $1 for the theater restoration fee, will be available at 7 p.m. on a first-come/first-served basis. Regular prices for the show are $26.50, $59.99 and $79.99.Smallest Audience for ‘Idol’ Debut in Series History

Under the threat of bankruptcy, The Motion Picture & Television Fund, the entertainment industry’s health and social services charity, announced that its acute-care hospital and long-term care facility in Woodland Hills , Calif., would close. In a statement Jeffrey Katzenberg, chairman of the foundation’s board said, “MPTF is initiating these changes because it’s the right thing to do, but the fact is that we have no choice.” He added, “Although we are in good shape today, the acute-care hospital and long-term care facility are generating operating deficits that could bankrupt MPTF in a very few years.” The fund will focus instead on community-based care. Charlie Chaplin, Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks and D.W. Griffith founded the nonprofit in 1921.

I'm just about the only person in America who favors sweatshops, and I expect a few brickbats for my Thursday column. Let me clarify a couple of things. First, I don't deny the criticisms that are usually made of sweatshops -- the unhealthy conditions, the abuses, the low wages, and so on. Indeed, I think sweatshops are often worse than commonly perceived, because some kinds of factories -- such as those manufacturing leather garments -- often use chemicals that are dumped in nearby streams, raising environmental concerns as well.

Bernard L. Madoff played it safe at his bail hearing in Federal District Court on Wednesday. Not only was the disgraced financier wearing a bullet-proof vest, it was color-coordinated with his dark suit, although it did stand out just a bit.

I've got two thoughts on the selection of Carol Bartz as chief executive of Yahoo. First, Yahoo's board appears to have selected her for exactly the same reasons it chose Terry Semel. Second, her first big test will be a decision on whether to outsource Yahoo's search operation to Microsoft. I'm not as convinced this is a good idea as many analysts and observers are.

In the convoluted world of college athletics and education, sometimes it takes a while for academics to acknowledge what appears to be obvious. That's what happened at the University of Michigan, where The Ann Arbor News ran a series of articles last March with evidence that 251 athletes took independent study classes between 2004 and 2007 with the same professor and their grades were radically higher than in their regular classes. The series made it obvious that many of these athletes were steered to the professor, John Hagen, to help keep their eligibility. (Michigan, of course, denied this, kicking and screaming.)

There's no question that the picture quality delivered to a TV by various sources has sharply improved, in part thanks to the cables that connect the two devices. VHS, the now virtually extinct videotape standard that won out over Betamax, produced basically a terrible picture, unwatchable by today's DVD standards. But even that image could be improved by using an S-video cable to connect a VHS player to a TV, rather than the yellow, red, and white connectors known as RCA cables.

This fall, The Times Magazine asked the highly regarded portraitist Nadav Kander to photograph Barack Obama's administration as it was being assembled. The result is "Obama's People," 52 full-page color portraits taken in mid-December and earlier this month in Chicago and Washington of the vice president-elect and the incoming president's advisers, aides and cabinet secretaries-designate, along with the legislators who are likely to be key to moving the administration's agenda along. In the online presentation of the portfolio, Mr. Kander and the Times's director of photography, Kathy Ryan, discuss putting those portrait sessions together and what happened behind the scenes. FLORENCE, Italy -- Comme des Garçons made a first-time appearance at Pitti showing its more classic Homme Deux line, previously only available in Japan. Smart move. This is a very retail-friendly line focused on tailoring. The play-on-formal collection, almost completely dark, featured a lot of vests with polka-dot linings, great jackets with cutaways and wool rather than the expected satin lapels. I loved the higher-waisted pleated pants. Prepare for the pleat ... we'll see if we see more of that in Milan and Paris!

With Citigroup now planning to whittle itself down into a fraction of its current gargantuan self, the firm is under the spotlight more than ever. Moving up its earnings announcement to Friday from next week only adds to the scrutiny.

Wine | The White House needs a new wine policy, a columnist advises Obama. The Bush-era custom of serving only "strapping, assertive" domestic wines -- including an '05 Mondavi that's like "sucking tree bark" -- just won't do in the new dispensation of multilateral nuance and subtlety. In short, it's time to end our dependence on domestic wine sources and stimulate the economy as we build up the strategic wine cellar reserve. [Slate]

The last remaining structural remnants of the 460-foot-long ramp at the World Trade Center site, leading from street level down nearly to bedrock, were hoisted up and out of ground zero by a crane on Wednesday -- there being no ramp any longer on which to haul the X-shaped truss work.

Winter can bring all sorts of unwanted critters inside, but in recent years the Cimex lectularius, or bed bug, has begun invading more and more homes and hotels across the country. Nobody is entirely sure why; some suggest that the outlawing, for perfectly legitimate environmental reasons, of DDT and its successor pesticides has promoted the bugs' comeback. What is clear is that these little blood-suckers are very democratic, attacking the well-off and the poor alike, especially in crowded urban areas. The bites leave welts but apparently do not deposit disease--though that's small consolation to sufferers.

Reports and rumors of Fidel Castro's imminent demise are swirling with tropical-storm force winds. The 82-year-old Castro, ailing from an undisclosed illness, did not appear at the Jan. 1 celebrations of Cuba's 50th anniversary of the revolution he led.

Terror | The worst places in the world to be a terrorist, an article says, are Singapore, Jordan, Egypt, Russia and -- France? Wait a minute, France? Yes, with tough police tactics and long detentions without charge, the oft-derided "cheese-eating surrender monkeys" belong in the ranks of nations "making unsavory choices between protecting civil rights and providing security" by favoring the latter. [Foreign Policy]

New York City will spend $24 million in federal financing to rehabilitate and resell 115 foreclosed homes, one of the most aggressive steps in recent years that city officials have taken to prevent the vacant properties from becoming a blight on neighborhoods, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced on Wednesday.The city will use the money to take control of so-called real estate-owned homes, or foreclosed properties owned by banks that have failed to be sold at auction. The city has already bought the first four homes -- two on Staten Island, one in the Bronx and one in Queens.

Marketcetera, a Silicon Valley-based start-up, has developed open-source trading software that it says will make the creation of custom financial trading systems easier and cheaper. Rather than creating their own products, financial services firms, hedge funds and others can pick up the Marketcetera Platform software and use it as a basic framework for their operations. The financial companies just plug their algorithms and trading policies into the system and let it handle the demanding processing jobs required to obtain and analyze financial data.

It's a question that has been on many a political pundit's lips: does Barack Obama's victory signify a historic electoral realignment, the end of Republican dominance and the start of a new Democratic ascendancy? Writing in The New Republic, John B. Judis says yes. Obama's "election is the culmination of a Democratic realignment that began in the 1990s, was delayed by September 11 and resumed with the 2006 election." Michael Tomasky, in The New York Review of Books, is less sure: "the jury is still out," he says. Meanwhile, over at Commentary, John Podhoretz sees "a wholesale flight from the Republican party but not an epoch-making reversal of partisan or ideological direction." However one comes down on the question of an interparty realignment, though, it does seem that an intraparty realignment has indeed taken place. Obama's Democratic party is not your parents' Democratic party.

The laid-back, family-living-room-style event drew some of the biggest names in town - Tom Cruise, Freida Pinto, Danny Boyle, Warren Beatty, Elizabeth Banks, Kristin Scott Thomas, Ralph Fiennes, Marisa Tomei, among others - many of whom have either been interviewed by Hirschberg for one of our magazine covers or for T's popular "Screen Test" video series. While some doubt the wisdom of Yahoo's selection of Carol Bartz as chief executive, the move would actually seem to be a logical step, assuming most shareholders would still like to see a full-blown deal with Microsoft. Ms. Bartz brings technology credentials solid enough to make her a credible candidate and has worked for enough different companies that she should be able to maintain the strategic detachment that will be required. But perhaps even more important, she apparently has no poisonous past with Steve Ballmer of Microsoft, who just can't seem to resist letting people know just how personal it got between him and Jerry Yang, Ms. Bartz's predecessor.

It may simply be a bump in the road for President-elect Barack Obama's transition, but the news that his pick for treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, failed to pay more than $34,000 in federal taxes within the past decade is, as The Times's Jackie Calmes notes, at the very least a "major embarrassment" for the Obama team.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has emerged as the top choice of New York State voters to fill the Senate seat being vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton, easily besting Caroline Kennedy, according to Quinnipiac University poll results released on Wednesday. The results found that a plurality of respondents believed Ms. Kennedy was not qualified and would not be a good senator, though many believed that Gov. David A. Paterson will appoint her anyway.

What once looked like a gleaming example of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's financial skill -- the Yankee Stadium deal -- is suddenly looking like one of his biggest vulnerabilities. State lawmakers have subpoenaed team and city officials to an emergency hearing on Wednesday in advance of a vote scheduled for Friday on whether to extend $372 million in additional tax-free financing for the stadium.

MSNBC at theaters, coffee shops on inauguration day | Inauguration coverage by the cable news channel MSNBC will be projected onto movie theater screens in 21 cities next Tuesday, Wednesday's New York Times reports. The channel is also planning to announce a partnership with Starbucks to simulcast its coverage in 650 of the company's stores. (1/14, 7:30 a.m.)

Shares in Bank of China rose Wednesday after Royal Bank of Scotland sold its entire stake in the mainland's No. 3 lender for $2.37 billion, joining a recent string of investors who have cut their holdings in Chinese banks.
A new report indicates investment losses left Gulf Arab government funds more than $80 billion poorer last year despite the windfall from record oil prices, The Associated Press reported.

Blockbuster is stamping its brand on CinemaNow's system for delivering movies over the Internet, providing the video rental chain with another avenue for reaching consumers who want to rent and buy movies without traveling to a store.

Struggling U.S. automaker Chrysler is in talks to sell assets to Renault-Nissan and parts supplier Magna, sources with knowledge of the discussions have told Reuters, though the French automaker Wednesday denied such talks were under way.
Installing a grand artistic exhibit at European Union headquarters in Brussels has become part of a tradition for each new country taking over the E.U.'s rotating presidency.
Staggered by losses despite two federal rescues, Citigroup is accelerating moves to dismantle parts of its troubled financial empire in an effort to placate regulators and its anxious investors.

Man Group, the world's largest listed hedge fund firm, plans to take legal action, in conjunction with its investors, over the firm's exposure to the alleged fraud by U.S. financier Bernard L. Madoff, according to Reuters.

The bad bets made by executives at Independent Bank of Michigan are on display in spots across the state: a defunct bowling alley, a new but never occupied shopping center and the luxurious Whispering Woods Estates, which offers prime lots for never-constructed dream homes.

Behavior | How teamwork becomes groupthink: "Members of a group are understandably hesitant to cooperate with, even acknowledge, the good ideas of 'internal rivals'-that is, their own colleagues." So either the good ideas come from outside, at greater cost, or the team collaborates so well they march resolutely in "accelerated, false consensus" off a cliff. [Utne Reader]

President-elect Barack Obama intends to nominate Julius Genachowski, an adviser on technology issues and a longtime friend, to become the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton reported, citing advisers to Mr. Obama.

President-elect Barack Obama is nearing an appointment of his "car czar" and appears to be focused on Steven Rattner, the financier with close connections to the Democratic Party, The New York Times reported, citing people briefed on the conversations.

Japan's Toshiba said it is in talks to buy Fujitsu's hard-disk drive business, a deal that would create the world's largest maker of small hard drives and is reportedly worth between $340 million and $450 million.
JPMorgan Chase shares climbed nearly 7 percent on Tuesday after the company said late Monday it is bringing forward its results by six days.

A senior executive at the Swiss bank UBS was declared a fugitive on Tuesday, two months after being indicted by a federal judge in connection with a widening investigation of UBS's offshore private banking services, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.
Bank of America will call its securities brokerage business Merrill Lynch Wealth Management and continue to use the bull logo, the bank said in a memo to employees Tuesday.

An unusual foreign foray into the German newspaper business ended Tuesday when Mecom, a British media investment company, sold its German publications in an effort to reduce its debt, The New York Times's Eric Pfanner writes.

In tapping Carol Bartz as Yahoo's new chief executive on Tuesday, the company's board has selected a seasoned manager and tough-minded technology executive who established Autodesk, the maker of design software, as a market leader and successfully steered it through a boom and bust cycle, The New York Times's Miguel Helft writes.

Broad stock indexes rose slightly as a rebound in oil prices lifted energy producers and improving credit markets helped banks, but blue chips were lower amid concern about falling profits.

The United States attorney's office in Manhattan has filed lawsuits against the owners of five theater district hotels -- the Ameritania, the Amsterdam Court, the Carter, the Moderne and the Radio City Suites -- that accuse the hotels of violating the federal Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990.

Anthropology | One searches in vain to find a state of pacifism in nature, an anthropologist writes -- not that famous researchers haven't tried. Margaret Mead's idyllic Samoan tribes were later discredited; so were Jane Goodall's chimps. "There has been a persistent belief through countless societies that life is better, much better, somewhere else." But not where the chimps tear the baby baboons apart "limb from limb." [Wall Street Journal]

Curtis Joyner, the presiding judge in the case, let stand potential charges of libel and conspiracy against Susan Polgar and Paul Truong, two members of the board who are married.
After selling some of her buttery products at farmers’ markets in the Boston area, Tzurit Or opened Tatte Fine Cookies and Cakes last spring in Brookline, Mass.
An Op-Ed column on Sunday, about Frank Sinatra, misidentified the arranger of the Sinatra version of “My Way.” He was Don Costa, not Nelson Riddle.

The Red Bulls traded midfielder Dave van den Bergh to F.C. Dallas for forward Dominic Oduro and a second-round selection (18th over all) in Thursday’s Major League Soccer draft. The teams also swapped first-round picks — the Red Bulls will select 11th over all; Dallas will select 14th.

Hill ’n’ Dale Farms said the multiple graded stakes-winning filly Indyanne was euthanized after breaking an ankle during a race last month. A statement from the farm said veterinarians determined it would have been inhumane to continue treatment.

Frank Spaziani, a long-time assistant at Boston College who was passed over for the head coaching job in 2006, was named Tuesday to succeed Jeff Jagodzinski, who was fired last week after two seasons when he interviewed for the Jets’ coaching job. Spaziani, 61, built top defenses during his 10 years as coordinator with the Eagles. ¶Utah Coach Kyle Whittingham might have been the only coach to cast a No. 1 vote for his team, but his fellow coaches gave him a consolation prize by naming him the American Football Coaches Association’s coach of the year in the Football Bowl Subdivision. Whittingham’s Utes went 13-0 and beat Alabama in the Sugar Bowl for the best record in the program’s 115-year history. Utah also has the longest current bowl winning streak at eight with Whittingham winning the last four. But Utah finished No. 2 in The Associated Press poll and fourth in the coaches’ final poll. coach.

Hélio Castroneves is being replaced on Team Penske by the Australian driver Will Power — at least until Castroneves’s tax evasion trial is resolved. Castroneves, a two-time Indianapolis 500 winner, has pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax evasion involving about $5.5 million in income stashed in offshore accounts. He is scheduled to go to trial in Miami on March 2, just over a month before the IndyCar season begins. Tim Cindric, the president of Team Penske, said Power, a former Champ Car star, would handle the winter testing for the car assigned to Castroneves and be ready, if necessary, to race. ¶Hall of Fame Racing became the latest Nascar team to use a merger to stave off collapse, aligning with Yates Racing to keep its operation running into the new season. Hall of Fame ended its technical alliance with Joe Gibbs Racing at the end of last season, then laid off most of its workers last month as sponsorship difficulties put its 2009 schedule in doubt. The building that the team leased was also put up for sale. Under the new alignment, Hall of Fame’s No. 96 will switch to Ford and operate out of Yates’s recently expanded facility. No driver was chosen for the No. 96, which used multiple drivers last season after J. J. Yeley was fired midway through the year. merge.

Frank Gifford, the Giants' Hall of Fame running back, never intended to write a book about the 1958 N.F.L. championship game between the Giants and the Baltimore Colts. Someone else was supposed to: David Halberstam.

An article in some editions on Jan. 5 about Michael Weisser, the new rabbi at the Free Synagogue of Flushing, Queens, reported that the synagogue’s religious school closed some years ago. The article may have left the incorrect impression that the synagogue currently offers no religious instruction at all. It still provides preschool and family education classes on weekends, as well as preparation for bar mitzvahs and bat mitzvahs.
An editorial on Tuesday about the Rainbow Room’s struggles cited the wrong amount of rent set by an arbitrator. It is $6 million a year, not $6 million a month.

The Books of The Times review last Wednesday, about “Appetite for Self-Destruction: The Spectacular Crash of the Record Industry in the Digital Age,” by Steve Knopper, referred incorrectly to efforts to limit copying of music on Digital Audio Tapes in the mid-1980s. Widgets were installed in tape players to limit copying; record labels did not install them on the tapes.
A senior Pentagon official in the Bush administration said that interrogators had tortured a Guantánamo detainee.
Evgeni Malkin and Jordan Staal each scored goals, and Sidney Crosby had a pair of assists that sparked the Penguins to a 4-2 victory against the Flyers on Tuesday.
Kobe Bryant sank a 3-pointer with 27 seconds left and the Los Angeles Lakers beat the undermanned Houston Rockets, 105-100, on Tuesday night.

An article on Jan. 1 about New York’s settlement of a sexual harassment case against Edwin Méndez-Santiago, who recently resigned as commissioner for the aging, misspelled the surname of his successor, and, because of an editing error, also misspelled her given name. She is Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, not Lillian Barios-Paoli.

A picture caption on Saturday with an article about a vote by the House of Representatives to give women new tools to challenge sex discrimination by employers gave an incorrect given name from The Associated Press for the co-president of the National Women’s Law Center, who met with Speaker Nancy Pelosi. She is Marcia Greenberger, not Marsha.

Because of an editing error, an article and a headline on Sunday about the selection of the Rev. Dr. Sharon E. Watkins to participate in the national prayer service the day after the inauguration of Barack Obama described her role at the ceremony incorrectly. Although she will deliver the sermon, she will not be “leading the service.”.

An article on Saturday about immigrant families who choose charter schools as a way to shield their children from the American youth culture misstated the age of Yaqub Ali, an eighth grader in Minneapolis, and referred incorrectly to his arrival in the United States. An article on Saturday about plans by Barack Obama’s mother-in-law, Marian Robinson, to live in the White House quoted incorrectly from a 2007 interview with her son, Craig Robinson, about her concerns over Mr. Obama’s safety. The point that “she was very afraid for his safety” was a paraphrase of comments by Mr. Robinson; it was not a direct quotation. (When asked about the issue, Mr. Robinson said, “My sister and my mom were worried about it the most.”).

An article on Sunday about the competition to be the next chairman of the Republican National Committee misstated one candidate’s position on abortion. The candidate, Michael Steele of Maryland, says he opposes abortion in all cases; he does not support exemptions in cases of incest and rape, or when the life of the mother is in danger.

In case you were waiting to hear who might be singing on Sunday for the opening event of the presidential inauguration before deciding whether you’ll attend, here are some of the performers. Yes, Bruce Springsteen, above, top left, will be there. Also Beyoncé, top right, and Bono, bottom left. And Stevie Wonder, Will.i.am and Shakira, too. All at the same event. They’re singing at the Lincoln Memorial in a program that starts around 2:30 p.m.; it is free and open to the public. And if you can’t stand the cold, the concert will be presented that night from 7 to 9 on HBO. Apart from those already mentioned, here are more names of what the Presidential Inaugural Committee is calling the initial talent lineup: Garth Brooks, above, bottom right, and Mary J. Blige, Sheryl Crow, Renée Fleming, Josh Groban, Herbie Hancock, Heather Headley, John Legend, Jennifer Nettles, John Mellencamp, Usher and James Taylor. In addition to music, there will be readings of historical passages by Jamie Foxx, Martin Luther King III, Queen Latifah and Denzel Washington.

Much of the great art in France may be ancient, but the audience is about to get much younger, officials hope. President Nicolas Sarkozy unveiled a plan on Tuesday that will allow all French youths under 25 and schoolteachers to enter museums free starting April 4, Agence France-Presse reported. In a speech promoting French culture in the coming year, Mr. Sarkozy also said that he would lift a partial freeze on state financing for the performing arts. He announced as well that he planned to create a new national history museum.

ROME -- Cardinal Pio Laghi, a veteran Vatican diplomat who in 2003 urged President Bush not to start the war in Iraq, died Saturday in Rome. He was 86. He died at a hospital in Rome where he had been receiving treatment for a blood disease, Vatican Radio said in a statement.

Four members of Congress have asked the Department of Labor to monitor the search for a new executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, requesting that it ensure a transparent and aboveboard election. ''I'm concerned about fairness,'' Representative Edolphus Towns said Tuesday from Washington in a telephone interview. ''The election to replace Gene Upshaw is important, and we want to make certain that the process is fair and open.''

Peter R. Orszag, President-elect Barack Obama's choice for budget director, called for urgent action at his confirmation hearing to ''jump-start the economy out of the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression'' and said the new administration wanted $775 billion to $800 billion for public works, transportation and other projects. But Mr. Orszag warned the Senate Budget Committee that even without new stimulus spending, the federal budget deficit in the current fiscal year was ''likely to exceed $1 trillion -- more than 8 percent of gross domestic product and the largest in our history with the exception of the Civil War and the two World Wars.''

MacMILLEN--William Charles, Jr.,longtime resident of Lawrence, New York, on January 8, 2009 at the age of 95. Born May 24, 1913 in Troy, New York, to the late William C. and Anna (Dugan). Bill graduated from Williams College in 1935 and Albany Law School in 1937, cum laude. He served as a major in the United States Army Air Forces during World War II and was decorated with the Legion of Merit. Bill is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years, Barbara Southack Christy Downing, and by his children, Anita MacMillen Bird (J. Raymond) of Point Pleasant, New Jersey, William C. III (Kay) of Burbank, California, and Nancy MacMillen Brown (John) of Pomona, New York, and his stepson, Paul Cook Downing, III (Martha) of Topsham, Maine. Also surviving him are seven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. His stepdaughter, Sally Downing Candler Thompson, predeceased him. Bill practiced as a lawyer in the firm of MacMillen & Filley, Troy, New York from 1939 to 1942 and thereafter began a long association with Robert R. Young, first as his assistant and then as the President of the Federation of Railway Progress until the late 1940s when he began a career in the film and entertainment industry as an officer of Pathe Industries, Eagle Lion Films, Eagle Lion Studios and Eagle Lion Classics Inc., which was sold to United Artists in the early 1950s. A banker and investment banker, he was the President of Colonial Trust Co., a director and President of the Cosmos American Corp., a founder of Lexington International Inc., a venture capital firm, a director of Commercial Alliance Corp. from its inception in 1963 to 1984, a director of Financial Federal Corporation from its inception in 1989 to 2005, a founder and director of Republic National Bank and Republic New York Corporation from its inception in 1965 to December 1999, a commentator and member of The Management Executives Society for over forty years and President of William C. MacMillen & Co., an investment banking firm, from 1960 to 2005. Bill was an avid sports fan, who was a founding director of the Cleveland Browns, a lifelong fan of the New York Mets and the New York Giants and a longtime thoroughbred racehorse owner and breeder; one of his horses, Sweet Woodruff, was named Horse of the Year in 1979. He was a member of The Jockey Club and the Turf and Field Club, where he was the President from 1972 to 1981. Bill also served as President of the New York Division of the Horsemen's Benevolent Protective Association. A jazz aficionado, a competitive bridge player and an athlete, particularly in squash and tennis, Bill was a lifelong member of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Lawrence Beach Club, The Racquet & Tennis Club, the Saratoga Golf Club, The Sky Club and the Saratoga Reading Rooms. He will be remembered by his family and his many friends as a man of the utmost integrity who enjoyed a debate with his fine wit, candor and intellect. A memorial tribute and luncheon will be held at The Racquet & Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue, on Friday, January 16, 2009 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bill's memory to BEST, Backstretch Employees Service Team of New York, Belmont Park, Gate 6, Cottage 28B, 2150 Hempstead Turnpike, Elmont, NY 11003, would be appreciated.

Harvey Ginsberg, a New York book editor who served long tenures at G. P. Putnam's Sons, Harper & Row and William Morrow & Company, and whose most loyal writers included John Irving and Saul Bellow, died on Dec. 30 in Manhattan. He was 78. The cause was respiratory failure, said his nephew, Michael Kahn. Mr. Ginsberg had Parkinson's disease, he said.

Coosje van Bruggen, a critic, art historian and artist known for the colorful public sculptures she created around the world with her husband, the Pop artist Claes Oldenburg, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 66 and had homes in New York and Beaumont-sur-Dême, France. The cause was metastatic breast cancer, said Andrea Glimcher, director of communications at PaceWildenstein, which represents Ms. van Bruggen.

KAU--Nicholas James Peter April 15, 1990, beloved son of Elizabeth Olmsted and Randall Kau and brother to Andrew and Timothy, died unexpectedly on January 10, 2009, at the age of 18. A lifelong Upper West Sider, Nicholas attended Park Avenue Christian and Trinity School before matriculating at Cornell University in 2008. Iron man wrestler, uproarious comic, Mario Party champion, walking Bmovie encyclopedia, master Shakespearean, Francop hone, bonnie bairn, char siu bao connoisseur, harlequin and ladies' man, storyteller and beach bum, footloose, generous, irrepressible, and joyous, Nicholas taught everyone around him to embrace their passions and love the just and noble. His death leaves desolation in many hearts, yet these same hearts rejoice with the utmost pride in his life--pride in his intelligence, kindness, and poise; pride in his beauty, vigor, and laughter. His family invites friends to stop by to pay their respects at a vigil any time between 6pm and 9pm on Friday, January 16, 2009, and a mass of the resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 11am, both at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, entrance on 87th St. between Broadway and West End Ave. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date at Trinity School. Instead of flowers, if you wish, please contribute to the Nicholas J. P. Kau fund at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 St., New York, NY, 10024. We hope to support theater and athletics as his particular passions.

HAMID--Henry A.,beloved husband of Carolyn Hamid, passed away on December 26, 2008 from ventricular fibrillation. Mr. Hamid retired from Wellington Associates in 1972 where he served as a General Manager of a chain of 24 hotels located throughout the United States, including the St. Regis, Gotham & McAlpin and Stanhope Hotels in New York City. Mr. Hamid was CEO of National Sugar Corporation and was on the Board of Directors of the NYC Hotel Association. He was also a real estate investor and management consultant. Early in his career, Mr. Hamid was General Manager of GAC Corp., a National Theatrical Management Agency which owns the Hamid-Morton Circus and was instrumental in booking the Beatles in the early 1960s in Convention Hall in Atlantic City. The family also owned the Steel Pier in Atlantic City. Mr. Hamid was the son of Ameen A. Hamid who performed in Buffalo Bills Wild West Shows in the late 1800s and early 1900s. Mr. Hamid was 81 years old and a graduate of Blair Academy and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute with a BS in Electrical Engineering. He is survived by his wife Carolyn Hamid, daughters Debra Hamid-Zygmunt and Pamela Sutherland, and three grandchildren, Alanna, Caroline and Henry Sutherland.

The Internet may not be such a dangerous place for children after all. A task force created by 49 state attorneys general to look into the problem of sexual solicitation of children online has concluded that there really is not a significant problem.

Physics met politics at the confirmation hearing on Tuesday for Steven Chu, the Nobel laureate scientist chosen by President-elect Barack Obama to head the Department of Energy, and the physicist, if not the physics, bent a bit by backing away from earlier statements that gasoline prices should be higher and that coal was his ''nightmare.'' Dr. Chu answered an array of questions from the Senate energy committee -- about his position on new nuclear reactors (yes, at least for a few plants), offshore drilling (only as part of an energy package) and new coal-burning power plants (a few, until we figure out a better way). He told the lawmakers that ''last year's rapid spike in oil and gasoline prices not only contributed to the recession we are now experiencing, it also put a huge strain on the budgets of families all across America.''

BANKS NEED MORE MONEYBen S. Bernanke, chairman of the Fed, said the widely reviled bailout program needs to pour hundreds of billions of dollars more into the same banks and financial institutions that had already received taxpayer money. WHERE THE MONEY GOESIndependent Bank of Michigan, a small community institution with a long record of bad loans, is using its share of federal bailout money not to extend credit as intended, but to shore up its own weak finances. [A1.]

WALDMAN--Seymour, noted labor lawyer and longtime partner in prominent labor and employment rights firm Vladeck, Waldman, Elias and Engelhard died January 10th near his home in Croton-on Hudson, New York. He was 82 years old. Born in Brooklyn New York, Mr. Waldman was a committed and zealous advocate for the rights of workers. Over the course of his distinguished 50 year career, Mr. Waldman was an active participant in the labor movement, representing clients such as the International Longshoremen, Tugboat, Transit and Bricklayers Unions. Mr. Waldman also served for over three decades as village attorney for his hometown, winning key court cases that led to the transformation of a fetid garbage dump into scenic Croton Point Park. An avid and accomplished tennis player, he and his son Dan were a top ranked father-son tennis team in the East and he passed on a love of the game to his other children. Beloved husband, devoted father and grandfather, a man of quiet grace, he will be dearly missed. A memorial service will be held on January 26th at 3:00pm at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, Manhattan.

College-bound procrastinators, beware: When state budgets get tight, application deadlines can tighten up, too. At Fresno State, part of the California State University system, the original deadline for freshman applications was Feb. 1. But last Friday, the university stopped taking freshman applications, three weeks early.

InternationalCHINESE PARENTS REJECT SETTLEMENT A group of Chinese parents whose children were poisoned by tainted domestic dairy products turned down a government-sanctioned compensation package, and asked instead for long-term health care for the victims and medical research into the illnesses that still afflict tens of thousands of children. The parents have become an irksome challenge to officials seeking to quell public anger over the contamination of the nation's dairy supply. PAGE A9

The losses of the Titans and the Giants last weekend meant that a No. 1 seed would not reach the Super Bowl for the first time since the 1997 season. It was the first time that the two No. 1 seeds lost in the divisional round since the current seeding system was established in 1990, but a No. 1 seed had lost in the divisional round in each of the previous three seasons.

(13) MAKE 'EM LAUGH: THE FUNNY BUSINESS OF AMERICA Billy Crystal hosts this six-hour comedy showcase featuring more than 90 performers, writers, producers and historians as they take on topics like social and political change, race relations, gender issues, standards and taboos. Peyton Manning and Eli Manning each had a top receiver embroiled in investigations involving guns. The Giants' Plaxico Burress shot himself by accident, and the Colts' Marvin Harrison will not face charges, at least for now, in an incident involving his gun April 29. ... The Steelers are in the A.F.C. title game for the seventh time since the 1994 season; they have hosted five of the games, losing four. ... The Eagles have been to the N.F.C. title game five times in eight seasons, going to the Super Bowl once. ... Regardless of who wins the N.F.C., a team with nine regular-season victories will be in the Super Bowl for the first time since the 1979 season, when the Los Angeles Rams did it. ... In two games, the Ravens and the Steelers combined for 65 points; on Thanksgiving, the Eagles and the Cardinals combined for 68. (NYT)

A Lebanese antiquities dealer has been arrested in Bulgaria over the theft of ancient Egyptian artifacts, Reuters reported. With assistance from Interpol, Ali Abu Taam, who was accused of helping a convicted antiquities thief, Tarek al-Seweissi, smuggle 280 artifacts out of Egypt, was arrested on Wednesday. Mr. Abu Taam and the thief are accused of mislabeling artifacts as glass bottles and hid ing them in boxes of electronics and toys marked as exports to smuggle them out of the country. Mr. Abu Taam, who owns an antiquities dealership and lives in Geneva, was convicted in absentia by an Egyptian court in 2004 on charges of helping Tarek al-Seweissi smuggle artifacts and was sentenced to 15 years in prison and fined about $9,000. In 2003 Mr. Seweissi was arrested and Mr. Abu Taam has remained at large until now.

From TV Decoder:The CW is expanding the universe of the low-rated but much-buzzed-about drama “Gossip Girl.” An episode in May will take the form of a prequel, laying the groundwork for a spin-off that could debut as soon as the fall, the network said.

A French photographer has filed a copyright-infringement lawsuit against Richard Prince, the visual artist, the Web site Photo District News reported. In the suit, Patrick Cariou says Mr. Prince illegally borrowed photographs from Mr. Cariou’s book “Yes Rasta,” based on Rastafarian culture for a series of collage paintings. The paintings were displayed in December at the Gagosian Gallery, whose owner Lawrence Gagosian was also included in the suit, along with Rizzoli, the book publisher, which produced a book based on the show. The suit accuses all parties of copyright infringement and seeks unspecified damages. Mr. Cariou’s book, which includes about 100 black and white photographs, was published by powerHouse Books in 2000. The lawsuit says that at least 20 of the 22 collages in the exhibition of Mr. Prince’s series “Canal Zone” used Mr. Cariou’s photos. Mr. Prince has been criticized before for using images without photographers’ permission, but is unapologetic about it.

Real-life psychics and mediums are invited to audition for a chance to work with the cast of the coming Broadway production of “Blithe Spirit,” the producers announced. They are seeking mediums, or actors who also happen to be mediums, to conjure the spirit of Noël Coward or to display any psychic abilities at all in the audition, which will be held Jan. 22 at Sardis. “Blithe Spirit,” the comedy written by Coward in 1941, is to begin previews on Feb. 26. … Primary Stages is offering some potentially very inexpensive tickets to its coming production of “Shipwrecked! An Entertainment — The Amazing Adventures of Louis de Rougemont (As Told by Himself)” by Donald Margulies. Continuing the seasonlong program announced last summer, the company will offer “pay what you can” seats, available two hours before curtain, for the first two previews, on Jan. 27 and 28. The show is to run through March 7 at 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59 St. (primarystages.org). A trailer for the 1945 film version of “Blithe Spirit.”

Globalization has enabled millions of people to experience the joy of the arts, but it also has presented a few challenges. On Jan. 26, the John Brademas Center for the Study of Congress at New York University will try to tackle some of them when it hosts a colloquium on the Art and Artifacts Indemnity Act. The act was passed by Congress in 1975 to reduce the costs of insuring international exhibitions. The event will bring together Rep. Christopher Shays, a Republican from Connecticut; Alice Whelihan, the indemnity administrator for the National Endowment of the Arts; Mr. Brademas, who as a congressman from Indiana was the chief sponsor of the act; the president and chief executive of the American Association of Museums, Ford Bell;, and others at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service in an attempt to examine how the act has become a precedent for federal support of the arts internationally and how it can be enlarged and expanded. The result, organizers hope, will be a set of recommendations that will be sent to Congress for consideration.

Google isn’t the only organization taking steps to make important works of literature available online. The Morgan Library & Museum in New York has invited technicians and scholars to create a digital facsimile of one of its Gutenberg Bibles, the library has announced. The Morgan has three copies of the work, printed in Mainz, Germany around 1455 and considered to be the first significant printed book in the West. The project is a result of a collaboration between the library and the Humanities Media Interface Project of Keio University in Tokyo. Images of all 1,026 pages of the bible will be on the library’s Web site. This is the latest effort by the library to expand its audience on the Web; It has already created digital copies of Book 1 of “Paradise Lost” as well as the delicate illustrations by Jean de Brunhoff from its recent exhibition “Drawing Babar: Early Drafts and Watercolors.” And it has begun to digitize the 183 tapes in the Paris Review archive, part of the Morgan’s permanent collection, including interviews with James Baldwin, Doris Lessing and Eudora Welty.

Perhaps inevitably, Robert Redford opened the Sundance Film Festival here Thursday night with a parting shot at the Bush administration. "Panic," "angst," fear," Mr. Redford said, reeling off a litany of dark nouns. He wasn't talking about the films, he said, but was referring to stuff he claimed would be disappearing next Tuesday when a new administration takes over. The politically minded Mr. Redford carried on a bit about hope, change and diversity in film before turning the lectern over to Geoff Gilmore, the festival director.

Literature | "Pride and Prejudice," "Wuthering Heights" and other Victorian novels may have served an evolutionary survival function, researchers surmise, reinforcing the types of behavior that benefit society, just as cautionary tales did in older societies. The novels' basic conflict between communitarianism and dominant behavior "mirrored the egalitarian dynamics of hunter-gather society, in which individual dominance is suppressed." O.K., now what if nobody reads? [New Scientist]

The Ed Hardy brand is a phenomenon that is, in the context of today's pop culture, instinctively logical: Here is Hardy, an artist who works in one of the stranger art forms -- tattoos, quite elaborate -- and on perhaps the strangest of all art media -- human skin, still alive, thank you very much -- and were you to acquire one of his works of art, you could virtually guarantee a marvelous explosion from your parents. Thus the explosion of the brand. (When I was in Mexico City a few months ago, you couldn't throw a Dos Equis without hitting a massive Ed Hardy billboard.) On the other hand, were your parents familiar with the depth of Hardy's artistry, they might applaud your investment acumen.

In his annual State of the City speech at Brooklyn College, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will promise to build a bulwark against what he fears will be a prolonged national recession. The cornerstone of his remarks, according to a draft prepared for delivery [pdf], is a nine-point strategy to preserve and create 400,000 jobs and improve the city's finances.Mr. Bloomberg's address, his last address before he asks voters to grant him an extraordinary third term, included a check-list of modest steps to help New Yorkers cope with the current recession. He also evoked Franklin Roosevelt and the Depression, as well as the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970s, in an attempt to bolster the city's resolve but also pave the way for some of his austerity measures.

One of New York's last horse and cart street peddlers died last Thursday at the age of 82. Vincent Cincotta, also known as "Jimmy the Peddler," gave up his horse and cart almost 40 years ago, in 1970, and opened Jim and Andy's grocery store in a space he and his partner had been renting as a storage area. Since then, Jim and Andy's has been a permanent fixture on Court Street, known for its basic décor of linoleum and crates in an neighborhood where bars became bodegas and then restaurants. Ostensibly a sauce invented and made by prostitutes, it is said that pasta puttanesca was designed to lure customers with its aroma. Other explanations have more appeal to the minimalist cook: that the prostitutes were too busy to cook much, or that they had no storage for fresh ingredients and cooked entirely from the pantry. My favorite legend has it that it was a favorite not of prostitutes, but of women who wanted to serve a quick meal at home in order to move on to other things. Whatever the origin, no better wintertime pasta sauce has come down to us.

The Bagger pulled into Sundance yesterday and did all the right things, including stopping by Albertsons to buy enough provisions to feed the Third Division. Before your correspondent headed out into the thin mountain air to look for all kinds of color and items for you, he stopped back at his condo for a little nap at 7 pm. He woke up 11 hours later. People will tell you that the mountain air will attack flatlanders like the Bagger with quiet ferocity, but he did not see it coming.

On Nov. 11, 2008 the Colorado Rapids removed the interim tag from Gary Smith's title and made the Englishman the sixth coach in the history of the Major League Soccer club. Smith was a coach and player in England where he spent one year with Colchester United, two years with Barnet, and four years with Fulham. PHELPS--Jonathan. On January 10, 2009 an Angel was born. In the wake of his flight, Jonathan Phelps left a legacy of thoughtfully crafted ballets, heartbreaking poetry, and most notably, his incomparable dancing. He shined onstage with The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater, The Jamison Project, Donald Byrd/The Group, and Walkerdance. During his 42 years, the son of Richard and Laura Phelps, graced this planet; educating and mentoring young hopeful dancers and taught us all, by his glowing example, what it is to be compassionate. He is survived by his partner Chet Walker, brother David Phelps, sister Lee Yarlet, niece Emily Replogle, and nephew David Phelps II. If you haven't had the pleasure of knowing Jonathan, you may meet him at www.jonathanphelps.org, an evolving website created by his colleagues and family at Walkerdance.
