KAUFMAN--Esther Jean, nee Israel, born on September 23, 1914 in Sylacauga, Alabama, died peacefully on January 13, 2009 in Stamford, CT. Esther was a beautiful, intelligent, loyal and loving wife, mother, daughter, sister, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and great-aunt and will be greatly missed by her family and friends. She graduated from the University of Alabama and then moved to New York to become a writer for Ralph Edward's radio show ''Truth or Consequences.'' She also developed the idea for Edward's TV show ''This is Your Life.'' In 1944 Esther married the late Dr. Daniel R. Kaufman and together they spent 25 years in Great Neck, NY where they raised their children Risa Frackman and Bill Kaufman and where Esther was a substitute teacher and President of the Great Neck chapters of Hadassah and The Council for Jewish Women. After the death of her husband, she moved to Greenwhich, CT and later Stamford, CT. Esther was the daughter of Anna and Julius Israel and the sister of the late Mel Allen, legendary sportscaster. In addition to her children, Esther is survived by her son-in-law Robert Frackman, daughterin-law Elizabeth Metcalf, brother Laurens Allen, sisterin-law Marjorie Allen, stepgrandson David Frackman and his wife Kirsten Cole, great-grandson Max Frackman, niece Carolyn Bern and her husband Dr. Jeff Bern, nephew Dr. Andrew Allen, grandnieces Anna Bern and Sydney Allen, and grandnephew Aaron Bern. Funeral Services will be held at Temple Beth-El in Stamford, CT on Friday, January 16 at 1:00pm.

10 P.M. (Discovery) TREASURE QUEST This new series ventures into international waters as Odyssey Marine Exploration -- a crew of researchers, deep-ocean marine archaeologists, conservators and R.O.V. (remotely operated vehicle) pilots -- plunges to the ocean floor in search of precious artifacts, like the one at left, from shipwrecks. The season begins with a journey to a secret location in the English Channel. KILEY--Mildred Sarah Eulas, 101, died January 13, 2009, at Heath Village in Hackettstown, NJ. Born in Kearny, NJ, Mrs. Kiley was a resident of Culver Lake, NJ, and Union, NJ, before moving to Hackettstown. She was almost the Kearny High School high jump champion (set school record in practice). Mrs. Kiley worked for Prudential Insurance Co. A singer of ''I Get the Blues When It Rains'', she was a minor stage mother, taught her grandchildren how to skinny dip, and generally liked a good time. We thank her for marrying our Dad, for helping us find fun in life and nurturing our devotion to each other. The last surviving child of the late Ed and Anna Eulas, Mrs. Kiley's predeceased siblings included Edna Selman and her husband, Jack, Alfred Eulas and his wife, Mildred, and Edward Eulas and his wife, Ann. She was the loving widow of Joseph; the mother of Joseph, Jr. and his wife, Eileen, of Otisfield, Maine, Robert and his wife, Lynne, of Williamsburg, Virginia, Jean Strand of Venice, Florida, and Richard and his wife, Patti, of Houston, Texas; the grandmother of 13; and the great-grandmother of 27. Mass of Christian Burial will be held 10am on Saturday, January 17, at Our Lady Queen of Peace Church in Branchville. Interment will follow at Frankford Plains Cemetery. Memorial donations may be made to Our Lady Queen of Peace Church, 209 Route 206, Branchville, NJ 07826 or to the Heath Village Employee Appreciation Fund, Heath Village, Hackettstown, NJ 07840 or to a Charity of your choice. Services are under the direction of the Wood Funeral Home, 16 Main Street, Branchville, NJ.

Lisa P. Jackson, chosen to head the Environmental Protection Agency, said Wednesday at her confirmation hearing that she would restore scientific and legal integrity to an agency battered by charges of political interference and coziness with industry. But Ms. Jackson evaded questions on whether she would grant authority to California and 16 other states to regulate vehicle tailpipe emissions, promising only a speedy review of the issue. Nor did she directly answer questions on whether and how the agency would address carbon dioxide regulation under the Clean Air Act, an authority granted the agency by the Supreme Court in 2007.

KAU--Nicholas James Peter April 15, 1990, beloved son of Elizabeth Olmsted and Randall Kau and brother to Andrew and Timothy, died unexpectedly on January 10, 2009, at the age of 18. A lifelong Upper West Sider, Nicholas attended Park Avenue Christian and Trinity School before matriculating at Cornell University in 2008. Iron man wrestler, uproarious comic, Mario Party champion, walking Bmovie encyclopedia, master Shakespearean, Francop hone, bonnie bairn, char siu bao connoisseur, harlequin and ladies' man, storyteller and beach bum, footloose, generous, irrepressible, and joyous, Nicholas taught everyone around him to embrace their passions and love the just and noble. His death leaves desolation in many hearts, yet these same hearts rejoice with the utmost pride in his life--pride in his intelligence, kindness, and poise; pride in his beauty, vigor, and laughter. His family invites friends to stop by to pay their respects at a vigil any time between 6pm and 9pm on Friday, January 16, 2009, and a mass of the resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 11am, both at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, entrance on 87th St. between Broadway and West End Ave. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date at Trinity School. Instead of flowers, if you wish, please contribute to the Nicholas J. P. Kau fund at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 St., New York, NY, 10024. We hope to support theater and athletics as his particular passions.

MADISON SQUARE GARDEN fairly reeked of authenticity Jan. 9 to 11, the aroma of prime fertilizer -- bull dung by any other name -- assailing the crowds that had gathered for the Professional Bull Riders 2009 tour event. Fans were greeted, as well, by the scent of dirt, some 700 tons of it cushioning the landings of riders being tossed by 2,000-pound bulls. Backstage the smell of leather was at least as sharp, as cowboys called Travis, Cody and Shane suited up in ornate chaps and boots that had seen their share of wear. Their gear was showy for sure. But it doubled as armor in a competition billed by its organizers as the ''toughest sport on dirt,'' one highlighted on occasion by rag-dolling (the rider is dragged by the bull) and hooking (the rider is speared by a horn).

The veterans Ángel Berroa, Kevin Cash, Jason Johnson, Todd Linden and John Rodriguez were among the 20 nonroster players invited to the Yankees' spring training camp, the team announced Wednesday. Linden and Rodriguez will compete for a job as an extra outfielder with Shelley Duncan, who cleared waivers and was sent outright to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre. Duncan is one of several returning minor leaguers who have been invited to camp, including the top outfield prospect Austin Jackson and the top relief prospect Mark Melancon.

Currently, there are no industry standards for what terms like ''organic,'' ''natural'' or ''eco-friendly'' mean when used to describe a mattress, and while some companies disclose all the contents of their products, others identify only some. The New York Times contacted 17 mattress manufacturers and asked for the following information: whether their products contain petroleum-based polyurethane foam, natural latex or synthetic latex (and the percentage of each); the method of fire resistance used to meet federal guidelines; and substances contained in the outer wrap, or ticking. Then consumer advocates familiar with environmental health issues, organic labelling or textile standards were asked to weigh in.

IN a market crowded with partly hydrogenated, heavily artificial and almost entirely processed snacks, it can be challenging for on-the-go athletes to find sports nutrition that is actually nutritious. But a new category of sports bars may offer a more wholesome alternative. Food bars, or fruit and nut bars, are packaged snacks made from a small number of natural ingredients, such as dates or almonds, with little processing. While eating one of these bars is not quite the same as nibbling on nuts or a handful of fresh figs, they are convenience foods marketed as healthier options to more standard sports bars, or those which include an eye-tiring list of polysyllabic ingredients.

O'NEILL--Mary Ellen ''Mitzi'' (McDonald), of Durham, NC formerly of Baldwin, NY and the Bronx, NY died at her home on January 13th. Loving wife of 50 years to James O'Neill, mother to James, Roderick and Christine, mother-in-law to Reggie, Ronna and Oona, grandmother to Madeline, Connor and Juliet. A graduate of Fordham University, Hunter College and C.W. Post, Mitzi, as she was known to her friends and family and ReRe as she was known to her grandchildren, was a teacher in the Oceanside NY School District for 18 years teaching speech, reading, math, science and the gifted program. Mitzi was Trustee of the Oceanside Library Board, President of the Oceanside PTA, President of the Oceanside Scholarship Fund, President of the Oceanside High School Lacrosse Alumni Foundation, President of Oceanside Community Service, Secretary to the Oceanside Federation of Teachers and Editor of the OFTimes, the PTA Nassau District Leader and wrote the first Reading is Fundamentals grants in Oceanside. Mitzi will always be remembered for her strength, determination and tenacity; love of family, friends, the arts and life; sense of adventure; and compassion for the needy. She was a connoisseur of garage sales and an expert at the NY Times crossword puzzle. Mitzi took such joy in and was very committed to her role and responsibility as a teacher, treating every student with respect, and ensuring they always felt safe in her classroom. She had only one rule -that no student would ever be embarrassed in her classroom. ''As I look ahead, I'm reminded of those times when a parent would come to my classroom in despair about a child. When no words seemed to offer comfort, I'd finally say...but he's only ten...God isn't finished with him yet. And now in leaving I share with you ...God isn't finished with me yet either...and it may be that the best is yet to come.'' The family will receive friends on Friday January 16th from 6:00pm8:00pm at Walker's Funeral Home, 120 West Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27516. A service celebrating her life will be held on Saturday January 17th at 9:30am at St. Thomas More Church, 940 Carmichael Street, Chapel Hill NC 27514. In lieu of flowers the family is welcoming donations to Duke Homecare & Hospice in the name of Mary Ellen O'Neill, 4321 Medical Park Dr., Suite 101, Durham, NC 27704.

The perils of the ever-lengthening careers of rock stars continue. Aerosmith canceled what would have been its first concert in Venezuela when the band’s lead guitarist, Joe Perry, was forced to undergo emergency knee surgery, Reuters reported. The surgery was a result of complications related to a replacement knee Mr. Perry, 58, received in March. The concert was scheduled to take place Feb. 1 in Caracas. The band has been making plans to record an album with new material since their last album, “Just Push Play,” was released in 2001.

Boy George was sentenced to 15 months in jail in East London on Friday, The Associated Press reported. The former lead singer of the 1980s hit band Culture Club, whose real name is George O’Dowd, was convicted of falsely imprisoning a male escort by handcuffing him to a wall in a London apartment in 2007. The ruling follows Mr. O’Dowd’s conviction in December for handcuffing Audun Carlsen to a wall hook at Mr. O’Dowd’s apartment. Judge David Radford said Mr. O’Dowd, 47, was guilty of “gratuitous violence.” In 2006, Mr. O’Dowd was sentenced to community service with New York City’s Department of Sanitation after pleading guilty to falsely reporting a burglary.

Beginning on Monday, National Public Radio will offer fans of the Boss the opportunity to listen to Bruce Springsteen’s coming album, “Working on a Dream” in full starting at 11:59 pm Eastern time on its Web site, www.NPR.org/music. NPR will also be the only radio network to broadcast “We Are One: The Obama Inauguration Celebration at The Lincoln Memorial” on Sunday, when Mr. Springsteen is scheduled to perform along with dozens of other musicians. The concert will air on public radio stations nationwide, and be streamed live on the NPR Web site. The album will be released Jan. 27.

Adding another feather to his cap, Philip Seymour Hoffman will make his movie directorial debut with an adaptation of Bob Glaudini’s play “Jack Goes Boating,” Variety reported. Mr. Hoffman, who appeared in the production as an actor when it had its premiere at the Public Theater in 2007, is the co-artistic director of the LABrynth Theater Company, which produced the play, about two couples in Manhattan. Along with Mr. Hoffman, two other actors from the stage version will appear in the film:, Daphne Rubin-Vega and John Oritz, who is the other co-artistic director of LABrynth, along with the actress Amy Ryan. The movie, which will be produced by Overtures Film, is scheduled to begin filming in February.

The producers of “Speed-the-Plow” announced that they had filed a grievance with Actors Equity over Jeremy Piven’s departure from the show. Mr. Piven, who played the Hollywood producer Bobby Gould, left the show in December after his doctor said he should not continue to perform because he was suffering from elevated levels of mercury, which may have been the result of large amounts of fish in his diet.
Andrew Wyeth, one of the most popular and also most lambasted artists in the history of American art, died at his home in Chadds Ford, Pa. He was 91.
The three-week-old Gaza war continued to rage as diplomats in Cairo and Washington worked to secure a cease-fire.
Yielding to demographics, Taos Ski Valley opens its slopes to snowboarders.

My column this Saturday is about the need to find a systemic solution to the problems that continue to plague the banking system. With Citigroup getting a new bailout a few months ago, and Bank of America getting one this week, clearly the current "let's fix one bank at a time" approach isn't working.

As Washington prepares for what is likely to be the biggest gathering in its history, planners are warning of large crowds and long lines. In an effort to tamp down the crowds, they are sending a blunt message: Stay home.

The Demon Deacons (15-0, 2-0) play at No. 10 Clemson (16-0, 2-0) Saturday in a marquee Atlantic Coast Conference matchup.

Ronen Bergman, a correspondent for Yedioth Ahronoth, an Israeli daily, is the author of the "The Secret War With Iran." He joins a continuing discussion on the war in Gaza at Room for Debate.
Jon Gruden is the latest coach to be fired, in something of a surprise. Well, at least he was surprised, and so was General Manager Bruce Allen.

More than a quarter of the Washington establishments that serve alcohol have received permission to stay open a little longer over the next several days, the city's alcohol regulatory board announced Friday.

When President-elect Barack Obama takes office Tuesday he will be facing high expectations. Americans expect their presidents to hit the ground running, and the initial 100 days set the tone for a president's first term.

New Yorkers are invited to a Book Review event at 7 p.m. next Wednesday, Jan. 21, at the Tribeca Barnes & Noble store. Sam Tanenhaus, the Book Review's editor, will host a discussion of the best books of 2008, with Joseph O'Neill, author of "Netherland"; Liesl Schillinger, a frequent Book Review contributor; and Dwight Garner, a book critic for The Times. We'll also be recording the event for next Friday's "Inside The New York Times Book Review" - our WQXR radio show and podcast.

A well-known executive recruiter on Wall Street is leaving the firm he co-founded and setting up his own shop. Joe Goldsmith, who recruited Vikram S. Pandit as head of Citigroup's alternative asset management unit under its then-chief executive, Charles O. Prince, officially opened his new firm Goldsmith & Company, on Thursday, according to a letter he sent to clients.

President-elect Obama dined at a place with a bit more panache than Ben's Chili Bowl Thursday night. To celebrate Michelle Obama's birthday, they walked a few steps from their residence at the Hay Adams Hotel to one of the city's better eating establishments, Equinox.

Substations are the poor stepchild of the electrical grid. They are critical because they allow utilities bring high-voltage lines close to where electricity is consumed in homes and businesses. But they lack the perverse elegance of utility poles or transmission towers. And unlike the 70 percent of Con Edison's electrical cables that are buried underground, they are often eyesores surrounded by chain link fences.

At the end of Friday morning's screening here of "No Impact Man" - the movie about an attempt by a New York writer named Colin Beavan and his family to live for a year without making a dent in the environment, not even by using a scrap of paper- Mr. Beavan promptly circulated 400 or so postcards among the crowd. The cards urged Hillary Clinton to make climate change a top priority during her tenure as Secretary of State. Mr. Beavan said the cards would be carried to Mrs. Clinton by hand. Next to me, one of them promptly wound up crumpled and tossed on the floor, another bit of Sundance litter. (I tried to decline mine out of respect for the environment and The New York Times policy against overt political acts, but to no avail.)
Have you ever wanted to just sit on your couch and watch YouTube on your TV?

In the days before digital TV, watching DVD movies on a standard picture-tube TV was not a lot of fun. If you wanted to see the film the way the director intended, you bought or rented the "wide-screen" version. But then the image had to be shrunk down to fit inside the squarish screen, so a good chunk of screen real estate went unused. Unless you had a giant-sized tube set (and given their enormous weight, few did) or rear projection set, the picture was pretty small.
If you've ever traveled abroad, you know how poor cellphone service in this country can be.
Yesterday I got a press release with Boost Mobile's new flat-rate prepaid plan -- $50 a month for all you can eat. But is it a deal?

They were thought to be even less likely to win it, with fewer than two dozen participants picking Arizona to lift the Lombardi Trophy.

The splash-down of a US Airways jetliner into the Hudson River on Thursday, with all 155 aboard safe, seemed nothing short of a miracle. Capt. Chesley B. Sullenberger III, a veteran pilot, managed that most challenging of feats, landing on water, allowing passengers to walk off the plane without injury. Two other major crashes in recent years -- a crash on takeoff in Denver last month and a fiery crash in a thunderstorm in Toronto in 2005 -- also resulted in no deaths. We asked a panel of experts if survivability in plane crashes is more dependent on the talent of the pilot or on the aircraft design.

Leon Bernard Heyward did not die until last October, at the age of 45. But his name was added Friday to the official list of people who died as a result of the attack on Sept. 11, 2001. That brings the death toll to 2,752. The accounting is kept by the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner, which said that Mr. Heyward was counted as a casualty "due to exposure to World Trade Center dust following collapse of the World Trade Center." The issue of how to treat and compensate those who were exposed to the dust -- particularly rescue workers -- has proved to be one of the most vexing problems of the aftermath. A spokeswoman for the medical examiner said she had no information on what Mr. Heyward was doing at the towers that morning. The cause of his death was given as lymphoma, complicating sarcoidosis, a lung disease. The manner of death was listed as homicide.

On and on it goes, searching for prodigies in Africa, North America, South America and apparently Eastern Europe, too.

I hear that shortly after taking office, President Obama will restore American funding to the U.N. Population Fund (UNFPA) and end the "gag rule," which cut all U.S. funding for any organization that offered any information about abortion services, even in another country. These will be huge steps forward. The Bush administration's refusal to support UNFPA and reproductive health groups has meant less family planning, more unwanted pregnancies and of course more abortions and maternal deaths. It has been a callous and counter-productive policy.

Gov. David A. Paterson said on Friday morning that he had been prepared to make his Senate pick this weekend, but decided to hold off on the announcement out of deference to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and the inauguration of President-elect Barack Obama.

This week: Evan Thomas on the 2008 presidential campaigns; Motoko Rich with Notes From the Field; Gary Hart on the foreign policy challenges facing Barack Obama; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

FLORENCE, Italy - I'm sitting on the train to Milan, across the aisle from two incredibly stylish Japanese men, most likely fashion buyers as everyone on the train from Florence to Milan is leaving Pitti Uomo and going to the fashion shows. I have to say that the Japanese fashion flock are stealing the show here. Amazing personal style, with what is becoming a bit of a signature look for a group of them: very natty, often checked sport jackets, worn with a coordinated checked shirt underneath a crew-neck sweater, along with slender pressed gray flannel trousers, argyle or some other colored sock and a very fine English shoe. A slightly more classic take on a dandy. United Arrows, one of the best men's stores in Tokyo, exhibited its own line, Camoshita, at the show: checked suits, a matching tweed jacket and vest with a white shirt and wool bow tie, a contrasting windowpane wool trouser and an off-center-buttoning single-breasted fawn-colored wool coat -- all epitomizing this new dandy look.

A passenger jet hits a couple of geese and crashes into the Hudson River. It sounds simple, but it's not. As collisions between planes and birds rise, there is a debate over the cause of the increase and a race to find ways to prevent catastrophe. Bruce Barcott and Jonathan Rosen, authors who have both written books on birds, put "bird strikes" in environmental and historical perspective.

On the last business day of his second term, President George W. Bush decided to appoint one last Justice Department official. In a press release Friday, Mr. Bush said he said he intended to name Edwin S. Kneedler to be acting Solicitor General.

It has been a rocky time at the top of one of Europe's biggest soccer clubs for Ramon Calderon. His tenure as the president of Real Madrid came to an abrupt and unceremonious end Friday when he stepped down amid mounting pressure.
The Treasury Department said Friday that it would lend Chrysler's finance arm $1.5 billion to help it make new car loans as part of a broader program to revive the sputtering domestic auto industry.

Gov. David A. Paterson took in nearly $3.7 million in the second half of 2008 but spent at a healthy clip for someone not seeking office last year. In all, he sent $1.8 million out the door. Among his expenses, he paid nearly $200,000 to Global Strategy Group, the political consulting and polling firm that has been the go-to consultancy for Eliot Spitzer and Mr. Paterson, though Mr. Paterson scaled back its role late last year.He also donated to a number of Democrats, including Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and several State Senate candidates. He even gave to Gov. Christine Gregoire of Washington. He also donated $25,000 to the Working Families Party, a labor-backed party with considerable clout in Albany that has differed with the governor's budget plans.

Craig McCarthy with the Park City Chamber of Commerce has one of those great Chamber-of-Commerce voices. "It's a beautiful day, isn't it?" he boomed over the cell phone on Friday morning. "No snowing, or blowing, or anything." Promotional duties aside, Mr. McCarthy said it is still too early to tell whether the widely expected downturn in Sundance attendance is really occurring. "We're seeing a lot of last-minute planning, much more so than in the past," Mr. McCarthy said. He doesn't figure on getting any real sense of the crowd count at the festival and surrounding events until the middle of next week.

Many of us have spent a lot of time over the past year and a half obsessing about the TED spread, the difference between LIBOR and the interest rate on T-bills. TED was a good indicator of fear in the banking system; the good news is that it's way down.

And I've had a lot of fun listening to and participating in Charley Steiner's afternoon "Baseball Beat," which airs today between 1 and 3 p.m.

Bank of America's not-so-surprising announcement on Friday that it is being bailed out by the federal government because of excessive losses at its new Merrill Lynch subsidiary raises a number of questions. The most significant one is this: What did Bank of America know and when did it know it? And why are Bank of America shareholders learning about the huge losses only now, after their shareholder vote on the Merrill deal?

I own a condominium unit in a building on East 23rd Street. The board of managers wants to adopt an approval process for all new rentals and sales. This is a very burdensome procedure, which will require owners to produce financial statements, applications, leases, etc., to determine whether the board will exercise its right of first refusal. The management company will also charge $600 for processing, and there will be 30-day approval process.

Capt. Conrad H. Roy Jr. and his three-man crew on the tugboat the CO were near Governors Island on Thursday when they heard on their radio that a plane had just gone down in the Hudson River. Another tug was nearby, but it was hauling oil and was unable to help. So Captain Roy, who was returning to New Haven after dropping off a barge of construction supplies in Peekskill, N.Y., headed back up the Hudson to the crash site.
Ron Dennis, the team principal at McLaren, one of Formula One's most storied franchises, announced that he will relinquish his role as of March 1.

On other pages in The Times you'll find a proper obituary of Ricardo Montalbán, who died Wednesday in Los Angeles, due to causes not released to the press. Here we'll take a moment to luxuriate in the Mexican actor's fashion impact. With all due respect to Tom Wolfe, no other man has done more for the crisp, structured white suit than Montalbán, who wore the getup weekly for six years as Mr. Rourke on "Fantasy Island." The inexplicable feats performed by Rourke paled in comparison to the miraculous spotlessness and masculine structure of that three-piece, always set off by a stark black necktie (and sometimes a pocket square). Montalbán has now gone to that wicker wing chair in the sky, but his look is immortal. The best homage this season comes from Kilgour, whose sharp, blinding-white getups will make you look as smooth as Corinthian leather.

In the second installment of our "T Takes: Brooklyn 09" video series, directed by Brody Baker, we follow our white-tuxedo-wearing protagonist, played by Charlie Cox ("Stardust"), to a mysterious rendezvous with the caller from Episode 1. This latest chapter in this enigmatic tale co-stars the milk-skinned model Lily Cole, who began posing at 14, a year before the starmaker Steven Meisel photographed her for the cover of Italian Vogue. The organizers of Slamdance, the other film festival right up the street from the Sundance, have watched the travails of the indie exhibition world with interest, but not much fear. Although one of their films has already been picked up - Revolver, a U.K. distributor, bought a film called "City Rats" in advance of the festival - most of the movies there are not coming soon to a movie theater near you. That doesn't, however, mean that they won't show up on a screen somewhere. Much of the festival is being streamed live online, and Peter Baxter, the festival's president, says that alternative means of distribution will give filmmakers more leverage and more audience than they have had in the past.
One of the more remarkable images from the Hudson River landing of the US Airways flight on Thursday is the photo of passengers standing calmly on the floating wings, waiting to be rescued.

The Sundance Film Festival appears to have sidestepped those early calls for a boycott by opponents of California's Proposition 8, which banned gay marriage in the state. The activists were trying to put the squeeze on Mormon-owned businesses here, because some Mormons had contributed heavily to the successful pro-8 campaign last fall. But festival officials have stepped carefully around such demands, making certain, for instance, that no film is screened only in the Holiday Village theater in Park City, operated by Cinemark, a chain whose chief executive, Alan Stock, donated to Proposition 8's backers in the November election. The idea is to give anyone who has qualms about Cinemark the opportunity to see a movie somewhere else.

During the housing boom, they were among those who persuaded Mr. Eakes of the acceptability of some proposed state regulations that would strictly limit, though not ban, prepayment penalties on the small fraction of prime mortgages that had them, including those from World Savings. As the Ukrainian-Russian dispute over gas dragged into its 10th day on Thursday, the Ukrainian prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, announced that she and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had agreed to meet Saturday in Moscow. The Russians have also invited officials from other countries in Europe, and a spokesman for the European Commission said the European Union energy commissioner would also attend the talks. Ukraine and Russia, which have tense relations, are suffering in the world's economic downturn and are looking to come up with the best financial terms they can for the gas and its transportation through Ukraine and on to Europe. The dispute has left Europe without most of its Russian gas supplies since Jan. 6.

An appeals court on Thursday overturned the conviction of a former Atlanta police officer sentenced to prison for lying to F.B.I. agents about the killing of a 92-year-old woman in a botched drug raid. In tossing out the conviction of the former officer, Arthur Tesler, on the state charges, the Georgia Court of Appeals said Fulton County prosecutors had failed to prove where the lying took place.

KAU--Nicholas James Peter April 15, 1990, beloved son of Elizabeth Olmsted and Randall Kau and brother to Andrew and Timothy, died unexpectedly on January 10, 2009, at the age of 18. A lifelong Upper West Sider, Nicholas attended Park Avenue Christian and Trinity School before matriculating at Cornell University in 2008. Iron man wrestler, uproarious comic, Mario Party champion, walking Bmovie encyclopedia, master Shakespearean, Francop hone, bonnie bairn, char siu bao connoisseur, harlequin and ladies' man, storyteller and beach bum, footloose, generous, irrepressible, and joyous, Nicholas taught everyone around him to embrace their passions and love the just and noble. His death leaves desolation in many hearts, yet these same hearts rejoice with the utmost pride in his life--pride in his intelligence, kindness, and poise; pride in his beauty, vigor, and laughter. His family invites friends to stop by to pay their respects at a vigil any time between 6pm and 9pm on Friday, January 16, 2009, and a mass of the resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 11am, both at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, entrance on 87th St. between Broadway and West End Ave. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date at Trinity School. Instead of flowers, if you wish, please contribute to the Nicholas J. P. Kau fund at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 St., New York, NY, 10024. We hope to support theater and athletics as his particular passions.

Vowing to cooperate with India in the investigations of the Mumbai terrorist attacks, a Pakistani official said Thursday that 124 people had been arrested in a crackdown against a group linked with the attacks. In a televised news conference, the official, Rehman Malik, a senior figure in the Interior Ministry, said the Pakistani government had formed a high-level committee that would examine information provided by India. Mr. Malik said leaders of Jamaat-ud-Dawa, a charity that is seen as a front for Lashkar-e-Taiba, the militant organization India has said was behind the Mumbai attacks, had been detained. He added that 5 camps, 20 offices, 87 schools and 6 Web sites affiliated with Jamaat-ud-Dawa had been shut down. Pakistani officials say any Pakistani citizen who is accused of involvement will be tried in a Pakistani court.

The Czech government apologized Thursday for commissioning an art installation that depicts Bulgaria as a series of hole-in-the-floor toilets after Bulgaria lodged a formal complaint. The work, intended to celebrate the Czech Republic's six-month presidency of the European Union by reflecting something special about each union country, was meant to comprise contributions from artists across Europe. But the Czech artist David Cerny and two of his friends constructed it themselves, representing the countries with crude and not necessarily flattering national stereotypes. Romania is shown as a Dracula-themed amusement park, while Sweden is a giant Ikea box, Germany is a series of highways that resemble a swastika and Britain is missing from Europe altogether. As the work was officially unveiled in Brussels, Alexandr Vondra, the Czech deputy prime minister for European affairs, said the Bulgaria portion would be taken out if Bulgaria insisted. ''I apologize to Bulgaria and its cabinet if they feel insulted,'' he said.

Three workers from the International Committee of the Red Cross were abducted Thursday by men believed to be members of the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group in the southern Philippines, officials said. Military officials identified the abducted workers as Andreas Notter of Switzerland, Eugenio Vagni of Italy and Mary-Jean Lacaba of the Philippines. They were abducted on Sulu, a southern island province where Abu Sayyaf and other rebel groups have been active. Lt. Steffani Cacho, an army spokeswoman, said the workers had been advised about the security situation on the island, ''but because the I.C.R.C. is a neutral organization, they refused armed escorts.'' There was no immediate claim of responsibility. The Red Cross in Manila said the workers were in Sulu to inspect a jailhouse as part of its efforts to improve Philippine prisons.

President Nicolas Sarkozy appointed a former Socialist as the minister of immigration and national identity on Thursday in a move intended to muffle critics of his administration's most controversial post. Éric Besson, left, replaces Brice Hortefeux, a longtime Sarkozy ally who will be minister of social affairs. Mr. Hortefeux, whose hard-line behavior toward immigrants has been strongly criticized by the left, ended 19 months at the head of the Immigration Ministry by saying that nearly 30,000 illegal migrants were expelled last year, a 29 percent increase from 2007 and more than the 26,000 that Mr. Sarkozy had requested. Mr. Besson once called Mr. Sarkozy a ''lackey'' of President Bush but joined Mr. Sarkozy's team before the 2007 election.

Foreign Minister Patricia Espinosa took exception on Thursday to a recently published study by the United States Joint Forces Command that described Mexico and Pakistan as ''weak and failing states'' that need to be watched. In an interview, she said that the country's drug war had been intense but that the government had made inroads. Most of the killings have been among drug traffickers, she said, adding that half the murders have been isolated in just four cities: Ciudad Juárez, Tijuana, Culiacán and Chihuahua. ''Mexico is not a failed state,'' she said. Another recent report, by Barry R. McCaffrey, a retired Army general and former drug czar, said Mexico was ''on the edge of an abyss'' and ''could become a narco-state in the coming decade.''

COLON NEVARES--Jorge. June 4, 1935, to Janury 9, 2009. The family of ''Georgie'' Colon Nevares records with sorrow and desolation the sudden passing of our patriarch. His coronary attack in San Juan deprives us of his charm and companionship and deprives his 5,000 employees across Puerto Rico of what Governor Luis Fortuno calls his vision and wise counsel. He is deeply mourned by his wife of 50 years, Toni Gerena, his three daughters, Yaz (and Valentin) Hernandez of New York City, Yazmin (and Nito) Cortizo of Panama City, and Yovani Colon of San Juan; his son Jorge (and Marie) Colon Gerena of San Juan; and eight grandchildren. The definition of selfmade man, Georgie rose from credit manger at Hotel San Juan International to founder and CEO of a conglomerate of fast food Companies including the franchises of Wendys, Longhorn, Sizzlers, Applebee's plus a portfolio of real estate. In 1960, he founded Commonwealth Loan Corporation, a consumer finance company, which was sold in 1972 to First Pennsylvania Bank. He was president and CEO of Banco Economias and chairman of the company operating El Comandante Racetrack. For the past 25 years, he has been Chairman of the Board of Trustees of School of Medicine, Universidad Central del Caribe. Since 1994, he has served as Consul General of the Republic of Panama in Puerto Rico. A gregarious host, Georgie and Toni constantly opened their home to Puerto Rican singers and musicians. He was renowned for his hospitality, humanity, egalitarianism, talent for friendship and passion for history. In business, he was ambitious, competitive, and scrupulously fair. For his family, friends and employees, Jorge Colon Nevares will forever fill a place in the pantheon of la isla del encanto.

When Carlos Peña of the Tampa Bay Rays evened the score with two outs in the sixth inning of Game 5 at a drenched Citizens Bank Park, practically everyone assumed his hit would prevent the Phillies from being declared World Series champions in a rain-shortened game. But Commissioner Bud Selig had already resolved that the game would be played to completion, regardless of the score or how long the rain delay lasted. The confusion that followed should be avoided now that baseball owners approved on Thursday a rule change that requires postseason games to be played to completion. That includes play-in games, which technically count as regular-season games. Any suspended game will resume, when conditions allow, at the same site and point where it was left off.

8 P.M. (TCM) TRIBUTE TO THE SCREEN ACTORS GUILD Part 1 of this two-installment salute begins with ''The Children's Hour'' (1961), in which a malicious student (Karen Balkin, foreground above) tells a lie about the relationship between Karen Wright (Audrey Hepburn, third from left) and Martha Dobie (Shirley MacLaine, second from left), the headmistresses of a private girls' school. William Wyler directed this adaptation of Lillian Hellman's play (also starring James Garner, right), which earned five Oscar nominations. In ''The War Wagon'' (1967), at 10, a rancher (John Wayne) and a hired gun (Kirk Douglas) join forces to take on the ruthless owner (Bruce Cabot) of a mining company who betrayed them both. And in ''Elephant Walk'' (1954), at midnight, the young bride (Elizabeth Taylor) of a rich planter (Peter Finch) tries to cope with life on her husband's ancestral tea plantation in Ceylon, inconveniently built in the middle of a jungle path used by elephants. 7 A.M. HAWKES--Thomas P.,92, of Fort Myers died Monday, January 12, 2009. He had been a resident there for the past 23 years, formerly of New York, NY and Wantagh, NY. Mr. Hawkes was a member of the American Brewing Association (A.B.A.), past President of Piel Brothers, Brooklyn, NY, created Bert and Harry Cartoon Advertisements, Director of Drewrys USA, Executive VP Schaefer Brewing Company, Brooklyn, NY, and Director of Strohs Brewing Company, Detroit, Mich. Surviving are his children, Marilyn Zabin, Barbara Cogswell, Michael Hawkes, Richard Hawkes, Dennis Hawkes, Thomas Molloy, Donald Molloy, John Molloy, Joan Morgan and Carol Graff, 19 grandchildren, and 17 great-grandchildren. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Eleanor, his second wife, Mary Ruth, and a son, Michael Molloy. Services were held in Fort Myers, FL, and a memorial service will be held in New York on a future date.

O'NEILL--Mary Ellen ''Mitzi'' (McDonald), of Durham, NC formerly of Baldwin, NY and the Bronx, NY died at her home on January 13th. Loving wife of 50 years to James O'Neill, mother to James, Roderick and Christine, mother-in-law to Reggie, Ronna and Oona, grandmother to Madeline, Connor and Juliet. A graduate of Fordham University, Hunter College and C.W. Post, Mitzi, as she was known to her friends and family and ReRe as she was known to her grandchildren, was a teacher in the Oceanside NY School District for 18 years teaching speech, reading, math, science and the gifted program. Mitzi was Trustee of the Oceanside Library Board, President of the Oceanside PTA, President of the Oceanside Scholarship Fund, President of the Oceanside High School Lacrosse Alumni Foundation, President of Oceanside Community Service, Secretary to the Oceanside Federation of Teachers and Editor of the OFTimes, the PTA Nassau District Leader and wrote the first Reading is Fundamentals grants in Oceanside. Mitzi will always be remembered for her strength, determination and tenacity; love of family, friends, the arts and life; sense of adventure; and compassion for the needy. She was a connoisseur of garage sales and an expert at the NY Times crossword puzzle. Mitzi took such joy in and was very committed to her role and responsibility as a teacher, treating every student with respect, and ensuring they always felt safe in her classroom. She had only one rule -that no student would ever be embarrassed in her classroom. ''As I look ahead, I'm reminded of those times when a parent would come to my classroom in despair about a child. When no words seemed to offer comfort, I'd finally say...but he's only ten...God isn't finished with him yet. And now in leaving I share with you ...God isn't finished with me yet either...and it may be that the best is yet to come.'' The family will receive friends on Friday January 16th from 6:00pm8:00pm at Walker's Funeral Home, 120 West Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27516. A service celebrating her life will be held on Saturday January 17th at 9:30am at St. Thomas More Church, 940 Carmichael Street, Chapel Hill NC 27514. In lieu of flowers the family is welcoming donations to Duke Homecare & Hospice in the name of Mary Ellen O'Neill, 4321 Medical Park Dr., Suite 101, Durham, NC 27704.

The thermodynamics of celebrity at Sundance are weird. If you are smushed up against somebody famous, manners suggest that you give them the dude nod and keep moving. But when movement occurs and celebrities are at large, it can create a panic. The Bagger was sitting outside the MySpace lounge waiting for a pal when a backwards-walking scrum of amateur and professional photographers came spilling over the top of the steps. Ashton Kutcher, who is here for "Spread," a feature about a young man who takes a horizontal route to the top, crested the steps. He looked every inch of the former fashion model he is, with operatic headgear and a fur-lined coat that looked like it required its own security detail. His velocity was matched by a pal on his arm and they hardly broke stride on their way in to the café, leaving behind a clutch of pros and ams who stared into their digital screen to see what they had captured and to discern its meaning. "He's looking right at me!" screamed one. Yes dolly, you had your moment.

An article on Thursday about the Indian movie star Akshay Kumar, whose new film, “Chandni Chowk to China,” opened on Friday in the United States, misstated the box office revenue in the United States for the opening weekend of the film “Jodhaa Akbar” last year in a passage about whether Mr. Kumar’s film will attract American audiences. An article on Friday about J. Ezra Merkin, a New York financier under investigation in the Bernard Madoff fraud, misstated the losses of Bard College, whose money Mr. Merkin invested with Mr. Madoff. It lost $3 million of its $11 million investment, not the entire investment. The article also referred incorrectly to the role of the late Leon Levy in Mr. Merkin’s appointment to the board of the Levy Economics Institute at Bard College. While Mr. Levy introduced Mr. Merkin to Bard officials, he did not recommend him for the board.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of an imaging device for breast cancer over the objections of front-line agency scientists misstated, at one point, the surname of the president of the National Research Center for Women & Families, who is a longtime critic of the agency’s approval process. As the article noted elsewhere, she is Diana Zuckerman, not Zucker.

A picture caption on Monday with the continuation of an article about efforts by intensive care units to reduce their patients’ long-term health problems misidentified a health care worker shown talking to Kenneth Ebron, a 70-year-old patient. He is Dr. Dale Needham — not Jen Zanni, a physical therapist.

Leonard E. B. Andrews, who rocked the art world when he bought 240 previously unknown Andrew Wyeth works depicting a mysterious, sometimes nude woman known as Helga -- and then rocked it again when he sold them three years later at a big profit -- died on Jan. 2 at his home in Malvern, Pa. Some initial judgments about the popular movement behind Barack Obama's presidency will be formed by perceptions of the crowd at this inauguration. The last 11 inaugurations have drawn 200,000 to 1.2 million people to the Capitol steps, and predictions have ranged from a million to four million for Mr. Obama's Jan. 20 speech. No enterprise is more critical to the organizers of mass events than crowd size, but most estimates amount to little more than guesses that get repeated over and over. Yet, there is a science of estimating crowds that has become quite reliable if employed carefully. If you know the dimensions of a space, you can estimate the number of people in it with aerial photographs and standard judgments about density, tempered by realistic estimates of transportation capacity.

Jon Gruden won a Super Bowl in his first season in Tampa Bay. In the next six seasons the Buccaneers went 0-2 in playoff games, missed the postseason four times and lost their final four games this season -- including a loss at home to the Raiders in the season finale -- to miss the playoffs after starting 9-3. On Friday, Gruden and General Manager Bruce Allen were fired, an outcome that was shocking mostly for its timing. The announcement came almost three weeks after the regular season, after Gruden had made staff moves and after several teams had already hired some of the hottest coaching candidates.

KAU--Nicholas James Peter April 15, 1990, beloved son of Elizabeth Olmsted and Randall Kau and brother to Andrew and Timothy, died unexpectedly on January 10, 2009, at the age of 18. A lifelong Upper West Sider, Nicholas attended Park Avenue Christian and Trinity School before matriculating at Cornell University in 2008. Iron man wrestler, uproarious comic, Mario Party champion, walking Bmovie encyclopedia, master Shakespearean, Francop hone, bonnie bairn, char siu bao connoisseur, harlequin and ladies' man, storyteller and beach bum, footloose, generous, irrepressible, and joyous, Nicholas taught everyone around him to embrace their passions and love the just and noble. His death leaves desolation in many hearts, yet these same hearts rejoice with the utmost pride in his life--pride in his intelligence, kindness, and poise; pride in his beauty, vigor, and laughter. His family invites friends to stop by to pay their respects at a vigil any time between 6pm and 9pm on Friday, January 16, 2009, and a mass of the resurrection will be celebrated on Saturday, January 17, 2009 at 11am, both at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, entrance on 87th St. between Broadway and West End Ave. A celebration of his life will be held at a later date at Trinity School. Instead of flowers, if you wish, please contribute to the Nicholas J. P. Kau fund at Trinity School, 139 W. 91 St., New York, NY, 10024. We hope to support theater and athletics as his particular passions.

HODES--Robert B.,a longtime partner and former CoChairman of New Yorkbased law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP, died on January 15, 2009, at his home in New York City. He was eighty-three and lived in New York City and Sharon, CT. The cause was cancer. Mr. Hodes was born on August 25, 1925 in Brooklyn, NY, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James Hodes of New York and Sag Harbor, L.I. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1946, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an L.L.B. from the Harvard Law School in 1949. While at Dartmouth, he enlisted in the U.S. Navy, in which he served as an officer during World War II. Mr. Hodes was associated with Willkie Farr & Gallagher for over 50 years, beginning his career in the firm's tax department. He became a partner in 1956, served as CoChairman from 1969 to 1995, and was of counsel to the firm until he retired at age eighty. Mr. Hodes served on the boards of directors of numerous public and private companies and not-for-profit corporations. At the time of his death, he was a vice-chair of the board of the National Philanthropic Trust. He was formerly president of the boards of directors of the Beaver Dam Sanctuary, the Cross River Reservoir Association, and 860 United Nations Plaza. He was a member of The Anglers' Club, the Harvard Club of New York City, and formerly of the Essex Yacht Club and Shelter Island Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife of twenty-four years, Cecilia Mendez Hodes and their son and daughter, James Mendez Hodes and Maria Paz Mendez Hodes. Of two sons from a previous marriage, he is survived by Paul W. Hodes and two grandchildren, and was predeceased by son Tony Hodes. He is also survived by a sister, Dorothy Hodes Lyle. The family requests privacy at this time; funeral services are private through Frank E. Campbell. The family asks that in lieu of flowers or visiting, support might be offered to the Breadline of the Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 West 31st Street, New York, NY 10001.

Contributions should be sent attn: Jane MacDonald, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029.

International law governing warfare is based on the four Geneva Conventions, which were revised and expanded after World War II. The fourth convention governs the protection of civilians. The conventions were updated by two protocols in 1977, in large part to deal with African guerrilla movements, to govern the protection of victims in international and noninternational armed conflicts. Israel has not ratified the protocols, but says it has adopted the main points into its own code of conduct.

HODES--Robert B. It is with great sadness that the partners, counsel, associates and staff of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP mourn the passing of our former partner and counsel, Robert B. Hodes. Bob joined our firm after graduating from Harvard Law School and for the next 60 years practiced corporate and tax law. As a young partner, Bob attracted a number of small corporations as clients and advised those clients as they grew into large, well-established companies. His acquisition of young, entrepreneurial clients in the early 1960s set the stage for much of the growth and success this firm has enjoyed. Bob was a man of vision, integrity and humor. He was a wise and thoughtful leader, friend and counselor who will be greatly missed by us all. We send our deepest sympathies to Bob's wife, Chechi, and to his children, Paul, James and Paz. Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP

When President-elect Barack Obama and his family move into the White House on Tuesday, they will be joined by Michelle Obama's 71-year-old mother, Marian Robinson. Some commentators have relished not just the novelty of the situation, but its sitcom possibilities -- the most powerful man in the world living with his mother-in-law! But the White House has always been home to many different kinds of families, all of whom re-invented the place to fit their needs. The drawings below show how four presidents -- Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln, James Garfield and Franklin D. Roosevelt -- lived and worked in the White House. Thomas Jefferson never liked the White House: too big, too grand for the American president. He was determined to suggest ''republican simplicity'' and this mainly involved rearranging furniture. For instance, what his predecessor John Adams had used as a formal reception room -- today's State Dining Room -- Jefferson turned into his office, crowding the lofty space with books from his library, trunks filled with files and a long table with many drawers, into which Jefferson personally sorted his correspondence. In 1801, when Jefferson moved in, parts of the house were still unfinished, including most of the second-floor family quarters, and he spent much of his time on the White House's main floor. -- WILLIAM SEALE, the author of ''The President's House''

The actor Patrick Swayze, who was hospitalized a week ago with pneumonia, was released on Friday and was resting at his Los Angeles area home, People magazine reported. Mr. Swayze, 56, the star of the new A&E series “The Beast,” was told a year ago that he had Stage 4 pancreatic cancer and worked on the first season of “The Beast” while undergoing chemotherapy. Mr. Swayze missed only one day of work while filming the 13-episode season of “The Beast.”

“Zombie,” a solo play about a serial killer and sex offender, adapted and performed by Bill Connington from a novella by Joyce Carol Oates, will open off Broadway following a run last summer at the New York International Fringe Festival. Previews begin Feb. 18 for a Feb. 21 opening at the Theater Row Complex in Clinton (zombietheplay.com). … Antigone, the stalwart heroine of Greek tragedy, is the subject of “Fire Throws,” a new work from the company Ripe Time (“Betrothed”) scheduled to run Feb. 18 through March 28 at 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan. The show features two Antigones: the ancient Greek one and an embodiment of the symbol she has become, of a devoted fighter against the abuse of power. The show was written and directed by Ripe Time’s founding artistic director, Rachel Dickstein. … Marin Ireland and Steven Pasquale have been added to the cast of the coming Broadway transfer of “reasons to be pretty,” by Neil LaBute. The play, about a social circle that falls apart in the aftermath of a superficial comment about a woman’s pretty face, will include Piper Perabo and Thomas Sadoski, who appeared in the premiere at the Lucille Lortel Theater last year

Vladimir V. Putin, the prime minister of Russia, can add another title to his résumé: painter. Mr. Putin’s first canvas fetched about $1.1 million at a charity auction in St. Petersburg on Saturday, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Putin’s depiction of a frost-covered window framed by curtains was the evening’s top seller, beating out 29 other works including those by the governor of St. Petersburg, Valentina Matviyenko, and the opera singer Anna Netrebko. In all, the event brought in about $2.2 million, which will go to support two hospitals and a church.

The critically panned comedy “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” took in $32.3 million in its first week in theaters for the top spot at the weekend box office, according to figures released by Media By Numbers, a box office tracking firm. The Sony Pictures release stars Kevin James (“The King of Queens”) as a doofus-turned-hero in the tale of a suburban security guard at a New Jersey shopping mall besieged by criminals. Clint Eastwood’s “Gran Torino” (Warner Brothers), the only film in the top five that was a holdover from previous weeks, dropped to second place with $23 million, for a cumulative total of $74 million. “Notorious,” the biopic about Christopher Wallace, better known as Biggie Smalls, the Brooklyn rapper who was killed in 1997, earned $21.5 million for Fox Searchlight Pictures. The gory horror film “My Bloody Valentine 3D” (Lionsgate) took in $21.4 million, and “Hotel for Dogs,” the adaptation of Lois Duncan’s 1971 children’s book about a couple of kids on a mission to save stray animals, earned $17.7 million.

When the Emmy- and Golden Globe-winning series “Mad Men” returns for its third season, next summer, its creator and executive producer, Matthew Weiner, will remain in charge, Variety reported. After months of negotiating, Mr. Weiner and executives at Lionsgate, the company that produces the show, have agreed on terms for a new two-year contract. Mr. Weiner’s initial deal ended after the second season, which was completed in October, and he was seeking substantial increases in the show’s production budget and his salary. Specific terms of the seven-figure deal were not released, but the contract also requires Mr. Weiner to develop additional projects, including a feature film (not based on “Mad Men”) for the company. The writing staff of “Mad Men,” the drama about 1960s advertising executives, is expected to get back to work right away.

The renowned New Orleans chef John Besh has a wonderful way of telling a story with food. Planning a menu for Mike Tyson and company in honor of James Toback's new documentary "Tyson," at the Bon Appetit supper club here Sunday night, Mr. Besh went with what he called a "faux fillet" of Kobe beef. It was actually a beef short rib, removed from the bone, and kept on low heat in the oven, for more than a day. In the end, it looked as red and rare as a boxer's face, but, in truth, was thoroughly cooked.

Maya Moore scored a career-high 40 points to reach 1,000 faster than any player in Connecticut history, leading the top-ranked Huskies in a 107-53 rout over Syracuse on Saturday in Hartford.
The Indy Racing League is cutting two days from its Indianapolis 500 practice schedule to save money. The move is “clearly a response to the economic times,” the I.R.L. spokesman John Griffin said.
Texas Coach Augie Garrido, the N.C.A.A.’s career leader with 1,668 victories, was suspended indefinitely with pay by the university after he was arrested on suspicion of drunken driving.

Roger Federer crushed his Olympic gold-medal-winning doubles partner, Stanislas Wawrinka, to win an Australian Open tuneup event in Kooyong. Federer, who will try to equal Pete Sampras’s record of 14 Grand Slam titles when the Australian Open begins on Monday, broke Wawrinka’s serve three times in the first seven games and went on to beat him, 6-1, 6-3, in only 57 minutes.

The four-time Pro Bowl defensive end Julius Peppers has decided he will not sign a long-term deal with the Carolina Panthers when he becomes an unrestricted free agent on Feb. 26. Peppers, the Panthers’ first-round pick in 2002, believes Carolina’s defensive system is not for him, even after recording a career-high 14 ½ sacks this season.

The Pittsburgh Penguins and the Edmonton Oilers each tried to shore up a weak spot by swapping backup goaltenders, with the Penguins acquiring Mathieu Garon for Dany Sabourin, the minor league forward Ryan Stone and a fourth-round draft pick in 2011. Sabourin, at 28, is three years younger than Garon. Sabourin is 6-8-2 with an .898 save percentage and a 2.85 goals against average. Garon has a 6-8 record, an .895 save percentage and a 3.17 goals against average.

Zach Johnson played bogey-free for a 66 at the Sony Open in Honolulu, finishing atop a leader board so crowded that a dozen players were separated by three shots. Tadd Fujikawa, an 18-year-old who turned professional after his sophomore year in high school, delivered the best round of his life in the third round, making birdies on half of his holes for an 8-under 62 that left him two shots out of the lead.

David Beckham made his home debut for AC Milan, playing 81 minutes in a 1-0 victory over Fiorentina in the Italian league. Beckham is on loan from the Los Angeles Galaxy and hopes to stay sharp in hopes of earning a spot on the English national team.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Town Green column, about an after-school boxing program for at-risk teenagers in Stamford, misidentified a teenager shown being coached by Ahmad Mickens, a boxer and owner of the gym. He is Jose Suero, not Alex DeJesus.

An article on Jan. 4 about Anne Hathaway’s portrayal of Kym in the film “Rachel Getting Married” misstated one of her lines during a rehearsal dinner toast in which she confessed that she had gone through the 12-step program. She said, “Step, ball change” — implying that the process was as rote as memorizing a dance; she did not say, “Step will change.”.

An obituary last Sunday about Dr. Donald F. Gleason, who developed the Gleason score, which was used to assess the aggressiveness of prostate cancer, misstated part of the name of a professional society of which Dr. Bruce Roth, who commented on the continuing importance of the score, is an official. It is the American Society of Clinical Oncology, not “Cancer” Oncology.

The Sundance market is alive, dire predictions to the contrary notwithstanding. "Brooklyn's Finest," a star-filled cop drama directed by Antoine Fuqua ("Training Day"), found a buyer on Saturday, after screening Friday night. A relatively new company, Senator Film Distribution, in partnership with Sony Pictures' film acquisitions division, bought North American rights to the film, offering hope to the many movies coming up for sale over the next few days. The Creative Artists Agency and the William Morris Agency handled the sale.

An article last Sunday about an effort in Nashville to prohibit the government from using languages other than English included an incorrect statement from Councilman Eric Crafton of Nashville, the chief supporter of the city’s plan, about the California State Legislature. An article last Sunday about the Linux operating system Ubuntu, using information from its maker, Canonical, referred erroneously to Ubuntu’s market prevalence. Although IDC, a technology research firm, conducted a 2007 survey about the use of free operating systems like Ubuntu, it did not find that 11 percent of American businesses specifically used systems based on Ubuntu. IDC says it does not track that percentage.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about the government’s proposed sale of IndyMac Bank to IMB Management Holdings, a consortium of private investors, referred incorrectly to the loss-sharing arrangement struck between the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and IMB in the deal. Kudos to Joe Nocera (Jan. 4) for a balanced reporting of the role of risk management and the human element in the financial crisis of 2008. To discard useful financial-risk-measurement tools like the Value at Risk model because they didn’t prevent the crisis is akin to discarding casualty-insurance underwriting because it didn’t prevent Katrina. The limitations of VaR were well known from its advent; with a 95 percent confidence level, its predictive ability would fail statistically nearly once every 20 trading days.
My reaction to your “4-year-old foodie” (Pete Wells, “Food: Cooking With Dexter,” Jan. 4) reminded me of Dorothy Parker’s reaction to “The House at Pooh Corner”: “Tonstant Weader fwowed up.”.

It is so rare that Deborah Solomon interviews a woman (men are far more often interviewed — a gender bias I find disturbing), that the triviality of the interview with Joan Rivers (Jan. 4) is startling. Instead of asking probing, interesting questions related to women comedians and stand-up comedy in general, Solomon concentrates on externalities: skin, most of all. What a waste of our time and Joan Rivers’s — unless, that is, Solomon is asking these questions because she needs to compare Rivers’s efforts to stave off the aging process with her own personal efforts.

Americans have demonstrated a willingness to vote for senatorial candidates with no electoral experience both male (Caroline Kennedy’s uncle) and female (the senator she hopes to succeed), but we like to be able to assess our candidates’ qualifications for ourselves (Lisa Belkin, The Way We Live Now, Jan. 4). Kennedy faces questions about her candidacy not because she is a woman returning to the work force but because she is running in a special election with only one voter.

Rebecca Skloot (Jan. 4) considers various moral and legal issues related to the use of exotic nonhuman species as guides for disabled humans. Except for one: the interests of the animals themselves. Skloot quotes Lex Frieden at the University of Texas Health Science Center as saying that guide animals are akin to wheelchairs and other disability aids, insofar as the former are literally a “part” of the disabled person. The problem is, they aren’t — they are persons in their own right, born with a capacity for natural freedom that their “service” entirely deprives them of. Guide animals are brutally separated from others of their kind, are discouraged from seeking affection from other human beings and are reduced to a life of perpetual bondage to their masters. If there is a meaningful difference between “service animal” and “animal slave,” I fail to see it.

Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Jan. 4, about medical evacuations while traveling, misstated the cost of a membership with MedJetAssist, an evacuation service. A domestic membership, providing transportation to a hospital of the member’s choice when at least 150 miles from home in the contiguous 48 states, is $175, or $305 for a family. The rates that were listed, $250 and $385, are for regular memberships, good for medical evacuation during domestic or international travel.

HODES--Robert B. It is with great sadness that the partners, counsel, associates and staff of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP mourn the passing of our former partner and counsel, Robert B. Hodes. Bob joined our firm after graduating from Harvard Law School and for the next 60 years practiced corporate and tax law. In 1969, Bob became Co-Chairman of the firm, and remained in that position for more than 25 years. As a young partner, Bob attracted a number of small corporations as clients and advised those clients as they grew into large, well-established companies. His acquisition of young, entrepreneurial clients in the early 1960s set the stage for much of the growth and success this firm has enjoyed. Bob was a man of vision, integrity and humor. He was a wise and thoughtful leader, friend and counselor who will be greatly missed by us all. We send our deepest sympathies to Bob's wife, Chechi, and to his children, Paul, James and Paz. Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP

FLEMING--Peter E.,Jr. The partners of Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt & Mosle LLP. mourn the passing of our partner, Peter Fleming Jr. Peter was justly renowned as one of the most highly skilled trial lawyers in the United States, and was a dominant force in the Firm's litigation practice. He was the soul and conscience of Curtis and his advice and strength of character have inspired the entire Firm's practice of law. Those of us privileged to have known him and learned from him are exceedingly grateful for his life. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family.

THE NEWS In his final news conference as president, George W. Bush acknowledged on Monday that some things ''didn't go according to plan'' and that mistakes had been made. But he heatedly disputed the claim that his national security policies had damaged America's moral standing in the world. BEHIND THE NEWS Grayer and more wrinkled than he was eight years ago, Mr. Bush, 62, seemed relieved that his ''time in the klieg lights'' was ending. Still, though he said he would be ''getting off the stage'' on Jan. 20, he noted: ''I just can't envision myself, you know, with a big straw hat and Hawaiian shirt, sitting on some beach,'' adding, ''particularly since I quit drinking.''

SCHUSTER--Frederick Lee. Fred passed away on January 6, 2009 at the age of 74. He is survived by his wife Jean Schuster; children Debbie and Michael; grandchildren Steven and Joseph. He was a respected professor of Biology at Brooklyn College until his retirement and was actively involved in the research of pathogenic amoebae and emerging infectious diseases. His intelligence and keen sense of humor will be greatly missed by his family, friends and colleagues. We loved him.

THE collector car market, on the eve of the six auctions that take place in January in and around Phoenix, defies generalization. Some sectors of the market are down measurably, while others are not. Thank you for publishing Joshua Yaffa's article (Lives, Jan. 4). For decades I believed I suffered singularly, the only child forced to eat an organic-avocado-and-artisanal-cheese sandwich on sprouted-whole-grain bread while others gorged on glories like Twizzlers and M&M's or sandwiches floating on wondrous Wonder bread, so mesmerizingly squishy and soft. I, too, was raised by hippies in the '80s who gave no mystique to drinking, drugs or sex. What was verboten were sweets and junk food, except for my once-yearly indulgence of birthday sugar cereal (always Lucky Charms, a tradition that I've maintained), and ever since it has been the siren song. I longed for the Valhalla decadence of a Sizzler buffet and the rapture of a Hostess cherry pie until I broke free at 18 and discovered the divine pleasure of dipping pretzels into Marshmallow Fluff and late-night drive-through windows.

FLEMING--Peter Emmet Jr,. of Greenwich, Connecticut, one of the great trial lawyers of his generation, died of lung cancer on Wednesday at New York Hospital, New York City. He was 79 years of age. Mr. Fleming who was born in Atlantic Highlands, NJ and was a graduate of Princeton University and Yale Law School, and served in the United States Navy during the Korean War where he attained the rank of First Lieutenant assigned to the USS Oriskany. He was an Assistant United States Attorney under Robert Morgenthau and Silvio Mollo in the 1960s where he successfully handled some of the nations first white collar criminal prosecutions and in the process helped pioneer the governments now standard focus on white collar crime. As a private practitioner with the New York law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle, his success continued unabated for decades. He represented a continuous stream of clients in high stakes cases, including, among many others, Irving Kahn, Attorney General John N. Mitchell in the 1970s, the embattled Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert in the 1980s, boxing promoter Don King in the 1990s, and Adelphia founder and chairman John Rigas in the 2000s. Mr. Fleming was also a renowned fan of the New York Football Giants, having penned a novel about the team which, though not published, was the subject of much rumor and talk. He also gave freely to various charities. Mr. Fleming was a man of great decency, and left his mark on countless people from every walk of life. As his partners at Curtis Mallet commented, he taught us . . . the meaning and importance of character . . . What a great man. What a great loss. Theirs will be a common sentiment. His wife, Jane Breed Fleming died in 1990. Surviving are his sons Peter 3d of Manhattan Beach, California, James of Akron, Ohio, William of New York, New York and David of Greenwich, Connecticut; a daughter Jane of Los Angeles, California; a sister, Joan Sexton of Brooklyn, four daughters-in-law and eleven grandchildren. The family will receive friends Monday, January 19th at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT from 4pm to 8pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Tuesday January 20th at 10:30am in St. Mary Church, 178 Greenwich Ave. Greenwich, CT. Interment will follow in Putnam Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers Memorial Contribution may be made to a charity of ones choice.

Barack Obama will face some tough and complicated decisions on how to solve the economic crisis. But one decision is easy: Just by showing up for his own inauguration, he will bring a welcome financial boost to the nation's capital. Hotels, restaurants, stores and all manner of other businesses will benefit as celebratory consumers are likely to buck a national trend of slowed spending. Included in the mix will be a host of Obamarelated commemorative items, from transit-fare cards to jewelry to cupcakes. At left, Earl W. Stafford Sr. with Erick Speight of J.W. Marriott on the hotel's 12th floor; Mr. Stafford's foundation paid $1 million for a hotel package for the less fortunate. Above, Metro fare cards have a new look for the big day.

THE average weekday New York Times contains nearly 130,000 words of news, information and opinion. The newspaper employs layers of editors and multiple policies and procedures to make sure that every one of those words is as accurate as anyone can determine in the daily rush of history. But bad things still happen. Last month, because reporters and editors in three different parts of the paper did not take enough pains to verify information, The Times reported as fact a political telephone call that didn't happen, fell victim to a faked letter to the editor, and published a sensational anecdote about a college football recruiting battle that the paper cannot be confident is true.

Americans have demonstrated a willingness to vote for senatorial candidates with no electoral experience both male (Caroline Kennedy's uncle) and female (the senator she hopes to succeed), but we like to be able to assess our candidates' qualifications for ourselves (Lisa Belkin, The Way We Live Now, Jan. 4). Kennedy faces questions about her candidacy not because she is a woman returning to the work force but because she is running in a special election with only one voter. ROB ZWIEBACH San Mateo, Calif.

To the Sports Editor: Your Pushing the Limit series purports to highlight ''athletes who confront an opponent that must be mastered, not beaten.'' It is so rare that Deborah Solomon interviews a woman (men are far more often interviewed -- a gender bias I find disturbing), that the triviality of the interview with Joan Rivers (Jan. 4) is startling. Instead of asking probing, interesting questions related to women comedians and stand-up comedy in general, Solomon concentrates on externalities: skin, most of all. What a waste of our time and Joan Rivers's -- unless, that is, Solomon is asking these questions because she needs to compare Rivers's efforts to stave off the aging process with her own personal efforts. JEAN DAVISON Austin, Tex.

MEDITATING AT BOROBUDUR, CENTRAL JAVA, INDONESIA, SEPT. 6, 2008 James Travers-Murison, 44, a high school teacher from Melbourne, Australia: ''Borobudur is an incredible monument to Buddha's enlightenment; its spiraling bas relief sculptures are fast eroding and will soon disappear unless it is protected. I was there as part of a spiritual pilgrimage to connect to the universal consciousness, and I was meditating early that morning. Later that day, I went to take a shot of the monument but found that my camera was gone. I checked the restaurant, the room, the video cinema. I ran up the hill to where I had been meditating, but it was over two hours later. An American photographer had photographed me meditating and he showed me a shot that he zoomed in on to show my camera beside me. I knew that this was a sign; I had to let go and learn. I was seeking a wife, and that was the most important thing to me. I had to allow the cosmic intelligence to reveal the lesson. That I had to learn something about attachments to objects and desire before God would present me with a wife.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

COLON NEVARES--Jorge. June 4, 1935, to January 9, 2009. The family of ''Georgie'' Colon Nevares records with sorrow and desolation the sudden passing of our patriarch. His coronary attack in San Juan deprives us of his charm and companionship and deprives his 5,000 employees across Puerto Rico of what Governor Luis Fortuno calls his vision and wise counsel. He is deeply mourned by his wife of 50 years, Toni Gerena, his three daughters, Yaz (and Valentin) Hernandez of New York City, Yazmin (and Nito) Cortizo of Panama City, and Yovani Colon of San Juan; his son Jorge (and Mari) Colon Gerena of San Juan; and eight grandchildren. The definition of a selfmade man, Georgie rose from credit manger at Hotel San Juan International to founder and CEO of a conglomerate of fast food companies including the franchises of Wendys, Longhorn, Sizzlers, Ap plebee's plus a portfolio of real estate. In 1960, he founded Commonwealth Loan Corporation, a consumer finance company, which was sold in 1972 to First Pennsylvania Bank. He was president and CEO of Banco Economias and chairman of the company operating El Comandante Racetrack. For the past 25 years, he has been Chairman of the Board of Trustees of School of Medicine, Universidad Central del Caribe. Since 1994, he has served as Consul General of the Republic of Panama in Puerto Rico. A gregarious host, Georgie and Toni constantly opened their home to Puerto Rican singers and musicians. He was renowned for his hospitality, humanity, egalitarianism, talent for friendship and passion for history. In business, he was ambitious, competitive, and scrupulously fair. For his family, friends and employees, Jorge Colon Nevares will forever fill a place in the pantheon of la isla del encanto.

DREW--Todd. The staff of the ACLU deeply mourns the loss of our beloved colleague, Todd Drew, Director of Publications, who died Wednesday night from complications following surgery for cancer. Todd loved the ACLU almost as much as the New York Yankees, and, in his own words, he believed in ''baseball and an equally free, open, just society for everyone.'' He was unfailingly kind and generous, and anyone who ever had the good fortune to work with him will attest to his remarkable warmth and sincerity. Todd's legacy will live on not only through the tangible contribution of hundreds of publications that he produced for the ACLU, but also through the way in which he touched all of us with his generosity and kindness. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Marsha.
