To the Sports Editor: Re ''McNamee Set to Meet With Prosecutors,'' Jan. 13: What a waste of government resources to investigate the use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes. Other articles in The Times have mentioned that the courts and prosecutors are unable to handle the many hundreds of cases involving illegal immigrants. In light of that, spending so much effort pursuing Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens is criminal.

MAHONEY--Edward P. Father, Duke Emeritus Professor of Philosophy and a Catholic Priest in the Raleigh Diocese of North Carolina, died January 8, 2009. He was born November 3, 1932 in New York City, the son of Patrick J. Sr. and Kathleen Brady. He is survived by his brothers Patrick J. Jr., Kerry, Myles, and Stephen. Ed received his BA at Cathedral College, an MA in Philosophy at St. John's University, and an MA in Political Science and his Philosophy Ph.D. at Columbia University. He wrote his dissertation, The Early Psychology of Augustino Nifo, under the direction of Paul Oskar Kristeller, the noted scholar of Medieval and Renaissance thought. Ed went on to become an internationally recognized scholar of medieval and Renaissance philosophy in his own right. He had a particular interest in later medieval psychology, in late medieval and Renaissance receptions of Aristotle, and in historical accounts of ''the Great Chain of Being.'' Besides authoring numerous articles on later medieval, Renaissance and early modern authors and topics, he edited Medieval Aspects of Renaissance Learning (1974) and Philosophy and the Humanities (1976), and he published a collection of his essays, Two Aristotelianisms of the Italian Renaissance: Nicoletto Vernia and Agostino Nifo (2000). Ed was a member of the Duke Department of Philosophy for forty years, starting in 1965. He held fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities and the John S. Guggenheim Foundation and was a Fulbright Teaching Fellow at the University of Rome. He served as a President of the Society for Medieval and Renaissance Philosophy, and was a longtime member of both the Board of Directors of the Journal for the History of Philosophy and the Editorial Board of the Journal of the History of Ideas. Ed was a lively undergraduate teacher and a forceful proponent of interdisciplinary medieval and Renaissance studies at Duke. He served as dissertation advisor for several graduate students who now have tenure track or tenured academic positions. In addition, he ministered to students and professors at the Newman Center in Chapel Hill, NC, who know him affectionately as Fr. Ed. Ed leaves behind a rich legacy of dedicated service, teaching and scholarship. Memorial donation information: www.hallwynne.com. Select Obituaries.

GOLD--Alfred I.,fondly known at ''Fritz'', a resident of Park Avenue, New York and Westhampton Beach, New York, passed away peacefully, at the age of 86, on January 8, 2009. Fritz was the adored husband of Patricia and the late Shirley Robbins. He is survived by his loving children, Andrew and Peter, their wives Sara and Merrydith, stepson Allan, five grandchildren, Collyn, Rachel, Benjamin, Daniel and Charlotte and niece and nephew Bill and Wendy Kaminer. Fritz, a Yale graduate, had a very successful career in Real Estate, spanning over fifty years as an architect, builder and principal of many commercial properties on Long Island and Queens. As an avid collector and respected historian of American and British maritime art, he was a devoted trustee and contributor at both the South Street Seaport in New York and the Peabody Museum in Salem, Massachusetts. A veteran of World War II, Fritz served on the western front, spending eight months as a prisoner of war. Fritz received the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart for his service to his country. A memorial service will be held on a later date.

HART--Arielle, M.D.,died on January 15th at Mt. Sinai Hospital after an 18 month battle with lung cancer. She was 42 and a nonsmoker. A life-long New Yorker, Arielle was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and the University of Chicago. She earned her M.D. from Sackler Medical School at Tel Aviv University but left practicing medicine to stay home with her three wonderful children, Zachary (11), Juliette (10) and Natalie (7). It was always her plan to return to medicine when her children were grown. In addition to her adoring husband, Michael T. Cohen, she is survived by her mother and stepfather, Tamara and Scott Spolan, her father and stepmother, Sylvan and Davia Hart, and her brothers Ira and Alan. She also leaves behind countless broken - hearted friends. Arielle loved music, cooking, public school, Montauk, science but most of all her children. She brought joy and fun to all who knew her. Funeral Services were held at Park Avenue Synagogue on Friday, January 16th. The family has requested that charitable donations be made to ''The Mount Sinai Medical Center'' to be used for Lung Cancer Research under the direction of Dr. Stuart Packer. Contributions should be sent attn: Jane MacDonald, Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029.

Rebecca Skloot (Jan. 4) considers various moral and legal issues related to the use of exotic nonhuman species as guides for disabled humans. Except for one: the interests of the animals themselves. Skloot quotes Lex Frieden at the University of Texas Health Science Center as saying that guide animals are akin to wheelchairs and other disability aids, insofar as the former are literally a ''part'' of the disabled person. The problem is, they aren't -- they are persons in their own right, born with a capacity for natural freedom that their ''service'' entirely deprives them of. Guide animals are brutally separated from others of their kind, are discouraged from seeking affection from other human beings and are reduced to a life of perpetual bondage to their masters. If there is a meaningful difference between ''service animal'' and ''animal slave,'' I fail to see it. We need to find other ways to provide necessary services for the disabled.

BARNETT--Dr. Tess Forrest, a clinical psychologist, psychoanalyst and family therapist died suddenly on January 14th, 2009 in Sarasota, Florida, where she had retired from her private practice in Great Neck, New York. Dr. Forrest Barnett was born in Brooklyn, New York on April 14, 1922. Orphaned in childhood, she put herself through Brooklyn College and the Master's Program at Columbia University's Teacher's College. After earning her Ph.D. at Adelphi University and completing her post-doctoral training at the William Alanson White Institute, Dr. Forrest Barnett established a private practice in Great Neck, New York, and served on the teaching and supervisory faculties at William Alanson White, the New York University Post Doctoral Program, the Gordon F. Derner Institute of Advanced Psychological Studies at Adelphi University and the Manhattan Institute in New York City. A pioneer in the field of family therapy at the Jewish Board of Family and Children Services in New York City, she taught and published numerous papers on the integration of individual psychoanalysis and family systems therapy, as well as on dreams. Along with her husband, Dr. Joseph Barnett, M.D., also a psychoanalyst, she taught at psychoanalytic institutes in Stockholm, Rio de Janeiro and Madrid. Dr. Forrest Barnett is survived by her children Roanne Barnett, Ph.D., Jonathan Barnett and her grandchildren Juliana Barnett Gildesgame, Ezra Barnett Gildesgame, Joseph David (J.D.) Barnett and Sarah Lauren Barnett. Services will be held on Monday, January 19th at 12:45pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the charity of one's choice or to the American Macular Degeneration Foundation.

The stock market declined sharply last week on reports of big write-downs and disappointing earnings by several big banks. JPMorgan Chase eked out a profit in the fourth quarter, although it was much less than in the previous year. By contrast, Citigroup and Bank of America both reported huge losses. Citigroup announced that it would split itself in two, while Bank of America said that it would be receiving billions of dollars in fresh government aid. In Washington, meanwhile, Congress released another $350 billion for use by the Treasury to help stabilize the financial system.

BARBER--Daniel. 59, of White Plains, NY, a long time employee of The New York Times Company passed away January 17, 2009 after a valiant, courageous battle with liver disease which he endured stoically and selflessly for the last several years. Dan had an unconquerable spirit, never giving up hope often stating that he is a fighter and fight he did until the end. Dan was a recipient of two liver transplants, one in 2002 and again in 2007. In 2004 he won two gold medals in tennis at the National Transplant Games at The University of Minnesota. He was a former member of the Seventh Regiment Tennis Club in Manhattan, West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills and County Tennis in Scarsdale and he had a gorgeous backhand that was the envy of many. Among his passions were aesthetics, reading, tennis, history and the NY Giants but he reserved his greatest passion for his family. He was a loving and beloved husband of 28 years to Marilyn and a devoted and adored father to Nikki, 15, the love of his life. Dan was a man of wit, style and keen intellect and he was a huge blessing in our lives. We are heartbroken and we will miss him forever.

Prolonging the biggest inaugural weekend surprise since William Henry Harrison declined to wear an overcoat, the underdog comedy “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” (Sony Pictures) continued to dominate the box office on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, according to estimates released by the tracking firm Media By Numbers. The movie, which stars Kevin James (of television’s “King of Queens”) earned $39 million over the four-day weekend; it made $31.8 million of that total in its first three days of release, outpacing recent comedies like the Jim Carrey feature “Yes Man,” which earned $18.2 million on its opening weekend in December. The No. 2 movie for the four-day holiday weekend was Clint Eastwood’s “Gran Torino” (Warner Brothers), which earned an estimated $26.2 million, followed by the horror movie “My Bloody Valentine 3D” (Lionsgate), which grossed an estimated $24.2 million.VIDEO: Watch the trailer for “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” here.

If you’re looking to burn a few calories while pounding out the tune to Hoagy Carmichael and Frank Loesser’s “Heart and Soul,” or to impress your gruff but loveable boss at the toy company you work for, make your way to the Please Touch Museum in Philadelphia. There, the museum has been given the 16-foot piano keyboard that Tom Hanks and Robert Loggia danced on during a memorable sequence in the 1988 comedy “Big,” The Associated Press reported. The famous prop was built in Philadelphia by the artist and engineer Remo Saraceni, who has constructed giant keyboards for museums, hospitals and other organizations. It was donated to the museum by a Pennsylvania couple who purchased it after the original release of “Big.” The museum plans to put the prop on display in February.

Two thousand years after he took on Julius Caesar and the Roman army, the pugnacious cartoon character Astérix is provoking another fight. Last week, the French company Hachette Livre bought a majority stake in Albert-Rene, the longtime publisher of the adventures of Astérix, the diminutive Gallic warrior. This followed an announcement by Albert Uderzo, the illustrator and a creator of Astérix, that stories featuring the character could continue after his death. (Rene Goscinny, the co-creator of Astérix, died in 1977.) But in a letter in Le Monde, Mr. Uderzo’s daughter, Sylvie, protested the sale, writing that “a handful of shadowy advisers” had prompted her father’s decision, BBC News reported. “It’s as if the gates of the Gaulish village had been thrown open to the Roman Empire,” Ms. Uderzo wrote, according to the BBC. “I am entering resistance against perhaps the worst enemies of Astérix, the men of finance and industry.”

A board member of the Screen Actors Guild apologized Friday for circulating an e-mail message critical of eight actors who oppose the authorization of a strike, Variety reported. The board member, Frances Fisher, had forwarded an anonymous message suggesting that guild members withhold their votes in the coming Screen Actors Guild Awards for nominees who have publicly stood against a potential strike. In a statement, Ms. Fisher said she had the message “to alert my private e-mail list of opinions and feelings that were circulating,” according to Variety. In her statement she apologized to the actors Josh Brolin, Kevin Spacey, Susan Sarandon, Michael C. Hall, Sally Field, Alec Baldwin, Steve Carell and Tony Shalhoub, and added, “Artistic merit should be the only criteria for award selection.”

Though audiences at the coming Broadway play “33 Variations” will most likely be focused on the star, Jane Fonda, she won’t have the stage all to herself. The producers announced that the cast of the Moisés Kaufman play would be rounded out by Samantha Mathis (of “Grey’s Anatomy,” not to mention “Pump Up the Volume”) and Colin Hanks (recently seen on “Mad Men”), as well as Zach Grenier, Don Amendolia, Susan Kellermann, Erik Steele and Diane Walsh. The play, in which Ms. Fonda portrays a musicologist obsessed with the work of Beethoven, marks her first appearance on Broadway in more than 45 years. It is scheduled to begin previews at the Eugene O’Neill Theater on Feb. 9 and run March 9 through May 24.

Fans of Isaac Asimov still haunted by the film adaptation of “I, Robot” will get their chance to wipe it from their memory banks: a movie version of Asimov’s “Foundation” novels is in the works, Variety reported. On Thursday, Columbia Pictures won a three-way auction for film rights to Asimov’s science-fiction epic, whose first volume concerns a mathematician put on trial after predicting the collapse of his civilization. Columbia, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment, beat Warner Brothers and 20th Century Fox for the rights. The studio plans to develop the film for Roland Emmerich, the director of the cataclysmic sci-fi movies “Independence Day” and “The Day After Tomorrow.” Financial terms were not disclosed, and a release date for the film was not announced.BONUS: Paul Krugman explains how the “Foundation” novels convinced him to become an economist at his Conscience of a Liberal blog.

Taking photos of snowy scenes can yield some beautiful images, but it can be a tricky process. That's because the camera's lighting meter is often confused by the bright white of snow and may reduce the aperture, resulting in photos that are too dark or bluish in tone.

It was an anxious time, the beginning of 1961. In the eight years before Jan. 20, 1961, the Soviet Union had tested a hydrogen bomb and had put in orbit the first satellite, Sputnik, which passed over the United States for months. Central Intelligence Agency analysts estimated that the Soviet economy was growing at a rate of between 6 percent and 10 percent a year, compared with the United States' growth rate of between 2 percent and 3 percent. Unemployment in America was at 7 percent and the country had gone into recession early in 1960.

Well, it turns out there was some basis for those rumors last summer that Joseph R. Biden Jr. might become Barack Obama's secretary of state -- because Mr. Obama asked him. In fact, Mr. Obama gave Mr. Biden a choice between being secretary of state and vice president. (At the time, of course, neither was a sure thing; Mr. Obama had yet to even accept the Democratic nomination for president, let alone win the election.)

Hockey's delayed reaction to Don Sanderson's death on Jan. 2 kicked in at full throat in this past week, triggered by talk that the N.H.L.'s G.M.'s would be taking yet another look at fighting in the game, the Ontario Hockey League's new rules on helmets and fighting, a major conference on concussions in hockey and -- in stark visual terms -- a few incidents in N.H.L. games, including one in which the type of injury that killed Sanderson was narrowly avoided.

I'm on the train to Washington for the Obama Inaugural. They said it will be a full train. I'll be staying in Washington with my friends John and Nina, who were neighbors when I lived in Georgetown, and, I guess, walking to just about everything. Nina says that in the 40 years she's lived in Washington, she's never seen people in such good spirits. It is going to be quite a time. I saw Lars Nilsson on my train: small world. He's on his way to Richmond, then Savannah. He looked out the train window and said it looked like Sweden. It sures looks cold.

By the time I sat down with Doug Marrone, the new Syracuse football coach, on Friday, he'd drunk two Red Bulls and was swigging a large Diet Coke. With the daunting job of rebuilding the Syracuse football program, he'll need the caffeine. Since Daryl Gross, the athletic director, fired Paul Pasqualoni late in 2004, the program has suffered through its worst four-year stretch in history. Marrone has been delivered a team low on talent and a fan base full of apathy. But if someone could turn around a program on passion alone, it would be Marrone. He's sleeping four hours a night as he tries to make Syracuse football relevant again. In an hourlong conversation in his office, Marrone expressed a genuine love for Syracuse football. He also riffed about alligator cheesecake, his experience working for newspapers, his college days on the Hill, a snowy New York City at 4 a.m., his vitamin fetish, his love of the Varsity, what exactly goes into an N.F.L. job interview and why he hates the term "West Coast offense."
This is an excerpt from a Q.& A. with Doug Marrone, the new football coach at Syracuse.

Never do the math in your mind at midnight. That lesson was brought home when this reporter was gently corrected by Jonathan Sehring, IFC's president, in front of about 100 chuckling peers at a morning panel discussion here. The 250,000 viewers Mr. Sehring hopes will buy Steven Soderbergh's "Che" after it becomes available on the company's video-on-demand service this week would roughly equate to a box-office haul of $1.8 million, not $18 million, as your dutiful correspondent reported in Monday's Business section of The New York Times. That many viewers would make the movie IFC's video-on-demand champion to date, but it would still be far short of the audience that has turned out to see a heavily promoted theatrical film like "Milk."

I don't usually disagree with Dean Baker, but I think he's wrong here. The really striking thing about corporate borrowing rates isn't that they're high by historical standards, although they are, but the fact that they're high even though interest rates on government debt are very, very low. Below I show the spreads on AAA and Baa debt against 30-year Treasuries: they really have spiked.

From the pageantry, false promises and color-washed revolutionary headshots of "Kimjongilia" (it means "the flower of Kim Jong-Il") to the bloody waters of "The Cove" (yes, kids, they kill Flipper, over and over again), Sunday turned into a trip down the rat hole of reality. It's not that more lighthearted documentaries don't exist here. Somewhere in this gigantic cinematic mash-up, Chris Rock tackled the subject of African-American culture in "Good Hair" last night. But the happier fare doesn't really go to the heart of Sundance, or the documentary art, for that matter.

Dolce & Gabbana have long held to the philosophy that one shouldn't whisper if a scream will do. And if the clothes have sometimes pushed the boundaries of bodaciousness into cone-boob caricature, the ads have gone even further. Scantily clad himbos in a men's locker room? Check. Pin a model down with five guys? Don't mind if they do! Of course others have minded: that last campaign was pulled from Spain and Italy in 2007. Correctly, D&G have always maintained their right to shock, but they've usually waited until the townspeople showed up at their palazzo doors to respond. Not in this economy. In an interview in Italy's La Stampa that's been picked up worldwide, they're giving us all a heads-up to polish our pitchforks, announcing in no uncertain terms that their next campaign will rock our worlds. How, you might ask? By showing a group of men praying. Pastor Rick Warren and Bishop Gene Robinson, don't start calling your agents yet. Messrs D and G have at least honored one boundary of good taste and hired models.

Are traces of the original Harlem settlement -- including an African burial ground -- awaiting discovery during the replacement of the Willis Avenue Bridge and the planned rehabilitation of the 126th Street Bus Depot?There will be no way to know for certain until the soil is dug up, but the prospect of such a discovery is being greeted both anxiously and eagerly by a couple of stewards of Harlem history. The bucolic farming village of Nieuw Haarlem was established in March 1658, meaning that it is still in its 350th anniversary year.

Technology | The futurist Ray Kurzweil wrote of a time when artificial intelligence overtakes human intelligence. But a blogger has doubts. Isn't the big story our emotional attachment to computers and projection of human qualities onto "the inanimate and dumb"? (Case in point: the iPhone.) Tuesday, 11:30 a.m. The problem with politicians is, they never seem to sound enough like poets, whose language is, by nature, richly imprecise. While the leaden political discourse has its uses - no one wants obscurity when it comes to nuclear launch codes - an occasional ambiguity might be nice. The inaugural address, for instance, to be broadcast at the Schomburg Center in Harlem, is the perfect opportunity for complex phrasing in the service of a broader national cause. Wouldn't it be great to be ennobled, even surprised, by a president's public words? Do not misunderestimate the power of such a thing. 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, Manhattan.

Harold Holzer, the author of several books on Abraham Lincoln and the historian for the upcoming New-York Historical Society exhibition, "Lincoln and New York," answered selected readers' questions about Abraham Lincoln's experiences in New York, where he gave the Cooper Union speech that advanced his 1860 presidential campaign, stopped on his way to his 1861 inauguration, and lay in state, at City Hall, following his assassination in 1865.

Edgar Allan Poe reaches his second century mark today. The young United States was a strange place for literary genius to develop, and Poe's career was relatively short (he died at 40, on Oct. 7, 1849), but through his works he inspired generations of writers throughout the world, and there has been no letup in the 21st century.

Headlines from the world of property:

Lindsey Vonn finished third in a World Cup downhill Sunday in Zauchensee, Austria, good enough to regain the lead in the overall standings. Vonn, the defending overall and downhill champion, trailed the co-winners, Anja Paerson of Sweden and Dominique Gisin of Switzerland, by 17-hundredths of a second. They each finished the 1.83-mile Kaelberloch course in 1 minute 47.52 seconds.

Meb Keflezighi, the 2004 Olympic marathon runner-up, surged to an early lead and won the men’s United States half-marathon championship in Houston. Keflezighi, an American who was born in Eritrea, won in 1 hour 1 minute 25 seconds. Magdalena Lewy-Boulet, a Beijing Olympic marathoner, won the women’s title in 1:11:47.

Scott Linehan declined the San Francisco 49ers’ offer to become their offensive coordinator, saying he was not ready to commit to his next coaching move. Linehan, a respected offensive coordinator for Miami and Minnesota, was fired four games into his third season as the St. Louis Rams’ coach last September.

The city of Vancouver, British Columbia, will borrow more than $360 million to ensure that the $800 million athletes’ village will be built for the 2010 Winter Olympics. British Columbia politicians voted unanimously to support legislation that allows Vancouver to borrow the money without going to a public referendum.

The Chicago Cubs traded outfielder Félix Pie, formerly a prized prospect, to the Baltimore Orioles for the left-hander Garrett Olson and the minor league pitcher Henry Williamson. The 23-year-old Pie hit .241 in 43 games with the Cubs last season after batting .287 in 85 games in Class AAA.
The Jets are expected to name Rex Ryan, Baltimore’s defensive coordinator, as their head coach this week.
Joe Flacco’s rookie season ended Sunday against the Steelers in a flurry of incompletions and interceptions.

Willis McGahee's neck injury in the final minutes of Sunday's A.F.C. championship game was the latest reminder of just how violent professional football is. At field level, and at full speed, the most honest way to describe it is frightening. And from Darryl Stingley and Mike Webster to Dennis Byrd and Ted Johnson, the league has left a trail of broken bodies almost as long as its history.Fans -- from the safety of a living room couch -- enjoy a vicarious thrill. The interchangeability of the names and bodies that ram into one another every week makes it easy to cheer the contact but not the consequences. That's the reason it takes all of three seconds to find YouTube collections like this. Chuck Bednarik's hit on Frank Gifford is legendary. But so are many of Jack Tatum's.

Among today's headlines:
An obituary last Tuesday about the French film director and producer Claude Berri misspelled the surname of an actress with whom he worked. She is Catherine Deneuve, not Denueve.
The roof of a São Paulo church caved in shortly after a religious service on Sunday evening, killing seven people and injuring 57 others.
When Ryan Clark stepped in to make a tackle in the fourth quarter, his helmet collided with Ravens running back Willis McGahee’s, who was later taken off the field.

A dance review on Friday about New York City Ballet, in a program that featured guest dancers from other companies, misidentified the dancer who led the Russian Theme in “Serenade.” She is Misa Kuranaga of Boston Ballet, not Patricia Delgado of Miami City Ballet. (Ms. Delgado danced the role known as the Dark Angel.).

An article on Friday about Kevin Pittsnogle, a former star basketball player at West Virginia University who is now teaching middle school, misstated the name of the high school where he once also starred. It is Martinsburg — not Martinsville — High School in West Virginia.

The Entrepreneurial Edge column on Thursday, about support for small businesses in the California counties of San Bernardino and Riverside, misstated the home foreclosure rate in the area. About 126,000 homes in the counties have received notices of default, not 350,000. (An estimated 360,000 homes, or one-third of the homes in the counties, are worth less than their mortgage balances and may be in jeopardy of default.).

An article on Friday about bird-plane collisions, believed to be what led a US Airways jet to crash-land in the Hudson River, misstated the year of the deadliest crash involving a bird strike and, because of an editing error, referred incorrectly at one point to the type of plane involved. The crash, involving Eastern Air Lines, occurred in 1960, not 1962. And as the article noted elsewhere, the aircraft was a propeller plane, not a jet.
A. J. Price scored 23 points to lead Connecticut to a 76-61 victory over Seton Hall in Hartford, the Huskies’ fifth Big East win since losing their conference opener to Georgetown.
Marc-André Fleury stopped 33 shots and Petr Sykora had a goal and an assist to lead the Penguins to a 3-0 victory at home over the Rangers.

An article on Friday about a study that found that college students are paying a higher proportion of the cost of their education included incorrect preliminary data provided by the authors of the study, the Delta Project on Postsecondary Education Costs, Productivity and Accountability. At private colleges that offer master’s degrees, the portion of education costs paid by students rose between 2002 and 2006 to 83.6 percent from 80.4 percent, not from 75.5 percent. At private institutions that offer bachelor’s degrees, the percentage rose to 63.5 percent from 61.1 percent, not from 57.7 percent. At private research universities, the percentage declined to 55.8 percent from 57.6 percent; it did not rise from 55.3 percent.

KELSEY--Howard Burr, died peacefully at the age of 93 on Wednesday, January 14, 2009. He was the devoted husband of the late Frances Voorhees Kelsey. His three loving children were at his bedside: Patricia K. Schultz of Richmond, VA, Peter B. Kelsey of Lovettsville, VA and Marjorie K. White of Annandale, VA. He also leaves his sister Elizabeth Kelsey Cameron, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A resident of Hightstown, NJ, and formerly Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ and Quogue, NY, he was a partner at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. He graduated from The Hotchkiss School, Yale University in 1937, and Columbia Law School. He was a lieutenant in the US Navy during World War II. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am on Thursday, January 22, at the First Presbyterian Church of Hightstown, followed by interment at the Quogue Cemetery in Quogue, NY on Friday, January 23 at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Llewellyn Park Preservation Foundation, 28 Oak Bend, Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ 07052.

The Parliament building here has been reduced to rubble. The five-story engineering department of the Islamic University is a pile of folded concrete. Police stations, mosques and hundreds of homes have been blown away. But now that the battle is over -- or has paused, after Hamas agreed Sunday to a one-week cease-fire with Israel -- what has been accomplished is unclear. Have three weeks of overpowering war by Israel here weakened Hamas as Israel had hoped, or simply caused acute human suffering? Israel knew it could not destroy every rocket or kill every Hamas militant. Israel said its central aim was deterrence, to make Hamas lose the will to keep shooting at Israel's cities. Did it succeed?

Lasantha Wickramatunga, an extraordinarily courageous journalist, wrote his own obituary. After he was murdered on Jan. 8, his letter from the grave appeared in papers all over the world including his own, The Sunday Leader in Sri Lanka. His farewell piece is not only a painful explanation of why another brave journalist would die while trying to publish truths that most people are afraid to whisper. It is also a powerful indictment of the increasingly brutal Sri Lankan government, which runs one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a journalist.

The Philadelphia Eagles were three minutes from celebrating their second trip to the Super Bowl in five years. Instead they were saddled with their fourth National Football Conference championship game defeat in their past five attempts.

FLEMING--Peter E.,Jr. The partners of Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt & Mosle LLP. mourn the passing of our partner, Peter Fleming Jr. Peter was justly renowned as one of the most highly skilled trial lawyers in the United States, and was a dominant force in the Firm's litigation practice. He was the soul and conscience of Curtis and his advice and strength of character have inspired the entire Firm's practice of law. Those of us privileged to have known him and learned from him are exceedingly grateful for his life. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family.

UMPHREY'S MCGEE ''Mantis'' (Sci Fidelity) By virtue of its intense and ever-changing shows, its obsessive fan base and the premium it places on spontaneity, Umphrey's McGee can be understood as a jam band, and one of the best. The evidence extends to countless live recordings, both sanctioned and tolerated, in time-honored tradition. By comparison, the group's studio albums can feel optional, almost beside the point.

ERHART--Charles H. Jr, former President and Chief Administrative Officer of W.R. Grace and Co., died on January 16, at New York Presbyterian Hospital from complications of Pulmonary Fibrosis. A lifelong resident of New York City where he was born in 1925, he attended the Buckley School and the Groton School. He served in the U.S. Army Air Corps during World War II before attending Yale University, from which he graduated in 1949. He worked at W.R. Grace, a New York City based diversified specialty chemicals company until his retirement in 1990. He began his career at Grace in 1949 as an Assistant in the mail room. During his time at Grace, he was credited with leading the Company's divestment of unrelated interests to focus on specialty chemicals. He continued to serve as a Director of diverse businesses and charitable organization through the summer of 2008. In his lifetime, he was a Trustee of the Leake and Watts Children's Home, St. Luke's/Roosevelt Hospital and the Groton School, as well as on the Vestry of the Church of the Epiphany in New York. He is survived by his wife Sylvia and his children: Victoria of St. Paul, MN, Margaret of Flagstaff, AZ, David (Grace) of Hadlyme, CT, Stephen of Santa Monica, CA, and Julia Erhart (Susan Bruce) of Adelaide, Australia. He is also survived by five grandchildren, three half brothers and a half sister. He was predeceased by a brother, William K. Erhart. A passionate skier and sailor, he had homes in Barnard, Vermont and Southwest Harbor, Maine. A Memorial Service will be held at the Church of the Epiphany in the spring. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Church of the Epiphany in New York, or the Groton School in Groton, MA.

PHILLIPS--John David (Jack) of Tuckahoe, NY and Pinellas Park, FL at 87, on January 14, 2009. Mourned by Anne, wife of 61 years, sons John and Thomas, daughter Nancy and her husband William Bave, and grandchildren Christine, William and Jonathan. Our love goes with you Pa. ANTONY AND THE JOHNSONS ''The Crying Light'' (Secretly Canadian) Listening to Antony sing can be nerve-racking. Taking cues from cabaret and Broadway and blues and gospel, his voice is spookily beautiful, but it's constantly on the move, with microvariations in pitch and tone that keep the ear on edge. His notes are never quite whole; often, they sound like questions.

WERTHEIM--Seymour S.,Beloved husband of Irene. Devoted father of Joel, Steven and Richard. Loving grandfather of Elliot and Jonathan. Founder of Wertheim & Company and partner in R. Wertheim & Co., C.P.A.'s. Services Today 1pm at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, L.I.

The Cardinals' run in the playoffs has taken many observers by surprise, including those who run the sports books in Las Vegas. At the Las Vegas Hilton, Arizona began the playoffs as the longest shot to win the Super Bowl, at 50 to 1, of the 12 teams competing. Before the season, the Cardinals' odds were only slightly higher, at 60-1, and that was for all 32 teams.

HODES--Robert B. It is with great sadness that the partners, counsel, associates and staff of Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP mourn the passing of our former partner and counsel, Robert B. Hodes. Bob joined our firm after graduating from Harvard Law School and for the next 60 years practiced corporate and tax law. In 1969, Bob became Co-Chairman of the firm, and remained in that position for more than 25 years. As a young partner, Bob attracted a number of small corporations as clients and advised those clients as they grew into large, well-established companies. His acquisition of young, entrepreneurial clients in the early 1960s set the stage for much of the growth and success this firm has enjoyed. Bob was a man of vision, integrity and humor. He was a wise and thoughtful leader, friend and counselor who will be greatly missed by us all. We send our deepest sympathies to Bob's wife, Chechi, and to his children, Paul, James and Paz. Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP

O Leader, Impress Us Tuesday, 11:30 a.m. The problem with politicians is they never seem to sound enough like poets, whose language is, by nature, richly imprecise. While the leaden political discourse has its uses -- no one wants obscurity when it comes to nuclear launching codes -- an occasional ambiguity might be nice. The inaugural address, for instance, to be broadcast at the Schomburg Center in Harlem, is the perfect opportunity for complex phrasing in the service of a broader national cause. Wouldn't it be great to be ennobled, even surprised, by a president's public words? Do not misunderestimate the power of such a thing. 515 Malcolm X Boulevard, Manhattan. Hearing in Hate Crimes

A Spare Times entry on Friday about the South Street Seaport Museum misstated the days the museum is open and parts of its admission policies. The museum is open Fridays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., not Fridays through Sundays. The $5 admission fee is for children 6 to 12 years old, not 5 to 12. A free admission period is during extended hours every third Friday of the month, not all day every third Friday.

Grandfather to Samuel. Adored brother to Mikki. Wonderful brother-in-law to Bonnie and Sid. Beloved uncle. Absolute gentleman. Respected and loved by all. Services at Schwartz Brothers, Queens Blvd., at 76th Rd, Tuesday, January 20 at 1pm.

LOWE--Eleanor (Ellie), passed away on January 18th, 2009. Beloved mother of Mona and Dan Morello, Sheldon and Maria Lowe, and Francine Lowe. Cherished grandmother of Billy, Alexa, and Danielle Lowe. She was very involved with Diabetes Research Institute, (Humanitarian Honoree) at Love and Hope Gala, and Leading Ladies. We will all miss her beautiful smile and generous heart.

Yes, the inauguration -- but first, the music. In the moments before Barack Obama is sworn in as president and delivers his Inaugural Address on Tuesday, another South Side Chicagoan will produce eloquence, of a musical kind. He is Anthony McGill, a clarinetist who will join the violinist Itzhak Perlman, the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the pianist Gabriela Montero. They will play a piece composed for the occasion by John Williams, perhaps best known for his film scores and pops conducting.

The calm face that Arizona quarterback Kurt Warner wore like a mask Sunday might have put his nervous teammates at ease, but his wife, Brenda, was not fooled. In the hours before the Cardinals' National Football Conference championship game against the Eagles, she described her husband's mood as ''crabby.'' She laughed. ''In the zone,'' she said, ''but crabby.'' The Warners' marriage has endured a period in which they got by with the help of food stamps, and their family has expanded to include seven children. As great a connection as Warner has had in these playoffs with receiver Larry Fitzgerald, it is nothing compared to his bond with Brenda, who believed in him when they were broke and again when his glory days seemed to be over.

Framed by the Lincoln Memorial's austere marble and facing a crowd of hundreds of thousands, President-elect Barack Obama on Sunday offered words of high inspiration about his forthcoming presidency that were interlaced with cautions about unrealistic expectations for quick remedies. Two days before he is to take the oath of office at the Capitol, Mr. Obama addressed a crowd that began at his feet below Mr. Lincoln's statue and stretched far down the Mall to the World War II memorial. The sea of people -- scarf-wrapped and stocking-capped, shivering under gray skies and 35-degree temperatures -- had poured onto the National Mall on Sunday afternoon to kick off three days of festivities to celebrate the inauguration.

When it comes to the services that owners of mobile devices use ''almost every day,'' younger Americans more often than older ones reach out and touch someone. According to comScore Mobile, a higher percentage of users in the 13- to 24-year-old group compared with the older group get out their phones to use services like texting or capturing video. Users from the younger demographic are three times more likely to use their devices as cameras. The service for which there is almost no generation gap is e-mail, a category that includes personal and business uses. SHELLY FREIERMAN

HART--Arielle. With loving thoughts we will always remember Arielle. Our hearts are with Zachary, Juliette and Natalie. We are with you, Michael, our esteemed Board member and former Chairman. Peace. Young Presidents Org. Metro New York

GAZA -- It was a day of digging and bitter discovery. Houses had lost walls, and the dead, after three weeks of war, had lost their faces. Families identified them by their clothes. As the people of Gaza emerged from hiding on Sunday, they confronted, for the first time, the full, sometimes breathtaking extent of the destruction around them wrought by the Israeli military. Bombs had pulverized the Parliament and cabinet buildings, the Ministry of Justice, the main university and the police station, paralyzing Gaza's central nervous system and leaving residents in a state of shock.

The foundation at Heinz Field shook late in the fourth quarter as fans danced and screamed and delighted in the Steelers' impending victory. Everyone who wore black and gold was thinking about another Steelers appearance in the Super Bowl, at least until Ravens running back Willis McGahee caught a pass from Joe Flacco and turned upfield.

HARDER--James D.R.,a New York actor, on Friday, January 9th, 2009, in Harwich, MA. Son of George Achilles Harder, a Titanic survivor, and Elizabeth Peebles Rhodes. A graduate of the Buckley School, St. Mark's and Princeton University, where he served as a trustee of the Triangle Club. An actor in over 130 stage productions; also television, movies, radio and commercials. Nominated for a Drama Desk Award on Broadway for ''Very Good Eddie.'' He was always tickled at still being recognized from the Big Fig Newton commercials. Jim is survived by his beloved wife, Dorothy; daughter Elizabeth; son-in-law Mark Ameres; and numerous nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Funeral services will be held at St. Jean Baptiste Church in New York City on February 12th, 2009 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Mark's School, 25 Marlborough Road, Southborough, MA 02653.
SCHECK--Dr. Raymond, 88, died on January 17th, 2009. Survived by his wife BettyLou, two daughters Nancy and Susan, and two grandchildren Elizabeth Nesoff and Alexander Mitchell.

Unlike the nation's banks, hedge funds haven't been lining up for government bailouts in the wake of losses they can't handle. But the funds do share one Wall Street problem: a huge mismatch between the short-term funds they take in and the long-term bets they make. Without a rethink of their business models, many in the hedge fund business risk going the way of the investment banking dodo.

WYETH--Andrew. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art mourn the passing of Andrew Wyeth. One of America's best - known artists, Wyeth had the singular ability to capture the atmosphere and emotional tenor of this country in his portraits and landscapes. In both 1967 and 1998 the Whitney held exhibitions devoted to Wyeth and is pleased to hold works by him in its collection. We extend our condolences to his wife Betsy, his sons Nicholas and James, his granddaughter Victoria and his many friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus, Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman, Robert J. Hurst and Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairmen, Neil G. Bluhm, President, Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director

ROSEN--Carol J.,on January 16 at Calvary Hospital after a year long battle with lung cancer. She was a devoted mother and sister, adoring grandmother and loving wife of the late Bernard Rosen. She was a graduate of Smith College. Carol was a successful career woman who started as a secretary and rose to become a Vice President of Administrative Services at Katz Communications in New York City. In her retirement she led a full, active life splitting her time between New York City and Highland Beach. She had a life long interest in art and was an accomplished artist in watercolor and oil painting. She will be sorely missed by her many friends and family. She is survived by her sister Jane Lowett, her children; Cindy and Ken Cook and Howard and Irina Rosen, her grandchildren; Sam, Ben, Aaron, Igor, Boris and Sophia. Services on Monday 11:00am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. Interment is at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Smith College, Class of 1952.

STRICKLAND--Loretta, May 11, 1938 to January 14, 2009. Services will be held at Calvary Mortuary Cemetery in Los Angeles, CA on January 20, 2009. Services will start at 9am. Loretta Strickland passed away at home. Loretta was a TV Executive for 50 years and leaves behind a tremendous amount of friends and business associates. She will be dearly missed. She is survived by her husband Dr. Stephen Bolkin and their son Miles Victor.

Don Galloway, who played well-groomed, straight-arrow characters in many television shows and movies -- most famously the series ''Ironside,'' in which he was the sidekick of the title character, a detective in a wheelchair played by Raymond Burr -- died on Jan. 8 in Reno, Nev. He was 71. His stepson, Robert Julian, announced the death to The Associated Press.

MELTZER--Theda (Taube), died peacefully at home in Manhattan on January 17, in her 95th year. She was the beloved wife of the late Manford Meltzer, and the daughter of the late Sam and Sarah Spatt. Taube is survived by her sons Peter and James, her granddaughter Alexandra, and her great-granddaughter Calliope, and also by her sisters Doris Sirow and Roberta Wells. She was predeceased by her sister Gladys Burrows. Taube was a tall, elegant lady, a witty conversationalist, an avid golfer and a talented needlepointer. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services private. The family will receive from 36pm on Monday, January 19th, at The Phillips Club, 155 West 66th Street.

The Magic Theater, a San Francisco institution that made a dire appeal for funds from its subscribers and audience members at the start of the year, has surpassed its goal and will stay open, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. The 42-year-old theater, which has staged the premieres of works by David Mamet and Sam Shepard, raised $455,000 from about 1,100 donors. Earlier this month, the theater announced on its Web site that it needed to raise $350,000 in about a week to pay down a debt of $600,000 or it would close. The theater now says it will complete its current season by reducing its budget from $2 million to $1.65 million, and postponing the premiere of the play “Mistakes Were Made” by Craig Wright until next season.

A German court has ruled that a collection of rare posters seized by the Gestapo in 1938 are the property of the son of their original owner, Bloomberg News reported. The collection of more than 4,250 posters, which includes pre-war advertisements for movies and cabaret shows as well as political propaganda, was seized from Hans Sachs, a Jewish dentist who was put in a concentration camp but later escaped with his family to Boston; the works eventually became the property of the Deutsches Historisches Museum in Berlin. Sachs’s son, Peter, now a retired airline pilot living in Sarasota, Fla., sued the museum last year for the return of the collection, estimated to be worth $5.8 million. In 2007, a German government panel turned down Mr. Sachs’s petition to have the posters returned, but on Tuesday a court was unconvinced by the government’s argument that Mr. Sachs had voluntarily given up the posters when he fled the country.

A coming album paying tribute to the British singer-songwriter Nick Drake will include a song performed by the actor Heath Ledger, Billboard reported. The track, a cover of Drake’s song “Black Eyed Dog,” was recorded by Ledger in 2007 for an art installation but was never released; Ledger died the following January from an accidental drug overdose. Drake, the gentle-voiced folk-rock singer of “Pink Moon” and “Things Behind the Sun,” struggled commercially during his career but became a critical and cult icon after his death from an overdose of antidepressants at age 26 in 1974. Other performers on the Drake tribute album, which was announced at the MidemNet music industry conference in France, include Eddie Vedder, Dave Grohl, Norah Jones and Jack Johnson.

Barack Obama hasn’t been president one full day and he has already inspired a new musical. “Obama On My Mind,” a musical with book, music and lyrics by Teddy Hayes, will make its premiere at the Hens and Chickens Theater in Islington, a borough of London, in March, Playbill.com reported. According to a news release, the show will take a “humorous look at the weird and wonderful world behind the scenes of a small Obama campaign office and the larger than life characters who make the wheels turn, the cogs whirr and bring in the votes.” The musical will feature a mixture of pop, rock, gospel and jazz songs; it is scheduled to begin performances on March 3 and make its official opening on March 5, before concluding its run on March 21.

The Louvre has begun conferring with banks in search of a financial institution to help manage its first-ever endowment, Bloomberg News reported. Some 18 different banks, including JPMorgan Chase and UBS, are in the running to manage the Louvre’s fund of $230 million, which it received from the United Arab Emirates to build a new museum on Saadiyat Island, near Abu Dhabi, which is scheduled to open in 2012. The museum is expected to receive about $323 million in additional funds from the emirate over the next 18 years. Each year, the Louvre raises about $157 million and receives about the same amount from the French government for running costs and maintenance. The Louvre said it planned to use money earned from the endowment to renovate its Greek and Roman art wing and build additions to the museum.

Lots of things can be said about Michelle Obama's clothes today for the swearing-in of her husband as the 44th president of the United States. The lemongrass yellow was not merely an unusual choice among the blues and reds; it was a stand-out choice. As many of you know, I'm a big fan of Isabel Toledo, who designed Mrs. Obama's wool lace coat and matching dress, so I'm completely and utterly biased. Let's hear it for fashion that is just a little bit eccentric, that in its texture and slight hint of sparkle gives a suggestion of mystery. Also, I like the fact that she wasn't engulfed by a big wooly coat; you could see the whole outfit, with her trusty cardigan showing a bit. You could see her.

Ethics | "At some point in life, the only thing worse than dying is being kept alive." That's the lament of a Minnesota hospital physician who sees a steady stream of debilitated, elderly patients kept alive through herculean feats of technology, even though in agony. People have to drop the illusion of immortality, he says, "before our nation's obesity epidemic and the surge of aging baby boomers combine to form a tsunami of infirmity that may well topple our hospital system and wash it out to sea." [Washington Post]

Richard Petty’s name will remain active in Nascar under a rebranding of the new team created by the merger of his organization with Gillett Evernham Motorsports. The new team will be called Richard Petty Motorsports (R.P.M.), capitalizing on Petty’s marketability. The two race teams had agreed to a partnership that keeps the sponsor-strapped Pettys in racing. Reed Sorenson will drive Petty’s famed No. 43 Dodge for R.P.M. this season. Petty’s No. 44 Dodge will be run by A. J. Allmendinger in at least the first five races of the season as the team tries to find more sponsorship. They will be joined by GEM holdovers Kasey Kahne and Elliott Sadler, who both have full-time rides.

Putz, hit .269 for the Mariners last year with 2 homers and 31 runs batted in.

Claude Lemieux, 43, is back in the N.H.L. after a five-and-a-half-year absence, joining the San Jose Sharks. The N.H.L.-leading Sharks recalled Lemieux from their minor league affiliate in Worcester, Mass. Lemieux is likely to play Tuesday night against Vancouver in the Sharks’ final game before the All-Star break.

The article also referred incorrectly to the relative of Mr. Freeman whose day care agency received union money. It was his mother-in-law, not his mother.

If you’re looking to burn a few calories while pounding out the tune to Hoagy Carmichael and Frank Loesser’s “Heart and Soul,” or to impress your gruff but lovable boss at the toy company you work for, make your way to the Please Touch Museum in Philadelphia. The museum has been given the 16-foot piano keyboard on which Robert Loggia (above left) and Tom Hanks (above right) danced in a memorable sequence in the comedy “Big,” The Associated Press reported. The famous prop was built in Philadelphia by the artist and engineer Remo Saraceni, who has constructed giant keyboards for museums, hospitals and other organizations. It was donated to the museum by a Pennsylvania couple who bought it after the release of “Big” in 1988. The museum plans to put the prop on display in February.

Two thousand years after he took on Julius Caesar and the Roman army, the pugnacious cartoon character Astérix is provoking another fight. Last week the French company Hachette Livre bought a majority stake in Albert-René, the longtime publisher of the adventures of Astérix, the diminutive Gallic warrior. This followed an announcement by Albert Uderzo, the illustrator and a creator of Astérix, that stories featuring the character could continue after his death. (René Goscinny, the other creator, died in 1977.) But in a letter in Le Monde, Mr. Uderzo’s daughter Sylvie protested the sale, writing that “a handful of shadowy advisers” had prompted her father’s decision, BBC News reported. “It’s as if the gates of the Gaulish village had been thrown open to the Roman Empire,” Ms. Uderzo wrote, according to the BBC. “I am entering resistance against perhaps the worst enemies of Astérix, the men of finance and industry.”.

Prolonging the biggest inaugural weekend surprise since William Henry Harrison declined to wear an overcoat, the underdog comedy “Paul Blart: Mall Cop” (Sony Pictures) continued to dominate the box office on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, according to estimates released by the tracking firm Media by Numbers. The movie, which stars Kevin James (“The King of Queens”), earned $39 million over the long weekend. It made $31.8 million of that total in its first three days of release, outpacing recent comedies like the Jim Carrey feature “Yes Man,” which earned $18.2 million on its opening weekend in December. The No. 2 movie for the four-day holiday weekend was Clint Eastwood’s “Gran Torino” (Warner Brothers), which earned an estimated $26.2 million, followed by the horror movie “My Bloody Valentine 3D” (Lionsgate), which grossed an estimated $24.2 million.

The A.F.C. championship game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Baltimore Ravens scored an easy ratings win for CBS on Sunday, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network took first place for the night with live coverage of the game, which earned more than 30 million viewers in prime time. (Final ratings were expected to be released Tuesday.) NBC’s “Saturday Night Live Presidential Bash 2008,” a comedic tribute to chief executives past and present, attracted a meager audience of just 4.9 million viewers on Sunday. Over all the network ranked third for the night, faring little better early in the evening with a “Dateline” special (5.8 million). ABC finished in second place with its regular lineup of “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” (8.6 million), “Desperate Housewives” (13 million) and “Brothers & Sisters” (8.9 million). Fox was fourth with reruns of its animated comedies.

Though audiences of the Broadway play “33 Variations” will most likely be focused on the star, Jane Fonda, she won’t have the stage all to herself. The producers announced that the cast of the play, by Moisés Kaufman, would be rounded out by Samantha Mathis (of “Grey’s Anatomy,” not to mention “Pump Up the Volume”), above, and Colin Hanks (recently seen on “Mad Men”), as well as Zach Grenier, Don Amendolia, Susan Kellermann, Erik Steele and Diane Walsh. Ms. Fonda portrays a musicologist obsessed with the work of Beethoven in what will be her first appearance on Broadway in more than 45 years. The play is scheduled to begin previews at the Eugene O’Neill Theater on Feb. 9 and run March 9 through May 24.

Fans of Isaac Asimov still haunted by the film adaptation of his “I, Robot” will get the chance to wipe it from their memory banks: a movie version of Asimov’s “Foundation” novels is in the works, Variety reported. On Thursday Columbia Pictures won a three-way auction for film rights to Asimov’s science fiction epic, whose first volume concerns a mathematician put on trial after predicting the collapse of his civilization. Columbia, a division of Sony Pictures Entertainment, beat Warner Brothers and 20th Century Fox for the rights. The studio plans to develop the film for Roland Emmerich, the director of the cataclysmic sci-fi movies “Independence Day” and “The Day After Tomorrow.” Financial terms were not disclosed, and a release date for the film was not announced.

A Screen Actors Guild board member apologized Friday for circulating an e-mail message critical of actors who oppose the authorization of a strike, Variety reported. The board member, Frances Fisher, right, had forwarded an anonymous message suggesting that guild members withhold their votes in the Screen Actors Guild Awards for nominees who have publicly stood against a potential strike. Ms. Fisher said in a statement that she had sent the message “to alert my private e-mail list of opinions and feelings that were circulating,” according to Variety. She also apologized to the actors Alec Baldwin, Josh Brolin, Steve Carell, Sally Field, Michael C. Hall, Susan Sarandon, Tony Shalhoub and Kevin Spacey , and added that “artistic merit” should be the only criterion for the awards.
A baker’s dozen of Andy Warhol’s four-minute black-and-white films, made without sound, were shown accompanied by live music at the Allen Room on Saturday.

A new national report on childbirth suggests that some long-term trends may be reversing themselves. The report, published Jan. 7 by the National Center for Health Statistics, found that more babies were born in 2006 than in any year since 1961. And after a 14-year period of decline, births among teenagers 15 to 19 rose 3 percent in 2006 from the year before.
Families of children with autism, for which there is no documented cure, face endless ups and downs.
The Boston Early Music Festival opened its season at the Morgan Library & Museum on Sunday with a concert of Italian works performed by the Venice Baroque Orchestra.
Dr. Robert L. Martensen has treated an estimated 75,000 patients and says the health care crisis is one of money, people and systems.
On Monday afternoon Chris Duhon added another highlight to the best season in his five-year career with a driving layup that gave the Knicks the lead for good against the Bulls.
The side-by-side comparison made possible by these twin sets of “Magnificent Obsession,” issued by the Criterion Collection, suggests how rapidly tastes evolve in popular culture.
Can the color of your eyes affect more than just your dating life?
The Boston-based company Kelley Donovan & Dancers showed “Borrowed Bones,” a new work by Ms. Donovan notable for its fluid, sensuous movement, on Friday.
How did people avoid malnutrition in societies, like those in the Arctic, where historically there was little or no produce?
At the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday, Vladimir Feltsman offered repertory favorites on a modern piano.
A government-sponsored poll found that nearly three of four Iraqis said they intend to vote in the upcoming elections, and a plurality said they plan to vote for secular candidates.
Russia and Ukraine signed an agreement resolving their dispute over the price of natural gas and said they would resume shipments of fuel as early as Monday evening.
In Oklahoma, where not a single county voted for Barack Obama, attitudes about his presidency are now softening.
The move puts Cisco on a collision course with traditional partners like Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M.
The number of passengers buying premium tickets dropped 11.5 percent in November; sales in economy class declined 6 percent.
Edmund White’s drama imagines a series of death-row encounters between characters firmly based on Timothy J. McVeigh and Gore Vidal.
Thinking in terms of longevity is appropriate when considering “Celestial Excursions,” the second opera in Robert Ashley’s current revival, which was restaged at La MaMa E.T.C. on Saturday.
Dual nationals who have more than one passport say having a choice can be helpful when traveling.
Human rights organizations, health groups and some foreign governments have united in condemning Senegal for imprisoning nine local AIDS activists.
An Iranian intelligence official said that two prominent doctors jailed since June were among four men sent to prison on charges of plotting against the government.
Amateur hockey player Donald Sanderson’s death has attracted national headlines in Canada and revived a longstanding debate over what role fighting should play in hockey.
Two studies found almost no evidence that taxpayers would be better off by paying judges more.
Some legal experts say the European authorities may have a harder time winning the case because Microsoft may be losing market share.
The Giants announced Monday that linebackers coach Bill Sheridan would be their new defensive coordinator, a sign the team wants to stay with the aggressive style championed by Steve Spagnuolo.
Though Lance Armstrong has proven himself a serial winner, there is little expectation that he will leave Australia a winner on Sunday when his comeback race, the Tour Down Under, ends.
The eastern town of Khost was hit by three explosions on Monday, including a double suicide bombing, leaving a teenager dead and at least 16 other civilians wounded.
Employers nationwide face challenges over whether or not to stay open, or give workers the time off for Inauguration Day.
Barack Obama paid tribute to Martin Luther King Jr. by helping out at a homeless center on Monday.
President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea replaced his top economic aides in a cabinet reshuffle aimed at restoring public trust, damaged during the global financial crisis.
The lawyer who fought against the early release from jail of a former Russian tank commander was shot dead, along with a 25-year-old journalist who was with him.
Legislators in Tibet passed a bill on Monday mandating an annual celebration of the date that the Communists declared rule over Tibet.
Once considered a relatively save haven, Australia’s mining-led economy “will unwind scarily fast” in part because of slower-than-expected growth in China.
Europe’s early gains on Monday were erased as investors worried that the British government’s latest move was a step toward nationalization of one or more banks.
European governments are moving more forcefully to take control over banks after a first round of costly bailouts came up short.
There is no clean outcome if a deal between Zimbabwe’s president and the prime minister in waiting fails.
Israel accelerated its troop withdrawal as Hamas reasserted control in Gaza and Palestinians sought to recover from the war.
An Australian writer was sentenced to three years in prison Monday for insulting the Thai monarchy in a self-published novel.
Researchers have found that bearded capuchin monkeys in the wild will select the most effective stone for use in cracking nuts.
A quick and inexpensive safety checklist reduced surgical complications and deaths.

Though audiences of the Broadway play ''33 Variations'' will most likely be focused on the star, Jane Fonda, she won't have the stage all to herself. The producers announced that the cast of the play, by Moisés Kaufman, would be rounded out by Samantha Mathis (of ''Grey's Anatomy,'' not to mention ''Pump Up the Volume''), above, and Colin Hanks (recently seen on ''Mad Men''), as well as Zach Grenier, Don Amendolia, Susan Kellermann, Erik Steele and Diane Walsh. Ms. Fonda portrays a musicologist obsessed with the work of Beethoven in what will be her first appearance on Broadway in more than 45 years. INAUGURATION COVERAGEBarack Obama (above, with Joseph R. Biden Jr., at the Democratic convention in August) will be sworn in as the 44th president on the steps of the United States Capitol amid performances by Aretha Franklin, Yo-Yo Ma, Itzhak Perlman, Gabriela Montero, Anthony McGill, the United States Marine Band, the United States Navy Band Sea Chanters and the San Francisco Boys Chorus and Girls Chorus. Elizabeth Alexander will recite a poem she has written for the event. The Rev. Rick Warren of Saddleback Church will give the invocation before Mr. Biden takes his oath as vice president, administered by John Paul Stevens, associate justice of the Supreme Court. John G. Roberts Jr., chief justice of the United States, will administer the oath of office to Mr. Obama. The Rev. Joseph E. Lowery, a founder of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, will offer a benediction. The inauguration will be followed by a parade along Pennsylvania Avenue. The ceremony will start at about 10, with Mr. Obama's swearing in at noon. Coverage begins at 5 a.m. on CNN; 6 a.m. on C-Span; 7 a.m. on ABC, CBS, NBC and TV One; 8:30 a.m. on Fox News Channel; 9 a.m. on Fox and MyNetworkTV; 9:30 a.m. on CBS; 10 a.m. on MSNBC and Channel 41; 11 a.m. on BBC America, BET Jazz, CNBC, TV5Monde and Channels 13 and 49; and 11:30 a.m. on BET, Current and Channel 47. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE NEIGHBORHOOD BALL: AN INAUGURATION CELEBRATION President and Mrs. Obama are to have their first dance of the evening at these festivities, held at the Washington Convention Center. Beyoncé, Mary J. Blige, Mariah Carey, Faith Hill, Jay-Z, Alicia Keys, Shakira and Stevie Wonder will perform; Nick Cannon, above, will be the D.J. ''A Moment in History: The Inauguration of Barack Obama,'' at 10, will report from inaugural balls in Washington and explore reactions from around the world to the Obama presidency as well as to the significance of the day to African-Americans. Charles Gibson, Diane Sawyer and George Stephanopoulos will report. A special edition of ''Nightline,'' at 11:30, will look back over the day's events.

McALOON--Rose Fichera, Ph.D. The Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies mourns the passing of Dr. Rose Fichera McAloon, dedicated psychoanalyst and inspiring teacher. She was much loved by her friends and colleagues, students and supervisees. The center extends its warmest sympathies to her family.

OLSON--Jesse, former Executive Vice President of 1199 Hospital and Health Care Workers Union, died on January 19 at age 84. A courageous advocate for social justice and civil rights, he devoted himself to empowering working people so they could better their lives. He is survived by his loving wife of 58 years, Adele; his devoted children, Paul and Nina; his sister, Fae Dryer; his daughter, Debra; and grandchildren Michelle and Daniel. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

VIDEO: Inside Gaza and Israel A video report on the latest developments from inside Gaza. Another video focuses on Israel's Arab citizens, who make up a fifth of the population and have seethed over the war in Gaza. Thousands of Israeli Arabs have taken to the streets in protest. Above, one such protest in early January in Sakhnin, a town in northern Israeli.

Two thousand years after he took on Julius Caesar and the Roman army, the pugnacious cartoon character Astérix is provoking another fight. Last week the French company Hachette Livre bought a majority stake in Albert-René, the longtime publisher of the adventures of Astérix, the diminutive Gallic warrior. This followed an announcement by Albert Uderzo, the illustrator and a creator of Astérix, that stories featuring the character could continue after his death. (René Goscinny, the other creator, died in 1977.) But in a letter in Le Monde, Mr. Uderzo's daughter Sylvie protested the sale, writing that ''a handful of shadowy advisers'' had prompted her father's decision, BBC News reported. ''It's as if the gates of the Gaulish village had been thrown open to the Roman Empire,'' Ms. Uderzo wrote, according to the BBC. ''I am entering resistance against perhaps the worst enemies of Astérix, the men of finance and industry.''

STERN--Barbara, esteemed Professor of Marketing at Rutgers University, Dr. Stern passed away peacefully on January 15. She is survived by her mother Rose, sister Carole, and daughters Leslie and Wendy. Donations in her memory may be made to the Visiting Nurse Service of New York at www.vnsny.org.

FAEDER--Marjorie, at age 89 on January 19, 2009. Loving wife to the late Alfred. Loving mother of Edward (Shelley), Robert (Maarit) and Michael. Devoted grandmother and great-grandmother. Beloved daughter of Maurice M. Dubin. Graveside services will be held today 3pm at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

FARBER--Steven. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Maimonides Medical Center notes with sorrow the passing of our college Dr. Steven Farber. Dr. Farber was a loyal friend and vocal advocate for the interest of his institution, our department, and most emphatically his patients. He worked tirelessly to advance those interests, and his powerful voice for the welfare of pregnant women in Brooklyn will be missed.

ILSON--Carol. We are filled with sadness over the unexpected loss of Carol, who had become such a vital part of our lives. Our hearts go out to Bernie and their children over the loss of this vibrant and brilliant woman whose joie-de-vivre was contagious. We shall miss her forever. Edwina and Marvin Marks

STEMPEL--Ellen (nee Flaum), 79, died suddenly on January 17, in Sunny Isles, FL. She was the beloved wife of Marvin for 57 years. Devoted mother of Lee, Andrew and Barry. Dedicated grandmother of Cameron, Jonathan and Nathan. Admired and adored by family, friends, colleagues and students. Funeral services at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck on Wednesday at 10:30am.

A MIRROR OF AMERICA More than any other metropolitan area, Columbia, S.C., has the economy that most mimics the national experience. Residents there expressed a mixture of hope, frustration, lowered expectations and skepticism about President-elect Barack Obama's ability to fix the problems. BLAME GAME Two banks are arguing in New York courts about which is responsible for a mortgage investment that went bad: Deutsche Bank, which created it, or M&T Bank, which bought it and lost millions. [B1.]

The eagle has landed? Not quite. In fact, it never took off. People watching the star-studded celebration on Sunday at the Lincoln Memorial might have noticed the cameo by Challenger, an imposing bald eagle that briefly appeared on stage, flapped its wings and exited with its handler.

PETRAGLIA--John F.,on January 18th, 2009. Retired General Counsel FDNY. Beloved husband of Jean (nee Scanlon), and the late Eleanor, devoted father of Monica and Edward McCabe, and John and Kim Petraglia, dear brother of William Petraglia and the late Vera Fencel, loving grandfather to eight grandchildren. Reposing Wednesday and Thursday 25pm and 7-9:30pm at Edward D. Lynch funeral Home 43-07 Queens Blvd, Sunnyside, NY. Funeral Mass, Our Lady of Fatima R.C. Church Friday 10am. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery Hauppauge, NY.

ILARDI--Vincent, 83, Renaissance historian - scholar, passed away on January 6. Predeceased by wife Nina, survived by son, relatives in USA and Italy, and host of friends worldwide. Memorial service for Nina and Vincent Ilardi, May 8 at Memorial Hall on campus of University of Massachusetts Amherst.
The New Old Age From Jane Gross's blog, nytimes.com/newoldage.

MELTZER--Theda (Taube), died peacefully at home in Manhattan on January 17, in her 95th year. She was the beloved wife of the late Manford Meltzer, and the daughter of the late Sam and Sarah Spatt. Taube is survived by her sons Peter and James, her granddaughter Alexandra, and her great-granddaughter Calliope, and also by her sisters Doris Sirow and Roberta Wells. She was predeceased by her sister Gladys Burrows. Taube was a tall, elegant lady, a witty conversationalist, an avid golfer and a talented needlepointer. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services private. The family will receive from 36pm on Monday, January 19th, at The Phillips Club, 155 West 66th Street.
National DIFFERING ON JUDGES' SALARIES

Well, it turns out there may have been some basis for those rumors last summer that Joseph R. Biden Jr. might become Barack Obama's secretary of state -- because Mr. Obama asked him. That heretofore-kept secret slipped out from Mr. Biden's wife, Jill Biden, when they were being interviewed on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show,'' which was taped Monday morning at the Kennedy Center and broadcast in the afternoon. Mr. Biden had been telling Ms. Winfrey that being vice president would be good for the family, and Ms. Winfrey asked what he meant by that.

The Connecticut women's basketball team has not won a national championship since 2004, when Diana Taurasi was the best player in college basketball and the Huskies stepped on the court with a confidence earned from years of dominance. It is too early to tell if this season's version of the Huskies, ranked No. 1 and undefeated, has rediscovered that moxie. But like the great teams of Connecticut's past, this one is proving to be a level above the competition.

SEGAL--Stanley J. January 19, 1926-January 18, 2009. Retired Hunter College professor and clinical psychologist in private practice. Resident of New York City, Damascus, PA, and Nevis, W.I. Dedicated parent with Isabelle of Eric Segal and Karen Shoplik and Amy and Everett Shorey. Doting grandfather of Ella, Margot, and Rachel. Devoted partner of Sheldon Soffer for 28 years. A celebration of his life will be held in the Spring.

FLEMING--Peter E.,Jr. The partners of Curtis, MalletPrevost, Colt & Mosle LLP. mourn the passing of our partner, Peter Fleming Jr. Peter was justly renowned as one of the most highly skilled trial lawyers in the United States, and was a dominant force in the Firm's litigation practice. He was the soul and conscience of Curtis and his advice and strength of character have inspired the entire Firm's practice of law. Those of us privileged to have known him and learned from him are exceedingly grateful for his life. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family.
