Indian Muslims burned portraits of President George Bush; Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel; and Mahmoud Abbas, president of the Palestinian Authority, during a demonstration in Mumbai to protest Israeli military strikes in Gaza.

ANDRON--Beatrice, died Sunday January 18th at the age of 89. She is survived by her husband of 67 years, Norman Andron, her three grandchildren Eric, Allan, and Vicki Friedman and her son-in-law Mark. Beatrice was born in Brooklyn New York to Judge Nathan Sweedler and Ada Meyer Sweedler and had one daughter, Patricia. A memorial service will be held for Beatrice at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck New York at 2pm on Tuesday January 20th. In lieu of flowers, please donate to National Ovarian Cancer Coalition.

BILICK--Jack, age 96, died January 18. Postal worker, teacher, social justice fighter and beloved husband of the late Betty, father of Larry (Netsy) and the late Susan, grandfather of Sari and Molly, brother, uncle and friend.

LEARY--Dr. Herbert Joseph, Jr.,died peacefully early Thursday morning, January 8th at the Haven Hospice, Edison, NJ. He leaves behind Lucille Goodreaux Leary of Essex Junction, VT and their two children, Kimberlyn Leary, Ph.D. of Cambridge, MA and Herbert Joseph Leary III, VMD of Kearny, NJ, all of whom were with him on that Thursday. Richard Shaw, a son-in-law, of Cambridge, MA and Patricia Ambrosio of Parlin, NJ, were with him as well. He is also survived by nephews Arthur Leary, Jr. and Sidney Goodreaux, Jr., nieces Cheryl Leary, Melissa Goodreaux, Monica Goodreaux, Melanie Goodreaux and their children. He was loved and will be missed by family, and the many students he mentored. He was born in New Orleans, Louisiana on March 26, 1937, the son of Herbert Joseph Leary, Sr. and Cecilia Bass Leary, and was the brother of Arthur Vincent Leary. He graduated from Dillard University in 1959 and went on to earn a Ph.D. in Chemistry from the University of Iowa. He was a Senior Engineer at the IBM Corporation in Fishkill, NY. After retiring from IBM, he became a professor of chemistry at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette. A born teacher with a generous heart and a visionary spirit, Leary saw far into the future and helped his children, his nieces, nephews, and his students to dream and transform their dreams into reality. He knew how to laugh and he understood what it meant to be a loyal son and friend. He was so proud of his family, in whose hearts he will reside forever.
I'm not going to make a long speech. I've got to save my best lines for tomorrow. BARACK OBAMA, at Calvin Coolidge High School in Washington. [A18]

ILSON--Carol, Ph.D. Psychoanalyst, educator and author, was a remarkable person who lit up the room whenever she entered. But her own source of joy and inspiration was her family. Dr. Ilson died suddenly in her sleep early in the morning at her home in New York City on Saturday, January 17, 2009. She was 75 years old. Dr. Ilson was still actively pursuing her practice in psychoanalysis at the time of her death. Her book on the legendary director and producer Harold Prince, ''Harold Prince, A Director's Journey'' went into four printings. Mr. Prince calls Carol his Boswell. Carol Ilson was also a successful director. Her direction of Israel Horovitz's play ''Line'' at the 13th Street Theater together with a rave review by Clive Barnes in the New York Times helped the play become the longest running play in the Off-Off Broadway theater circuit. Dr. Ilson also taught theater and dance as an adjunct professor in the theater department at Queens College for ten years. Dr. Ilson is survived by her husband, Bernie Ilson, Ph.D. -a veteran public relations man and author who has represented many of the most famous personalities in show business at his PR firm, Bernie Ilson, Inc. She is also survived by her son David and his wife Elyse, her son Jimmy and his wife Rhonda, and four grandchildren -Emily, Sadie, Jesse and Sam. Dr. Ilson is a graduate of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. She earned her B.A. at Queens College, her M.A. in Theater at Hunter College, and her Ph.D. at the Graduate Center, City University of New York. Early in her career, Carol Ilson under the name of Carol Colby pursued a career as a professional dancer appearing in night chubs and television including an appearance on the Sid Caesar Show. Her manager at the time was Bernie Ilson. Dr. Ilson has been a longtime Member of the Board of the Metropolitan Institute for Psychoanalysis. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday, January 21 at 1:15pm at the Riverside Chapel on Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St.

SMITH--Marjorie Parker, on January 17th, 2009. Inducted into the World Figure Skating Hall of Fame. Survived by five children and three grandchildren. Funeral Friday 10am from the Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home 9th St. (between 4th and 5th Avenues) Brooklyn. Funeral Mass 10:30am St. Saviour Church. Visiting Wednesday 7-9pm and Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to The World Figure Skating Museum and Hall of Fame 20 First St., Colorado Springs, CO 80906, will be appreciated.

SALTER--Rhoda, died peacefully at home yesterday. Born in Bialystok, Poland in 1920, Rhoda moved to New York in 1936. An outstanding scholar, she left graduate school with an M.A. to marry the love of her life, Andrew Salter, raise their two sons, and immerse herself in his career as psychologist and writer; many patients came early for a free hour of her therapy. Rhoda was the most devoted wife, mother, daughter, sister, aunt, mother-in-law, friend and grandmother. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to Planned Parenthood.

KAUFMAN--Herbert, born January 6, 1917, died January 13, 2009. Best friend and husband to Enid for 60 years. Devoted and supportive father to Meg and Ned. Indulgent and delighted grandfather to Emily. Respected and treasured friend to many. He will be remembered for his lifelong passions: architecture, history, landmark preservation, trains, travel, stories, and family. He was a deeply moral man, kind, generous, and a gentle man in the full sense of these two words. He will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Food Bank for New York City (Hunts Point Cooperative Market, 355 Food Center Drive, Bronx, NY 10474, www.foodbanknyc.org) would be appreciated.

LOWE--Eleanor (Ellie), passed away on January 18th, 2009. Beloved mother of Mona and Dan Morello, Sheldon and Maria Lowe, and Francine Lowe. Cherished grandmother of Billy, Alexa, and Danielle Lowe. She was very involved with Diabetes Research Institute, (Humanitarian Honoree) at Love and Hope Gala, and Leading Ladies. We will all miss her beautiful smile and generous heart.

SHATZ--Julius, on January 18, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Janette Shatz, D.D.S. Loving father of Lori Shatz and Peggy Tilles. Loved by his grandchildren Jonathan and Jessica and son-in-law Matthew Tilles. Services Wednesday 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

One estimable American novelist pays peculiar tribute to another in ''Terre Haute,'' a two-person drama by Edmund White that imagines a series of death row encounters between characters firmly based on Timothy J. McVeigh, the man convicted and executed for the bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building in 1995, and the novelist Gore Vidal. The play, first seen at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe in 2007 and later in London, was inspired by essays Mr. Vidal wrote about Mr. McVeigh and his motivations. After reading one, Mr. McVeigh invited Mr. Vidal to be a witness at his execution. In a Vanity Fair article from 2001, Mr. Vidal, who was still living in Italy, dryly noted that he was unable to attend this function: ''The attorney general had given me too short a time to get from here to there.''
GOLDFIELD--Bina 2/1933 -1/20/2006 Saved from the Holocaust. Dearly loved and deeply missed, but with us always.

KELSEY--Howard Burr, died peacefully at the age of 93 on Wednesday, January 14, 2009. He was the devoted husband of the late Frances Voorhees Kelsey. His three loving children were at his bedside: Patricia K. Schultz of Richmond, VA, Peter B. Kelsey of Lovettsville, VA and Marjorie K. White of Annandale, VA. He also leaves his sister Elizabeth Kelsey Cameron, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A resident of Hightstown, NJ, and formerly Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ and Quogue, NY, he was a partner at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. He graduated from The Hotchkiss School, Yale University in 1937, and Columbia Law School. He was a lieutenant in the US Navy during World War II. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am on Thursday, January 22, at the First Presbyterian Church of Hightstown, followed by interment at the Quogue Cemetery in Quogue, NY on Friday, January 23 at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Llewellyn Park Preservation Foundation, 28 Oak Bend, Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ 07052.

LANGE--Artie, passed away at age 90 on January 18 surrounded by his family. Loving husband of Bea for 63 years. Beloved father of Marvin and Eric and father-in-law of Ellen Metzger and Maureen Kritzer-Lange. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Danny and Rebecca. Devoted brother of Henry and brother-in-law of Marilyn Stern. Cherished by many nieces and nephews, great-nieces and great-nephews. Avid photographer and world traveler. Services will be held at 11:30am on Tuesday, January 20 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York, NY. Shiva will be on Tuesday following the services at Eric's home in Maplewood, NJ and on Wednesday and Thursday beginning at 2pm at Marvin's home in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Ronald McDonald House or a charity of your choice.

JACOBSON--Jerry, on January 15th, age 89; beloved husband of the late Sylvia (Rappaport); cherished father of Laura Wagner, Ellie Feldman, Carole (Doug) Rawson, adored Poppy of eight grandchildren; four great-grandchildren. Devoted brother of Rosalie Spiegel, Beatrice Jacobson. Resided in Santa Monica; formerly of Rockville Centre, Floral Park, Lake Worth. He will be remembered for his humor, strength, smile, devotion to his family and his zest for life...together again with Sliv.

Today, when Barack Obama promises to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution, an African-American will finally occupy the highest office in the land. (Hallelujah!) But the significance of that achievement may obscure another, easily overlooked first: a native of Hawaii will take residence in the White House. (Aloha!) Hawaii, which joined the Union only in 1959, had a relatively short Oval-Office-less streak. As the chart below shows, states have had to wait more than 70 years, on average, before one of their own ran for president or vice president on a major party ticket. (In the early days, some parties that might now be considered minor, were major by our standard. Also, we included those candidates born in or representing a particular state.)

The American Symphony Orchestra has announced its programming for the 2009-10 season, consisting of six concerts to be performed at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. The symphony, led for the 17th season by its musical director, Leon Botstein, will open on Oct. 14 with a performance of “Fervaal,” an 1893 work by the French Romantic composer Vincent d’Indy. On Nov. 15 the program will be titled “The Remains of Romanticism,” which will include works by Fuchs, Strauss and others. Further concerts in 2010 will feature the music of the American composer Henry Cowell, Robert Schumann’s “Scenes From Goethe’s ‘Faust'” and a series on the theme of Apollo and Dionysus. More information can be found online at americansymphony.org.

What a way to make a living. The trust representing Colin Higgins, the director and co-screenwriter of the film comedy “9 to 5,” has filed suit against Mr. Higgins’s former lawyer, saying the lawyer failed to represent Mr. Higgins’s interests in the coming “9 to 5″ Broadway musical, Variety reported. The lawyer, Barry L. Hirsch, had represented Mr. Higgins until his death in 1988. But the trust ended its dealings with Mr. Hirsch after learning he was also representing Patricia Resnick, the other screenwriter of the movie, and the author of the book for “9 to 5: The Musical.” The lawsuit says that Mr. Hirsch failed to secure Mr. Higgins’s stage rights for the musical project, and seeks damages for legal malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty. The musical is scheduled to begin previews at the Marquis Theater on April 7.

Gerard Mortier, the designated general manager and artistic director of the New York City Opera who departed the post in November before his first season, said that he had “no regrets” about the circumstances that preceded his departure, in an interview with the French newspaper Le Monde. Mr. Mortier’s short stay with City Opera was clouded by the revelation that he was also seeking the directorship of the Bayreuth Festival in Germany. He later quit the New York job, saying he had been promised an operating budget of $60 million, but was given only $36 million by the opera’s board. Previous City Opera budgets have been around $42 million. “I accepted the sacrifices, but there are limits,” Mr. Mortier said in Le Monde. “This opera must innovate to exist alongside the Metropolitan Opera. Today, I fear it disappears.” Mr. Mortier also said in the interview that he had been offered a position at Berlin’s Staatsoper Unter den Linden, but that working alongside its current musical director, Daniel Barenboim, would be like “two tigers on the same mountain.”

In theater, there’s no such thing as old age. When the national tour of Tracy Letts’s play “August: Osage County” commences in Denver on July 24, its cast will include Estelle Parsons, 81, the Academy Award winner and Tony Award nominee who joined the Broadway production in June as the venomous Weston family matriarch, Violet. Full casting and dates for the tour were not announced.

Taylor Swift’s album “Fearless” (Big Machine) enjoyed its seventh week atop the album sales chart, Billboard reported, the first time that a record has done so since 2004, when Usher’s “Confessions” spent 9 weeks at No. 1. “Fearless” sold 63,000 copies according to Nielsen SoundScan, a decline of 11 percent from the previous week. Beyoncé’s “I Am … Sasha Fierce” (Music World/Columbia) moved back into second place with 49,000 units sold, while the Nickelback album “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) fell to third with 46,000 units. The week’s top debut was the soundtrack to “Notorious” (Bad Boy), about the rapper Notorious B.I.G. The record, featuring tracks by Notorious B.I.G., as well as Jay-Z, Faith Evans, Jadakiss and Santogold, took fourth place with 43,000 sales.

In my Thursday column, I note the chance that President Obama will lead the U.S. to rejoin the world, and how eager the world is to have us a part of it again. I suggest that a couple of quick litmus tests would help establish his bona fides and reassure people: move toward closure of Guantanamo and a ban on torture, and also move the U.S. to a more balanced position in the Middle East.

In my first year of teaching English at a failing middle school in Brooklyn, I shared a classroom with a recovering alcoholic. While I frantically planned lessons on "The Outsiders," he regaled me with tales of whiskey-sodden escapades that could not have been further removed from my concerns. Across the hall, a special-education teacher who took me under her wing in those treacherous first months spoke about her years tending bar in Honolulu, Austin, Tex., and Brooklyn. Handling her unruly class at a cool remove, she lamented how much less she earned educating minds instead of plying them with drink.Popular culture has generally represented teachers as idealistic teetotalers, probably because it wants to see them that way. While TV series like "The Wire" and "Rescue Me" are awash in images of cops and firemen replenishing their bruised machismo with an endless procession of beers and shots, teachers must make do with sanitized schmaltz like reruns of "Welcome Back, Kotter" and its even cornier offspring, "Saved By the Bell." Maybe it's simply because the notion of a teacher cozying up to a bottle of pinot noir and a stack of "Animal Farm" essays isn't terribly romantic. Whatever the case, I doubt that a gritty HBO drama is in the works.

The last time the Bagger saw Jeff Dowd, known as The Dude in indie circles and to fans of "The Big Lebowski," he was throwing a viewing party on main street Park City for President Obama's inauguration and talking a great deal about "Dirt," an eco-documentary that he is ferociously representing. And then the Bagger split for LA to cover the Oscar noms and all heck broke loose. According to a witness, The Dude walked up to John Anderson, a critic for Variety, at the Holiday theaters in Park City and button-holed him for his opinion on the film as he was leaving. Mr. Anderson told him he didn't like the film and The Dude continued to lobby him, asking him what his responsibility was to broader green issues. The yammering continued all the way to the café at the Yaro hotel, Mr. Anderson barked him away, but The Dude circled back ten minutes later. Mr. Anderson threatened to punch the Dude if he didn't let him eat in peace and proceeded to do so. The police were called, but the Dude, who is a giant, passionate guy, did not press charges. Good lefty stalwart that he is, he is proposing that they have a panel instead about the social responsibilities of critics.

Consumer electronics manufacturers appropriately and regularly point out that to get the full Blu-ray experience, you need to pair a Blu-ray player with a TV capable of displaying its high-quality image. A 42-inch TV is about the smallest set that makes sense to use with Blu-ray, television manufacturers say, assuming you sit a normal distance from the screen. And even then, the set needs to be able to display a 1080p signal, or you won't see the benefits of Blu-ray resolution.

Or is it referring to the brightly colored, the boldly patterned, the more visually obvious - styles that distract one from the grim financials at hand? This week's inundation of precise tailoring, look-at-me silhouettes and dandy fabrics seems to suggest the latter.

Was there any more stupid controversy during the recent presidential campaign than the debate over whether we should talk to Iran or not? Things haven't improved much since then. Tehran's efforts to obtain the bomb may be one of the two or three most momentous foreign policy issues Barack Obama faces as he settles into the White House. It's certainly one of the most pressing (within a few months Iran may have enough enriched uranium to produce one bomb). Yet it's as if a blanket of silence has fallen over Washington's commentariate. Very few of these writers are talking about Iran. What's going on? Is the issue just too scary for us to contemplate?

With a major event like the inauguration, there are always two stories. There is the story that gets reported, and another parallel story, which for reasons of time, space and the vagaries of the scene, doesn't get reported. It would have been impossible to write about Michelle Obama's swearing-in outfit on deadline without staying close to a telephone, a BlackBerry and a computer. Given the security between the White House and the Capitol, and of course the throngs of people, her Toledo coat and dress would have seemed a speck of yellow from the mall. So I spent the day at a friend's house in my sweat pants and Uggs watching the television with a Basset hound named Rembrandt. I'd been in touch with Mrs. Obama's press secretary by phone, and on Tuesday morning as the Obamas were leaving Blair House, I got an email saying that the yellow dress was designed by Toledo. And that's when Toledo learned her outfit would go down in the history books-when she saw Mrs. Obama on television. Almost 12 hours later, Jason Wu, who designed her ivory chiffon ball gown, learned his information the same way. I was on the phone with Toledo a few minutes later. I was on the phone with Wu around 11 p.m., after I'd been to the Commander in Chief ball to see Mrs. Obama in the chiffon dress. Of course, since Ikram Goldman, the owner of the Chicago boutique Ikram, had helped Mrs. Obama and dealt directly with the designers-they had no contact, they told me, with the first lady-it was easy to form a short list of possible designers who might be involved in her inaugural wardrobe.

When it comes to income taxes, there are different types of people.

Recent electrical alterations in my building have revealed that I was illegally charged for 45 years for power consumed by other users. Con Edison estimates my loss at about $400 a year for those 45 years. What is my recourse?

I signed a contract in May 2007 for a preconstruction condominium. I closed a few weeks ago and later learned that on the day of my closing, an amendment was filed showing an increase in the estimated carrying costs of more than 25 percent, because the projected real estate taxes had doubled. Do I have any remedy? I probably wouldn't have signed the contract had I known the actual amount.

Karen Thorp drives 60 miles a day to and from her job as a senior deputy district attorney of Los Angeles County, where her specialty is prosecuting multiple-murder suspects and kidnappers. Her car is a Honda FCX Clarity fuel-cell sedan, and it runs on zero-emission hydrogen.

Announcing Times Open, a day-long event for developers interested in working with NYTimes.com as a news and information platform. When we started this Open blog, we also embarked on a mission to share more of what we do on the development side of The Times. So far, we've done that via conference presentations, open-source software, blog posts and (most recently and probably most importantly) our APIs. Times Open is the next logical step in our vision of NYTimes.com. We see our site as more than just a source of news and information: it's a platform on which news and information become building blocks.

A German court has ruled that a collection of rare posters seized by the Gestapo in 1938 belong to the son of their original owner, Bloomberg News reported. The collection of more than 4,250 posters, which includes prewar advertisements for movies and cabaret shows as well as political propaganda, right, was seized from Hans Sachs, a Jewish dentist who was put in a concentration camp but later escaped with his family to Boston; the works eventually became the property of the Deutsches Historisches Museum in Berlin. Mr. Sachs’s son, Peter Sachs, a retired airline pilot living in Sarasota, Fla., sued the museum last year for the return of the collection, estimated to be worth $5.8 million. In 2007 a German government panel had rejected his petition to have the posters returned, but on Tuesday a court was unconvinced by the government’s argument that Hans Sachs, who died in 1974, voluntarily gave up the posters when he fled Germany. The court held off ruling on whether the museum must hand over the collection to Peter Sachs.

Jack Bauer may leave international terrorists quaking in their boots, but he’s still no match for the combined might of Charlie Sheen and Jon Cryer. The CBS comedy “Two and a Half Men” handily won its Monday-night showdown with the Fox action series “24,” although Fox averaged the most viewers for the night over all, according to Nielsen’s estimates. At 9 p.m., “Two and a Half Men” was the evening’s most-watched show with 16 million viewers, topping the first half-hour of “24”; “24” averaged 12 million viewers for the night, enough to put it well ahead of NBC’s hourlong “Superstars of Dance” (6.8 million) and the CBS sitcom “Worst Week,” which drew 9.5 million viewers at 9:30. A two-hour episode of “The Bachelor” on ABC averaged 9.3 million viewers from 8 to 9, and 10.6 million from 9 to 10. Earlier on Fox, a new episode of the medical drama “House” (14.8 million) performed strongly at 8 p.m., while CBS’s “CSI: Miami” (14.5 million) won the 10 p.m. hour.
The company said it would end a program to sell ads in newspapers because the effort had not been as successful as expected.

The Louvre has begun conferring with banks in search of a financial institution to help manage its first-ever endowment, Bloomberg News reported. Roughly 18 banks, including JPMorgan Chase and UBS, are in the running to manage the Louvre’s $230 million fund, which it received from the United Arab Emirates to build a museum on Saadiyat Island, near Abu Dhabi, which is scheduled to open in 2012. The museum is expected to receive about $323 million more from the emirate over the next 18 years. Each year the Louvre raises about $157 million and receives about the same amount from the French government for operating costs and maintenance. The Louvre said that it planned to use money earned from the endowment to renovate its Greek and Roman art wing and build additions to the museum.

A coming album paying tribute to the British singer-songwriter Nick Drake will include a song performed by the actor Heath Ledger, Billboard reported. The track, a cover of Mr. Drake’s “Black Eyed Dog,” was recorded by Mr. Ledger in 2007 for an art installation; Mr. Ledger died the following January from an accidental drug overdose. Mr. Drake, the gentle-voiced folk-rock singer of “Pink Moon” and “Things Behind the Sun,” struggled commercially but became a critical and cult hit after his death from an overdose of antidepressants at age 26 in 1974. Other performers on the tribute album, which was announced at the MidemNet music industry conference in France, include Eddie Vedder, Dave Grohl, Norah Jones and Jack Johnson.

Barack Obama hasn’t been president one full day and he has already inspired a musical. “Obama on My Mind,” with book, music and lyrics by Teddy Hayes, will have its premiere at the Hens and Chickens Theater in Islington, a London borough, in March, Playbill.com reported. According to a release, the show will take a “humorous look at the weird and wonderful world behind the scenes of a small Obama campaign office and the larger-than-life characters who make the wheels turn, the cogs whirr and bring in the votes.” The musical will feature a mixture of pop, rock, gospel and jazz songs; it is scheduled to begin performances on March 3, with its official opening on March 5 for a run through March 21.

The Magic Theater, a San Francisco institution that made an urgent appeal for funds from subscribers and audience members at the start of the year, has surpassed its goal and will stay open, The San Francisco Chronicle reported. The 42-year-old theater, which has staged premieres of plays by David Mamet and Sam Shepard, raised $455,000 from about 1,100 donors. Earlier this month the theater announced on its Web site, magictheatre.org, that it needed to raise $350,000 in about a week to pay down a debt of $600,000 or it would close. The theater now says it will complete its season by reducing its budget to $1.65 million from $2 million, and postponing the premiere of the play “Mistakes Were Made” by Craig Wright until next season.

Protesters, a fixture of every inauguration since President Richard M. Nixon's in 1973, were few and scattered in Washington on Tuesday as Barack Obama assumed the presidency. It appeared that there were far more vendors looking to make a buck selling inaugural chocolate bars and Obama incense than protesters seeking to make a statement. Those who raised their voices were more likely to be expressing gratitude that George W. Bush was leaving office than displeasure that Mr. Obama was replacing him.

KASLOVE--Ruth H.,a longtime Norwalk resident, died January 19, 2009 at home in Wilton, CT. She was the widow of Bernard P. Kaslove, her husband of 47 years. She was born in New York City in 1923 to Samuel and Rose L. Halprin. Over a span of six decades, she devoted herself to service for Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization. Most recently she served for 12 years as the organization's NGO Representative to the U.N. She was a graduate and postgraduate of NYU. She is survived by her children, Jonathan Kaslove of Phoenix, AZ; Laurie Kaslove of Silver Spring, MD and Debra K. Browne of Wilton, CT and their spouses; Judith Kaslove of Redding, CT; nine grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren. She is also survived by her brother, Lawrence Halprin of Kentfield, California, and many cousins. A funeral service is scheduled for Thursday, January 22 at 11:30am at Congregation Beth El, 109 East Avenue, Norwalk. Funeral services are being handled by Collins Funeral Home of Norwalk.

Hallowell Jr. of Lake Placid, NY, Andrew W. Hallowell of Lincoln, MA and Tifany H. Babcock of Ferrisburgh, VT. Sister of Marriott Moszka of Sandwich, MA, Francis W. Welch III of Tucson, AZ and John H. Welch of Jamaica Plain, MA. Also survived by 12 grandchildren. Relatives and friends invited to attend a memorial service on Saturday, January 31st at 11am at St. Matthew's Church in Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Robin may be made to CEH Fund (cehfund.org).

ROCHE--John T.,a longtime executive of Kidder, Peabody & Co. Incorporated and a former President of Kidder Peabody Group died January 19 in Glen Cove, New York from complications related to Parkinson's disease. He was 76. Mr. Roche joined Kidder, Peabody in 1955 as an accountant. He worked in various finance and operating roles for the private securities firm, and was elected a Vice President and Shareholder and then Executive Vice President -Operations. He served in this capacity for many years until he was appointed President of Kidder Peabody Group upon its formation in 1986. Mr. Roche retired from the firm in 1987. John Thomas Roche was born in New York, New York on June 6, 1932, the oldest of four children of Thomas and Helen Roche. He graduated from St. John's University in 1953 and enlisted in the U.S. Army after graduation. He joined Kidder, Peabody after his discharge from the Army in 1955. Mr. Roche also held an honorary doctorate degree from St. John's University. Mr. Roche is survived by Claire, his wife of 55 years, his sons Bradley, Kevin and Bryan and 11 grandchildren.

Loving mother to Susan and Robert and grandmother to Lindsay, Spencer, Justin and Rachel, she is also survived by her sister Mae Breskin and her beloved long term companion Kenneth Winter. She now goes to join her late husband Irving Margolies-may their souls rest in peace for eternity.

To the top-secret nuclear codes, we now add one more technological weapon that is handed over to the incoming president at exactly noon on Inauguration Day: the root password to WhiteHouse.gov. President Obama had not yet taken the oath of office at 12:01 p.m. on Tuesday when the Obama administration took over the cyberaddress of the presidency, whitehouse.gov, with a flourish. A minute past noon, the Bush administration's familiar Web site, with eight years worth of archived press releases, speech transcripts, photographs, executive orders, and proclamations, was swept away into the hands of the National Archives. The homepage instead featured a large portrait of Mr. Obama and the slogan, ''Change Has Come to America: The Inauguration of President Barack Obama.''

The president's elderly stepgrandmother brought him an oxtail fly whisk, a mark of power at home in Kenya. Cousins journeyed from the South Carolina town where the first lady's great-great-grandfather was born into slavery, while the rabbi in the family came from the synagogue where he had been commemorating Martin Luther King's Birthday. The president and first lady's siblings were there, too, of course: his Indonesian-American half-sister, who brought her Chinese-Canadian husband, and her brother, a black man with a white wife. When President Barack Obama was sworn in on Tuesday, he was surrounded by an extended clan that would have shocked past generations of Americans and instantly redrew the image of a first family for future ones.

When Lou Neglia first opened his Brooklyn martial arts academy in 1974, students wanted to learn kung fu, inspired by the television show starring David Carradine. Then karate enjoyed a surge of interest after the release of the 1984 film ''The Karate Kid.'' Now nearly everyone who enters Mr. Neglia's school in Gravesend wants to learn mixed martial arts, the wildly popular staple of cable and pay-per-view television. ''It's the fastest-growing sport in the country,'' said Mr. Neglia, a former world kickboxing champion, in a rapid-fire delivery that he interrupted to take a stream of business calls. ''Boxing is dead.''

The comedian Josh Kornbluth says he never really considered himself Jewish until he sifted through a series of hypercolored portraits and emerged, as he puts it, one of Warhol's Jews. In 1980 Andy Warhol created a series of silk-screen prints called ''10 Portraits of Jews of the 20th Century'' depicting luminaries like Einstein, Kafka and Golda Meir. Critics were appalled and denounced the series as crassly exploitative; audiences responded far more favorably.

An old message comes in a new rapper at the Duke on 42nd Street, where the Green Thumb Theater of Vancouver, British Columbia, is presenting ''Cranked.'' The message is: say no to drugs. The specific drug is crystal meth, the powerfully addictive form of methamphetamine known on the street as speed or crank, and the medium for the message is rap, accompanied by spoken word and hip-hop music in an intermissionless 60-minute show, including a question-and-answer session.

The Islanders said Tuesday that goaltender Rick DiPietro, who signed an N.H.L.-record 15-year contract just 28 months ago, would miss the rest of the regular season because of persistent swelling in his left knee, which has been surgically repaired twice since June. Dr. Elliott Hershman, the team orthopedist, said that the 27-year-old DiPietro, who has played in only five games this season, would rest for six to eight weeks before doctors decided if he needed additional surgery.

ILSON--Carol, Ph.D.,Psychoanalyst, educator and author, was a remarkable person who lit up the room whenever she entered. But her own source of joy and inspiration was her family. Dr. Ilson died suddenly in her sleep early in the morning at her home in New York City on Saturday, January 17, 2009. She was 75 years old. Dr. Ilson was still actively pursuing her practice in psychoanalysis at the time of her death. Her book on the legendary director and producer Harold Prince, ''Harold Prince, A Director's Journey'' went into four printings. Mr. Prince calls Carol his Boswell. Carol Ilson was also a successful director. Her direction of Israel Horovitz's play ''Line'' at the 13th Street Theater together with a rave review by Clive Barnes in the New York Times helped the play become the longest running play in the Off-Off Broadway theater circuit. Dr. Ilson also taught theater and dance as an adjunct professor in the theater department at Queens College for ten years. Dr. Ilson is survived by her husband, Bernie Ilson, Ph.D. a veteran public relations man and author who has represented many of the most famous personalities in show business at his PR firm, Bernie Ilson, Inc. She is also survived by her son David and his wife Elyse, her son Jimmy and his wife Rhonda, and four grandchildren -Emily, Sadie, Jesse and Sam. Dr. Ilson is a graduate of the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. She earned her B.A. at Queens College, her M.A. in Theater at Hunter College, and her Ph.D. at the Graduate Center, City University of New York. Early in her career, Carol Ilson under the name of Carol Colby pursued a career as a professional dancer appearing in night chubs and television including an appearance on the Sid Caesar Show. Her manager at the time was Bernie Ilson. Dr. Ilson has been a longtime Member of the Board of the Metropolitan Institute for Psychoanalysis. Funeral Services will be held on Wednesday, January 21 at 1:15pm at the Riverside Chapel on Amsterdam Ave. and 76th St.

Perhaps the harpoons weren't what made Moby-Dick so cranky. Perhaps it was all that bellowing. Certainly Carlo Adinolfi yells his head off in ''The Whale,'' the one-man version of the Melville novel that he is performing at the Barrow Street Theater. After a while it becomes easy to imagine that the big, white beast might have simply wanted some peace and quiet. And it becomes harder to imagine what is so all-fired special about Melville's story.

IRVING--Inge Jollos, actress, civil rights activist, travel agent, mother and grandmother, died peacefully on January 16. She was 85 years old and lived in New York City. She appeared on stage, television, film and radio, and ran a boutique travel advisory firm, catering to the performing arts. Inge was born in Berlin, Germany, to noted protozoologist/geneticist Victor Jollos, and concert pianist and arts patron, Ilse Rappaport. With the support of a grant from the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars, they settled in Madison, Wisconsin, where Inge attended the University of Wisconsin In 1958, she married Ben Irving, the Assistant Executive Secretary of Actors Equity and noted labor mediator. Inge is survived by her three children, Victor, Jonathan and Deborah, and her two grandchildren, Nathaniel and Hannah. A memorial service to celebrate her life is being planned for the Spring. Inge requested that contributions be sent to the Actors' Fund.

The films “Milk,” “Frost/Nixon,” “The Reader,” “Slumdog Millionaire” and “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button” were nominated for best picture by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, while the filmmakers Danny Boyle (“Slumdog Millionaire”), Ron Howard (“Frost/Nixon”), David Fincher (“The Curious Case of Benjamin Button”), Stephen Daldry (“The Reader”) and Gus Van Sant (“Milk”) are the contenders for best director.

While countless comedy fans spent the 1960s and 70s poring over the rebellious routines of the standup George Carlin, so too did J. Edgar Hoover, according to F.B.I. records released by the comedian’s family and reported by The Associated Press. Among the documents that Carlin obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request before his death in June was an F.B.I. memo that noted his 1969 appearance on “The Jackie Gleason Show,” when he lampooned Hoover and the F.B.I. “His treatment was in very poor taste and it was obvious that he was using the prestige of the bureau and Mr. Hoover to enhance his performance,” the memo said, according to The A.P. The F.B.I. previously told The A.P. that it had no file on Carlin; an FBI spokeswoman told The A.P. she was looking into the apparent contradiction.

A consortium of television networks and production companies will pay more than $4 million to settle two class-action lawsuits filed by several hundred reality-show employees who said they had been subjected to unlawful working conditions, The Hollywood Reporter said. The employees, including segment producers and story editors for shows like “The Bachelor” and “Trading Spouses” sued in 2005, saying that they were told by the networks and production companies to forge time cards and forgo meal breaks while working 18-hour days. The Writers Guild of America helped organize the employees who filed the suits as part of a larger effort to have story editors of reality series recognized as writers. A judge in Los Angeles gave preliminary approval to a $2.57 million settlement in a suit brought against Fox and the production company Rocket Science Laboratories, and a $1.54 million settlement in a suit against ABC, CBS and other production companies.

Video-game players who prefer their digital playgrounds to be gritty, dystopian and riddled with crime can fire their guns in the air in celebration: the creators of the best-selling Grand Theft Auto game series have signed a new contract with the video game publisher Take-Two, Variety reported. Under the terms of the deal, the brothers Sam and Dan Houser, who helped found the Rockstar Games studio, and Leslie Benzes, the studio’s president, would continue to have their games distributed by Take-Two through 2012 and receive a share of profits from their games. The three will also create an independent company that will own outright any new games it creates. Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest entry in the series, has sold more than 10 million copies since its release last year; Take-Two generates about half of its revenue from software created by Rockstar Games.

A year after Britney Spears lost custody of her children and conservatorship of her career was given to her father, a parents’ organization is suggesting that she may not be the best role model for impressionable children. The Parents Television Council, a Los Angeles-based advocacy group, is asking radio stations not to play Ms. Spears’s single “If U Seek Amy,” saying it would violate broadcast standards if played between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m, Billboard reported. The council said that the title of the song, from Ms. Spears’s album “Circus,” sounded like an obscene phrase when said quickly. “It’s one thing for a song with these lyrics to be included on a CD so that fans who wish to hear it can do so, but it’s an entirely different matter when this song is played over the publicly-owned airwaves,” said the council’s president, Tim Winter, according to Billboard.

An independent publisher said it had completed an agreement to publish a novel tentatively titled “The Apple,” based on a movie screenplay that was, in turn, adapted from Herman Rosenblat’s falsified Holocaust memoir, “Angel at the Fence.” In December, the Berkley Books division of Penguin Books canceled the publication of Mr. Rosenblat’s memoir, in which he wrote that he met his future wife, Roma, while he was a prisoner of a German concentration camp during the Holocaust. Several scholars pointed out that details of Mr. Rosenblat’s story, including his claim that Mrs. Rosenblat would throw him apples over the camp’s fence from outside, could not have been true. Film rights for the memoir were sold to Atlantic Overseas Pictures, which commissioned a script. York House Press, a publisher based in White Plains, said it struck a deal with Atlantic Overseas Pictures to release a novel adapted from that script. In a release, York House Press said, “We will publish what has become one of the most controversial love stories of all time as fiction based on true events. Besides the love story, many people want to hear the story behind the story: why Mr. Rosenblat constructed and told his tale as he did. This will be included in the book.” A publication date for the book was not announced.

It can be hard for children to grasp the meaning and scope of history, but a group of fifth graders at Public School 3 in Greenwich Village understood perfectly when a 92-year-old time capsule turned up at their school. That's because putting together a time capsule is an annual project for the class."Our teacher brought the time capsule to our classroom," said Zach Lamariana, 11, describing the day the copper box was discovered behind a brass plaque by a construction crew doing renovations. "Our teacher opened it and we found all these old documents and stuff and this medal."

Lawyers representing a group of elected officials, prospective politicians and ordinary voters on Thursday appealed a federal judge's decision to reject their lawsuit, which sought to overturn the term-limits extension enacted last November.In the appeal [pdf], the lawyers essentially formalize their disagreement with every aspect of the decision that was issued last week by Judge Charles P. Sifton of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Among them are the judge's assertion that the extension did not violate voters' rights to free speech and his contention that the two-term limit that had been previously established by referendum did not need another referendum to be changed or repealed.

The morning's Oscar nominations sent a powerful message about the Academy membership: The strict admissions policies enforced over the last five years have now pushed it past a tipping point. The roughly 5,800 members, once a Los Angeles-oriented and commercially minded bunch, are now more filmic and more foreign. The many nominees over the last few years for indie-style films and international fare are now Oscar voters. That surely helped push "The Reader," with British roots, past "The Dark Knight," which is pure Hollywood.

PARIS -- Marc Jacobs and the Louis Vuitton men's studio director Paul Helbers have some design competition this season. Kanye West, who was sitting front row at the Vuitton show, has designed a line of five LV sneakers. Only one design, above, was featured in the show -- a monochromatic midtop with no frills, save for a quilted flap in the back, all the easier to tuck pants into. "The inspiration came from a jacket with a huge collar in the movie 'Dune,' " West says. "Most sneakers focus on the tongue, so I wanted to do something different." West knows whereof he speaks: he says he has no idea how many shoes he owns, but he does know that he routinely needs to send shipments off to storage. The LV-meets-Kanye kicks will be available at Louis Vuitton stores in June.

As I mentioned in my previous post, the talk all week in Milan was about "recession fashion" - what is appropriate, what will sell and what will provoke shoppers to purchase rather than just peruse. It is an oversimplication, I admit, but most of the fashion that we saw this show season fell into either the category of "shiny" dressy clothes or the relatively sober "matte" outfits. It was tailored dandyism versus rumpled, comfort clothes, which felt infinitely more recession-correct.

Kinnaird has also introduced a new line of Space.NK-branded scents.

The people who make Tropicana orange juice have calculated how much carbon is emitted to create a carton of juice, Andrew Martin writes in the Times Business section. Surprisingly, he says, ''the biggest single source of emissions was simply growing oranges. Citrus groves use a lot of nitrogen fertilizer, which requires natural gas to make and can turn into a potent greenhouse gas when it is spread on fields.'' They haven't decided whether to include the information on the cartons and, Andy writes, some environmentalists say such marketing efforts may rely on fuzzy math.

Never mind the hellaciously cold weather - according to the fashion calendar, now is the time to start shopping for summery frocks and platform sandals. But before you invest your hard-earned income into a runway trend (jumpsuit, anyone?), read first what the top fashion critics had to say. We've brought together critics' sound bites and runway images from nearly every women's show of the past fashion season, giving you a sense of what trends actually belong in your closet (hint: the new ethnic look). We've taken excerpts from reviews from The New York Times, The International Herald Tribune, the women's-wear trade publication Women's Wear Daily and style.com. More than 200 collections are summarized below - dig in, hear the critics out, then tell us what you think by leaving a comment at the bottom.

New York City's unemployment rate jumped to 7.2 percent last month from 6.2 percent in November as some employers cut back on hiring for the holiday season and others continued laying off workers, the State Department of Labor reported on Thursday. The city's unemployment rate is now at its highest level since July 2004 and equal to the national rate of unemployment, according to the report. In December 2007, the city's unemployment rate was 5.2 percent; a year before that, it was at a historically low level of 4.3 percent.

Anonymous Banker is back, one last time, with an idea to end the banking crisis. If you ask me, this idea isn't any crazier than a lot of other ones being bandied about -- and in fact, makes a lot more sense than most: create a new government bank that would take over failing banks and then roll those banks back out again -- to the same set of shareholders! -- when they becomes healthy and profitable again. I leave it to you, dear readers, to mull the pros and cons.

One of the more interesting tidbits in Thursday morning's Oscars announcement came with the letters "TBD" - to be determined -- next to the nomination for "The Reader." The Academy, with very rare exceptions, will credit no more than three producers, and has elaborate rules that have to do with who did what and how much time was spent on the set. But the film is credited to four producers: Sydney Pollack, Anthony Minghella, Donna Gigliotti and Redmond Morris. (There was a single sheet in the packet of info handed out to reporters at the event that said the following: Please Note: If no name is listed in the credits column, it is because the credits for that achievement are in dispute.)

I always wondered what Chinese New Year was like for visitors. Because many people, like myself, travel to our ancestral villages to visit grandparents and parents. Meals are prepared and eaten at home, not at malls and restaurants. Meanwhile, the expat population tends to fly to places like Bali or Thailand during the long weekend (this year, it's Sat Jan 24 to Wed Jan 28). So, in an odd reversal, the train to the rural New Territories is crowded, and the bar area of Lan Kwai Fong is a bit quiet.

PETA has withdrawn an offer to make an anti-dogfighting public service announcement with the suspended Atlanta Falcons quarterback Michael Vick after his release from prison. The organization said an agreement was reached with Vick’s representatives to shoot the spot, but that Vick’s lawyers sought assurance from PETA that the group would support his return to the N.F.L. “Saying sorry and getting his ball back after being caught enjoying killing dogs in hideously cruel ways for many years doesn’t cut it,” said Ingrid E. Newkirk, the president of PETA.

Mary D. Nichols, California’s chief air pollution regulator, formally requested that Lisa P. Jackson, President Obama’s choice to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, allow California and 13 other states to start regulating emissions of heat-trapping gases from passenger vehicles by granting the necessary federal waiver. If the Obama administration grants the waiver, these states — and eventually three more that have indicated they would adopt the same policy — can begin enforcing emission standards that would eventually require automakers to put more fuel-efficient cars on the market. Together, the 17 states represent about half of the American auto market. Last year, the Bush administration, breaking with precedent, denied California the right to establish its own standards in the absence of any federal mandates. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, in his own separate letter to President Obama, urged him to direct the E.P.A. “to act promptly and favorably” on the request.

The source of a salmonella outbreak that sickened almost 500 people around the country and is linked to six deaths is a peanut processing plant in Blakely, Ga., health officials confirmed. The plant is owned by the Peanut Corporation of America. More than 125 products have been recalled, including cookies, cakes, candy, prepared dinners and even dog treats. A list of recalled products is on the Food and Drug Administration’s Web site, fda.gov. Health officials warned consumers to check the site before eating anything that might contain peanut products. No peanut butter jars sold in supermarkets come from the plant, officials said.

Relatives of an 8-year-old boy who spent more than a week in an apartment with the body of his mother have come to Michigan to get him. The boy’s mother, Gaynell Tipado, 41, was found Monday in her apartment in the Detroit suburb of Romulus, where she had moved after being displaced by Hurricane Katrina. Ms. Tipado apparently died Jan. 9. Lt. John Leacher of the Romulus police said that the relatives, from Louisiana, had asked for privacy and that no additional information would be released. Lieutenant Leacher said that an autopsy was scheduled for Thursday but that foul play was not suspected in Ms. Tipado’s death. Her son spent 10 days in the apartment eating dried rice, butter and flour and buying groceries from a liquor store. The store owner contacted the authorities on Monday.

Two women whose sexual harassment complaints led to the resignation of an Ohio attorney general have reached a settlement with the state, officials said. The women, Cindy Stankoski and Vanessa Stout, will each receive $247,500 for reparations and lawyers fees. They filed sexual harassment claims against Anthony Gutierrez, a top aide to former Attorney General Marc Dann, above, early last year. Mr. Gutierrez was fired, and the scandal led to Mr. Dann’s resignation in May. Mr. Dann, a Democrat elected in 2006 on an anticorruption platform, admitted he had had an extramarital affair with an employee. A report by state investigators alleged that he ran a vulgar and unprofessional office and misused campaign money to make lavish payments to friends and family members. Attorney General Richard Cordray, a Democrat who took office earlier this month, praised the women’s courage. Mr. Dann said in an e-mailed statement, “While I am sympathetic to the challenges that these women faced, in my view the facts do not support a payout of this magnitude.”.

Alabama’s first black federal judge is leaving the bench next month after nearly three decades. The judge, U. W. Clemon of Federal District Court, spelled out his plans in a letter to President Obama. In the letter Judge Clemon said he was “ecstatic” over Mr. Obama’s victory, which he called the fulfillment of a lifelong dream to see an African-American president. Judge Clemon a former civil rights lawyer and state senator, wrote that it became clear to him last spring “that Almighty God had ordained” Mr. Obama “as the next president of this great nation.” The judge, 65, said he would join a Birmingham law firm on Feb. 1. He announced plans to retire in the fall, but decided to time his departure to coincide with Mr. Obama’s inauguration, guaranteeing that a Democratic president would appoint his successor. Mr. Clemon was appointed by President Jimmy Carter in 1980.

A former spokesman for Florida’s child welfare agency has pleaded guilty to producing child pornography, less than a week before he was expected to stand trial. A sentencing date for the man, Albert A. Zimmerman, has not been set, but the charge carries a mandatory minimum sentence of 15 years and a maximum of 30 years in federal prison. Mr. Zimmerman was arrested in February and accused of taking photographs of at least two teenage boys for distribution overseas. He was fired by the Department of Children and Families. One of the boys has been identified as a foster child of Mr. Zimmerman’s agency. New charges, including receiving and possessing child pornography, had recently been handed up.

The trust representing Colin Higgins, the director and a screenwriter of the film comedy “9 to 5,” has filed suit against Mr. Higgins’s former lawyer, saying the lawyer failed to represent Mr. Higgins’s interests in the coming “9 to 5” Broadway musical, Variety reported. The lawyer, Barry L. Hirsch, had represented Mr. Higgins until his death in 1988. But the trust ended its dealings with Mr. Hirsch after learning that he was also representing Patricia Resnick, the other screenwriter of the movie, and the author of the book for “9 to 5: The Musical.” The lawsuit says that Mr. Hirsch failed to secure Mr. Higgins’s stage rights for the musical project, and seeks damages for legal malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty. The musical is scheduled to begin previews at the Marquis Theater on April 7. Mr. Hirsch did not respond to requests for comment.
An appeals court has halted a planned hearing on the legal travails of the director Roman Polanski.

Gerard Mortier, formerly the designated general manager and artistic director of New York City Opera, who departed that post in November before his first season, said in an interview with the French newspaper Le Monde that he had “no regrets” about the circumstances that preceded his departure. Mr. Mortier’s short stay with City Opera was clouded by the revelation that he was also seeking the directorship of the Bayreuth Festival in Germany. He later quit the New York job, saying he had been promised an operating budget of $60 million, but was given only $36 million by the board. Previous City Opera budgets have been around $42 million. “I accepted the sacrifices, but there are limits,” Mr. Mortier told Le Monde. “This opera must innovate to exist alongside the Metropolitan Opera. Today, I fear it disappears.” Mr. Mortier also said in the interview that he had been offered a position at Staatsoper Unter den Linden in Berlin, but that working alongside its current musical director, Daniel Barenboim, would be like “two tigers on the same mountain.”.

Taylor Swift’s album “Fearless” (Big Machine) enjoyed its seventh week atop the album sales chart, Billboard reported, the first time that a record has done so since 2004, when Usher’s “Confessions” spent nine weeks at No. 1. “Fearless” sold 63,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, a decline of 11 percent from the previous week. Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Music World/Columbia) moved back into second place, with 49,000 units sold, while the Nickelback album “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) fell to third, with 46,000 units. The week’s top debut was the soundtrack to “Notorious” (Bad Boy), a movie about the rapper Notorious B.I.G. The record, featuring tracks by Notorious B.I.G. as well as by Jay-Z, Faith Evans, Jadakiss and Santogold, took fourth place, with 43,000 sales.

The American Symphony Orchestra has announced its programming for the 2009-10 season, consisting of six concerts to be performed at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. The symphony, led for the 17th season by its musical director, Leon Botstein, will open on Oct. 14 with a performance of “Fervaal,” an 1893 work by the French Romantic composer Vincent d’Indy. On Nov. 15 the program will be titled “The Remains of Romanticism,” which will include works by Fuchs, Strauss and others. Further concerts in 2010 will feature the music of the American composer Henry Cowell, Robert Schumann’s “Scenes From Goethe’s ‘Faust’ ” and a series on the theme of Apollo and Dionysus. More information can be found at americansymphony.org.

The rock quartet Coldplay, featuring, above from left, Jonny Buckland and Chris Martin, and the Welsh singer-songwriter Duffy were among the top nominees for the Brit Awards, the British music industry’s equivalent of the Grammys. Coldplay was nominated for best album, for “Viva La Vida or Death and All His Friends,” as well as best group and live act; Duffy was also nominated for best album for “Rockferry,” as well as best female solo artist and breakthrough act. Winners of the Brit Awards will be announced on Feb. 18. ... A new play by Suzan-Lori Parks, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “Topdog/Underdog,” will make its debut at the Public Theater as part of the 2009 Public LAB series, a joint production of the Public and LABryinth Theater Company. No details for the play were announced, except that it would run June 5 through 28. The series will also feature works by Darrell Dennis, Raúl Castillo, and Alex Timbers and Michael Friedman.

In theater there’s no such thing as old age. When the national tour of Tracy Letts’s play “August: Osage County” begins in Denver on July 24, its cast will include Estelle Parsons, above, 81, the Academy Award winner and Tony Award nominee who joined the Broadway production in June as the venomous Weston family matriarch, Violet. Full casting and dates for the tour were not announced. Over at the Public Theater, its production of Craig Lucas’s “Singing Forest” will feature Olympia Dukakis, 77, as a Holocaust survivor and psychoanalyst. The play, directed by Mark Wing-Davey, is scheduled to run from April 7 through May 17. The Public also announced that its coming production of Christopher Durang’s “Why Torture Is Wrong ...,” which runs from March 24 through April 26, would feature the actors Amir Arison, David Aaron Baker, Kristine Nielsen and John Pankow, and be directed by Nicholas Martin.

McALOON--Rose Fichera, Ph.D.,on January 19, 2009. Beloved wife of Paul, Loving mother of Sean and Alex, Cherished sister of Sebastian, Tina and Joanne, Devoted daughter of Iolanda, Aunt of Vanessa, Christopher, Julia and David. Dr. McAloon was born in Sicily and arrived in America as a child. Her heritage was expressed personally in her devotion to her family and her great cooking skill. Professionally, it was expressed in her interest in the Sicilian playwright Pirandello, who became a subject of her academic and psychoanalytical studies. She flowered as a psychoanalyst during decades of association with The Center for Modern Psychoanalytical Studies, where she studied and taught. In her private practice, in her own publications and as a supervisor, she maintained a particular interest in helping persons who wished to express themselves through writing. Rose will continue to be loved as much as she is missed. Reposing at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York City, Thursday 25pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Service Friday, 10am. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

STRAUS--Barnard Sachs, 89, died on Tuesday morning in Manhattan. Mr. Straus lived the entirety of his life in New York, and he took great pride in his city and his family. Mr. Straus worked both as a stockbroker and as a theatrical producer. His marriage to the late Joan Straus Cullman ended in divorce. He leaves behind his devoted companion of many years, Marjorie Hyman, as well as his son, Barnard Straus, Jr., of Evanston, IL and his daughter, Tracy Joan Straus, of Manhattan. He was the proud grandfather of Graham Paley Straus. Funeral services private. Warner in Good Company Cardinals quarterback Kurt Warner is making his third Super Bowl appearance, having won and lost as a member of the Rams. He needs 364 passing yards to become the career leader in the Super Bowl. He surpassed 364 in both of his previous appearances (414 in 2000 and 365 in 2002). The record holder is Joe Montana (1,142 yards). It will be harder for Warner to catch Montana in touchdown passes. Montana is the leader with 11; Warner has 3. BENJAMIN HOFFMAN

LaCAILLE--Joan. Managing Director of Warburg Realty, died suddenly at her home in New York City on January 9, of an undiagnosed disease. Born Joan Kelleher in Worchester, Massachusetts March 5, 1928, Joan was the daughter of Mrs. and Mrs. William Kelleher. She was an alumnus of the Baldwin School and Sarah Lawrence. She lived the kind of life of which most people only dream. Shortly after marrying Charles Wilson LaCaille of Montreal, Canada, the couple set sail for Africa. As Joan delighted in telling the story, they sailed on a trans-steamer, the trip took six weeks, and the only other guests aboard were nuns who had taken a vow of silence. Her husband died in Africa, but Joan stayed on for six more years, during which time she nurtured her love of animals, especially giraffes, on whose behalf she worked until the end of her life. When she returned to New York, Joan began a storied career first in public relations and then in real estate, becoming one of the foremost women in that field. There was no one more enthusiastic, more full of adventure, more energetic, and more generous than Joan. She loved to travel, visiting Dubai, Kenya, Russia, Sri Lanka, China, Iran, and Libya in recent years. This past November she made her last trip to Kenya, to her beloved Giraffe Manor, where she got to release her giraffe, named ''Joan'', into the wild. While always sensitive to the diverse cultures and peoples she encountered, she never fully could stop ''being Joan.'' Visiting Iran when she was 76 years old, she had no hesitation wearing a full hajib. However, when she left Tehran to spend several days in the countryside, she carried her flask of scotch underneath it, to assure her daily afternoon cocktail. A founding and tireless member of the board of directors of Puppies Behind Bars, Joan not only delighted in visiting the program in prison, but decided to spend her 80th birthday there, surrounded by her friends. Clearances secured and metal detectors passed through, Joan and her friends entered the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for an afternoon with inmates and dogs and then she delighted, in the following months, telling everyone she met, ''I spent my 80th birthday in prison!'' A memorial service to celebrate Joan's life will be held in New York in February and a Joan LaCaille Memorial Fund has been started at Puppies Behind Bars. To contribute to the fund or for information on the service, contact Puppies Behind Bars (puppiesbehindbars.com) or 212-680-9562.

LIEBEN--Beatrice, Ph.D. The family of Beatrice Lieben announces with great sadness her death at age ninety-five on January 20, 2009. Dr. Lieben, of Fort Lee, New Jersey, was a clinical child psychologist who founded and was for many years director of the Community School in Teaneck, NJ. In 1995 she was the recipient of the State of New Jersey Governors Award in Education, the Albert Einstein Education Award, for her achievements and contributions. Dr. Lieben was predeceased by her husband Samuel and her son Michael. She is survived by her sister Zipporah Epstein, her daughter Ellen Green, five grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Even through the daunting physical difficulties of the last period of her life, her warmth, generosity and humor never left her. We love her very much and will miss her deeply. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack NJ (201489-3800) at 11:30am on Friday, January 23. Contributions can be made to the Community School, Inc., 11 West Forest Avenue, Teaneck NJ 07666.

IRVING--Inge Jollos, actress, civil rights activist, travel agent, mother and grandmother, died peacefully on January 17. She was 85 years old and lived in New York City. She appeared on stage, television, film and radio, and ran a boutique travel advisory firm, catering to the performing arts. Inge was born in Berlin, Germany, to noted protozoologist/geneticist Victor Jollos, and concert pianist and arts patron, Ilse Rappaport. With the support of a grant from the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars, they settled in Madison, Wisconsin, where Inge attended the University of Wisconsin In 1958, she married Ben Irving, the Assistant Executive Secretary of Actors Equity and noted labor mediator. Inge is survived by her three children, Victor, Jonathan and Deborah, and her two grandchildren, Nathaniel and Hannah. A memorial service to celebrate her life is being planned for the Spring. Inge requested that contributions be sent to the Actors' Fund.

He was 84. He is survived by his loving family, son Alan Benjamin, daughter Julia Benjamin, stepson Jay Gupta, stepson Mark Gupta, and two grandsons Alex Benjamin and Jesse Benjamin. A memorial gathering will be held at All Souls Church, 80th and Lexington, February 20, at 4:30pm. Contact: brymemorial@gmail.com.

EPSTEIN--Eleanor (Krieger), passed away January 20, 2009 after a fall. Eleanor was born in New York City in 1911; the family moved to Boro Park where Eleanor remained until 2001 when she relocated to Massachusetts. Eleanor taught for many years at Shulamith School for Girls before she went to work for the NYC Board of Education. Teaching English to immigrants and basic skills to disadvantaged adults brought her great joy. When she wasn't teaching, she volunteered for Jewish organizations. Eleanor was a bright light with tremendous energy, compassion, generosity, and a sense of humor. She is survived by her children Gloria and Burton ''Bud'' Rose of Wellesley, MA, Grace and Herbert Friedman of Upland, CA, and Gedalia Arditti of CA; seven grandchildren, seven greatgrandchildren, and many nieces and nephews who loved Aunt Elly. She was predeceased by her husband Isidore ''Itz'' Epstein and daughter Arline ''Honey'' Arditti. Graveside service and burial will be held Friday, January 23, at 11:00am at Montefiore Cemetery, Queens, NY.

PLAYER COLLAPSES John Vaughan, George Mason's star guard, collapsed and was taken to a local hospital Wednesday night during the Patriots' 58-57 loss at Northeastern. Vaughn barely moved for more than 15 minutes and was carried off on a stretcher.

FOR decades snowboards and skis have shared similar technology: look at either from the side and they bow up between tip and tail. This design, called camber, helps riders flow from one turn to another. Then, in 2006, Lib Tech released a board that sounded unsafe to step on -- the Skate Banana -- and featured reverse camber, a k a ''rocker,'' because its ''U'' shape let it rock from tail to nose. This technology, which is common in surfboards, helped Lib Tech win design awards, and after strong sales last winter other manufacturers rushed to bring their own reverse camber models out this season.

LaCAILLE--Joan. The board of directors and staff of Puppies Behind Bars are extremely saddened at the death of our beloved colleague, Joan LaCaille, on January 9, 2009. A tireless presence, Joan never passed up an opportunity to talk to anyone about Puppies Behind Bars. She loved the dogs we worked with, she loved that we work to rehabilitate prison inmates, she loved that we donate our dogs to people whose lives they can improve. Joan was one of the kindest people we knew always asking after anyone who was ill or going through an emotionally difficult time. She was energetic, vivacious, generous, and one of a kind. There is no way to fill the void that has been created by her death, but she will be remembered always through the Joan LaCaille Memorial Fund that has been established in her name. The current, and former, board of directors and staff Puppies Behind Bars

Title Towns The discrepancy between the Steelers and the Cardinals in football history reflects their home cities' sports traditions. By the time the Arizona Diamondbacks won Phoenix's first (and so far only) professional title in 2001, Pittsburgh had already won 11. The Steelers added the city's 12th title in 2006. Pittsburgh is 110 years older than Phoenix, and its youngest professional franchise (the Penguins) is one year older than Phoenix's oldest (the Suns). NAILA-JEAN MEYERS

8 P.M. (Fox) BONES The series moves into a new time slot with back-to-back episodes. In the first, Brennan (Emily Deschanel) and Booth (David Boreanaz) join a circus as a knife-throwing act to uncover the killer of conjoined twins. The American Academy of Arts and Letters has chosen the poet J.D. McClatchy as its president, the organization said. Mr. McClatchy, a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in 2002 for his poetry collection “Hazmat,” and the author of essay collections like “American Writers at Home,” has served as editor of The Yale Review since 1991. He will serve a three-year term as president, succeeding the composerEzra Laderman.

Martin McDonagh, whose combustible mix of black comedy and bloody violence in shows like “The Pillowman” and “Lieutenant of Inishmore” has made him one of the best-known playwrights around, has in recent years turned to the movies. It’s paid off. A short film called “Six Shooter” won best live-action short a few years back. And on Thursday, he received a nomination for best original screenplay for “In Bruges,” a bloody (not surprisingly) comedy-thriller starring Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell, which he also directed.

Now into its fourth year, the trial of a former curator from the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles and an American antiquities dealer resumed on Friday in a Rome courtroom. This time the focus shifted to the dealer, Robert Hecht, who has been charged with Marion True, the ex-Getty curator, of conspiracy to traffic in antiquities looted from Italian soil. Both defendants deny the charges. A prosecution witness, the archaeologist Daniela Rizzo, presented documents and photographs of artifacts — an Apulian red-figured bowl decorated with a chariot, an ancient Greek candelabra — that prosecutors contend passed through Mr. Hecht’s hands. “We’d just love to know where some of them ended up,” Ms. Rizzo said pointedly while gazing at Mr. Hecht, 89, who was in court but did not take the stand. Alessandro Vannucci, his lawyer, said his client disputed the case made by prosecutors for the provenance of each object. Several objects sold by Mr. Hecht to institutions like the Getty and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York have been returned to Italy under pacts with the Italian government.

A faction within the national board of the Screen Actors Guild has issued a statement in support of the union’s embattled national executive director and chief negotiator, Doug Allen, and a compromise plan Mr. Allen recently proposed, Variety reported. The statement, signed by 34 board members and alternates, called for the guild’s 120,000 members to support a plan by Mr. Allen that would suspend a strike authorization vote and allow the membership to vote on a final contract offer from the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers. In its statement, the faction wrote that Mr. Allen was “the strongest and most dedicated national executive director-chief negotiator the Screen Actors Guild has seen in decades,” according to Variety. Other guild members have sought to fire Mr. Allen, saying he has mishandled negotiations with the producers’ group.

It’s a less Mad world. Starting with issue no. 500, to be released in April, the monthly satirical publication will become a quarterly, though it will expand to 56 pages from 48. The changes were announced by DC Comics, which publishes Mad Magazine and is owned by Warner Brother Entertainment. As befits the what-me-worry? attitude of the magazine, its editor, John Ficarra, had a sardonic spin on the news. “The feedback we’ve gotten from readers is that only every third issue of Mad is funny,” he said in a statement. “So we decided to just publish those.” On the bright side, anyone with a subscription to Mad will find that it now lasts longer. The fate of Mad Kids and Mad Classics is less kind. The final issues of those publications will be Feb. 17 and March 17, respectively.

Marking a renewed age of openness between Britain and the United States, our trans-Atlantic cousins have agreed to return us Sienna Miller for a few months so she can make her Broadway debut. Ms. Miller, 27, the model and “Factory Girl” actress (who was born in New York, but raised and lives in Britain) will star in the Roundabout Theater Company’s production of Patrick Marber’s play “After Miss Julie” for its 2009-10 season, the company announced. The play, to be directed by Mark Brokaw, transposes August Strindberg’s 1888 class drama “Miss Julie” to a British countryhouse in 1945; Ms. Miller is to play the title character, a young aristocrat served by a male valet and a female cook. A theater, dates and additional casting for the production were not announced.

CBS News announced on Friday that “60 Minutes’’ had secured the first interview with Captain Chesley B. Sullenberger III, the pilot who successfully landed his U.S. Airways jet on the Hudson River, along with his crew. But word of the interview, to be conducted by Katie Couric, set off immediate recriminations at her former employer, the “Today’’ program on NBC. That’s because Matt Lauer of “Today’’ had received assurances from the captain’s family and other representatives last weekend that he would have the first interview with Mr. Sullenberger, which was to have been conducted live, on Jan. 19. Soon after NBC began publicizing that appearance, it was abruptly canceled, at the request of the Airline Pilots Association, which had expressed concern about its bearing on the ongoing investigation into the emergency landing. Asked in an interview on Friday why the captain had since decided to pass over “Today’’ for “60 Minutes,’’ a Sullenberger family spokesman, Alex Clemens, said, “The five members of the crew spoke with each other and made a joint decision of how they would like to proceed.’’ In a statement, NBC said, “What Captain Sullenberger did in the cockpit on Flight 1549 was heroic and admirable. Unfortunately, people close to him have not acted nearly as admirably.’’

After a superb show tonight set around reflective panels, Raf Simons remarked that he and his staff see perhaps 250 young men for casting in Antwerp, and of course most of them come in wearing casual sportswear. But, he added, "If there would be one dressed up in a suit that would be avant-garde." Tailoring remains Simons' great fascination; it was his starting point in the mid-90s. The opening looks in this show-with a new cast of models-brought to mind the early days of his label, the simplicity and boyishness. Now, though, everything is rarified. Doesn't it pay to revisit and revisit? The suits and the coats are slim but the fit seems more accessible and mature, and Simons is now making all the clothes in Italy. It shows in the quality of the materials and construction.

Many people have faulted the federal government's coupon program to help consumers pay for a digital to analog converter box for creating a scheme that only government bureaucrats could love. Meanwhile, the program has run out of money.

As I write in my column this week, I received a number of smart, interesting ideas for reviving the banking system. In the column, I elaborated on one: recreating some kind of Resolution Trust Corporation, which was created by the first President Bush to manage and sell the bad assets on the books of the banks during the S&L crisis. I do not pretend that it is a perfect solution -- Tim Ryan, the former head of the Office of Thrift Supervision, who helped manage the country through that crisis, pointed out to me that the banking system is a lot more complicated than it was then. He also made the point that the O.T.C. had a mandate, by law, to take over insolvent S&Ls, while these days we quake at the thought of having the government take over a bank. "Nationalization" is a dirty word. If we could get past that, maybe we could get this problem fixed.
