PARIS -- If there is any silver lining to the current recession (I know, it's hard to find even a copper lining), it could be that designers are turning toward more realistic and lasting definitions of luxury. At Louis Vuitton, Paul Helbers said he was going for clothing that, though luxurious, could be worn every day without calling attention to itself. Yves Saint Laurent's Stefano Pilati was inspired by hip-hop gear's shapes and volumes, but avoided unnecessary flash by using mostly black and keeping his silhouettes as graphic and unencumbered as possible. Stuart Vevers, now in his second season at Loewe, was pleased to focus on making leather goods "with intrinsic value in their materials and design." Dries van Noten hit the nail on the head with his understated, nearly monochromatic collection of basics. And Raf Simons showed a season-defining cavalcade of immaculate suits and coats, which went from business formal to experimental, thanks to mirror insets and neoprene sleeves. For now at least, gone are the days when practically anyone could dye an ostrich pelt purple and call it a luxe statement -- and that is certainly not a bad thing.

Interestingly, Mr. Paterson said he did not pick Mr. Cuomo, whom he called "as qualified as anyone who I looked at," because it would have meant that all three of New York's statewide elected officials would not have been elected to their jobs.

PARIS - Stefano Pilati kicked off men's fashion week in Paris with a video presentation at Yves Saint Laurent's Rue d'Artois headquarters. The black and white film, by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, starred the actor Michael Pitt, who was shot in an unwavering tight frame, his facial expressions occasionally responding to the titillating pronouncements of an off-camera female voice speaking in French. ("I want to lick this animal skin I lift up the T-shirt that peeks out from your sleeves I want to hear the sound of six zippers. ") The video was a mood-setter for a small runway show, in which Pilati continued with his exploration of unexpected volumes. At the cocktail party that followed, he explained the he wanted to refer to the entire history of hip-hop, but interpreted in a graphic, luxurious and pared-down way - think MC Hammer meets the Bauhaus. This meant superbaggy pants cropped at the calf, patent leather boots, big jackets and occasional shots of color to break the predominance of black. (A woolly coat in vibrant blue, pictured below, stood out.) "I love the ideology of hip-hop because it has real passion," Pilati said. "Plus, the clothes are about playing with different proportions, which is something I've always done."

And on Thursday, he received a nomination for best original screenplay for "In Bruges," a bloody (not surprisingly) comedy-thriller starring Brendan Gleeson and Colin Farrell, which he also directed.

When Kirsten Gillibrand makes her way from the House, across the Capitol Rotunda, to join the ranks of Senate Democrats, she will find slim pickings in terms of committee assignments. A sense of utility pervades the Paris fall men's collections. At Louis Vuitton, models toted LV cases on standard-looking luggage carriers, their suits liquid and soft for movement and in shapes of ink, petrol and brown. This morning, Junya Watanabe's patchwork jackets and jeans evoked hunting gear. I'm always a sucker for the clothing at Farmer's Supply, wondering what I could do with a snap-front brown cotton jacket or an orange utility vest. Now I know. Watanabe has deconstructed the outdoor elements in a charming way: with reversible pinstriped suit jackets patched in red checks and corduroy, jeans and cropped khakis with patches, and coats with the illusion of a second vested layer. Dries Van Noten's collection, held last night at the Communist party headquarters, was a bit too frugal even for these times: too many one-color outfits and belted coats with an automaton cast. Yojhi's men looked sweetly frumpy - and drowsy - in pajamas and hooded bathrobe coats.

Even if you don't do all your online shopping in the virtual megamall that is Amazon.com, the site offers a way to let you remember the things you want to buy from other places. With a simple one-time drag-and-drop move, Amazon's Universal Wish List button can be added to the browser's toolbar. The next time you are out shopping on other sites - but aren't quite ready to buy - click the Wish List button on the browser to save a link to the item to your personal Amazon Wish List. Clicking on the item later on the Wish List takes you back to the original store when you're ready to get out the credit card.Have a question you'd like answered from J.D. Biersdorfer, The Times's tech guru? E-mail QandA@nytimes.com.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about the painter and teacher Ray Yoshida referred incorrectly to the location of the University of Hawaii at Manoa, which Mr. Yoshida attended. It is in Honolulu, in the city’s Manoa neighborhood; it is not “outside Honolulu.”.

A picture caption on Monday with an article about a carbon-fiber cello that Yo-Yo Ma considered playing at Barack Obama’s inauguration misidentified a member of the Joint Service Orchestra shown playing such a cello in a rehearsal for a preinaugural concert. He is Master Gunnery Sgt. Marcio Botelho of the United States Marine Band, not Senior Master Sgt. Bill Hones of the United States Air Force Band. (Sergeant Hones, who was also at the rehearsal, plays the double bass.).

An appraisal on Saturday about John Mortimer, the writer who created the curmudgeonly London barrister Horace Rumpole, referred incorrectly to Mr. Mortimer’s view of atheists. An atheist himself, he hated public displays of atheism, not atheists.

A brief article in some editions on Thursday about the collapse of a George Mason basketball player who sustained a concussion during a game misstated the team’s nickname in some copies. It is the Patriots, not the Colonials.

Paterson’s handling of the selection process for a senator to replace Hillary Rodham Clinton misidentified, in some copies, one critic who likened the ordeal to a “game show.” He is Martin J. Golden, a Republican state senator from Brooklyn — not Martin Connor, a former Democratic state senator.

The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about President Obama’s inauguration, misspelled the surname of a former 1960s radical whose association with Mr. Obama was raised as an issue in the campaign, but was not prominently mentioned on Fox News coverage of the inauguration. He is William Ayers, not Ayres.

A picture caption on Jan. 2 with an article about the Iraqi government’s taking formal control of Baghdad’s heavily fortified Green Zone misidentified, in some editions, the scene shown at the handover ceremony and it also carried an incorrect credit. The photograph, taken by Thaier al-Sudani for Reuters, showed a United States soldier standing guard as an Iraqi military band marched past during the ceremony. It did not show an Iraqi commando guarding dignitaries at that ceremony. (A picture of the commando, taken by Johan Spanner for The New York Times, ran in other editions.).
President Obama won the fight to keep his BlackBerry, but being the nation’s first e-mailing president comes with a specific set of rules.

An article on Thursday about new ethics rules imposed by President Obama on members of his administration paraphrased incorrectly from a statement by the Republican National Committee about a provision barring former lobbyists from working for agencies they had lobbied within the past few years. The committee criticized the Obama administration for violating the new standard in some of its appointments; it did not criticize the new rule.

The improvisational "T Takes: Brooklyn '09" series hits the halfway mark today with the third episode, featuring the melancholy singer/songwriter Angela McCluskey as our protagonist's mother. After making her musical presence known in the early '90s with the Los Angeles alt-rockers the Wild Colonials, McCluskey has found her niche with a mix of solo efforts and side projects; her collaboration with Telepopmusik earned a Grammy nomination for the single "Breathe." Her second solo album, "You Could Start a Fight in an Empty House," will be released this spring. When you're done screening, be sure post your opinions in the comments section.

I recently moved back from Paris and gave away my espresso machine. I figured my return to the United States would be a good time to switch back to drip coffee: strong, black and as American as Stanley thermoses and David Lynch. In college, "Twin Peaks" cemented my love for coffee. I watched the entire series, highly caffeinated, in one week during a cold Maine winter, and wanted more than anything to be Kyle MacLachlan, solving mysteries and eating pie. This highlight reel helps explain the allure.

While countless comedy fans spent the 1960s and ’70s poring over the rebellious routines of George Carlin, above, so too did J. Edgar Hoover, according to F.B.I. records released by the comedian’s family and reported by The Associated Press. Among the documents Carlin obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request before his death in June was an F.B.I. memo that noted his 1969 appearance on “The Jackie Gleason Show,” when he lampooned Hoover and the F.B.I. “His treatment was in very poor taste and it was obvious that he was using the prestige of the bureau and Mr. Hoover to enhance his performance,” the memo said, according to The A.P. The F.B.I. previously told The A.P. that it had no file on Carlin; an F.B.I. spokeswoman told The A.P. that she was looking into the apparent contradiction.
The return of ABC’s “Lost” was no match in the ratings for Fox’s “American Idol” on Wednesday.

A year after Britney Spears, below, lost custody of her children and control of her career was given to her father, a parents’ organization is suggesting that she may not be the best role model for impressionable children. The Parents Television Council, a Los Angeles advocacy group, is asking radio stations not to play Ms. Spears’s single “If U Seek Amy,” saying it would violate broadcast standards if played between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m, Billboard reported. The council said that the title of the song, from Ms. Spears’s album “Circus,” sounded like an obscene phrase when said quickly. “It’s one thing for a song with these lyrics to be included on a CD so that fans who wish to hear it can do so, but it’s an entirely different matter when this song is played over the publicly owned airwaves,” said the council’s president, Tim Winter, according to Billboard.

James Stewart, a scholar in 18th- and 19th-century European art who has been director of the Museum of Art at the University of Michigan, was named director of the Princeton University Art Museum. He succeeds Susan Taylor, who left in June.

Video-game players who prefer their digital playgrounds to be gritty, dystopian and riddled with crime can fire their guns in the air in celebration: The creators of the best-selling Grand Theft Auto series have signed a new contract with the video game publisher Take-Two, Variety reported. Under the terms of the deal, the brothers Sam and Dan Houser, who helped found the Rockstar Games studio, and Leslie Benzes, the studio’s president, would continue to have their games distributed by Take-Two through 2012 and receive a share of profits from the titles. The three will also create an independent company that will own outright any new games it creates. Grand Theft Auto IV, the latest entry in the series, has sold more than 10 million copies since its release last year.

The trial of Josef Fritzl, the Austrian accused of imprisoning and raping his daughter in a homemade dungeon for 24 years, will begin March 16, according to court officials in St. Pölten. The authorities say that Mr. Fritzl is mentally fit to stand trial for locking his daughter Elisabeth in a soundproof basement in the town of Amstetten and fathering seven children with her. He is also charged with murder for not providing medical care to the seventh child, who died. The trial will be closed to the public, a court spokesman said.

If you are hoping for a long career as a United States international soccer player, it helps to be left-footed and defensive-minded. While glory goes to the goal scorer, job security belongs to the defender. Of the 10 American players with 100 or more international appearances, three were defenders and two were goalkeepers. Two of the defenders played left fullback. ''It's a supply and demand issue,'' said Jeff Agoos, a former left fullback for the national team and the second-most capped player in team history. ''There's just not a lot of supply of left-sided players, not just in the U.S. but I think around the world.'' Most national teams play with some variation of the 4-4-2 formation, meaning there are more defensive positions to be filled than attacking spots, and two or three spots require a player to send long balls across the field with the left foot. MYERS--Wayne Alan, an eminent psychiatrist, psychoanalyst, and beloved husband and father died from lung cancer on Friday January 16, 2009. At the time of his death he was tended to by his devoted wife of forty years, Joanne, his daughter Tracy, his son Blake and his daughter-in-law Susan Grobman. Dr. Myers is also survived by his son-in-law Harris Fishman, and three grandchildren: Wyatt, Charlotte and Sophie. Emeritus Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at Weill Cornell Medical College and a Training and Supervising Analyst at The Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, Wayne Myers was a prolific contributor to his field. He published five books, including Shrink Dreams, a New York Times notable book in 1992; forty-eight book chapters and articles and nearly fifty reviews, commentaries and letters. His expertise included clinical process and technique, geriatrics and pioneer contributions to the intensive treatment of the aged, and studies in applied analysis and literature. He was an original and lucid thinker whose writings illuminated the clinical work of the residents and psychoanalytic candidates whom he taught and supervised. A superbly empathic and knowledgeable practitioner with a huge private practice, for many years he chaired Columbia's Admissions Service. Wayne Myers was born in New York on December 13, 1931 and graduated from The Bronx High School of Science. He went on to obtain a B.S. Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Arkansas in a mere two years before matriculating at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, where he received his medical degree in 1956. His psychiatric residency at Cornell/New York Hospital was interrupted by service in Korea, where Captain Myers became at twenty-eight Battalion Commander of the Fifteenth Medical Battalion. After completing his training at The New York Psychoanalytic in 1969, he moved on to teach and supervise candidates at Columbia in 1977, where he remained a mainstay until his death. A private service was held for the family and close friends.

IT was just after 8 on a cloudy January morning as the flat-bottomed pontoon boat made its way over the glassy surface of Kings Bay, 600 acres of fresh water in Crystal River, Fla. The bay, actually a spring-fed pool, is rimmed by attractive homes and lush greenery along its many coves and lagoons, but aboard the boat, no one cared. Huddled on aluminum benches were 10 wet-suited comrades. We represented a variety of countries and ages, but on this particular morning, we all wanted the same thing: to swim with the bay's most famous residents, West Indian manatees.

COOK--Constance. NARAL Pro-Choice New York deeply mourns the loss of Constance Cook, champion of reproductive rights for all women. As a New York State Assemblymember she sponsored and led the strategic effort to pass the bill that made New York the first state to fully legalize abortion in 1970-three years before Roe vs Wade. Her courage, intellect and passion influenced the hearts and minds of an entire nation. She will be deeply missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to Connie's family and all those who were touched by her legacy.

Kim Jong-il, the reclusive leader of North Korea, met with a senior Chinese Communist Party official, Wang Jiarui, on Friday in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang, according to Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency. There have been strong suggestions that Mr. Kim had a stroke in August, and the meeting was his first with a foreign official since the alleged stroke. Last week, an American researcher who travels frequently to North Korea, Selig S. Harrison, told reporters in Beijing that his sources had told him Mr. Kim had recovered.

COMBS--Bill, 86, died on January 20, 2009 while he was a patient for five days in Baptist Hospital, Miami, FL. He was born on August 9, 1922 in San Francisco, California and raised in New Rochelle, NY. He married Edmee Schaefer on June 16, 1945. He was a loving husband for 63 years. The couple has resided in Bryn Mawr, PA and most recently in Wyomissing, PA and Ocean Reef Club, Key Largo, FL. Bill had nine children: Bill III, George M., Lucia Combs Geraci, and C. Noel Combs Garapola all of Wyomissing, PA, Edmee (Toni) Combs West of West Chester, PA, Jerome J., Devon, PA, Suzanne Combs, Naperville, IL, and Thomas B., Tunkannoch, PA. Bill was preceded in death by a son, Richard Combs, and a granddaughter, Mimi Barrett. He has 27 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. Surviving sisters are Carol Syversen and Cynthia Combs, both of New York State. There are also many nieces and nephews and two brothers-in-law: Rudie Schaefer and William Schaefer. Bill Combs was lovingly known as ''Grumps'' by his family members. Bill was a 1945 Graduate of the United States Military Academy and served in World War II. He later became a graduate brewmaster and worked for the F. and M. Schaefer Brewing Company, Brooklyn, NY. In the late 1950s he went to work for the Skakel family and after several promotions became Vice President, General Manager of the Coke and Chemical Division of Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, St. Louis, MO. In the early 1960s he moved his family to Devon, PA and founded Wascon Systems, Hatboro, PA and subsequently sold it to the American Sterilizer Company, Erie, PA. He went on to start many companies, most notably, Tamaqua Cable Products, Schuylkill Haven, PA. He served on numerous Boards and was a member of many organizations. Always involved in maritime activities, he was a member of the Coast Guard Advisory Committee, participated in the rebuilding of the battleship U.S.S. Niagara, served as Sailing Master for the tall ship Gazelas voyage from Lisbon to Philadelphia, was Commissioner of the Delaware River Port Authority, and on the boards of Mystic Seaport Museum, Chesapeake Bay Maritime Museum, and the Philadelphia Ship Preservation Guild. Back in 1983, his yacht-Black Knight served as the committee boat for the Americas Cup Races. He was a member of a number of clubs, among them, the New York Yacht Club. Being the generous philanthropist that he was he served on the Board of Trustees at Cabrini College for many years. Funeral services will be held on Monday, January 26 at 11am at St. John the Baptist De La Salle Church, 420 Holland St., Shillington, PA 19607 (610 777-1697). Visitation with the family will be 10am to 11am at the Church. Immediately following the funeral everyone is invited to attend a light lunch at the YR Club, South Parkside Drive and Thrush Rd., Wyomissing, PA 19610 (610-376-1303). A memorial service at Ocean Reef Chapel will be arranged at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Children's Hospital Foundation, The Mimi Barrett Fund, P.O. LUNAR NEW YEAR The passage of time is maddeningly subjective -- a minute in traffic is never quite like a minute in front of the television -- and that is perhaps one reason people endlessly seek to measure it. History is littered with calendars that didn't survive (remember the Calendrier républicain, anyone?). But one that was too entrenched, and entertaining, not to have endured is the Chinese calendar, a system adopted about 4,700 years ago in which the second new moon after the winter solstice ushers in a new year, a new animal and 15 days of celebrations.

AS holes go, the one off Interstate 40 a short drive from Flagstaff is a whopper. From a distance it's a mere blip on the horizon, its rim rising 150 feet above the flat scrubland that dominates much of northern Arizona. But that rim hides a yawning expanse -- more bowl than hole, really -- 4,100 feet across and 550 feet deep. If they played a football game in the bottom, the sides could hold two million fans, give or take a luxury box or two. But what really raises this hole above humdrum is how it was created. About 50,000 years ago, a 150-foot lump of iron and nickel, a renegade from the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter, sliced through the sky out of the northeast at seven miles per second. When it hit it tore up the landscape in an instant, excavating several hundred million tons of dirt and rock and flipping layers of sandstone like pancakes.

A new digital plague has hit the Internet, infecting millions of personal and business computers in what seems to be the first step of a multistage attack. The world's leading computer security experts do not yet know who programmed the infection, or what the next stage will be. In recent weeks a worm, a malicious software program, has swept through corporate, educational and public computer networks around the world. Known as Conficker or Downadup, it is spread by a recently discovered Microsoft Windows vulnerability, by guessing network passwords and by hand-carried consumer gadgets like USB keys.

Best friends, after all, don't need to be alike.

CROWELL--David, of Quogue, NY, a gifted artist died Saturday, January 17. Married to Joan Crowell for 36 years, they lived in Quogue for the last 34. Mr. Crowell was born in Evanston, Illinois. He attended the Yale School of Drama, the Northwestern School of Speech, the Sorbonne and Bennington College. After a short stint on Broadway he returned to Bennington College as a Drama instructor, he served in the Marine Corps in WWII and then taught Drama at Bard College Annandale-onHudson, NY. He was an advertising executive and a restaurant owner. He had a notable career as a fabric designer, ghosting for name-designers such as Schiapearelli, Lilly Dach, Brooke Cadwallder, Bronzini, Dali and Mr John. Subsequently he started his own firm which was the subject of several articles, including a feature in the former Saturday Evening Post. He was a devoted gardener, renowned for his topiary of Yew and Juniper. The New York Times ran a feature story with a photograph of his garden in the Home Section. His art works included copper and pewter weather vanes, painted furniture, chess sets and jewelry. He was well known for his extraordinary witty Trompe L'Oeil boxes. He had exhibitions at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton, Long Island; the Gallery North, Setauket, Long Island; the Trompe L'Oeil Gallery in New York City; Park-McCullough house in North Bennington, VT; Quogue Library, Quogue, NY; the Designer Showhouse in Westhampton Long Island; the Hampton Square Gallery in Westhampton, Long Island and the Heritage House in Hamilton Bermuda. His work is in private collections throughout the United States, Europe and Asia. He was predeceased by three of his children, and is survived by his wife of 34 years, Joan Crowell, one daughter, five stepchildren, thirteen grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren.

Guards reputedly sent inmates to intimidate, threaten and silence uncooperative prisoners with brute force. Inmates were ordered to turn over money, and their every move, including when they could use the bathroom, was controlled. If word of an assault got out, the guards would allegedly orchestrate a cover-up. In fact, prosecutors said, a unit for teenagers on Rikers Island was run much like an organized-crime family -- and two correction officers were the bosses.

DORNBLASER--Mary M. (Hellier), 65, of Marion, MA died unexpectedly on January 3, 2009. She was a graduate of the Kingswood-Oxford School and Sweetbriar College where she spent her junior year living in Madrid. A longtime resident of New York City with the exception of 1970--1972 when she lived in Paris, Mimi, as she was known, initially worked as a translator for the Spanish government. She later became Special Events Director and Executive Assistant to Phillips Talbot of the Asia Society until his retirement. While with the society, she was a member of a delegation representing the Ford administration on a trade mission to China. She was a member of The Colony. Mimi is survived by her husband, George, a step-daughter, Sarah of New York City, a niece Sally Thomas of Toccoa, GA, and a nephew, Ted Hellier and his wife Susan of South Portland, ME as well as a grand-niece and several grand-nephews. Mimi would have appreciated it that any donations made on her behalf be sent to the Kingswood-Oxford School, West Hartford, CT. A memorial service will be held in Marion during the spring. Interment will be private.

ELSBERG--Ted. Born December 1, 1931. Died January 17, 2009. Adored husband of Adrienne, beloved father of Karen (Jonathan) Mendez and of David (Natalie) Elsberg, cherished grandfather of Payton, Brett and Dylan Mendez and of Benjamin and Laura Elsberg, dearest brother-in-law of Mel Wichter, precious brother of Marilyn Butchen and esteemed friend to many. Former captain of the Erasmus Hall High School basketball team, former captain of the New York University basketball team, former president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, former president of the American Federation of School Administrators. A man of illustrious and unique accomplishments. His death brings us unbearable sorrow. Memories of him will bring us joy forever.

BLACKSTONE--David, January 18, 2009. Prominent Criminal Defense Attorney, founder and first President of the Central Park Track Club, Long Distance Running Champion and founder of the amateur Physical Society died peacefully following a long struggle with cancer. A veteran of the US Marine Corps, Mr. Blackstone received his undergraduate degree cum laud from New York University and his law degree from Columbia Law School. Mr. Blackstone devoted the greater part of his 45 year legal career in private practice, defending individuals charged with murder in New York County. He was the senior member of the New York County Homicide Panel and served as a New York State Deputy Capital Defender. His beloved wife Lynn Terreri Blackstone survives him, as do his sons David T. Blackstone and US Army Capt. Ian T. Blackstone, we invite you to review his web site daveblackstonelaw.com. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, January 25, 2009, at 2:30pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st. Contributions may be made in Dave's memory to the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and the Central Park Track Club, a 501 (c)(3) tax-exempt organization.

Gage Bush Englund, who was a ballet mistress of ABT II, a former dancer with American Ballet Theater and the Joffrey Ballet and a former ballet mistress of the Joffrey II Dancers, died on Jan. 12 at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 77. The cause was cancer, said John Knapp, her son-in-law.

ZORN--Bruce Joseph, 89 years of age, of West Hartford, CT, died January 21, 2009 after a long illness. He was born in Trenton, NJ in 1920, son of John Zorn and Edna Papier Zorn, and brother of Warren S. Zorn (deceased). He was the loving husband for 62 years of Selma Levine Zorn of Brooklyn, NY and father of Francine Zorn Trachtenberg and her husband Stephen Joel Trachtenberg of Washington, DC, and Jonathan Zorn and his wife Jill B. Zorn of Columbia, CT. He was the proud and loving grandfather of Adam Trachtenberg and his wife Beth Hondl, Ben Trachtenberg and his wife Joanna L. W. Trachtenberg, Abigail Zorn and Hannah Zorn. A veteran of World War II, Bruce served in the First Army in England, France, Belgium and Germany, attaining the rank of First Sergeant. He was awarded the Bronze Star. From 1946 until his retirement in 1986, he lived in Brooklyn, NY, and was employed as office manager and treasurer for Eastern Duo-Fast, a company selling industrial stapling equipment. After moving to West Hartford, he volunteered for 20 years at the University of Hartford, working with foreign students in the English Language Institute. He is remembered by all who knew him as a loving husband and father, whose smile, integrity and disposition endeared him to all he met. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, January 25, 2009 at 11:00am in the Chapel of the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford. Interment will follow immediately at the Emanuel Synagogue Cemetery, Wethersfield. The family will receive visitors at the home of Selma Zorn in West Hartford on Sunday, January 25th from 6-8pm and on Monday, January 26th from 6:30-8pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorial contributions be made to a charity of the donor's choice. For further information, directions or to share memories of Bruce with his family, please visit online at weinsteinmortuary.com.

FRIEDMAN--Edward Ber nard, CPA, of Merrick, on January 22, 2009. Beloved husband of Lenore. Devoted father of Wendy Friedman, Lori Friedman and Amy Leist and loving father-in-law of Nick Allen and Dr. Scott Leist. Cherished grandfather of Ariel, Matthew and Dylan Leist. Longtime senior partner of Barasch, Friedman, Friedberg and Adasko Certified Public Accountants, PC. Services will be held on Sunday, January 25th at 10am, at Gutterman's, 175 N. Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY 11570. His passing has left a void in the lives of his family and friends that can never be filled. He will be truly and deeply missed by all who knew him. In keeping with Edward's generous spirit, the family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. Donation envelopes will be available at Gutterman's.

MINDLIN--Leon, age 84, died at home on January 20, surrounded by family. A talented linguist, he loved classical music, opera, Joyce and, above all things, le mot juste. He was quick-witted, endlessly curious, devoid of vanity and capable of great grace. He is survived by his sister; three children, Philip Mindlin (Iliana), Louise Daniels (Walter) and Jessica Mindlin (Alex Schafir); and seven grandchildren. Donations to the Innocence Project in lieu of flowers.

Situated on two acres, this 9,097-square-foot house overlooks Sprat Bay and St. Thomas harbor. It is five minutes to marinas, docks and diving sites. The property includes two parcels of land, and the guesthouse, with three bedrooms, is steps from the beach. The main house has an open floor plan with a large patio overlooking the bay, a 55-foot pool and six bathrooms. Agent: Peter Briggs, John Foster Real Estate, (340) 776-5000; www.usvi-realestate.com.

This 843-square-foot house is in a 600-acre private community. The guesthouse is 692 square feet and has two bedrooms and one bathroom. Scuba diving is popular here and elsewhere on the island. The main house has one bathroom, two fireplaces, a kitchen with commercial-grade appliances and a large deck with water views. Agent: Jane Sawyer, Coldwell Banker San Juan Islands Inc., (360) 378-2101; www.sanjuanislands.com.

On the plane, no longer Air Force One but now Special Air Mission 28000, they talked about the speech. George W. Bush, the former president, was heading home to Texas with his inner circle, having just left the Capitol, where his successor first thanked him for his service and then proceeded to discredit it. The Bush team had worked assiduously to make the transition smooth for the incoming President Obama and stayed out of the way as he used the postelection period to take leadership of the economy even before being sworn in. And now, as far as some of them were concerned, the new president had used his inaugural lectern to give the back of the hand to a predecessor who had been nothing but gracious to him.

ARMSTRONG KEEPS PACE Open road remained hard to come by for Lance Armstrong in his comeback at the Tour Down Under. Armstrong has made the occasional surge in this six-stage race in South Australia, but in Friday's fourth stage he remained with the main group of riders throughout the 88.9-mile journey from the start in Burnside Village in Adelaide to the finish in the Barossa Valley wine country.

Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Every Friday and Saturday at 7:30 and 8:30 p.m. (except Jan. 30 and Feb. 6, 21 and 27), ''SonicVision,'' an animated alternative-music show, will be presented in the Rose Center; tickets, $15; $12 for members. Through Aug. 16, ''Climate Change: The Threat to Life and a New Energy Future,'' an interactive display. Through May 25, ''The Butterfly Conservatory, Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter.'' Through March 1, ice-skating on the outdoor Polar Rink; Mondays through Thursdays, noon to 8 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 10 p.m.; Saturday, 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. $10; $9 for students and 60+; $8 for children 3 to 12; $8, $7 and $6 for members. In the Imax theater through May 23, playing alternately every hour on the half-hour from 10:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., ''Wild Ocean,'' about underwater survival of migrating species, and ''Dinosaurs Alive!,'' a search for dinosaur remains. Timed tickets to ''Climate Change'' and ''The Butterfly Conservatory,'' as well as tickets to Imax films, include museum admission: $24; $18 for students and 60+; $14 for ages 2 to 12. Suggested general admission: $15; $11 for students and 60+; $8.50 for children. Supersaver tickets, including museum and Rose Center for Earth and Space admission, the Hayden Planetarium space show (''Cosmic Collisions'') and all special exhibitions: $32; $24.50 for students and 60+; $20 for ages 2 to 12. Hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5100, amnh.org.

JONES--Alfred Leonard, Ph.D.-passed away January 14. Raised in Brownsville, where he was a street handball champion; WWII pilot; cofounder of the MHCC, which provided mental health services for decades; lover of art; master of words; father to Chris and Rosanna and grandfather to Julian. After serving in WWII, he returned to NYC, where he counseled repatriated Holocaust survivors. Dr. Jones received his Doctorate in Philosophy from NYU where he was honored with the Founders Day Award for his outstanding scholarship; he went on to teach post-doctorate students. He was well known for his lectures at Cooper Union, was president of NYSCP, volunteered with the local police precinct as a consultant and was a revered neighborhood friend. Known to friends and family as Dr. Jones or Jonesey, he will be missed by many. Services Sunday, January 25, 4pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam.

James Stewart, a scholar in 18th- and 19th-century European art who has been director of the Museum of Art at the University of Michigan, was named director of the Princeton University Art Museum. He succeeds Susan Taylor, who left in June.

SOIFER--Herman, died Monday January 19th at his home in Rancho Mirage, CA, he was 96. An innovator and long time legend in the men's clothing industry, he founded Brookfield Clothes in 1945, retiring to Palm Springs in 1983. He is survived by his loving wife, Carol Soifer, daughter Marcia Ammeen, son-in-law James Ammeen and granddaughter Gabrielle Ben-Eli.

FOR CHILDREN B.Y.O.K. Once people become parents, they often leave their B.Y.O.B. days behind. Now 92YTriBeCa, a new satellite of the 92nd Street Y, is offering the perfect substitute: B.Y.O.K., or Bring Your Own Kid. As the title implies, this series is devoted to cross-generational fun, and so on Sunday it will present Brady Rymer and the Little Band That Could. Mr. Rymer and his former group, From Good Homes, once opened for Bob Dylan and toured with Dave Matthews, so he can please parents. And his American roots rock is already a hit with children. At 11 a.m., 200 Hudson Street, at Canal Street, (212) 601-1000, 92ytribeca.org/BYOK; $15.

While countless comedy fans spent the 1960s and '70s poring over the rebellious routines of George Carlin, above, so too did J. Edgar Hoover, according to F.B.I. records released by the comedian's family and reported by The Associated Press. Among the documents Carlin obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request before his death in June was an F.B.I. memo that noted his 1969 appearance on ''The Jackie Gleason Show,'' when he lampooned Hoover and the F.B.I. ''His treatment was in very poor taste and it was obvious that he was using the prestige of the bureau and Mr. Hoover to enhance his performance,'' the memo said, according to The A.P. The F.B.I. previously told The A.P. that it had no file on Carlin; an F.B.I. spokeswoman told The A.P. that she was looking into the apparent contradiction.

GIANNANTONIO--Anthony J.,76, of Palisades Park, on January 20. Visiting Saturday 7-9pm and Sunday 3-5 and 79pm. Mass Monday 10:45 St. Michael's Church. Call for information (201)944-0100 or visit www.frankpatti.com.

This 2,100-square-foot house is in the Hatteras Dunes area close to several scuba diving locations and beaches. The house was built in 2006 and has a heated swimming pool with a wet bar, a hot tub and water views. Interior features include nine-foot ceilings, hardwood floors and a fireplace in the living room. The house has three and a half bathrooms. There is a game room and an attached two-car garage. Agent: Dan Johnson, Midgett Realty-Hatteras, (252) 986-2841; www.midgettrealty.com.

JACOBS--Richard, 83, of Great Neck, NY, formerly of Flushing, adored husband of 63 years to Ruth, left behind a loving, devoted family of sons, Gary and Scott, daughters-in-law, Vickie and Chris, grandchildren, David, Brittany and Alexandra, and greatgrandson, Orion. Respected, loved and admired for his kindness and generosity, Richard, a retired psychotherapist, will be sorely missed by all those privileged to have known him.

The Senate Intelligence Committee, led by Senator Dianne Feinstein, heard testimony on Thursday from Adm. Dennis C. Blair, President Obama's choice to serve as director of national intelligence. A protester raised a sign as Mr. Blair made his opening statement.

This 3,890-square-foot contemporary built in 1999 is on nearly two acres in the Laurel Hill subdivision, which has hiking trails and a shared tennis court. It has valley views, three bathrooms, 10-foot ceilings and an ''in-law'' apartment. Agent: Carolyn Laflamme, Jones Realtors; (413) 585-0400; www.jonesgrouponline.com.

NOLOBOFF--Evelyn Uslan. June 24, 1914-January 20, 2009. Hers is not a simple story, yet even in the end, she made it easy for everyone. Evelyn passed peacefully in her sleep at her home in Northern Miami. She is survived by her children Dale, Vic, Steven and Jody, her grandchildren Rob, Jamie, Jeff, Alexxa and Rob, greatgrandchild Shane, 13 of the best nieces and nephews and the three greatest sisters ever, Rita, Pearl and Estelle. She will be missed.

Thirty years ago as a rookie in the moribund World Hockey Association, Wayne Gretzky was a precocious teenager about to jolt his sport into a new era. Twenty years ago, Gretzky played his first season with the Los Angeles Kings, who received him from Edmonton. His mission: to generate a Sun Belt boom for the N.H.L. in the epicenter of show business.

IRVING--Inge Jollos, actress, civil rights activist, travel agent, mother and grandmother, died peacefully on January 17. She was 85 years old and lived in New York City. She appeared on stage, television, film and radio, and ran a boutique travel advisory firm, catering to the performing arts. Inge was born in Berlin, Germany, to noted protozoologist/geneticist Victor Jollos, and concert pianist and arts patron, Ilse Rappaport. With the support of a grant from the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars, they settled in Madison, Wisconsin, where Inge attended the University of Wisconsin In 1958, she married Ben Irving, the Assistant Executive Secretary of Actors Equity and noted labor mediator. Inge is survived by her three children, Victor, Jonathan and Deborah, and her two grandchildren, Nathaniel and Hannah. A memorial service to celebrate her life is being planned for the Spring. Inge requested that contributions be sent to the Actors' Fund.

ART Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art.

Melissa Dixson, 30, a painter, taught herself taxidermy four years ago after developing multiple sclerosis. She sees taxidermy as a fine art, and has sold some pieces, including a pair of playing foxes, at the SoHo design store Moss. She works at a bookstore and lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with her husband, Stephen Floyd, and cat, Stella. ''The first time that I got a squirrel, I looked at it and I said, 'Am I going to be able to do this? Am I really going to be able to cut this thing open?' But once you think about it as a project and something that you have to do, it's really no different than cutting chicken to make for dinner. I definitely don't do pets. I get calls from people that are just grieving, like their dog has a week to live and they don't know what to do and they can't imagine their life without it. And what I do isn't going to bring the dog back and I just can't give someone an unreal expectation. I got a call yesterday about how to preserve a turnip. I couldn't help him, but that goes in the hall of fame.''

The last two years have been sobering for Freddy García, whose shoulder has kept him from being the premier starter he was for eight seasons. He has bounced to the Philadelphia Phillies and the Detroit Tigers, and now he will try with the Mets. The Mets agreed to a minor league contract with García, according to a person with knowledge of the deal who was granted anonymity because the move had not been announced. García will have a chance to compete for a spot in the rotation.
Douglas Sirk's 1954 film, with Rock Hudson and Jane Wyman, plays on Thursday as part of the series Imitations of Life: Stahl vs. Sirk, at Anthology Film Archives.

His Wall Street pedigree seems impeccable. A top job at Goldman Sachs. The chief of the New York Stock Exchange. Finally, the reins of the stock market's ''thundering herd,'' Merrill Lynch. But in less than 15 minutes on Thursday, the charmed career of John A. Thain was derailed.

My Sunday column is about Bill Gates and his first annual letter, which will be released Monday. You can sign up for it or read it on the Gates Foundation site, and by all means also take a look at the video of parts of my conversation with Gates.

It was a day of high excitement in Espasante. The town was celebrating, with the rest of Spain, the arrival of Los Reyes Magos - the three wise kings - who distribute sweets and presents to its children. It was also the day that Anton the town pig was raffled off.

I'm hearing reports of heavy Sudanese government bombings in Darfur, and even tank attacks on villages. It's hard to be sure what is going on, but I wonder if President Bashir isn't trying to frighten the ICC of the consequences if it issues the arrest warrant for him as expected in the next few weeks. One version is that in North Darfur, there have been bombings near Anka and heavy Janjaweed attacks, and that in South Darfur there were heavy bombings in the Muhajiriya area, more Janjaweed attacks and even attacks on civilian villages using Sudanese tanks.
Thanks to my old college buddy and good friend Tom Rielly for reminding me that today is the 25th anniversary of the Macintosh; it went on sale Jan. 24, 1984.
Harunur Rashid, 17, a Bangladeshi immigrant, is one of 87 students in the first class at English Language Learners and International Support Preparatory Academy.
Leslie Lopez' sons, Tariq and Johan, 4, have undergone heart transplants recently. They have lived in hospitals and homeless shelters and are constantly struggling to stay healthy.

There's a very happy retired French teacher and tennis coach in California today. Her name is Jane Roberts. In 2002, after the Bush administration blocked $34 million Congress had approved for the United States contribution to the United Nations Population Fund, known commonly as Unfpa, she co-founded 34 Million Friends, a group trying to fill the gap $1 at a time. She wrote a book on women and human welfare, as well.
Despite new management at the White House, this Sunday's breakfast menu doesn't look all that different, especially as the economic crisis continues to dominate the news.

I used to forget to look at the titles in Sunday puzzles, which meant I sometimes missed important information. Now I try to avoid the titles because sometimes, like today, they give away the gimmick. I guess I was supposed to think of Katie Scarlett O'Hara but as soon as I saw Fiddle Dee Dee I started looking for the big Double-Ds in the theme answers.
Kay Yow, North Carolina State's Hall of Fame women's basketball coach, died Saturday after a long battle with cancer. She was 66.

Language | Esperanto, would-be lingua franca of global harmony, still has its practitioners, an article says, claiming up to two million speakers worldwide. With their conventions and college clubs, they are tight-knit "like members of a secret society or persecuted fringe religion." And can kick back reading "Winne-La-Pu" or "Taglibro de Anne Frank." [Boston Phoenix]

MONTREAL -- If anyone wondered whether a recent fighting-related death would spur the N.H.L. into finally undertaking a deep philosophical discussion on whether it is time to ban fighting in hockey, the answer came on Saturday from Commissioner Gary Bettman.

ATLANTA -- Georgia Tech Coach Paul Hewitt said the truly gifted high school players, like LeBron James or Kevin Garnett, should not have to wait for one season after graduating before turning pro, as per N.C.A.A. and N.B.A. rules.

Forward Garrett Klotz, a Philadelphia Flyers farmhand playing for the Philadelphia Phantoms in the A.H.L., was hospitalized Friday night after a seizure following a fight in a game against the Manchester Monarchs.
Stephen Danley played forward for Pennsylvania from 2003 to 2007 and is a Marshall scholar at the University of Oxford.

President Obama's books remain at the top of this month's best-selling political books, as they have since the election in November. And to stay in stride with the gala celebrations surrounding his inauguration, "Audacity of Hope" still holds at No.1, while "Dreams From My Father" moved up a notch to the No. 2 position. "Michelle" by Liza Mundy creeps back onto the list at No. 14. Thus far, this is the only book to appear on The Caucus' Poli-Books about the First Lady.
Columnist Nicholas Kristof talks with Bill Gates about aid to developing countries during the economic downturn and about vaccine breakthroughs on the horizon.

The Slovakian Extraliga web site hokejportal.sk persuaded the president of the Slovak Republic, Ivan Gašparovic, to predict the outcome of this weekend's matches. KNOXVILLE, Tenn. - To players who express an interest in becoming a basketball coach, Tennessee's Pat Summitt offers a simple piece of advice: major in psychology.
The Vancouver Giants took their first step toward the Memorial Cup by qualifying for the Western Hockey League playoffs in just 46 games.

Much of the reaction to Gov. David A. Paterson's choice of Kirsten Gillibrand to fill the vacant junior Senate seat from New York focused on her moderate to conservative positions on hot-button issues.
Is this weekend's acrostic "just what you need when you don't expect it"? Our acrostic schedule got bumped around but we'll get back to every other week.

Internet | Did someone say digital democracy? Au contraire, Nicholas Carr writes. In a "blink of history's eye," he says, (1) a single medium, the Web, dominates the supply of information, (2) a single search engine, Google, dominates navigation of that medium, and (3) a single information source, Wikipedia, dominates the Google search results. Behold the Web, once "radically heterogeneous," now "radically homogeneous." [Britannica]

debate Barack Obama's foreign policy convictions.

“Underworld: Rise of the Lycans,” a prehistory to the first two “Underworld” movies, rewinds to when the werewolves rebelled against their vampire masters.
Even before thieves stole the money from his food stamp account a few months ago, it had already been a difficult year for 81-year-old Vladimir Fishman.
Mrs. Cook was a former New York State assemblywoman who co-authored a law that legalized abortion in the state three years before Roe v. Wade.
Mr. Werber was a link to the Yankees of Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig and was the leadoff hitter in the first major league baseball game to be televised.
The dean of discipline at an all-boys Roman Catholic high school in the Bronx was suspended after being charged with propositioning and groping a 19-year-old student in his office.
Mr. Perle was a composer, author, theorist and teacher who won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1986 and was widely considered the poetic voice of atonal composition.

Researchers in Cambodia are finding that traditional drugs used to battle malaria are becoming less effective.
Tim Duncan had 30 points and 15 rebounds and Michael Finley hit a pivotal 3-pointer for the San Antonio Spurs with 22.6 seconds left to clinch a 94-91 victory against the visiting Nets on Friday.
Six people accused of fraudulently obtaining money from Louisiana’s Hurricane Katrina homeowner grant program were charged in federal court.
The Swiss authorities on Friday released from jail the last of three family members suspected of smuggling atomic technology to Libya and Iran.
Timothy F. Geithner’s assertion that China manipulates its currency isn’t the only sign that an Obama administration may take a tougher stance toward Beijing.
Renewable forms of energy have their place in meeting our needs, and putting a price on carbon dioxide emissions will make them more economically appealing.

Federal aid to states will save essential programs, as well as keep states from rushing into short-term fixes that could have bad long-term consequences.
An executive order to lift restrictions on international family planning groups will safeguard women’s lives and basic rights, including free speech and the choice of whether to bear a child.
It is time for Albany’s many self-declared reformers to toughen ethics requirements and oversight of lawmakers — as evident in the indictment of Senator Joseph Bruno.
Kirsten Gillibrand needs to move beyond some narrower views suited to her old constituents and embrace her role as a senator of a powerful, diverse and complicated state.

The Texas Board of Education voted to drop a 20-year-old mandate that science teachers explore with their students the “strengths and weaknesses” of all theories.
To avoid downsizing as the economy declines, law firms are migrating to where creditors fight over corporate remains.
Barack Obama’s ascent to the presidency does not mean that all black children will automatically have an easier — or equal — route to success.

First Centennial Bank of Redlands, Calif., was seized by a state regulator, the third bank in the nation to fail this year.

The mass-market fiction best-seller list on Page 20 this weekend describes “Blasphemy,” by Douglas Preston, incorrectly. The description should say: “A C.I.A. operative tracks scientists with a huge supercollider who are poised to discover the secret of creation.” (The published description is for an earlier book by the same author.).
In its seeming failure in 1981, the New Jewish Times had, in fact, anticipated a later generation of edgy and hip Jewish journalism.
The oilfield services company reported a 17 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings and said it would cut 5,000 jobs worldwide during the first half of the year.
Dow Chemical is in talks to close its proposed $15.4 billion buyout of Rohm & Haas, the specialty chemicals maker, after federal regulators approved the deal, the companies said.
In his process to pick a new U.S. senator, Gov. David A. Paterson’s leadership has appeared disorganized to many.
Harley-Davidson said its fourth-quarter profit fell 58 percent and that it would cut back some operations and reduce motorcycle shipments this year to cope with a decline in demand.

A picture caption on Page 8 this weekend with an article about Alexandra Pelosi’s new documentary on the former pastor Ted Haggard misidentifies the woman shown standing with him. She is Gayle Haggard, his wife — not Ms. Pelosi.
An executive pitched in at the Four Seasons for a historic day in Washington.

An art review on Friday about two exhibitions at the Morgan Library & Museum — “The Thaw Collection of Master Drawings: Acquisitions Since 2002” and “Oil Sketches From the Thaw Collection” — misstated the date of the last Thaw exhibition at the Morgan. It was 2002-2003 — not 1994.

An article on Friday about the Academy Award nominations misstated Michael London’s role in the production of “Milk,” which received eight nominations. He is an executive producer of the film, not a producer.
Officials in Newport, R.I., hope that the replica of an 1812 warship will create jobs, attract tourists and spur interest in the state’s maritime history.

A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about a concert of works by Mendelssohn scheduled for Wednesday, at the Museum of Jewish Heritage in Battery Park City, misidentified the conductor who is presenting the program. He is Stephen Somary — not Johannes Somary, his father.
A classical music entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the New York Philharmonic misidentified the Haydn symphony the orchestra will perform tonight and on Tuesday. It is No. 89, not No. 88.
Baendu Lowenthal had 21 points and 10 rebounds to help visiting Fairfield shock No. 20 Marist, 73-65, in overtime Friday.

An article on Wednesday about a village in Gaza that was razed during the 22-day war between Israel and Hamas misspelled the surname of a resident whose orchard grove was destroyed in the conflict. She is Noha Shawa, not Noha Shawal.

An article on Tuesday about the scheduled elections in Iraq’s Anbar Province, once the center of an insurgency that followed the American military’s toppling of Saddam Hussein, referred incorrectly in some editions to Gen. Saadoun al-Jumaili, an Iraqi officer who said a reconstructed version of Mr. Hussein’s banned Baath Party was secretly operating in Anbar. General Jumaili is a former commander in the Iraqi Air Force, not a current one.
The killers’ motives were unclear, but an Iraqi official said a preliminary investigation indicated that some of the women might have been prostitutes.

TRASOFF--Victor. Sweet, kind, loving husband of Barbara Meister; father of Vicki Wolfe, Nina and Rod (Jilg) and David; grandfather and great-grandfather. Barbara will be at home Sunday, February 15, 2-7pm.

DeWITT--Eugene (Gene) A.,passed away early Thursday morning after a four-year battle with cancer. He was a devoted husband to Dianne DeWitt, father to Kate DeWitt and his four step-daughters and their husbands, Anna and Andrew Silverman, Stacey and Remy Bertin, Elexis and Christopher Lewis, and Jacqueline Mariash. He was also a caring and giving grandfather to Cooper Silverman. Gene was a graduate of Tufts University, and for more than 40 years built a well-respected career in marketing advertising and media strategy advising some of the worlds largest and smartest advertisers on how to develop and implement breakthrough communications strategies. Along the way, Gene worked with AT&T, BMW, British Airways, Coca-Cola, Chrysler, Discovery Channels, DuPont, General Electric, General Motors, Johnson & Johnson, L'Oreal, McDonald's, Pepsi Cola, Sears and The Wall Street Journal. Gene was also an avid supporter and contributor to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Manhattan Theatre Club, The Metropolitan Opera and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations be given to Saint Bartholomews Church by visiting www.stbarts.org/donation .asp. Services will be held at Saint Bartholomews Church on Park Avenue between 50th and 51st Street on Tuesday, January 27 at 3pm. Gene's loss will be deeply felt. With all our love.

Two young children and a caregiver were killed Friday by a man wielding a knife who had used a ruse to get into a day care center in the village of Dendermonde, 20 miles from Brussels, the police said. The man, who was not identified, wore a bullet-proof vest, according to the authorities; he was arrested not far from the day care center. The police did not identify the children who were killed, except to say that they were both younger than 3 years old. Two adults and 11 children were wounded in the attack.

Plus it's hard to beat $2 beers and plentiful seafood. At left, a thatched-roof pier at Pigeon Point in Tobago. nytimes.com/travel

Pope Benedict XVI is expected to revoke the excommunication of four schismatic bishops, Italian news outlets reported. The four, whom Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre made bishops in unsanctioned consecrations in Switzerland in 1988, reject many reforms of the Second Vatican Council. Bringing them back could heal a rift with traditionalists. But one of the four, Richard Williamson, provoked outrage this week when he told Swedish television he believed ''the historical evidence'' was ''hugely against'' the conclusion that six million Jews had been ''deliberately gassed in gas chambers as a deliberate policy of Adolf Hitler.''

A 42-year-old Briton wanted for sabotaging some United States government computers in the nine months after the Sept. 11 attacks won a delay in extradition proceedings on Friday after high court judges in London were told that he had recently been given a diagnosis of Asperger's syndrome, a social developmental disorder that his lawyers said could explain his obsession with hacking and make him a suicide risk in an American prison. The Briton, Gary McKinnon, above, has admitted hacking into nearly 100 computers belonging to the United States military and NASA; he has said he was looking for classified documents on unidentified flying objects.

If you are hoping for a long career as a United States international soccer player, it helps to be left-footed and defensive-minded. While glory goes to the goal scorer, job security belongs to the defender. Of the five Americans with the most international appearances, three were defenders. Two of the defenders played left back. ''It's a supply-and-demand issue,'' said Jeff Agoos, a former left back for the national team and the second-most capped player in team history. ''There's just not a lot of supply of left-sided players, not just in the U.S. but I think around the world.''

Laurent Nkunda, the Congolese rebel leader whose brutal tactics and Congo-size ambitions have threatened to bring about another catastrophic war in central Africa, was arrested late Thursday, removing an explosive factor from the regional equation.

COMPANIES too often hinder their own success by focusing too narrowly on selling products and not on what their customers actually need, says Dev Patnaik, a business strategist. Businesses could be more successful -- and see competitive opportunities faster than their rivals -- if they looked differently at what they were doing. Mr. Patnaik, founder and chief executive of Jump Associates, a firm in San Mateo, Calif., that advises companies on growth strategies, and a part-time professor at Stanford, has written a book, ''Wired to Care: How Companies Prosper When They Create Widespread Empathy,'' scheduled for release this month.

Prime Minister Manmohan Singh of India entered a hospital on Friday to undergo heart bypass surgery on Saturday, officials said. The governing Congress Party has dismissed concerns that his health will interfere with its campaign for general elections, which must be held by May, but there has been speculation that the party chief, Sonia Gandhi, has been lining up her son, Rahul Gandhi, as the country's next prime minister. Mr. Singh, 76, underwent heart bypass surgery in 1990 and angioplasty in 2003.

Critically acclaimed works like “Home,” by Marilynne Robinson, and Roberto Bolaño’s “2666,” as well as a first novel, “The Ballad of Trenchmouth Taggart” by M. Glenn Taylor, are among the finalists for the annual National Book Critics Circle awards, which were announced Saturday at the Housing Works bookstore in SoHo. “The Lazarus Project,” by the Bosnian-American writer Aleksandar Hemon, and Elizabeth Strout’s “Olive Kitteridge” round out the fiction nominees, which were revealed along with finalists in poetry, criticism, biography, autobiography and nonfiction. Winners will be announced on March 12. Some of the biggest surprises were books that were well-received last year but not named finalists, like “How Fiction Works” by James Wood, “A Mercy” by Toni Morrison and “Netherland,” by Joseph O’Neill. Two honorary prizes were also announced: A lifetime achievement award for the American center of PEN, the international association of writers devoted to the defense of free speech and human rights; and a special criticism award for Ron Charles, book critic of The Washington Post. A full list of the nominees can be found here.
In the Wings

“Paul Blart: Mall Cop,” about a bumbling yet heroic security guard, once again ruled the weekend box office. The film, starring Kevin James (who is also a co-writer and co-producer), earned $21.5 million for Columbia Pictures, bringing its total to $64.8 million in two weeks, according to the box office tracking firm Media by Numbers. Second place went to the only newcomer in the top five: “Underworld 3: The Rise of the Lycans” (Sony). The vampires-versus-werewolves thriller starring Michael Sheen (“Frost/Nixon”) earned $20.7 million in its first week. Clint Eastwood’s “Gran Torino” (Warner Brothers) dropped to third place with $16.3 million ($97.9 million to date), followed by “Hotel for Dogs” (DreamWorks), which took in $12.4 million ($37 million). And coming in fifth, just a few days after being nominated for 10 Oscars, “Slumdog Millionaire” totaled $10.6 million, a huge increase over last weekend’s take ($5.9 million).

The George Balanchine ballets “Coppélia” and “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and Peter Martins’s “Romeo and Juliet” will be among the highlights of the New York City Ballet’s spring season, scheduled to begin April 28 at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center. The season, which will run through June 21, will encompass 40 ballets and feature a national “Live From Lincoln Center” broadcast of “Romeo” on May 21. The lineup will also include world premieres of works by Benjamin Millepied, a principal dancer with City Ballet, and Jiri Bubenicek, a principal dancer with the Dresden SemperOper Ballet. The offerings will include pieces by Balanchine, Jerome Robbins and Christopher Wheeldon.

“Push: Based on the Novel by Sapphire,” which is, as the title indicates, based on the 1996 book by the single-named poet, won both the grand jury and audience awards at the Sundance Film Festival on Saturday. The film, directed by Lee Daniels, stars Mo’Nique, Mariah Carey, Paula Patton and Gabourey Sidibe, who plays the central character, an illiterate, obese 16-year-old named Precious Jones. Mo’Nique also picked up a special jury prize for acting for her role as the girl’s cruel mother. Other winners announced at the ceremony, held at the Park City Racquet Club, included a grand jury prize for Ondi Timoner’s “We Live in Public,” about the Internet pioneer Josh Harris, in the U.S. documentary category. The audience award in the same category went to “The Cove,” directed by a former National Geographic photographer, Louie Psihoyos, about a secret cove in Japan where government sanctioned killing of dolphins takes place. A complete list of winners is here.

Working carpets is a skill, one that the Bagger never seemed to catch on to. Mixed events -- where television and movies end up in the same mishagosh -- make it especially hard. It's not that the Bagger doesn't watch television, he just doesn't work it. And so for 90 minutes, there was a parade of TV stars who all seem nice and everything, but don't help the cause. And then for the last 20 minutes, the carpet turns into a game preserve, thick with exotic and otherwise rare quarry. It can leave the hunter a little overwhelmed, especially because he hates to miss anything. Gee, it's swell that I am talking to Penelope Cruz, but then again, Mickey Rourke just ambled on by. Sometimes it is made easier -- Brad and Angelina arrived late and weren't stopping and Sean Penn avoided the press on his way in.

We are at a crossroads. It is the beginning of a new administration and the end of an old one. There are those who would like to forget the last eight years. It's the magic-slate idea. As if you could lift up an acetate window and those eight years would suddenly vanish.

On the way in, Kate Winslet told the Bagger that she never gets used to this stuff, that she always gets nervous and out of sorts. She was talking about the red carpet, but she may as well have been talking about laps to the podium. Ms. Winslet just took another lap, this time for her supporting work in "The Reader," the weaker, if you can say that, of the her two roles this year. She was more composed than she was at the Globes, and much more brief. Perhaps it's because of her training regimen, which other actresses might want to take note of. "As long as all of this is going on, I have stopped exercising and am eating whatever I want."

Monologue | Aired Friday night on NBC: There were two million people crammed into the National Mall this week, and not one arrest. Not one crime was committed in Washington. Of course, that'll all change now that Congress is back.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Of course this was the inauguration week in Washington, and they have been hauling rubbish out in its wake. In fact, 130 tons of garbage have been hauled out of Washington. And that's not including the previous administration.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: There's big business popping up around Obama. There's plates, coins, T-shirts, and now, the Chia company has immortalized him in clay. And what better way to honor a president than to have sprouts growing from his brain pan?

The economy is on everyone's mind, but even more so is how the latest economic news affects our money. To guide you through the often confusing world of personal finance, we've revamped the Your Money section. New features include:

Culture | Bloated, depressed, hooked on empty optimism. Who needs hemlines or lipstick sales when you have Oprah as a barometer of the zeitgeist? "Her current crisis - her inability to understand how someone as wealthy and powerful as she is can feel so overwhelmed, helpless and in peril - captures, in miniature, the nation's free-floating angst." [New York Post]
Every level of junior hockey was busy on Saturday night. The junior report begins with action in the Ontario Hockey League.

Finance | You thought the cause of the meltdown was subprime mortgages or Wall Street greed. But this article identifies what's "underlying the whole mess" -- "global imbalances." That is, the "savings glut" in emerging economies that can find no better home than the American economy, because of those nations' own "immature" systems -- which in turn stokes Americans' excesses. The scary part is, efforts to address the imbalances have long failed and stimulus efforts will only sustain them. [Economist]

Shane Mosley dominated from start to finish Saturday night, scoring a technical knockout of Antonio Margarito 43 seconds into the ninth round to win the World Boxing Association welterweight title in a stunning upset in Los Angeles.

Aliann Pompey, a former N.C.A.A. champion at Manhattan College, won the women’s 400 meters in 51.85 seconds at the New Balance Games at the Armory track in Upper Manhattan. Clayton Parros, a senior at Seton Hall Prep, won the men’s 400 meters in 47.58. Parros and Pompey, who reached the semifinal round in the 400 while competing for Guyana at the Beijing Olympics, will run the 600 yards Friday at the Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden.

Journalism | From a Mexican mogul's investment in The New York Times to an ex-K.G.B. spy's purchase of London's Evening Standard, a columnist sees a silver lining. "The crisis in newspapers has thrown up a novel opportunity for any would-be Citizen Kane: to burnish his reputation not by using his titles to sing his praises or settle scores, but by being the non-interfering benefactor credited with saving a beloved news franchise from disaster. The rise of the moral media mogul?" [Financial Times]

Pat White, the West Virginia quarterback, passed for 95 yards and a touchdown and directed two scoring drives to lead the South to a 35-18 win over the North in the Senior Bowl on Saturday in Mobile, Ala. White, a native of nearby Daphne, was named the game’s most valuable player.

Steve Stricker shot a 10-under-par 62 on PGA West’s Nicklaus course to overtake Pat Perez and rewrite a couple of PGA Tour records at the Bob Hope Classic in La Quinta, Calif. Stricker took a three-shot lead over Perez in the 90-hole tournament. Perez shot a 67 at Bermuda Dunes. Stricker was at 33-under 255, bettering the tour’s 72-hole record of 31 under. Stricker’s 61-62 were also a tour low for consecutive rounds.

A listing in the Manhattan section of “Residential Sales Around the Region” last Sunday, using sales figures supplied by the Corcoran Group, gave incorrect prices for a condominium at 25 Fifth Avenue in Greenwich Village. It was listed at $4.9 million, not $4.925 million, and it sold for $4.85 million, not $4.825 million. The listing also omitted a broker. Besides the Corcoran Group, Classic Marketing also participated in the sale.

I enjoyed Molly Worthen’s portrayal of Mark Driscoll and Seattle’s Mars Hill Church (Jan. 11), but I had to laugh at her notion of Calvinism as some fringe element of Christianity. Driscoll and Mars Hill seem solidly aligned with the bulk of evangelical doctrine, and Driscoll’s “hip” approach to Christianity doesn’t put much meaningful distance between him and other American churches that teach the Gospel as outlined in the Bible.

Steven Pinker argues that while our genes don’t determine who we are, they may have a great influence on our behavior (Jan. 11). As a biological anthropologist, evolutionary theorist and researcher of human behavior, I’m here to tell you Pinker is overshooting the mark.

MINDLIN--Leon, age 84, died at home on January 20, surrounded by family. A talented linguist, he loved classical music, opera, Joyce and, above all things, le mot juste. He was quick-witted, endlessly curious, devoid of vanity and capable of great grace. He is survived by his sister; three children, Philip Mindlin (Iliana), Louise Daniels (Walter) and Jessica Mindlin (Alex Schafir); and seven grandchildren. Donations to the Innocence Project in lieu of flowers.

LINZER--Morton. Almost 80. Always young. Loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, friend. We called him ''Lightning-in-a Bottle''! He lit up our world with a zest for life, his joy in giving, his delight in discovery. He encouraged us all and took so much pride in our every effort. Our lives were richer because of him. He will be sorely missed. We ask that you plant a tree in Israel in memory of our Morty. This would have pleased him so much.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Jan. 10, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

THE 10 Filipino nurses were branded by the Suffolk County district attorney as derelict in their duties, accused of abandoning five chronically ill children, four of whom were on ventilators, and one terminally ill man by quitting their jobs in 2006 in a labor dispute. But in a strongly worded ruling, a state appeals court, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, has barred District Attorney Thomas J. Spota from prosecuting the nurses. The court said that he joined with their employers in forcing them into ''involuntary servitude'' by using criminal sanction to require them to work against their will, thus violating the nurses' constitutional rights under the 13th Amendment.

CHLOË SEVIGNY, ''Big Love'' star, clothing designer. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW I have a path of vintage shops in the East Village that I walk around to. The dress is from one them -- Atomic Passion, I think. It was really long, like most Edwardian and Victorian dresses, and I cut off one of the tiers. The cardigan is part of my fall collection for Opening Ceremony. It has wool elbow patches and nice, big pockets to shove your hands into when you're feeling awkward or insecure. My Chanel purse was a Christmas present to myself. It's like playing Tetris trying to fit all my stuff in it. The boots are an old pair of Prada's, and the tights are from the Sock Man. I love that place, but the guy's the grumpiest man on earth. He's like the Soup Nazi, but he sells socks.

More than a dozen people, including four children, have been killed since Friday in Spain and France, where winds of up to 100 miles per hour have torn roofs from buildings, blown down trees and power lines and whipped up huge waves. The Spanish authorities said that four children were killed and several others injured on Saturday when the roof of a sports center in Sant Boi de Llobregat, near Barcelona, collapsed in winds.

KAPLAN--Seymour (Pete), died peacefully at home on January 23, 2009. Beloved husband of June, brother of Edith Safyer, loving father of Susan, Peter and Bunny Kaplan, grandfather of Jeremy and Alex. A graveside funeral will be held on January 25, 2009.

Designer fashion took a back seat at the Inauguration. Dressing was all about surviving the cold and reflected the multicultural taste of a democracy. The high point for those huddled outside the fenced-in Mall, above, was when Barack Obama took the oath of office. There was no shouting, no dancing, just a dignified calm. The impossible had happened. Everyone exhaled at once.
COHEN--Harris David. January 25, 1967 to August 13, 1985. After all these years, you're always one with us. Unkie, Amy and Gaby
